On Sat, 6 Apr 1996, Kristofer Ananda Carrison wrote:

> 	As you may remember from my intro I'm doing a video project on
> house dancing.  Or, at least what I consider to be house dancing.  Two
> months ago if asked to visually describe what house dancing is,
> I would have shown a select few of the most stylish circle dancers.
> My fascination with their attitude, ability and creativity is what
> led me to become enamored with, and want to become a part of, that
> select group.  Thus, I started scruitinizing their dancing, mimicking
> certain moves and attitude, and eventually got caught up in the
> whole ego-based performatitive thing that is circle dancing.
> 	What I've begun to realize is that circle dancers are only a
> small group of ravers, and definately not representitive of the raving
> community as a whole.  So, to call them house dancers is wrong, and
> possibly a disservice to the community.  Their dancing is visually
> beautiful, but hardly better than say, someone who for the first time
> in their life has mannaged to break away from their insecurities, enter
> into the music, and dance with abandon.  Is this what I should show
> in my video?


At most parties you have people who are beautifully coordinated and can do 
all the right "moves."  Some of these 
people are circle dancers, others are people with less attitude who 
really know how to dance.  Watching these bodies in motion is beautiful 
and is a true talent.  There is a definite style of dancing at raves that 
differs from other scenes or cultures.  However, there are also those of 
us who have our talents placed elsewhere and are a bit more 
"rhytmicly-challenged."

At the October Friends and Family I really tuned into how I felt dancing
and also I watched closely at how others danced.  At the beginning of the
night my body felt awkward, the motions I was performing didn't *feel*
right, but by the end of the night I had reached a state where everything
felt perfect.  As I watched others, I realized what a wonderful form of
self-expression dancing is.  You could tell people who completely let
themselves go and danced their hearts out.  Even people who couldn't do
the right "moves" were beautiful when they danced from their heart.  It
was the ultimate form of self-expression, and you cold see peoples'
personalities and uniqueness from their motions.  When I had finally 
reached a state where my body felt the perfect motion, I know I had 
reached my true form of self-expression.  Sometimes this expression is 
not as methodic nor trained as those who know how to do the right moves, 
but it is highly unique and therefore truly beautiful.

I know I will never be a very structured, rhthmic dancer, but I also know 
how it feels when I reach a state where my body is in *MY* own unique 
motion.  To me it is this unique self-expression that defines "rave" 
dancing.  Motion does a body good.  I love to move my body in many  
different ways and feel the pleasure that I can create for myself.

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: The Gathering: epilogue
Date: Mon, 08 Apr 1996 11:01:25 -0700
From: George Feil <george@unrrts.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Well, I've been very amused by all the posts regarding the worthiness
of paying $20-25 to attend a Martin event. Here's my review of the
event itself:

Having difficulty getting the entire entourage of mine to get it
together, and having made a pit stop at a friend's cast party for a
dance performance, we finally made it there around 12:30. The parking
lots were already jammed, so I knew there was a big crowd inside. The
security line at the time was moderate (about 5-10 min.), and the
guards were quite friendly by that time. Only one ticket seller,
though, which caused another delay. Hmmmpf.

We finally enter, and are immediately taken up by the vibe. Lots of
cool herbal drinks and fruit smoothies, someone giving away fruit at
another table. Someone selling shirts. It was like a bazaar outside of
a Dead show.

The Thump Room was really thumping. Lots of lasers and strobes were
completely dazzling the crowd. Almost everyone is moving and grooving
to the deejays, who were -- unusually enough -- located right in the
middle of the dance floor. The vibe was particularly strong and steady
throughout the night.

The Not-so-Thump Room was the big surprise. It was like one giant
living room party. The deejays were sitting low, with their tables low
with them. Lots of trance and ambient flowing here. The chill-out
space occupied the rear of the room, with lots of mats, soft chairs,
and stuffed animals :) all over the place.

After attending The Dec. '95 Gathering, and Vision last February, I
felt this was one of the best Martin parties yet. The $20 I and my
friends spent was definitely worth it -- even though the party was 1
hour shorter due to the time warp. The only thing really missing was a
slightly better water flow at the free water bar (they ran out several
times during the evening, causing long waits for a refill).

As far as things are concerned, I think that value is in the mind of
the consumer. Some people will be content driving in a $10000 Dodge
Neon, while others will prefer plunking $19000 down on an Acura
Integra. Both types of drivers may (or may not) get a sense of having
gotten good value for the car they own, regardless of the price.

Kudos to Martin for an all-in-all well organized and executed event.

-G


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Apr  8 11:28:56 1996

Subject: Gathering/Sunset reviews
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

The Gathering and Sunset review
==============================

We showed up kinda late,  around 12 mid.   There was a small line to
get in,   but we finally got in,  and WOW!!    We immediately headed
for the "non-thump" room,  which was thumping and getting off BIG
TIME.    Later on,  I head for the big room.  WOW!  The visuals were
insane,  and they got a multi-color laser system that gave my brain
and eyes some real treats while dancing.

In talking to Martin,  he says that 2400 people showed up,  as this is
the most crowded I've seen for this great venue.

As usual,  they had opened up the side doors,  letting in that cool
fresh air.

The music was great,  danced a long time,   but there were too many
breaks on some of the sets.    The music was not as loud as it was in
the previous times I've been at this venue.    It was just about right.
Good clean sound.

Over in the other non-thump room,  some slower funky toons were
really getting down..

The rave ended at 7 am,   and we headed back to Marin to chill,   go
hiking later,  and eventually headed out to where the boat was
waiting for the Sunset boat party.

Sunset Boat party
================

I've never seen such a happy and energetic crowd.   The boat was
incredible,   Galen started things off with some really good thumpin
house,  and I immediately started dancing as everyone else was still
getting on board.

The boat eventually got underway,  as we chugged out over the Bay.
The FOG cast an eerie finger out over the Bay.

Down in the main room,   things were really getting hot until I asked
one of the ship people to open the side doors,  and things really
cooled down.

Jon Howard went on after Galen,  and did an incredible thumpy
funkey set.    For some reason,  the music didn't seem to be so loud
down in the main room.

Upstairs,   Allan was spinning some of the most bazaar toons I've
heard yet.   Sorta sounds like a humpback whale getting flushed
down the toilet...   :-)

The boat at this time,  was just crossing under the Golden Gate,  and
laying back looking up at the bottom of the bridge was a real head
trip.

In the meantime,  Solar was on,   spinning some great house toons,
and everyone was GETTING OFF big time.    The music could have
been a little louder,  but I suppose they had to keep it turned down
low for some reason.

Anyway,  the boat party was much better than I expected,  and
dancing on a moving boat was really cool.

Great party....

The Crunchman

Chris Chervin wrote:
>My biggest problem is I want to make a career in parks and recreation.  
>I may have to make a sacrifice and cut my hair to gain something I 
>want.  I can't express the ammount of frustration and anger this 
>situation gives me.  Any ideas, suggestions, knowledge?  Thanks 
>everyone.

Yeah: lose the attachment to your hair.  My hair has been really long (past 
my shoulders), really short (flat top) and every variation in style you can 
imagine except bald.  What matters is what's under the surface, not what 
people see on the outside.  Cut it.  It's just hair.  You may find, after 
you've passed the probation period at your job, that you'll be able to grow 
it back out with little or no flack.  In fact, why not have fun with it?  
Since it's just hair, and it CAN grow back, get it really butched.  Go for 
something really short on the sides and back, longish on top, and style it 
straight back with a little gel.  Or go for the buzz cut.  Then take a 
picture of it so you can show your buddies and laugh your asses off after 
you grow your hair back out.

Change is good...

S

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

We got there about 1am.  There was the usual great sound systems, 
though alittle too loud in the somewhat of an ambient room.  I say 
somewhat because most of the time the music that I heard there was 
pretty fast to chill to, but I did hear some nice slower stuff, but had 
to stay on the outskirts of the room cause it was too loud.

In the big room I felt there was a lot of a chaotic energy.  People 
were moving all around, facing different directions.  I didn't like 
having the dj in the middle of the dance floor.  Found it a little 
disorienting at first, and I think it kept people walking around more 
on all sides of the dj.  Near the dj it was several rows deep of people 
watching the dj.  Outside of that, it was grand central station.

After sitting a little outside the chill room, feeling on the negative 
side, watching people go by, thinking that alot of the people there 
didn't have much of a concept of the spiritual aspect of raving I was 
feeling tempted to go home.  With angela's enthusiasm I decided to give 
it another try, and as we walked toward the big room, I readjusted my 
expectations of the party.  I decided that I didn't need to have a 
great vibe with everyone dancing together to have a good time.  If it 
was still too crowded to not be bumped every 10 seconds while dancing, 
I would stand around like many others and listen to the music and get 
off on the visuals (which were really good).

It was about 4:30 now, and we found a spot not too far from the dj.  As 
I was standing there I noticed it wasn't as crowded, and people seemed 
more focused on the music.  At that point I senced a nice vibe, and 
decided to make the most of it, and started dancing wild to the fast 
trance music, trying to send out as much happy love vibes as I could to 
as many people as I could.  From 4:30 on I had a GREAT time.  I think 
it took a while for people, myself included to settle in.  Also I think 
by 4:30 alot of people who probably aren't into raving that much might 
have left.

There was plenty of water, easy to get from the dispensors.  Last time 
I had to pour from the big delivery type water bottles.  The visuals 
were great.  

Near the end the camra man was up on top of the dj booth encouraging 
everyone to raise the energy.  Then Martin got up there as  well giving 
a lot of encouragement.  This was nice, but after a bit it felt alittle 
mtvish as people were exicitingly waving at the camra.

The time I had from 4:30 on helped make up for the previous 3 hours.  
Looking back at it and after reading a few wicked posts, it seems that 
wicked might have been the party to got to. 

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Apr  8 12:06:07 1996

On Mon, 8 Apr 1996, George Feil wrote:

OH MY GAWD!!!!  I forgot about Day Light Savings and I did not realize it 
had occurred until I read this post.  I had it written on my calendar, 
which I obviously forgot to check.  That answers why there were so many 
people already at the library yesterday at exactly 1 p.m. (when it 
opens), it was actually 2 p.m.  And, I came into work an hour late and no 
one said anything.  Duh, I am a total idiot, but I thought I'd share it 
all with you, so you can have a good laugh.  Just think, if I hadn't 
read this post, I would have continued my day one hour behind!!!

Subject: music in g.g park
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

After a night of dancing sunday was a great day to hang out in gg park. 
Upon entering the park by where the roller skaters skate to music there 
were a bunch of people watching and listening to the funky discoey 
dance tunes.  We got there just as they stopped the music to introduce 
this new sound system that will be in the park every weekend.

Only tapes were being played, but it had a great sound.  Anybody know 
why this rollerskate area can have amplified sound every week?
>From my understanding rave parties need permits in other parts of the 
park.  It seems like none is neccessary at this roller skate spot.
GG park is a big park.  Why can't they accommodate a techno spot?

Futher down by the that big green house thing there was this trippy 
band called Thoth playing under the bridge.  They have a spacey middle 
eastern sound.  After they finished I bought their cd then tranced out 
a bit at the drumming circle at hippy hill before leaving.

:)
peter

Wow, that was a long-winded harangue in response to a simple attempt to 
share my positivity.  I regret that I did indeed draw your fire, my 
intent was not to draw such negativity.  Regarding what was said below, 
however, I can't speak for everyone, but I'll agree that I am probably as naive as you so 
eagerly point me out to be.  I don't know Martin, so I don't pass 
judgment on him either way.  I can't say that I like your blanket 
generalizations of what amounts to "everyone on this list is a 
hypocrite" (especially since we've never met), but I respect that you 
feel that way for whatever reasons you do.  

What I do know is that PLUR is NOT dead here, I think it still lives in 
some of us, even if not in you, so I ask that you do not include me in your 
overgeneralizations where this is concerned.  I'm not perfect, but I'm 
trying to the best of my ability, as I'm sure many on this list are, to 
live up to the set of ideals based on PLUR.  Most of us may not live 
completely by those standards, but I'd like to think a lot of us are 
trying.  Dismiss it as foolish naivete if you will, but I'd rather go on 
fooling myself that I can achieve these ideals than to mindlessly submit 
to the bleak picture of reality that you have painted below.

Respectfully,

volt

Oh, excuse me!

Wanted to thank everyone who made it out to the small get together for the
Organic On-Line new office space party.  It was a fun night, in a great
space that will be a new office for Organicians.  Unfortunately it won't be
used again for parties.

It was a *free* party on the fifth floor of an old building in SOMA.  The
main dance area was long and wide and it never got over crowded, so wasn't
too hot.  There were big windows at the end that looked out onto the Bay,
to the DJ's back, and Moonpup played a great sunrise set.  Bryce threw down
some elcectic stuff including...Rock Lobster!?  Very unique, but definitely
not out of line.  The party seemed to be sort of unique.  There was an
interestingly good mix of people.  As you can imagine, with Wicked and The
Gathering going on, there were a lot of new faces mixed with those that
weren't up for the massives.

The vibe took a while to get rolling, but it fanned out and managed to keep
people smiling.  The chill area was nice and broad and cozy and is now a
quite reception area between offices.  WBL played a GREAT ambient set and I
think it was from the chill area that the vibe spread through out the
party.  Greg and Cindy arranged a beautiful alter.

Main room line-up: Phred spun first, followed by I think DJ Forrest, then
Bryce and finally Moonpup.

One funny note:  A young guy walks up to me as I was dancing, with a wig on
and these dope pistachio green sued Hush Puppies my friend gave me for my
birthday, and asks:  "Do you do this for a living?"  Looking around, I was
like, "Hell, no!  I work for a software company in Berekeley.  But if you
can think of a way to make money off dancing at parties, I'm all ears!"

Cheers!

Tony

P.S.  Are there pre-sale tickets to Harmony?  Anyone know the details on
that?  The voice mail doesn't say.

Krishna asked...
>        I guess I'm wondering what other people think of circle
>dancers, and, if they can be considered house dancers.
>
>Confused about this,
>Krishna

Eric said....
My impression is that the circle dancing is a leftover of the horrible
break-dancing era, and that those who circle dance are just showing off
their moves.  If there's a more honorable motive for it, I'd like to
know...



Hey Eric, come on, there's nothing dishonorable in showing off your moves...  I
know from personal experience that you like to watch people dance  ; )   ... and
circle dancing is a chance for people who love to dance to share their stuff,
and appreciate each other -- yes, it's originally from street dancing, and it's
different than when we dance alone and trance out, or collectively and get that
amazing group energy ... but it can be way fun too!  I love to watch circle
dancers - when they're not too aggressive about overtaking all the good dance
space!

From: Leslie Ayres <71165.755@compuserve.com>
To: "sfraves@hyperreal.com" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Sunset Boat Perfection
Message-ID: <960408211751_71165.755_GHL128-5@CompuServe.COM>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Thank you Pacific and everyone who put that party together yesterday!
Everything about it was really great!  The music was right on, and the two rooms
were always completely different -- between two rooms of dancing, a front deck,
a back deck, and a roof deck, there was always some place to go to for a new
sound or scene!

THe Red and White Fleet is a good boat choice, lots of outdoor seating, and the
crew were really nice, security was mellow -   I'll never forget sailing under
the Golden Gate Bridge with that amazing older windsurfer guy pacing us and
waving!  Or coming up along Angel Island, looking like we were Gulliver landing
on a fairy tale island.  Or going under the Bay Bridge, a totally urban feeling,
hearing the cars overhead, then it got silent as we went underneath -- the woman
next to me said "It's an eclipse!"  And it was.

And it wasn't too crowded!  

Thanks for a wonderful end to my weekend!

Leslie   : )

p.s.  Yes, Wicked rocked as always -- I have to say, guest djs are a nice
change, but I'm always happiest with our local heros!

On Sun, 7 Apr 1996, John S. Lee wrote:

> I understand that you like e-mail, and can easily converse in person.  My
> sources indicate you do so easily and readily (and from personal experience
> I do attest).  All I suggest is try to do a face to face with Martin,
> that's all.

I do like e-mail. I conduct many of my day to day activities via e-mail, 
have made business deals via e-mail,etc. etc. It also has the advantage 
of allowing one to gather their thoughts before speaking. 

I am not at all opposed to meeting Martin. I think much of this whole 
thread has been obfusicated by the feeling that I have something 
personal against this person. I don't at all. I have attempted to keep 
my comments general, but have been put in a position where it appears to 
some that I am striking out against him.  

> I bought a book today called "Silicon Snake Oil" by Clifford Stoll.  He has
> struck a chord with me.  He says, in the intro:
> 
> "Perhaps our networked world ins't a universal doorway to freedom.  Might
> it be a distraction from reality?  An ostritch hole to divert our attention
> and resources from social problems?  A misuse of technology that encourages
> passive rather than active participation?..."
> 
> I tend to agree with him.

It really is a double-edged sword. Many of the interest groups/info 
really can move people to action by offering a community of people with 
like interest and concerns. OTOH, it can definitely be used by those who 
sit behind keyboards, throw insults at people, and take no action to 
change or understand the things they don't like (much of USENET today....)
Like any tool, it's all in how you use it.

> I guess I'd rather press flesh (ala handshake, and please make it firm, I
> hate weak handshakes), be close enough to hear you breath, see your eyes as
> you think, and watch your body gestures as you talk.  I suspect, like Stoll
> I am not the first.  I think many may find e-mail uncomfortable, epsecially
> with those they have not met face to face.

I do understand and think you have a valid point. It is much more 
difficult to express tone in e-mail. I also have met quite a few people 
through e-mail, including many of our own S.F. Ravers, and am comfortable 
with this medium also. But I see what you are saying.

> >You forgot one don't: Don't question any of the above because if you
> >don't like the "answer" people will call you nasty names.
> 
> I replied to Krishna's post to GeoffW. And agreed with GeoffW's assertion.
> I know you well enough to know these comments would never sway you to tone
> down your vitriol against Martin.

Again, I feel this is another instance of misconception. This whole issue 
has been made to be about Martin, and this was not my original intent.  
As Geoff pointed out, where is the Bagkok tribe or whoever they are?
I would like to see their justification for their actions more than 
someone who is widely recognized as throwing a good party. The only 
reason this whole issue became about Martin is because he happened to be 
throwing a party that I see as being expensive with questionable 
truth in advertising(everyone puts similiar things on their fliers), and people 
were talking about going. The second iteration of this thread started because 
of the same thing, but with a different person bringing up the issue. 

> You have a right to your opinion.  I guess we are both in the same boat.
> We suffer for our opinions sometimes.  I kinda take the good with the bad.

Yup, but we both stand up for what we believe in, something that I find 
few people willing to do.

> >> I don't know if Adder even knows Martin, or if many on this list know the

> >> or aspouse an 'opinion' have even TRIED to talk to the person face to face.

> I have done enough partying to last 10 lifetimes.  I have done enough
> dancing in UG's and "commercial" venues in SF to last 10 lifetimes.  I have
> seen the best and worst of it.  I have seen g-d, the blue buddah, and
> matrix horses on the submixer (huh? can I get a witness GW).  I go out
> rarely since I have other things to do.  Partying is much less important to
> me because I have a large netowrk of friends in SF (which BTW, I got
> through dance culture).  I am not negative on dance culture, on the
> contrary, I promote it!  But I tell you this much.  UG use to be a massive
> phone netowrk in this city.  Yeah you found out, but it was usually by a
> phone call.  Which, by today's standards of e-mail and such, would seem
> organic.

No issue here, I remember a few years back... Just saying that things are 
still going on where the info is not widely disseminated. Also I would 
question anything that is not "underground" automatically being 
commercial. I associate commerical with profit.

> Q: "Can I ask you a question?"
> A: "You can ask."
> 
> In other words you can ask, he is under no obligation to oblige.
> That is my logic.

Well, I don't know if I would consider your above statement a 
"suggestion," but I appreciate your clarification.

> >Well, lessee.... We are disagreeing strongly... You have made your

I see no problem with this form of communication either, and find it a 
very valid method. It's analogous to a phone. While one may prefer to 
discuss matters in person rather than through a telephone, it is still 
very much a valid form of communication. 

> >And I would not expect you to. You have seen enough of my statements and
> >opinions to draw an opinion of me. If I had to talk to every person in
> >the world with whom I disagreed with strongly about something, I wouldn't
> >have a whole heck of a lot of time to live my life. Many politicians,
> >the DMV, every wacko on daytime t.v., etc. Yup there sure are a lot of
> >people I disagree with. And by your logic it would be DISRESPECTFUL not to

> >expressed an opinion, my personal experience and/or their actions and words
> >nonwithstanding. Now, if given the opportunity to speak with the person
> >and the other party was to turn down that opportunity if even the
> >remotest chance that something productive would come out of it, *THAT*
> >would be disrespectful.
> 
> I say you can form an opinion, but to make accusations about them from said
> opinion is irresponsible.  There is a difference between opinion, libel,
> and slander.  There is plenty of legal precedent for this idea.

There is also a very fine line between opinion and accusation, and I feel 
we may not agree on what that line is. Further, my understanding of libel 
and slander is that they involve "malicious intent." I have never had any 
such intent.

> >I would invite you to consider your thinking in this matter. The way I

> >   gonna be talking with people you disagree with

> allotment similar to mine than yours perhaps.

Valid and to be encouraged when possible, but useable on a larger scale, 
unlikely. At least we can agree that both our methods are "valid."

> >Wouldn't this mean that by exclusionary pricing that the promoters of a
> >party were engaging in discrimination by economics?
> 
> Oh yes, I do agree!  However, no real attempt has been made to make the
> minority community aware of the dance culture here.  I mean Ameba, for
> example, is in Upper Haight, not the Fillmore or Hunter's Point.  Most
> parties are thrown in the city, and not the outlying areas, where there are
> ample minorities (crime nothwithstanding, this is still a fact).  So I
> think it is many factors.  I think that there is another section of the
> dance community that has done a goo djob of infusing brown, and that is the
> acid jazz & jungle movements here in SF.

I think that locating spaces, and safety of such spaces may definitely 
contribute to some of this. 

At any rate economics is very much a part of the issue. I see lots and 
lots of flyers from lots of different production companies. And on a very large 
percentage of them, I see things like "we want to bring ALL people 
together," or something very similar, rather it be a free party or a 
$50 NYE mega-rave. And it got me to thinking on the above lines. How can 
someone desire really be to bring all different kinds of 
people(economically AND culturally) if they charge prices that prevent 
this from occuring on any significant scale?

Hate is a path as any other. Hitler was not born with a dislike  or 
hatred of Jewish people, and Farrakhan was not either. When however I 
see the fruition of someones hatred as with Hitler, I bring it up, in 
case it can spur the evaluation of where someone else is on that 
path before and if they are handed power and respect.

On Sun, 7 Apr 1996, Chris Chervin wrote:

> Hey all,
> 
> I've run into a bummer of a situation.  Just recently I was given an 
> offer and accepted a seasonal job at Donner Memorial State Park.  The 
> interview and the offer were both over the phone last month.  Some 
> forms to fill out were sent to me along with rules on uniform and 
> GROOMING standards. The grooming standards is for males and stated that 
> my hair could not go past my collar, could not be in a pony tail or 
> braided, ect.    I have not checked on the female grooming standards 
> (plan to go downtown tommorrow and look it up) but I don't think that 
> they would be required to have short hair.  
> 
> Since I've been hired if they tell me I must cut my hair to keep the 
> job would this be a case of discrimination according to sex?  Not that 
> I could afford a lawyer.  

I have been through the exact same thing. I have contacted the 
State Labor board  about it. Currently you have no legal recourse unless you 
live in Santa Cruz(?) I think, who has passed an anti-apperance discrimination 
law. Someone correct me on the city if it is incorrect, I am not positive.

Basically you are left with a couple of questions. 

1) Is your hair more important than this job? 
2) What kind of organization is it that will not allow you to be who you 
   are(assuming of course you are clean and not stinky ;-)
   and will you be happy with them in the long term? 

I found a different job. And have managed to ever since, although I have 
encountered this discrimination again. But if you are making a career 
of what you are doing, and everyone is going to require you to cut your 
hair, then deeper consideration is in order.

                                            Black Adder

> know, I sometimes do ambience at parties as Dionysus Dreams. I always
> like to think of what I do as a multi-media, enviromentally interactive
> artist. I DJ (CDs mostly), perform live music and soundz, create visual
> enviroments,  and invite
> people to participate with me in the creation of some incredible public
> art forms that are very ephemeral yet very deep in their lightness. In
> responce to Cassandras's posting I find myself in deep agreement. I
> really am not so happy when chill rooms turn into trip-hop, trance,
> whatever dance rooms (although a short taste now and athen can be tasty).
> I really strive for a beatless (mostly) atmosphere sound that blends with
> the ambient room sound rather than forcing  (this may be an exageration
> of others efforts) the vibe. My rooms evolve and grow and continue to do
> so long after the party is over.
>  I try very hard to be the yin to the yang of the kinetic energy on the
> dance floor. Now I like the trip hop and trance stuff Enourmesouly ;),
> however I thing any decent rave needs an ambient room that is peaceful
> enough to nap, have heavy cuddles, socialise and more  =).
>   I would like to encourage others to communicate their desires for rooms
> like these at any given event.

hey Everyone,


  Well my 2nd gathering, and another solid party. 

In the main room, the dj in the center of the dance floor. this
is my favorite set-up, but i think a platform putting the dj about
4 feet above the crowd is more effective then on the ground (via
Liquid Holiday in DC (whatta party!!;)).  Dj Dan and John Williams
were on tight.  When Dan played South Side was the highlight :)

The chill room was rather beat-y with plenty of place to chill and
hang out as well as dance.  I really was excited to hear Alex
Patterson play and he did not disapoint!  Amazing set, mind-fucking
the way he mixed IMO. 

  Over all a good party.  I wasn't sure how i was going to feel
about it at the beginning of the night, but by the time i left
i was glad i had come.  something about these (Gathering, Vision)
parties that make me introspective about my rave goings, and always
a bit more positive about it leaving.

peace,

doug ) ( doug@hyperreal.com

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Apr  8 17:16:20 1996

From: KaySEE <kirstenc@uclink.berkeley.edu>
Reply-To: KaySEE <kirstenc@uclink.berkeley.edu>
Subject: Oscillations
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9604081621.B28835-0100000@uclink.berkeley.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; CHARSET=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

A week or so ago, I was going to comment on how the vibe on this list had 
taken a very positive turn.  During the winter there wasn't necessarily 
negativity floating around, but rather a pervasive "blah-ness."  There 
was party reviews (always nice IMO), but that was about it.  No spirit.  
Then, somehow, with the advent of spring, things changed and things got 
much cheerier.  It was really cool.  Everyone was talking about how they 
got to meet everyone else on this list, and moral was amazing.  There was 
a bunch of good-will and really great threads.

I didn't bother to read the Gathering thing because it didn't interest 
me.  A few people posted about how the whole thing sickened them, and a 
couple of newbies were really disillusioned.  Well, when I first subbed to this 
list about 8 months ago, I was put off by things like this.  But, now, 
that I know things come and go, I don't really care.  I just take it for 
what it's worth and partake in what interests me.  When I first subbed, I 
was also new to the whole internet thing, and extremely skeptical of this 
whole information super highway bullshit.  But, since then, I must say 
that I have learned quite a few things.  Some reinforced my skepticism, 
but some also taught me quite a bit.   

I have subbed to other lists (not necessarily rave lists), but I 
usually end up unsubbing because they loose their interest.  But, there 
is honestly something unique about the people on this list.  I have 
never "listened" to such intelligent people with so much insight.  I 
have truly enjoyed this.  I have enjoyed expanding my music interests 
and participating in political discussion.  And somehow everything almost 
always relates to some aspect of raving.  I am sure a lot of this has to 
do with the fact that it centers around the Bay Area, which in itself is 
a unique place that we are all drawn to.  

For anyone who is disenchanted right now, just wait around.  This is a 
neat place to be.  So, I guess my post is kind of a "tribute" to the 
intelligent, generous, and unique atmosphere that is generated here.  
Each person plays a part, and I, for one, enjoy everything.  (But, alas, 
I am a perpetual optimist!!!!)

I soon hope to meet many of you.  I will once again appear from hiding 
this coming weekend (thank gawd) and more in the future.  But, in the 
meantime, my energy still goes out to everyone.



Cheers, 
kc

kirstenc@uclink.berkeley.edu
.*.*.*.*.*.*.*.*.*.*.*.*.*.*

"Talk is cheap..."

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Just saw this on Hyperreal and don't think it's been posted lately...
Just what I needed to make it through the rest of this hellish Monday!
	Enjoy!!!

-------
Top Several Signs Your Rave Is About to Get Busted.

 -  Those guys in suits standing next to the front door.
 
 -  The laser prints 'Raid...get...out...now....' on the back wall.
 
 -  When you go to watch the DJ spin, and all you find is a mixtape on on
    auto-reverse.
 
 -  The people shouting 'ECSTASY, GET YER ECSTASY HEAH!...'
 
 -  Spritely teenagers run around shouting "whee, I'm so fucked up"
 
 -  The deaf little old lady in her housecoat and slippers comes
    over to see what "all that racket" is about
 
 -  The local TV station arrives to do a fluff piece on "evil all-night
    dance parties"
 
 -  A parent walks around with a flashlight checking out every E-ing
    couple making out in the chill room
 
 -  Those neat new flashing lights *aren't* intellabeams
 
 -  Your thoughts mysteriously turn to bacon
 
 -  You begin imagining cold metal on flesh
 
 -  You hadn't noticed those siren sounds in that song before
 
 -  You're on a roof top and the live drummer starts up
 
 -  Someone just offered a balloon to the fire marshall
 
 -  People are setting off fireworks in the ecological preserve 
 
 -  The guys from mixing lab just found out where your location is
 
 -  Your power fails, but the streetlight is still on...
 
 -  Your beeper goes off and the number is "50505050"...
 
 -  The cops are talking to your liaison people for the fourth time, but
    this time they're pointing into what all your maps said was nothing
    but undeveloped forest...



-- 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Hello everybody,

I just thought I would throw this out to the group, in the hope of 
finding some leads. My boyfriend and I would like to move into a 
warehouse and it is turning into a daunting task to find live-in places, 
matching the criteria we have. We would like to live in the SOMA area, 
not have it be too exorbitantly expensive, have a drive-in garage. My 
boyfriend is in a band, so it needs to be very noise friendly (sound 
studio). Does anybody have some clues or some better resources than I? It 
would be *greatly* appreciated, and it could be a place for future 
parties, if anything works out...Or is it futile...? Thank you, Talilla

this is pretty random, but at least it's not about the gathering flame wars!

i was just sitting here cracking my trick shoulder (yuck!) and thinking ...
i was just remembering that at the black dog show (last year?) there was a
full-on, licensed masseur/physical therapist giving brief massages for, i
dunno, five bucks or so.  he brought his workbench and everything, and i
was a damn fine experience to have all the kinks worked out of you by
somebody who _really_ knew what he was doing.  i also never realized until
then exactly how much the headpiece on those tables looks like those
deluxe padded toilet seats. :)

anyway, i just thought that it would be really great if this guy -
or one of his compatriots - came out to one of the rave events upcoming 
(harmony?)  

of course, if wishes were fishes, we'd all cast nets.  let there be spam!
matt.

Subject: Re: Gathering
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


>In the main room, the dj in the center of the dance floor. this
>is my favorite set-up, but i think a platform putting the dj about
>4 feet above the crowd is more effective then on the ground (via
>Liquid Holiday in DC (whatta party!!;)).  Dj Dan and John Williams
>were on tight.  When Dan played South Side was the highlight :)

Having the DJ on the dancefloor (at the same level as the dancers) is sort
of traditional here in SF.  It is symbolic that this is not a rock concert
and that the DJs are not to be worshiped as rock idols, they are just like
everyone
else and above all, there should be no "spectators".  've found that in practice
this seems to work well, most DJs I know seem to prefer this arrangement in that
you can feel the crowd and the crowd can feed you energy (especially the folks
down front :).  Sometimes it opens you up to unexpected attacks (like when some
dude who has had too much of whatever and decides the DJ is Satan and must be
destroyed, or when God speaks to some gal and tells her to lift the tone arm
so she can deliver his message) but in the long run many wounldn't have it
any other way.

Subject: RE: Help--A question of discrimination.
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Straight from CCH Human Resources Management report (a report on the law re: 
HR) para. 2384A:

>> [re: federal discrimination laws] A dress code that prohibits jewelry on 
men but not on women, or a regulation that restricts hair length only on men 
is not sexual  discrimination against men.

Enforcement of different grooming or dress policies for men and women is 
permitted under discrimination laws if the policy is not:
        - used to inhibit equal access to employment
          opportunities between men and women;
        - an employer's attempt to deny employment
          to a particular sex; and/or
        - a significant employment advantage to either sex. <<

A few lines later:
>> [a company's] rule, in all likelihood, will prevail if there is 
reasonable justification for the restriction, and [the company has] not been 
lax in enforcing the rule. <<

I can empathize: I was in the U.S. Navy for six years.  Women could grow 
their hair to the ground if they wanted, with the only requirement that they 
keep it above their collar when in uniform.  I did let my bangs grow to my 
chin (_way_ longer than the max. length allowed for men), but had to use a 
gallon of gel every morning to keep them glued to the top of my head :P

Good Luck!
 --Michael

Subject: A Poem (non-rave but nice)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Yes, I know this is not directly related to the rave culture so flame me
personally please ... I thought that it was a brilliant statement ... It has
pertinence.
___

Does It Matter?
     written by an anonymous high school student and apppears in the book:
     Growing Up Gay.

My father asked if I am gay.
I asked, "does it matter?"
He said,  "no, not really."
I said "yes."
He said,  "get out of my life"
I guess it mattered.

My boss asked if I am gay.
I asked, "does it matter?"
He said,  "no, not really."
I said "yes."
He said, "you're fired, faggot!"
I guess it mattered.

My friend asked if I am gay,
I asked, "does it matter?"
He said,  "no, not really."
I said "yes."
He said, "don't call me your friend."
I guess it mattered.

My lover asked "do you love me?"
I asked, "does it matter?"
I said "yes."
I told him, "I love you."
He said,  "let me hold you in my arms."
For the first time in my life, something matters.

My God asked me, "do you love yourself?"
I said, "does it matter?"
He said, "yes."
I said,  "how can I love myself? I am gay."
He said,  "that's the way I made you."
Nothing again will ever matter.




			___ r a n d a l l @ c a d e n c e . c o m ___
			when an electron vibrates the universe shakes

Hey all

I recently found a flyer for an upcoming party called Progress.  Found 
this little tiny 2"x4" green flyer with a simple black design 
photocopied onto it amongst a huge number of enormous multi-colored 
computer graphic flyers for such parties as Lucky Charms.  According to 
the voicemail recording, there have been 8 Progress parties so far, and 
this one is their one year anniversary.  Has any one ever been to any 
of these Progress parties, & if so, how were they?  So far this sounds 
interesting to me, the party's on April 20th, would be interested in 
hearing if anybody else has any opinion on them.  Each party appears to 
be based on each of the Celestine Prophecy's Nine Insights (I think 
this one addresses #8), which seems pretty cool *so far*, but as usual 
you can never tell about a party if you don't know anything about the 
people who put it on.  The voicemail number is (415) 974-4391, maybe 
some of you can tell "The Signs" to look for with voicemail recordings 
as well as the signs you all have listed for flyers? ;)  According to 
the voicemail, Ethan's spinning, among other recognized names, can't be 
all bad, eh?

So, anybody have any opinions or experience with these particular 
parties?


Love,

Actually, in the last issue of the Beastie Boys' mag "Grand Royal" there's
a 5-page article devoted to the "schlong." in it they list almost all of
the popular names for the haircut. I can remember the following:

schlong
safety cut (safe from parental disapproval while still maintaining an air
of faux teen rebellion, that is)
soccer rocker
hockey haircut
ape drape
neckwarmer
butt cut
mullet
Billy Ray Cyrus

entertaining as usual then i really felt the LOVE when darkhorse some

afternoon/sunset feel good, be happy house mix!  man, i LOVE house music!

the white bell bottoms in case i shared dance space with you, say hi!  i
just got back from the airport so i'm just gonna say...

Arthur Chandler wrote:
> 
> On Mon, 8 Apr 1996, Geoff White wrote:
> 
> > Having the DJ on the dancefloor (at the same level as the dancers) is sort
> > of traditional here in SF.  It is symbolic that this is not a rock concert
> > and that the DJs are not to be worshiped as rock idols, they are just like
> [SNIP]
> 
>   Is the arrangement unique to San Francisco -- or, at least, is it 
> practised here more than elsewhere?
> 

Maybe practiced more, but not unique to. Earth 2 Sea, Doc Martin's afterhours 
in LA back in '92 (and incidentally the club that got me to appreciate house music) was 
set up so Doc was in the middle of the dancefloor, which created a great 
energy.


Joe

had the pleasure of experience about 15 minutes worth at a Crysalis party

From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9604091511.AA18546@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
Subject: Re: Sunset Boat Perfection
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Tue, 9 Apr 96 8:11:18 PDT
In-Reply-To: <960408211751_71165.755_GHL128-5@CompuServe.COM>; from "Leslie Ayres" at Apr 8, 96 5:17 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> Thank you Pacific and everyone who put that party together yesterday!
> Everything about it was really great![...]

I'll second Leslie's comments; this was probably the best boat party
Janie & I have ever been on.  Sold out, but not oversold, 2
good sound systems, excellent Djing, beautiful crazy
vibe.  (Hey Brenda, it was nice meeting/dancing with you!)

Galen started the off downstairs with a set that rocked while
Allen excreted some trippy weirdness - everything from jungle to
King Crimson to ??? - on the upper deck which went very well with the 
moving floor.  John Howard followed Galen with some rollocking house,
But it was Darkhorse who may have been the musical highlight for us. The
shit he's been spinning lately, dubby funky chunky crunchy munchy with 
tons of cool samples (Clink Eastward westerns, guitar feedback, etc.),
and some noisy nutty hip hop.  Solar finished up downstairs
with some more house and up above I finally got a taste of Professor 
Smith - great stuff: he spun some stripped down jungle tunes giving 
me the opportunity to figure out how to dance to the stuff.  I'll get
it one of these days.

Besides all the great music & people, there were the wonderful
sights of the bay: the city, the fog, the bridges, the water.
I never get sick on boats (unlike Solar who thankfully did not
puke on the spinning turntables), but I do become quite a klutz -
so apologies to everyone whose feet I stepped on, must of been about
150 of you.

The only downer was that I had some equipment I had to bring to/from
the boat, so I had to park nearby in the heart of the Pier tourist
area.  $25 garage parking for a $20 party!  Guess we'll be eating a
lot of ramen noodles for dinner over then next few weeks. ;) 

And for those of you who love Sunset but are getting bummed by the
size of the crowd: this Saturday, from 1 to 8pm there's a free
(food donation for Open Hand) party at the Presidio.  DJs
include Tracy and Solar, and they have a permit.  I don't have
the flyer, but hopefully it will get onto the calender.  L8er ;)

Lee
_________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com  (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )  lee@hyperreal.com
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Content-Type: text
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> On Mon, 8 Apr 1996, Geoff White wrote:
> 
> > Having the DJ on the dancefloor (at the same level as the dancers) is sort
> > of traditional here in SF.  It is symbolic that this is not a rock concert
> > and that the DJs are not to be worshiped as rock idols, they are just like
> [SNIP]
> 
>   Is the arrangement unique to San Francisco -- or, at least, is it 
> practised here more than elsewhere?
> 
> 
Personally I think DJ's (unlike children) should be heard and not seen.  One
of my (only) dislikes about Wicked is that everyone seems to stand in lines,
facing the dj booth.  It feels terribly regimented and because of it there
seems to be a lot less interaction between people than there could be.

I seem to remember one Wicked (Masters at Work?) where the Djs where upstairs.
This, to me, works much better.  People focus at lot less on *who* is spinning
and more on what is being played (which helps avoid the 'rock idol' syndrome).

Neil.
neil@nit.airtouch.com

On Tue, 9 Apr 1996, Lee Fogel wrote:

> > Thank you Pacific and everyone who put that party together yesterday!
> > Everything about it was really great![...]
>
> I'll second Leslie's comments; this was probably the best boat party
> Janie & I have ever been on.  Sold out, but not oversold, 2
> good sound systems, excellent Djing, beautiful crazy
> vibe.  (Hey Brenda, it was nice meeting/dancing with you!)
>
> Galen started the off downstairs with a set that rocked while
> Allen excreted some trippy weirdness - everything from jungle to
> King Crimson to ??? - on the upper deck which went very well with the
> moving floor.  John Howard followed Galen with some rollocking house,
> But it was Darkhorse who may have been the musical highlight for us. The
> shit he's been spinning lately, dubby funky chunky crunchy munchy with
> tons of cool samples (Clink Eastward westerns, guitar feedback, etc.),
> and some noisy nutty hip hop.  Solar finished up downstairs
> with some more house and up above I finally got a taste of Professor
> Smith - great stuff: he spun some stripped down jungle tunes giving
> me the opportunity to figure out how to dance to the stuff.  I'll get
> it one of these days.
>
> Besides all the great music & people, there were the wonderful
> sights of the bay: the city, the fog, the bridges, the water.
> I never get sick on boats (unlike Solar who thankfully did not
> puke on the spinning turntables), but I do become quite a klutz -
> so apologies to everyone whose feet I stepped on, must of been about
> 150 of you.
>
> The only downer was that I had some equipment I had to bring to/from
> the boat, so I had to park nearby in the heart of the Pier tourist
> area.  $25 garage parking for a $20 party!  Guess we'll be eating a
> lot of ramen noodles for dinner over then next few weeks. ;)
>
> And for those of you who love Sunset but are getting bummed by the
> size of the crowd: this Saturday, from 1 to 8pm there's a free
> (food donation for Open Hand) party at the Presidio.  DJs
> include Tracy and Solar, and they have a permit.  I don't have
> the flyer, but hopefully it will get onto the calender.  L8er ;)

I would recommend checking it out...I went to two of them, which 
were good (albeit the Acme thing). When I did the map-point for one of 
them, I noticed a great-vibey-type of group going in (no yucky 
attitudes...). Jane, who throws this party, usually gets DJs who do 
their job :) and she is concerned with the atmosphere of the party. I'm  
glad she's still able to throw Progress, and it's not too Celestine 
based, but there is usually an alter of some sort. Basically, the odds 
are in favor of this being a party you might enjoy! Hope that helps, Talilla

>Michael!")

>like a  cliche).  In fact, the only thing remotely resembling a rave that
>I've ever been to was this commercial thing held in China Basin a couple
>years ago (music: good; space: awful).  I've been primarily a club-scene
>person ever since I moved to the Bay Area around mid-1992.  Before that was
>a part of my life that didn't even have a club scene, much less raves.  As
>for clubs, when I do go out (which lately hasn't been very often), I usually
>go to Universe on Saturdays (there's a clue here :)  That's about all my
>commitment to my career will allow.  Unfortunately, this has led to my
>fulfilling the old adage, "All work and no play...."

>SFRaves page and this list.  Heaven :)

On Mon, 8 Apr 1996, Milton Cecil wrote:

>  (everything in SF is commercial at this point, 
> > >> UG?  There hasn't been UG in SF for a couple of years now...).. 
>  
> tell that to the people who attended a free underground party at organic
> saturday..... 
>  
> it may not be as underground as it used to be.........but it still
> exists.........moonpup

So that brings up the question of whether or not to post reviews of these 
"super secret underground parties" on sfraves. 

If I had not been "in the know" about this great little free party and 
then kept hearing all kinds of wonderful things about it posted on 
sfraves, I would be feeling pretty bitter and it brings up those feelings 
of elitism.  

I kind of have a rule of thumb that I live by: if it is not a party that 
we can post about on sfraves prior to it happening, then we should not 
post reviews about it either.   It is kinda like rubbing it in everyone 
else's face..."nya nya nya! I'm more connected to the cool stuff than 
youuuuu are!!"

This is just how I feel about it....any other thoughts or comments?

love,
Amy

Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id LAA20665; Tue, 9 Apr 1996 11:48:32 -0700
Received: from alpha.xerox.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id LAA20658; Tue, 9 Apr 1996 11:48:28 -0700
Received: from godzilla.ADOC.xerox.com ([13.242.128.10]) by alpha.xerox.com with SMTP id <19248(7)>; Tue, 9 Apr 1996 11:47:39 PDT
Received: from beluga.adoc.xerox.com ([13.242.128.26]) by godzilla.ADOC.xerox.com with SMTP id <4273>; Tue, 9 Apr 1996 11:47:30 -0700
Received: from ccMail by beluga.adoc.xerox.com (SMTPLINK V2.11.01)
	id AA829075460; Tue, 09 Apr 96 11:43:34 PST
Date: Tue, 9 Apr 1996 12:43:34 PDT
From: Diane_Tabellija@adoc.xerox.com
Message-Id: <9603098290.AA829075460@beluga.adoc.xerox.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: A Green Door Review
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

   I've been wanting to check out the Green Door on Friday nights for weeks 
   and finally got a chance to last Friday.  The cover was only $5 (I think 
   we came in after midnight, so it might have dropped in price) and the 
   venue is that wonderful little restaurant in Stevenson Alley nr 10th.
   
   The space is great w/r/t the lighting, mirrors, loungey booths, and 
   simple classic architecture with the exception of the location of the 
   dance area but that can't be helped due to the floor plan of the 
   restaurant.  Groovesters should note that the dance area is also on 
   carpet.  The space is very conducive to conversations in the bar/booth 
   area which is great for socializing.
   
   While I came specifically to hear Thomas play (I've got a thing for his 
   style these days!), the entire time I was there, Felix played.  The 
   style of music (to me) is funky, trip-hopping, deep grooving music 
   that's similiar to what's played upstairs at Roots (though it's been a 
   while since I've been to Roots, too!).  
   
   Since it's only been around for a short while, things haven't quite 
   picked up #'s-wise but I hope so 'cause it's a sweet set-up I'd go to 
   again to dance and schmooze a bit w/o having to deal w/an all night 
   crowded dance.  From my assessment of attendees it's more diverse than 
   any other club I've been to for a while w/clubbers, trendy fashion 
   plates, ravers, and even a few artistes.  The mix of people made it a 
   delight for me to go "clubbing" again.
   
   See ya on the dance floor,
   Diane

Subject: Re: Serotonin
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

At 09:53 PM 4/4/96 -0800, you wrote:
...autoreceptor, and the brain thinks there is no 
>serotonin circulating.  As a result, the brain nearly all of its 
>serotonin in bulk.  THus, the "pleasurable" effects felt after dosing LSD 
>come from the brain's own realease of all of its serotonin.  This is why 
>serotonin is so depleted following LSD (or MDMA) intake, and can be for 
>up to six months.  This may also account for why subsequent LSD or MDMA 
>doses have less effect than the 1st time; the brain has not 
>remanufactured enough serotonin before the second dump.
>
> From what I've read, there have been no statistically 
>measurable effects of long term serotonin depletion, but that doesn't 
>mean they don't exist.  
>
>Take care
>
>-alberT
>
>
Wow, ya learn something new everyday.
Thanks. 
Only problem is, (perhaps a new study), do headtrips get worse when one
knows exactly what is going on inside his/her brain? (OH SHIT! I'M RELEASING
HIGH AMOUNTS OF SEROTONIN AND MY AUTORECEPTORS ARE ALL FUCKED UP!!) ha ha 
- Courtney

Given the response to the coffee "undrugged" question, I think I will be
bringing a coffee maker and the accompaniments to parties I help with (FnF,
Chrysalis - to start).  I think espresso would be a much bigger commitment,
in that it would require a machine that could recharge fast, and keep a
steady stream of steam (say THAT three times ;^)  Plus someone would have
to be with it all night.

My thought was to have a 20 cup coffee maker, and then a thermos to hold
about 20 cups.  That means at any one time we could have about 40 cups of
coffee available.  Also, that means one person doesn't have to stand around
making coffee for everyone, but once in a while someone could make a fresh
pot (or should that be a "dope" pot?)  I don't see myself standing around
making coffee for everyone, but rather making it available to everyone.

Coffee maker, thermos, filters, good fine ground coffee, sugar, cream and
cups are the only other requirements I can think of.  I'll package it all
in a milk crate to make it easily portable, like the alter material.

Thank for your thoughts on the matter.  Now all we need is a name.  Hmmm?
How about: Kophee, Coughy, Caw-fee.  Tag line:  Fuck that herbal E, drink
coffee!

I really should focus this energy on work...

Peace!

Tone

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Apr  9 13:01:20 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id NAA29393; Tue, 9 Apr 1996 13:01:20 -0700
Received: from dfw-ix1.ix.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id NAA29374; Tue, 9 Apr 1996 13:01:15 -0700
Received: from  (solle@srf-ca4-25.ix.netcom.com [199.182.131.153]) by dfw-ix1.ix.netcom.com (8.6.13/8.6.12) with SMTP id NAA13368 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Tue, 9 Apr 1996 13:04:10 -0700
Date: Tue, 9 Apr 1996 13:04:10 -0700
Message-Id: <199604092004.NAA13368@dfw-ix1.ix.netcom.com>
From: solle@ix.netcom.com (Christopher Solle)
Subject: Beware...
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I think that you all should here this. So I'm going to lend my keyboard and 
posting rights on this list to a close friend. My appologies in advance if it 
bums some of you out.  But I think it's important. And yes, it is rave related. 
-C.S.


Hello Friends...

Beware... On Saturday evening I attempted to introduce a friend into the raving 
world via The Gathering.  My friend, a pretty heavy Deadhead and very open to new 
experiences, talked me into heightening our experience in a rave way.  Nothing 
new to either of us but the consequences of our actions would be.  Having failed 
to plan ahead, we then did something that I rarely ever do, trust my health, 
safety, and sanity to some completely unknown individual (that may sound stupid 
but I think you know what I mean).  The following experience was hellish to say 
the least, and lasted all of the way through to Monday morning. In fact my hands 
are still shaking as I type this meassage.  Poisoned would be an understatement.  
Three times as bad as my worst flew experience, maybe.  I am completely and 
totally angry with myself, for after 5 years in the scene, being naive enough to 
think that everybody at such an event operates under the same morals and ethics 
that my friends do.  They in fact do not.

Beware... Both my friend and I have been through some pretty serious stuff in the 
past and are in no way new to this scene and the experiences often associated 
with it.  I am forever in debt to my friend and while I considered myself and old 
pro (pretty jaded huh?), I couldn't have made it through without his help.  With 
the "Bro your gonna be all right" mantra still in my head my sympathies go out to 
those who were unlucky enough to run into the same person that we did that 
evening.

Beware...I remember being at the Fashion Center in '92 when some punk pulled a 
gun on a friend of mine because she was trying to make him smile.  That's when I 
knew that things had changed.  I stayed away for a little while but slowly made 
it back.  After last Saturday it's gonna take a whole lotta convincing.

Beware and be careful. 
-JC

i can buy that - it took me a while to work up to it myself.  and well it
should - it was an extremely intense experience.  not to knock amateur
massages, which are delightful of course, but the pros really do take it
to a completely different level.  you could feel muscles and joints moving
around and relaxing that you didn't even realize you had until they got
worked on!  it's probably just one of those things that you have to get
rolling, and then people will say, yeah, i gotta try that too.

anyway, i'll conclude my random blithering by saying that if you get n
opportunity to try this out while _altered_ :) or after intense physical
exertion (groovin'!), DO IT.  you won't regret it.
matt.

Forwarded message:
> Personally I think DJ's (unlike children) should be heard and not seen.  One
> of my (only) dislikes about Wicked is that everyone seems to stand in lines,
> facing the dj booth.  It feels terribly regimented and because of it there
> seems to be a lot less interaction between people than there could be.

heard a sound bite from a rave promoter a while back, saying that a rock
concert involves thousands of people all facing the same way and looking
at the stage, while a rave is more orientation-neutral - interpret that
how you like.

seems to me that the lighting shows are more to blame for getting
everybody to face front and zone than the dj stack - i think it would be
nice (although prob. tricky) to get more of a surround lighting effect so
you wouldn't miss much by not staring at the speakers.

of course, you can always just turn around and dance upstream like a
salmon.  try it sometime when nobody else is - it's sort of a neat little
head trip, especially at really big events.
matt.

At 10:09 PM 4/7/96, anne petrie wrote
>If we want to be a community in resonance, we must attempt to keep ourselves
>balanced.  IMO, we need to avoid the traditional "rock & roll concert
>positioning" . . . what I mean is that IMO we need to avoid putting a
>particular person or group on a pedestal (or conversely, on the proverbial
>chopping block).
>I believe that this "positioning" can have a negative effect on the raving
>community because it can degenerate into merely audience and performer, static
>object and passive observer.  We're all equal participants in the community,
>whether we realize it or not . . .  hugs or eye contact or a great smile can
>influence a person just as much as a DJ's music or a promoter's prices.  To end
>this little preach session, I'm going to quote Howard Thurman:  "Don't ask
>yourself what the world needs.  Ask yourself what makes you come alive, and go
>do that, because what the world needs is people who have come alive."

        You always have the BEST quotes to give out :) Thanks.  Recently
i've been learning that this idea is applicable everywhere, and has
somewhat of a scientific basis. The idea of 'following the beat of your own
drum and dancing in harmony with the universe' is totally a complexity
theory (next step after chaos theory) idea. Complexity sees things as being
systems and processes, all interweaving on various micro-to macro scales.
Your human body has certain processes and cycles going on and if you're in
touch with those cycles you're also in touch with the cycles around you.
So, if you look within and feel like you should do/be something, no matter
how 'illogical' it's possible that this is the sensing of larger
socio-economic and whatever 'psycho-spiritual' cycles that are 'around us'
(but also part of us). So, by listening to that inner voice, and following
it, you always end up being exactly at the right place, at the right time
and doing the right thing and that, to me, makes me feel really alive. :)
        Thing is, i think, is that everyone's 'calling' (in the large
'career' picture or what they should be doing at a rave) is different, so
one can't really tell someone else what's best for them, one can only speak
from personal experience. To make this a lil' rave related, when i don't
have a ton of fun at a party, and someone else asks my opinion on it i'll
say "well i didn't have the best time, did you?" because i know that 'in
reality' a party can be BOTH good and bad, depends on your subjective
experience :)
        Well, i guess it was my 'calling' today to babble pointlessly ;)

        peace,
                brad

At 11:47 AM 4/9/96, Courtney Nielsen wrote:
>At 09:53 PM 4/4/96 -0800, you wrote:
>...autoreceptor, and the brain thinks there is no
>>serotonin circulating.  As a result, the brain nearly all of its
>>serotonin in bulk.  THus, the "pleasurable" effects felt after dosing LSD
>>come from the brain's own realease of all of its serotonin.  This is why
>>serotonin is so depleted following LSD (or MDMA) intake, and can be for
>>up to six months.  This may also account for why subsequent LSD or MDMA
>>doses have less effect than the 1st time; the brain has not
>>remanufactured enough serotonin before the second dump.
>>
>> From what I've read, there have been no statistically
>>measurable effects of long term serotonin depletion, but that doesn't
>>mean they don't exist.
>>
>>Take care
>>
>>-alberT
>>
>>
>Wow, ya learn something new everyday.
>Thanks.
>Only problem is, (perhaps a new study), do headtrips get worse when one
>knows exactly what is going on inside his/her brain? (OH SHIT! I'M RELEASING
>HIGH AMOUNTS OF SEROTONIN AND MY AUTORECEPTORS ARE ALL FUCKED UP!!) ha ha
>- Courtney

        I totally think so. I'm not a biochemist (or even have any training
related to science really, just an inquisitive mind) but everything works
on feedback, why should the neurochemical/experiential brain/body work any
differently?
        Sometimes you can even convince yourself that you're high when
you're not, and soon (i think) your brain will make itself high by
releasing/inhibiting the right neurochemicals just as you would if you were
high. Getting "high" is only teaching your brain how to do something.
After you have to try to get it to do it on it's own, without the training
wheels ;) IMHO, of course, but i know that thinking certain ways brings
'natural' highs that are totally wild :)
        peace,
                brad

Here's a good example why it is important to have a responsible
promoter who can work with the authorities to throw legal,
safe, permitted parties in cooperation with local police.  Keeping
the scene completely underground (i.e. illegal) can have dire
consequences for the entire scene, as it apparently has in Salt Lake 
City.  Ignorance breeds suspicion.  - Lee 

--------------------------------------------------------------
Please forward this to whomever else might find it interesting.

We've been having quite a controversy in Salt Lake City Utah RAVES.
The Rumor is that we SERVE alcohol and GANGS intitiate their members.
How realistic Does this seem to you?
The past three months or so almost every party has been busted.  Some
Ravers have  lost hope.  We need help out here in SLC to prove to our
community that RAVES are not what they think they are.

                                                Your friend, 
                                                   Heather

Received: from STATE-DOMAIN-Message_Server by state.ut.us
	with Novell_GroupWise; Tue, 26 Mar 1996 17:33:49 -0700
Message-Id: <s1582a7d.049@state.ut.us>
X-Mailer: Novell GroupWise 4.1
Date: Tue, 26 Mar 1996 17:33:37 -0700
From: Susan Burke <gvpbmain.sburke@state.ut.us>
To: 1LYNCHHE@UVSC.EDU
Subject:  What is your knowledge of RAVES? -Reply

Dear Ms. Lynch:

Thank you for your inquiry regarding Rave parties.  Governor Mike
Leavitt has requested that I respond to your questions directly.  

Because the Rave party phenomena is taking place mostly in the Salt
Lake City area, I contacted the Salt Lake City Police Department Vice
Squad to discuss your concerns.  Sgt. Kenneth W. Hansen responded
that Rave Parties are a problem for the police department because they
have found that the individuals who sponsor the parties do not have
business licenses, therefore, putting those who attend the parties at risk.
Through licensing, businesses are required to meet certain health and
safety codes.  They must also meeting bonding requirements to protect
them from liability issues.  An unlicensed business could be a potential
death trap.  The issue, therefore, is not Constitutional.  

Sgt. Hansen also indicated that there is a historical record of alcoholic
beverages being served to minors at these parties.  Not only is this in
violation of state laws, it poses a serious threat to the safety and
welfare of the drinker and the public at large.  It is also my understanding
that Rave Parties are intentionally covert and secretive to avoid scrutiny
by officials that are charged with public safety, licensing and taxes.  A
Rave Party would be considered a legal function if those sponsoring the
party complied with all city, county, state and federal laws.  

In regards to gang activity at these parties, officers from the Salt Lake
Area Gang Project have reported that gang violence and recruiting have
taken place at Rave Parties.  There is also residual activity occuring
outside of the Rave Party location where rival gang members have been
involved in violent and criminal activity as of a result of being attracted to
the Rave Party in the first place.

I do not believe it is the intent of our cities to deny young people the
opportunity to congregate and attend parties.  It is, however, the
responsiblity of local and state government to ensure that the health and
safety of young people are preserved.

Sincerely,

Susan Burke
Anti-Violence Coordinator

Subject: Re: DJs on the Dance Floor

In-Reply-To: <199604092034.NAA13229@elaine27.Stanford.EDU>

> > Personally I think DJ's (unlike children) should be heard and not seen.  One
> > of my (only) dislikes about Wicked is that everyone seems to stand in lines,
> > facing the dj booth.  It feels terribly regimented and because of it there
> > seems to be a lot less interaction between people than there could be.
> 
> heard a sound bite from a rave promoter a while back, saying that a rock
> concert involves thousands of people all facing the same way and looking
> at the stage, while a rave is more orientation-neutral - interpret that
> how you like.
> 
> seems to me that the lighting shows are more to blame for getting
> everybody to face front and zone than the dj stack - i think it would be
> nice (although prob. tricky) to get more of a surround lighting effect so
> you wouldn't miss much by not staring at the speakers.

My thoughts have fluctuated on this one.  There once was a time when I 
read everyone facing the same direction as a vestige of the 
_hierarchized_ spectator/performer dichotomy epitomized by rock concerts.  
However, I have had a change of opinion.  It _can_ serve to minimize the 
self-consciousness of other dancefloor environments (where the moves have 
names, and where people are there to be seen, whether they like it 
or not), while at the same time, heightening and making most diffuse the 
_presence_ and _energy_ of the collectivity.  Everyone is in the 
periphery, making the group, rather than any individual, the _object_ of 
attention.  This said, everything has to do with _context_, 
particularly the specific spatial arrangement of the given party 
environment.  My desire that everyone more-or-less face the same direction 
is not universal.  The mainfloor setup at Come-Unity is one example of a 
mixed set-up, where you have two dancing groups -- let's call them the Jets 
and the Sharks -- facing each other.  Unlike in Westside Story, however, 
there is no competition between the groups, and no one has knives ;).  

> of course, you can always just turn around and dance upstream like a
> salmon.  try it sometime when nobody else is - it's sort of a neat little
> head trip, especially at really big events.

Depending on the situation, I'll occasionally feel compelled to do the 
same.  However, I am conscious of how the direction of my gaze can have 
an effect on other individuals' level of self-consciousness.  Rok.

At 10:59 AM 4/9/96, Amy R Starkey wrote:

>So that brings up the question of whether or not to post reviews of these
>"super secret underground parties" on sfraves.

I don't know.  I mean, this is a newsgroup, not a party line, so if a party
doesn't get posted to SFR does that mean it's exclusive?  I'm sure there
are lots of parties that don't get posted, mainly because when that
happens, there's the potential for hundreds upon hundreds of people showing
up.  Some venues can't hold that.

>If I had not been "in the know" about this great little free party and
>then kept hearing all kinds of wonderful things about it posted on
>sfraves, I would be feeling pretty bitter and it brings up those feelings
>of elitism.

But if it's a word of mouth party, then I guess people just have to realize
that there was a good party that happened that they didn't know about
becuase they didn't know anyone involved.  It's not elitism, it's just the
nature of life.  You can't know everyone or get invited to everything and
have to be comfortable in accepting that.  If someone is truly bitter then
maybe that should be a call for them to become more involved in the scene,
by helping a group, or just showing a sincere commitment to the cause,
getting to know people.

Believe it or not, we all have missed lots of small parties.  Even you Amy!
;^)  And would you feel bitter if someone posted about a party they had
fun at, or would you say, "Right on!  I'm glad a party went off.
Hmmm...maybe I'll email the person that posted and let them know I'd love
to get involved with the next little party they throw."

The really interesting thing about this scene is that we are extremely
fortunate on SFR to have access to where most of the parties are happening
here in SF.  Prior to SFR, what was there a phone tree or something?  I
just recently met a guy who says he raves but didn't know how to find out
about them.  I have a friend visiting from Australia and he wanted to know
what was happening around the city.  Was there a paper he could get to find
out about parties?  And you know, there really isn't, at least that I know
of.  The Guardian will list what's happening at 1015, or Bahia, but where
is The Gathering listed?  How do new people find out about even massives?

Anyway, I guess the question is whether people should post about
undergrounds that aren't listed here on SFR, and I think that's my round
about way of saying I think it's all right, that most promters in the Bay
area are not intentionaly exclusive, but rather have to keep in mind
spacing and crowd control issues.

Tony

luvz and kisses,
