On Tue, 9 Apr 1996, Lee Fogel wrote:

> Here's a good example why it is important to have a responsible
> promoter who can work with the authorities to throw legal,
> safe, permitted parties in cooperation with local police.  Keeping
> the scene completely underground (i.e. illegal) can have dire
> consequences for the entire scene, as it apparently has in Salt Lake 
> City.  Ignorance breeds suspicion.  - Lee 
> 
> --------------------------------------------------------------
> Please forward this to whomever else might find it interesting.
> 
> We've been having quite a controversy in Salt Lake City Utah RAVES.
> The Rumor is that we SERVE alcohol and GANGS intitiate their members.
> How realistic Does this seem to you?
> The past three months or so almost every party has been busted.  Some
> Ravers have  lost hope.  We need help out here in SLC to prove to our
> community that RAVES are not what they think they are.
> 
>                                                 Your friend, 
>                                                    Heather
> 
> Received: from STATE-DOMAIN-Message_Server by state.ut.us
> 	with Novell_GroupWise; Tue, 26 Mar 1996 17:33:49 -0700
> Message-Id: <s1582a7d.049@state.ut.us>
> X-Mailer: Novell GroupWise 4.1
> Date: Tue, 26 Mar 1996 17:33:37 -0700
> From: Susan Burke <gvpbmain.sburke@state.ut.us>
> To: 1LYNCHHE@UVSC.EDU
> Subject:  What is your knowledge of RAVES? -Reply
> 
> Dear Ms. Lynch:
> 
> Thank you for your inquiry regarding Rave parties.  Governor Mike
> Leavitt has requested that I respond to your questions directly.  
> 
> Because the Rave party phenomena is taking place mostly in the Salt
> Lake City area, I contacted the Salt Lake City Police Department Vice
> Squad to discuss your concerns.  Sgt. Kenneth W. Hansen responded
> that Rave Parties are a problem for the police department because they
> have found that the individuals who sponsor the parties do not have
> business licenses, therefore, putting those who attend the parties at risk.
> Through licensing, businesses are required to meet certain health and
> safety codes.  They must also meeting bonding requirements to protect
> them from liability issues.  An unlicensed business could be a potential
> death trap.  The issue, therefore, is not Constitutional.  
> 
> Sgt. Hansen also indicated that there is a historical record of alcoholic
> beverages being served to minors at these parties.  Not only is this in
> violation of state laws, it poses a serious threat to the safety and
> welfare of the drinker and the public at large.  It is also my understanding
> that Rave Parties are intentionally covert and secretive to avoid scrutiny
> by officials that are charged with public safety, licensing and taxes.  A
> Rave Party would be considered a legal function if those sponsoring the
> party complied with all city, county, state and federal laws.  
> 
> In regards to gang activity at these parties, officers from the Salt Lake
> Area Gang Project have reported that gang violence and recruiting have
> taken place at Rave Parties.  There is also residual activity occuring
> outside of the Rave Party location where rival gang members have been
> involved in violent and criminal activity as of a result of being attracted to
> the Rave Party in the first place.
> 
> I do not believe it is the intent of our cities to deny young people the
> opportunity to congregate and attend parties.  It is, however, the
> responsiblity of local and state government to ensure that the health and
> safety of young people are preserved.
> 
> Sincerely,
> 
> Susan Burke
> Anti-Violence Coordinator
> 
> 
> 
> 

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Apr  9 15:23:51 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id PAA15347; Tue, 9 Apr 1996 15:23:51 -0700
Received: from netcom16.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id PAA15342; Tue, 9 Apr 1996 15:23:48 -0700
Received: from localhost by netcom16.netcom.com (8.6.13/Netcom)
	id PAA19462; Tue, 9 Apr 1996 15:22:35 -0700
Message-Id: <199604092222.PAA19462@netcom16.netcom.com>
To: inanna@ccnet.com
CC: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Re: underground 
Date: Tue, 09 Apr 96 15:22:35 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Diana Greer <inanna@ccnet.com>:
| Thanks for posting!  I feel the same way.  I have been attending raves
| for 2 years, but I have been a raver in my heart for all of my life.  I
| believe it is bad form to talk publicly about something that was not
| available for the public.

I generally prefer openness to cliquishness, unfortunately the fact
that the police are undoubtedly reading this list means that some
secrecy is needed. An open invitation to an underground provides a
much-too-easy tip-off on what they consider "illegal activity" (i.e. an
underground party that isn't greasing the palms of SFPD for protection,
and bribing the SF Fire Department to overlook fire regulations). I'm
of course speaking about undergrounds/raving in general -- not about
the legality of particular the underground party in SF on Saturday
night.

At least when it is spoken about online & after-the-fact one can ask,
"say friendly raver... remember me?? ... next time one of these
happens, could you let me know...."  while at the same time, not giving
a heads-up advance warning to the police infiltrators on SFRaves. At
least in that way, if the person is a cop, the wise would proably at
least get to know them well enough to vibe them before inviting them to
one's parties. Of course, the best undercover/infiltrators are really
good at being two-faced about this (so please, everybody, be careful!).

Although this is a bad analogy, the "underground railroad" that helped
free slaves in the Southern US and bring them to the north was an
illegal and secretive activity that required such measures of
cliquishness to guard against a clearly immoral and unjust "law". The
underground railroad activities were illegal and prosecutable in those
times, but are seen as heroic nowadays. Perhaps the fight to freely
assemble and party/dance/whatever in any location at any hour may be
seen as illegal nowadays -- but who knows how stupid your laws may look
in the future.

-- Niels.

hi -

i had originally agreed with amy as far as the concept of the intention
behind the post.  but, when i read tony's post, i didn't feel the energy
behind it was "na na na na na, i went to an underground party and you
didn't!"  i felt he was truly sharing some positive energy about an
experience that he felt good about.  so, i don't think it's that there
should be that you should or you shouldn't but your reason or intention
for posting or not posting.  did that make sense?

bren :)


On Tue, 9 Apr 1996, Tony Rotundo wrote:

> At 10:59 AM 4/9/96, Amy R Starkey wrote:
>
> >So that brings up the question of whether or not to post reviews of these
> >"super secret underground parties" on sfraves.
>
> I don't know.  I mean, this is a newsgroup, not a party line, so if a party
> doesn't get posted to SFR does that mean it's exclusive?  I'm sure there
> are lots of parties that don't get posted, mainly because when that
> happens, there's the potential for hundreds upon hundreds of people showing
> up.  Some venues can't hold that.
>
> >If I had not been "in the know" about this great little free party and
> >then kept hearing all kinds of wonderful things about it posted on
> >sfraves, I would be feeling pretty bitter and it brings up those feelings
> >of elitism.
>
> But if it's a word of mouth party, then I guess people just have to realize
> that there was a good party that happened that they didn't know about
> becuase they didn't know anyone involved.  It's not elitism, it's just the
> nature of life.  You can't know everyone or get invited to everything and
> have to be comfortable in accepting that.  If someone is truly bitter then
> maybe that should be a call for them to become more involved in the scene,
> by helping a group, or just showing a sincere commitment to the cause,
> getting to know people.
>
> Believe it or not, we all have missed lots of small parties.  Even you Amy!
> ;^)  And would you feel bitter if someone posted about a party they had
> fun at, or would you say, "Right on!  I'm glad a party went off.
> Hmmm...maybe I'll email the person that posted and let them know I'd love
> to get involved with the next little party they throw."
>
> The really interesting thing about this scene is that we are extremely
> fortunate on SFR to have access to where most of the parties are happening
> here in SF.  Prior to SFR, what was there a phone tree or something?  I
> just recently met a guy who says he raves but didn't know how to find out
> about them.  I have a friend visiting from Australia and he wanted to know
> what was happening around the city.  Was there a paper he could get to find
> out about parties?  And you know, there really isn't, at least that I know
> of.  The Guardian will list what's happening at 1015, or Bahia, but where
> is The Gathering listed?  How do new people find out about even massives?
>
> Anyway, I guess the question is whether people should post about
> undergrounds that aren't listed here on SFR, and I think that's my round
> about way of saying I think it's all right, that most promters in the Bay
> area are not intentionaly exclusive, but rather have to keep in mind
> spacing and crowd control issues.
>
> Tony

In-Reply-To: <Pine.3.89.9604091339.B5716-0100000@uclink2.berkeley.edu> from "Kyung Rok Lee" at Apr 9, 96 02:30:03 pm

Precedence: bulk


> > seems to me that the lighting shows are more to blame for getting
> > everybody to face front and zone than the dj stack - i think it would be
> > nice (although prob. tricky) to get more of a surround lighting effect so
> > you wouldn't miss much by not staring at the speakers.
> 
Hmmm, not sure about the lighting.  Look at Wicked, where the projections
are at the back, yet most people seem to face forward.  I think what would
really help this would be speakers all round, rather than lighting (and
moving the DJ booth).
 
> My thoughts have fluctuated on this one.  There once was a time when I 
> read everyone facing the same direction as a vestige of the 
> _hierarchized_ spectator/performer dichotomy epitomized by rock concerts.  
> However, I have had a change of opinion.  It _can_ serve to minimize the 
> self-consciousness of other dancefloor environments (where the moves have 
> names, and where people are there to be seen, whether they like it 
> or not), while at the same time, heightening and making most diffuse the 
> _presence_ and _energy_ of the collectivity.  Everyone is in the 
> periphery, making the group, rather than any individual, the _object_ of 
> attention. 

Not if they're facing the DJ, which would make him/her (the individual) more 
the focus than "the group".

> This said, everything has to do with _context_, 
> particularly the specific spatial arrangement of the given party 
> environment.  My desire that everyone more-or-less face the same direction 
> is not universal. 
> 
To be honest, I can't stand having people all face the same direction.  I find
it really boring and am more or less constantly changing which way I'm facing
while dancing.  I find I pick up more "energy" looking at other people, all
getting into the same thing.  Everyone's so different, that's what I enjoy
about it (confessions of a chronic people-watcher :-).

> > of course, you can always just turn around and dance upstream like a
> > salmon.  try it sometime when nobody else is - it's sort of a neat little
> > head trip, especially at really big events.
> 
> Depending on the situation, I'll occasionally feel compelled to do the 
> same.  However, I am conscious of how the direction of my gaze can have 
> an effect on other individuals' level of self-consciousness.  Rok.  
> 
I'd never thought about any possible effect on someone else's self-consciousness
 - I don't stare at people, I'm usually just looking around, smiling a lot,
having a good time.  It's the individuals that make the whole experince fun -
the ones you meet, the ones you share a dance space with for a while, etc.

Neil.

> > 
> Hmmm, not sure about the lighting.  Look at Wicked, where the projections
> are at the back, yet most people seem to face forward.  I think what would
> really help this would be speakers all round, rather than lighting (and
> moving the DJ booth).
>  
> > My thoughts have fluctuated on this one.  There once was a time when I 
> > read everyone facing the same direction as a vestige of the 
> > _hierarchized_ spectator/performer dichotomy epitomized by rock concerts.  
> > However, I have had a change of opinion.  It _can_ serve to minimize the 
> > self-consciousness of other dancefloor environments (where the moves have 
> > names, and where people are there to be seen, whether they like it 
> > or not), while at the same time, heightening and making most diffuse the 
> > _presence_ and _energy_ of the collectivity.  Everyone is in the 
> > periphery, making the group, rather than any individual, the _object_ of 
> > attention. 
> 
> Not if they're facing the DJ, which would make him/her (the individual) more 
> the focus than "the group".

This is a good point.  Facing in the direction of the dj may, 
however, be partly symptomatic of something else you bring up -- speaker 
location/orientation.  Also, when the dj's are situated on the ground level 
-- as I like them to be in most situations -- you can't really see her/him if 
you're beyond the first few rows of concentric circles/semi-circles.     

> > This said, everything has to do with _context_, 
> > particularly the specific spatial arrangement of the given party 
> > environment.  My desire that everyone more-or-less face the same direction 
> > is not universal. 
> > 
> To be honest, I can't stand having people all face the same direction.  I find
> it really boring and am more or less constantly changing which way I'm facing
> while dancing.  I find I pick up more "energy" looking at other people, all
> getting into the same thing.  Everyone's so different, that's what I enjoy
> about it (confessions of a chronic people-watcher :-).

Yup, I like eye-contact, too, and getting off on how other people are 
going off.  I didn't want to make it seem like I wore horse blinders or 
something.  It's just that, in general, having my body generally 
oriented in the same direction as everyone else's makes, IMO, for the 
highest degree of dancefloor selflessness.  Once again, this depends on 
circumstances, and is far from a rule for me.  

Let's examine the act of freaking.  On a couple of occasions at a 
rave/rave-style event, I've been approached by women seeking to do the old 
bump'n'grind.  Nothing inherently wrong with this form of dancefloor 
intimacy -- it was just the wrong dancefloor.  I felt kinda selfish dancing 
this way, since my energy was being focussed on one individual (not to 
mention body region) and not to the body-at-large.  This may just be my 
own strange over-analysis of the situation.  Stangely enough, I kinda like 
when heterosexual men or women get together for a good same-sex freak cuz' 
I'm down with people feeling free enough to toy with such boundaries.  
(Same could be said for homosexual "transgressions").  _Elevated 
same or mixed group dancefloors hugs (not too long) and freak sessions are 
cool, too, cuz' it's fun to see just how fucked up they are ;).  I draw 
the line at drunk-funk-mac-daddy-gap-band-party-trains.     
  
> > > of course, you can always just turn around and dance upstream like a
> > > salmon.  try it sometime when nobody else is - it's sort of a neat little
> > > head trip, especially at really big events.
> > 
> > Depending on the situation, I'll occasionally feel compelled to do the 
> > same.  However, I am conscious of how the direction of my gaze can have 
> > an effect on other individuals' level of self-consciousness.  Rok.  
> > 
> I'd never thought about any possible effect on someone else's self-consciousness
>  - I don't stare at people, I'm usually just looking around, smiling a lot,
> having a good time.  It's the individuals that make the whole experince fun -
> the ones you meet, the ones you share a dance space with for a while, etc.

You're right!  

Rok.

> i had originally agreed with amy as far as the concept of the intention
> behind the post.  but, when i read tony's post, i didn't feel the energy
> behind it was "na na na na na, i went to an underground party and you
> didn't!"  i felt he was truly sharing some positive energy about an

> for posting or not posting.  did that make sense?

Tony's post also enlightened me and my stance on the topic.  I think it 
boils down to how the person who posts intends it to sound.  The person 
may *have* that attitude of "I know about these cool parties and you 
don't" or have the attitude that Tony does when posting about these super 
hush-hush raves. Thanks, Tony, for a better, healthier perspective. :)

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Apr  9 18:15:46 1996

Received: (from ausman@localhost) by soda.CSUA.Berkeley.EDU (8.6.12/8.6.12) id SAA11408 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Tue, 9 Apr 1996 18:15:37 -0700
Date: Tue, 9 Apr 1996 18:15:37 -0700
From: James Ausman <ausman@CSUA.Berkeley.EDU>
Message-Id: <199604100115.SAA11408@soda.CSUA.Berkeley.EDU>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: sunset review
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Wow, whatta party! The trippiness started early for me, as my friend
decided to "find parking" rather than take a bus. Well, we found it
finally, after half an hour of driving around Fisherman's Wharf. The
tourists found my bright hair mesmerizing, and I even saw a couple of them
pointing and taking pictures. Which is fine by me, but still unsettling.

So after walking blocks and blocks through a sea of camera wielding tourists,
I finally saw a guy wearing a silver jacker and funky sunglasses. His
clothes just screamed "Raver!" and sure enough, he was there for the boat
party and pointed me in the right direction (please no flames about what
kind of clothes ravers wear). In fact everyone there seemed especially
colorful and beautiful and dressed up. I have always been struck by the
beauty of the people at raves, which I think is more of a consequence of
our smiles anything else, but this group was dazzling.

The trip around the bay was great fun. I liked dancing in a rocking boat,
since we would get tossed around and gently into each other. It helped
break down the barriers even more than dancing usually does.

We broke into fog just before passing under the Golden Gate Bridge
and having its ghostly presence hovering over us, with fog horns 
blaring, made me feel small and special at the same time. We circled
back into the sun near Marin, missing sunset under the bridge (which
we couldn't have seen anyway) and instead got a close view of the
brilliant greeen, shining hillside. "Shangri-La!", Samona said, and
I had to agree. Marin has always seemed sort of like Shangri-la to me,
but it really looked the part that day.

We had some interesting guests in a seagull that drafted us for
miles, never flapping its wings and a couple of sail boarders who
seemed to get a kick out of our enthusiasm. We made a turn on a dime
in Tiburon (?) harbor. I didn't konw you could spin one of those
boats around that fast. 

Later that night we drove around Alcatraz and passed under the Bay Bridge.
I was inside dancing mostly after dark. The music was actually a little
too quiet for my tastes, first time that has ever happened.

Now, this was a $20 party and "worth it" at least to me. But I think
that charging this much definitely changes the party. Perhaps
it is just me, but at every Sunset I have ever been at, I have felt
an incredibly powerful "love vibe" flowing outward. Sometimes I really
fell like we are creating some sort of magic spell or something. I really
didn't feel that this time. Maybe it was due to the way we were all sort
of broken up around the boat or something else, but while the crowd was
friendly, happy, and beautiful, the vibe wasn't really there for me.

Peace,
Jim

> 
> 
>Personally I think DJ's (unlike children) should be heard and not seen.  One
>of my (only) dislikes about Wicked is that everyone seems to stand in lines,
>facing the dj booth. People focus at lot less on *who* is spinning
>and more on what is being played (which helps avoid the 'rock idol' syndrome).

>Neil.
>neil@nit.airtouch.com

I prefer a party where people stand in line facing the DJ booth! Not only
does it give a focus for people's energy, but a lot of people appreciate
being able to watch how the DJ is mixing..especially if he/she is a
technical wizard.  I've only tried mixing a couple of times myself, but that
was enough to realize how hard some of the stuff the great ones do (and make
look easy). I don't feel I've had a complete party experience if I can't see
what's going on. I agree with Neil about the 'rock idol'syndrome, but I
think (hopefully) people aren't focused on _who_  is spinning, but on _how_
they are spinning.  Also, how else can you find out what the name of that
amazing track is if it doesnt't have any words! That's why you'll always
find me front and center...

juliet

>
>>Diana Greer <inanna@ccnet.com>:
>>  I
>> believe it is bad form to talk publicly about something that was not
>> available for the public.
>
>I generally prefer openness to cliquishness, unfortunately the fact
>that the police are undoubtedly reading this list means that some
>secrecy is needed.

Y'know I've got a list of phone numbers of the cool people I've met off this 
list.  It started with the phone list for the folks from Tahoe, but it's 
growing.  I've also got each of the person's email addresses.  If I was to 
communicate an underground rave, I'd send it the message to people I'd 
actually met.  I don't think I'd be particularly discriminating in any other 
way.  If this also sounds "cliqueish", well, ok, but I see it as being safe.

I know and you all know that, while there may be certain illegal activities 
occurring at some raves, in the grand scheme of things these parties are so 
much safer and more positive than your average beer bust.  For that reason, 
I'd take some sort of precaution to communicating some party information.  
There are some events that deserve to be underground in the sense that 
knowledge of the event is distributed as widely as possible yet carefully 
protected at the same time.

My $.02.

S

Dear Ms. Burke,

	I'm sure most members of the rave community appreciate your 
concern for their welfare.
	I think many of us would also find that concern seriously misplaced.
Government authorities like yours have created a climate in this country 
which does not value free celebrations of life, dance, and music.
	You have created a bureaucratic process which deadens life, and 
laws which seek to restrict our freedom  to do in our own lives and with 
our own bodies as we see fit.
	Not only do you make no attempt to experience or enjoy the rave 
experience yourself, you attempt to prevent others from doing so, in 
violation of both the letter and the spirit of our country's highest law.
	The concept of public service in America today has been twisted 
into a perverted concept of benign paternalism by many of our 
ever-growing number of public servants.  Citizens are not respected and 
looked up to as the rulers of this nation, as we were intended to be, but 
rather looked upon as irresponsible inconveniences hindering the march 
toward a grey new world of method, order, inoffensive blandness and 
complete government control.
	Well, despite your best efforts, there is a vibrant culture 
out here undreamt of in your commission studies, white papers, and 
environmental impact reports.
	It is a culture more sensitive to real quality-of-life issues 
than your drinking laws, health codes, and permit requirements.  This 
culture is not preoccupied with physical and economic security as is the 
establishment.  We are more concerned with protecting people from the 
very real danger of losing touch in our society with what it means to be 
human, to be alive, to *appreciate* and cultivate beauty, creativity, and 
joy.  You mean to safeguard us, but you are only guarding our bodies.  We 
are the watchdogs of the mind, the spirit, and the soul.
	I challenge you to show me where in the Constitution, either in 
the letter or spirit of the highest law of our land from which all our 
other laws derive their legitimacy (or lack thereof) and which is in turn 
dependant on the consent of the governed, it is written or implied that 
you Ms. Burke, or any other elected or appointed official of the state of 
Utah are empowered to disrupt a nonviolent celebration of life.
	The fact is you have no such mandate.  What you are engaged in is 
crimes against humanity -- not (yet) on the scale of those tried at 
Nuremburg, but crimes agasint humanity nevertheless.
	In the name of the ravers, the deadheads, the drug users, the 
poets, the artists, the writers, the freethinkers and free spirits among 
us, I ask you to stop.
	Because we will always be with you -- even in the slave fields 
and the gulags we are with you.  And however much it is expected of you 
to do your job, you always have a choice, no matter how the Hitlers and 
Stalins of the world (both those in a position to reveal their brutality 
and those constrained from doing so) would have you believe otherwise.
	I do not expect you to listen to me seriously.  To do so would go 
against years of training and the culture of the government for which you 
work.  But ravers are an optimistic bunch. We like to find the love in 
everyone.  Freeing this love is what our gatherings are about.  We call 
it "vibe".  If the vibe in your workplace is not on this level, do you 
ever ask why not?  Do you dare to dream that it could be?
	I've never met you Susan, but I know that as a human being you 
are capable of more than processing paperwork, that there have been 
moments in your life when you were too happy to even consider interfering 
with someone else's happiness.  I hope you live to have many more such 
moments, perhaps even at a rave.  If I saw you at one, I would like to 
give you a hug to remind you that the best things in life are free.
	Please, let us be free.

Much love, & best wishes, 
				<<< Starchild >>>



--------------------------------------------------------------
Please forward this to whomever else might find it interesting.

We've been having quite a controversy in Salt Lake City Utah RAVES.
The Rumor is that we SERVE alcohol and GANGS intitiate their members.
How realistic Does this seem to you?
The past three months or so almost every party has been busted.  Some
Ravers have  lost hope.  We need help out here in SLC to prove to our
community that RAVES are not what they think they are.

                                                Your friend, 
                                                   Heather

Received: from STATE-DOMAIN-Message_Server by state.ut.us
	with Novell_GroupWise; Tue, 26 Mar 1996 17:33:49 -0700
Message-Id: <s1582a7d.049@state.ut.us>
X-Mailer: Novell GroupWise 4.1
Date: Tue, 26 Mar 1996 17:33:37 -0700
From: Susan Burke <gvpbmain.sburke@state.ut.us>
To: 1LYNCHHE@UVSC.EDU
Subject:  What is your knowledge of RAVES? -Reply

Dear Ms. Lynch:

Thank you for your inquiry regarding Rave parties.  Governor Mike
Leavitt has requested that I respond to your questions directly.  

Because the Rave party phenomena is taking place mostly in the Salt
Lake City area, I contacted the Salt Lake City Police Department Vice
Squad to discuss your concerns.  Sgt. Kenneth W. Hansen responded
that Rave Parties are a problem for the police department because they
have found that the individuals who sponsor the parties do not have
business licenses, therefore, putting those who attend the parties at risk.
Through licensing, businesses are required to meet certain health and
safety codes.  They must also meeting bonding requirements to protect
them from liability issues.  An unlicensed business could be a potential
death trap.  The issue, therefore, is not Constitutional.  

Sgt. Hansen also indicated that there is a historical record of alcoholic
beverages being served to minors at these parties.  Not only is this in
violation of state laws, it poses a serious threat to the safety and
welfare of the drinker and the public at large.  It is also my understanding
that Rave Parties are intentionally covert and secretive to avoid scrutiny
by officials that are charged with public safety, licensing and taxes.  A
Rave Party would be considered a legal function if those sponsoring the
party complied with all city, county, state and federal laws.  

In regards to gang activity at these parties, officers from the Salt Lake
Area Gang Project have reported that gang violence and recruiting have
taken place at Rave Parties.  There is also residual activity occuring
outside of the Rave Party location where rival gang members have been
involved in violent and criminal activity as of a result of being attracted to
the Rave Party in the first place.

I do not believe it is the intent of our cities to deny young people the
opportunity to congregate and attend parties.  It is, however, the
responsiblity of local and state government to ensure that the health and
safety of young people are preserved.

Sincerely,

Susan Burke
Anti-Violence Coordinator

     less than reliable) for info. on parties etc.

     have been DJing for the last year.

     scene. Here, unfortunately, it seems that things are beginning to fade a 
     little, although the Temple of Sound in Dublin is one of the best clubs I 
     have ever been to.

I'd like to think that I'm a pretty decent person, I have to live with me 
so at least that's what I tell myself. I don't sell crack, I don't have a 
gun, I don't say "hella" a lot. I get upset every now & then & have my 
bad hair days just like everybody else on this planet, but for the most 
part I'm a pretty mellow guy.

Sometimes all it can take is a few words from somebody and all of a 
sudden you're in a parrall univerise where Spock has a goatee and you're 
an asshole. I don't know, I think some people rave to much, sometimes 
myself included.

On top of that I lost my backpack with *both* my jackets. It's like 
losing your best friend. And it's not like I'm one of those people who 
just carelesslly drops it on some random place on the floor. I put it on 
top of the speakers, so that it can be seen from most corners of the 
room. First time this has ever happen to me. Sun had his backpack gone 
through and his jacket & cash taken. Spent 60 mins. afterwards looking 
through the homebase with no luck & according to security at the lost & 
found some 8 different people also came up with missing possision stories.
Thank you Oakland.

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

giving away some records...

imr and Orbitrecords are proud to be giving away five copies of the
limited (200 copies) pre-release of the .x09 fzz ep.  As described in the
last installment of 'from the horse's mouth...' this record explores "the
boundaries of experimental percussive dance music, integrating syncopated,
bouncy rhythms with highly abrasive jagged drum tones and samples." 

In any event, if you'd like to win a copy of this 4-track 12" single 
here's what you have to do...

	Write a review of a DJ-oriented record that is
	approximately 100 words in length.  Send it to 
	imr@world.std.com and we'll award records to the 
	five best written reviews.  

Good luck, and don't hesitate to enter since it seems that the more effort
the giveaways require the less competition there is.  We may even ask some
of the winners to write for 'slipmat' in the future since we're planning
on turning 'slipmat' into its own e-zine around the same time we convert
imr into a new Web-oriented e-zine. 

If you'd like to check out imr just send the message "subscribe" to
imr-request@world.std.com (note, though, that the e-zine covers a wide
variety of music and therefore some of the content may be of interest to
readers of this list while other content may not).

 i just moved down to the area from the portland, OR.  platinum is the store 
which i bought my mixer and turntables.  this is how their deals work.  usually 
they are able to give low prices for cash purchases, with credit/check 
purchases being only slightly more.  the owner is a great guy, cuz he said that 
if i'd ever want to sell my decks, he'd buy them back at a good price.  give'em 
a call, it's worth it.
 well that's my two cents worth on equipment.  does anyone know of any good 
spots going off this weekend? (i've been out of town for a long time)

On Tue, 9 Apr 1996, Matt Kodama wrote:

> Forwarded message:
> > Personally I think DJ's (unlike children) should be heard and not seen.  One
> > of my (only) dislikes about Wicked is that everyone seems to stand in lines,
> > facing the dj booth.  It feels terribly regimented and because of it there
> > seems to be a lot less interaction between people than there could be.
> 
> heard a sound bite from a rave promoter a while back, saying that a rock
> concert involves thousands of people all facing the same way and looking
> at the stage, while a rave is more orientation-neutral - interpret that
> how you like.

One thing that I really like at raves is that you really can dance 
ANYWHERE.  It doesn't matter if you are by yourself, in a group, near the 
music, far away, etc.  If you feel like dancing, you just do it.  Now, 
when I am at some other party or even in a club, I do this.  It always 
elicits weird looks, and that in turn reminds me of how much I appreciate 
the "rave-atmosphere."  :)  

luv,
kc

> i just pulled out a flyer, and the phone numbers on sfrave's web site are
> indeed wrong.
> the phone #'s should be: 510-895-3550 and 415-337-4928
> 
> more from the flyer:
> "Beyond Space-Time Productions
> What grand temple has been erected for his greatness esteemed principle, his
> awesome beauty? Can any place capture the morning rods of golden sun? Or the
> beams of the enchantress when she is in full bloom at midnight as her
> children, the stars, twinkle and dance in the heavens? There is no place
> that has ever been made that could honor such an entity that is all things,
> except in you.
> Ramtha from the school of enlightenment."

The last Kundalini I went to was in July of 1995.  It was absolutely 
horrible.  I think they had lost their space and had found a last minute 
small dance club to have it in.  This place could only hold about 150 
ppl, but they let in what seemed to be 3 times that amount.  It was so 
crowded that you could not walk one foot.  It was truly the feeling of 
being a herd of cattle.  The heat and humidity got so intense that water 
was dripping off all of the walls.  It was the worst party I have ever 
been to.  I'd be really hesitant to go again, unless I knew that the 
July incident was a freak occurance.  Does anyone have any more information 
about this?  


--kc

John said....	The last few Kundalinis have had bad reports, but the
first three were all very good... The first was at the Trocadero, 	then
Caesars,then the roller rink at Antioch... and they were a 	lot of fun. So...
they have the capacity to throw a good party.  	Whether they will again
or not remains to be seen.  If it ends up 	being in a known good space, I
would probably give them the 	 	benefit of the doubt,and give it a
chance.

		
I've been to three Kundalinis -- the one at the Troc was ok...  the one at
Ceasars, I'd have to say was one of the weirdest parties I've ever been to --
average age 15, hanging out in little clusters -- there was a discount before 11
or something, but then they held the line up and charged the higher amount even
though we'd been waiting in line, saying "you should have come earlier!" --
plus a gangsta element, perhaps due to the geographical location) -- I left that
night at 1:30 a.m.!

But I went to one Kundalini 2 hrs south of Seattle outdoors at Rainbow Valley,
which I'm pretty sure is the same people, and it was really great.... music was
great, well-organized, beautiful location with no hassles....

So I have to concur, the location would make the difference, 'cause the dj
lineup has some of my favorite names in it -- Spun, Garth, Donald Glaude, Quest
(Donald and Quest are from Seattle) -- these guys all really make a place come
alive!  

good luck!  Leslie  : )

From: patti@sonic.net (Patti Tufty)

FILM EXTRAS NEEDED ASAP!!!!!!!!!

What is it?:

A film to be shown at the General Motors Pavillion at the Olympics in
Atlanta this summer.

When is it?:

Sunday, April 14th starting at 8am. Extras must be prepared to spend the
day there. Shooting could end early, but may go as late as 5pm.

Who do we need?:

About 100 extras at Stanford Stadium. Friends and family can be in it too..
but children must be old enough to withstand being in one place for an
extended period of time.

What do they get for their trouble?:

Besides the fame? There is no fortune... extras will not be paid. However,
extras will get a free lunch,  and could win some valuable prizes!   They
get the fun and excitement of being part of a real film shoot, and could
get their 15 seconds of fame at the Olympics!

What should they do?:

Contact me, Patti Tufty at 707-664-8519 to get more information and
register. Time is of the essence, so call as soon as possible!

A good thing to do is get a couple of sound catalogs and find the 
cheapest prices and a place like Pro Sound in LA will match your lowest 
price and ship the next day.  I like Pro Sound because their salespeople 
are on the ball and know what they are talking about and are willing to 
bargain if you make a $1500 order.

     Well I've been lurking now for 5-6 months, wonder if that's some sort 
     of record ? - also wonder how we would ever know (? :)). Anyway, time 
     to out !!
     
     I'm fae' Scotland & that's where I first got into the scene circa `92. 
     Don't have much of an accent as I've lived in England for `bout half 
     my life (Durham & Portsmouth) - so you'll probably be able to 
     understand me !! Best party I've ever been to would be the Hogmanay 
     (New Year for all you sassenachs !) 93-94 bash held at Prestwick 
     Airport  - Prodigy, Shades of Rhythm and more, while to cap the event 
     our "designated driver" managed to crash the car, not once but, 
     *twice* on the way home !! Rezerection also rooled. Guess you can tell 
     I like massives - the buzz from a couple of thousand people all going 
     off to some serious techno just gets me where I live. Hmmmmm.
     
     Prior to hauling ass down here I spent almost 3 yrs in NYC - took me a 
     while to get into the scene & find a posse but we had a lotta lotta 
     fun. Never really enjoyed the Sound Factory (Junior was a bit too soft 
     for my tastes), but once the Tunnel became an all-nighter it was (and 
     is) just *the* best !! The Roxy on Fridays is also thumping but was 
     shut down for a long time while I was there (boo-hoo).
     
     Have hit a few parties down here starting with Exxon back in October, 
     best so far would have to be those Wicked things. Excellent vibe !! 
     Personal hates include 1015 & Sound Factory (I didn't know any better, 
     honest Guv !!) Oh, bio for wetware would be : 27, `bout 6' tall, with 
     short brown hair (used to be real long (...sob, sob)), generally rave 
     in pretty boring togs - jeans / whitish T with design. Spot me by 
     green pumas or purple Docs and, of course, the silly smile.
     
     This list is fantastic - you guys really have a *nice* thing going 
     here. Respect.
     
     Btw: Check out an article in this weeks Economist mag comparing 
     properties of & attitudes to Prozac & E. Interesting angle.
     
     Btw II - The Sequel: Anybody have any info on amateur foottie (SOCCER 
     that is !!) leagues in/around SF ?? Would be much appreciated, Ta  !
     
     Btw III - Etc: Can I have a laminate now ?
     
     Shouts out to Volt & I hope to meet a lot more of you soon !!

** Mainstream Alert **

Every day between 5 and 6PM KMEL (106.1) has a dj mix show: happy club
house and hip-hop.  I've caught this show a few times because, I have to
admit, sometimes I like that mainstream clubby simple house music (silly
lyrics, relentless house beat, obligatory siren and drum progression).

But you wouldn't believe the stuff morphing into "house" these days!!
Salsa music, ballads, rap songs - with full house beats under them!
Basically, they're recycling known musical quantities, and simply adding a
house beat, creating bizarre hybrids.

And the other day they played that club song..."you gotta lick it before we
kick it..." (you know the one!)...with a chant interpersed, "RAVE ON! RAVE
ON! RAVE ON!"

AAAAHHHHH!!

On Wed, 10 Apr 1996, Starchild wrote:
> Government authorities like yours have created a climate in this country 
...
> You have created a bureaucratic process which deadens life
...
> 	Well, despite your best efforts, there is a vibrant culture 
> out here undreamt of in your commission studies, white papers, and 
> environmental impact reports.
...
> What you are engaged in is 
> crimes against humanity -- not (yet) on the scale of those tried at 
> Nuremburg, but crimes agasint humanity nevertheless.
...
> 	Because we will always be with you -- even in the slave fields 
> and the gulags we are with you. 
...
> Hitlers and Stalins of the world 
...

Well, it's good to see we're opening a healthy dialog... er, wait, no, I 
wouldn't exactly call that healthy... 

Seriously, Starchild, someone who took the time to personally respond to
Heather has at least some sympathy and concern for her questions and this
culture, and does not deserve the language you used on her.  If you really
want to start a conversation, you have to start from understanding where they
come from, what their knowlege of the situation and environment is, and not
make any presuppositions of their intent.  In the above message you ascribe
the many frustrations we have with a deliberate conspiracy to deprive us of
happiness - which presumes an awful awful lot that just isn't substantiated. 

The tone of Susan's message, to me, was "play by the rules - get permits 
- and you will be treated with respect from the government".  This is 
true anywhere - you have to play by the rules to drive a car, you have to 
play by the rules to do just about anything.  Sometimes those rules feel 
pretty arbitrary or even just plain wrong, but sometimes they do make 
sense, like limits on maximum number of occupants in a building.  I know 
you are a staunch libertarian, and favor as few rules as possible, but 
what will you tell me when the floor eventually caves in at the Acme 
warehouse?  

The answer to this is to do what many people in different communities have
done - approach the community authorities as equals, *respecting* their
opinions and belief systems and mores, and working within them.  I do not
feel that there is a fundamental disconnect between raving and the rest of
the population.  I have seen too many cops come across a renegade party, see
that it was safe, and decide to let it continue, to think that there is some
biological switch that makes you one way or the other. 

Show the Salt Lake community why raves have nothing to do with gangs (and 
who knows, maybe in SLC there really is a problem with that - it was 
certainly a problem in LA when I was there), why it is a safe 
environment, etc.  Get a permit to have a daytime party on a Sunday in a 
park in the center of town.  Go through the right steps to have at least 
some of the parties 100% kosher with the local jurisdictions.  This has 
*certainly* worked in many places, such as Richmond here in the Bay 
Area.  

And it sounds like there is someone at the other end of the phone line 
willing to listen.  Hey, if Susan can be convinced that having 100 people 
dancing at a party leads to fewer acts of violence amongst the population 
than having 100 people on the streets or 100 people watching football, 
she might become a big supporter.  

But don't fritter away the opportunity by comparing them to Hitler and 
Stalin.

	Brian

Precedence: bulk


FDA Warns Against 'Natural' Euphoric Drugs

WASHINGTON (Reuter) - U.S.  health officials warned Wednesday against
using diet supplements containing ephedrine sold as alternatives to
street drugs such as ``Ecstasy'', saying they posed serious health
risks.

The Food and Drug Administration said the products, often targeted at
adolescents and young adults, are marketed under brand names with
implications that they produce euphoria, heightened sexual sensation and
awareness or increased energy.

It said they contain botanical or ``natural'' sources of ephedrine, an
amphetamine-like stimulant that can have dangerous effects on the
nervous system and heart.

The FDA said the possible adverse effects ranged from heart attack,
stroke, seizures, psychosis and death to less serious ones such as
dizziness and irregular heartbeat.

It said the risks were serious and it was investigating the production
and marketing of ephedrine-containing products sold as alternatives to
illegal street drugs.

The FDA said that many of the products bear labels implying they can
produce a ``high'' and it said it considered this type of promotion and
these claims to violate the food and drug law, even as amended in 1994.

It said it was committed to take any action needed to remove such
products from the market.

But the agency added that under the amended law it has to act
product-by-product to show that something is unsafe rather than be able
to require a manufacturer to prove its product is safe before it can be
marketed.

The agency said that ingredients listed on the panels of the products
may include ma huang, Chinese ephedra extract, ephedra herb powder,
epitonin or ephedrine, any of which indicate the present of ephedrine.

The FDA asked that consumers who have had an adverse reaction after
taking a dietary supplement or any product containing an ephedrine
alkaloid to call the agency at 1-800-FDA 4010.

It said health professionals who have treated patients with adverse side
effects should call the FDA's Medwatch hot line at 1-800-FDA-1088.

-----------------------------------------
Andrew Knutsen            andrewk@sco.com
Santa Cruz Operation      (408) 427-7538

Good vibes about the Progress folks!

I went to one last August (their sixth party...?) after hearing about them
for a while (they were going off monthly last spring and summer).  For some
reason I cannot remember the exact location or even who spun :(, but it was
in a smallish SOMA warehouse, 3 floors.

Lighting was minimal, but the sound was good, the music was going off, and
the dance floor vibe upstairs was really strong (_that_ much I do
remember!)  Downstairs in the chill room were some amazing instruments that
I have wished to see at parties ever since...a round stone bowl with a
mallet that emitted this amazing deep tonal sound, more like a vibration
that filled the room (!)...and a looong blowhorn-type thing that also
created an ethereal, deep sound.   This _really_ helped create a sacred
temple-like environment...There were microphones set up and people
accompanied ambient with their voices, and then there was even freestyle
rap!

I very much dig the union of rave parties with spirituality... Progress,
which was envisioned to echo each of the Celestine Prophecy's Nine
Insights, is one of the only parties I know of (any others?) that has so
visibly highlighted the connection.  I know many of us have experienced
spiritual awakenings during parties (I sometimes refer to them, only among
those who know, as my "temple"), but often it is left for us to find that
on our own.  A more active approach, like Progress', could bring many to
the same awareness, IMO.

Also, the Progress I went to was only (!) $8.   One thing that really
proved their integrity to me was the fact that, after one in the spring got
busted, they subtracted I think $5 off of their next party for people who
had bought tickets for the busted one :).   If memory serves me correctly,
didn't they also throw a free daytime party to also make up for it?  (Fuzzy
here, anyone know?)

I haven't seen the flier - can someone post the info?  Thanks!  Love.  Nancy

>I went to one last August (their sixth party...?) after hearing about them
>for a while (they were going off monthly last spring and summer).  For some
>reason I cannot remember the exact location or even who spun :(, but it was
>in a smallish SOMA warehouse, 3 floors.


This sounds like the Acme, no?  True, I have always immensely enjoyed parties 
I've gone to at the Acme, but my guess would be that a lotta people would 
boycott this particular party simply based on that location.



>I very much dig the union of rave parties with spirituality... Progress,
>which was envisioned to echo each of the Celestine Prophecy's Nine
>Insights, is one of the only parties I know of (any others?) that has so
>visibly highlighted the connection.  I know many of us have experienced
>spiritual awakenings during parties (I sometimes refer to them, only among
>those who know, as my "temple"), but often it is left for us to find that
>on our own.  A more active approach, like Progress', could bring many to
>the same awareness, IMO.


I've not heard a lot about this particular aspect of these parties, actually, 
except one person said that the party he went to itself didn't really seem to 
have much to do with C.P. at all with the exception of having the pertinent 
Insight printed on their flyer.  But obviously a rave can be plenny spiritual 
without being required to relate to the Celestine Prophecy specifically! :)


>Also, the Progress I went to was only (!) $8.   One thing that really
>proved their integrity to me was the fact that, after one in the spring got
>busted, they subtracted I think $5 off of their next party for people who
>had bought tickets for the busted one :).   If memory serves me correctly,
>didn't they also throw a free daytime party to also make up for it?  (Fuzzy
>here, anyone know?)
>I haven't seen the flier - can someone post the info?  Thanks!  Love.  Nancy


I've gotten several responses about these parties, the reviews have been really 
mixed.  Several people said they were pretty mediocre, and several seemed to 
really think the ones they attended were really good.  Of course, several of 
those parties from what I heard were thrown at the Acme, so that's gonna color 
a few opinions anyway.  So far, it still sounds like there's possible hope for 
this one, I had a chance to talk a little to the girl who was handing out 
flyers for Progress at MAD on Monday, she said the price would be about 
$10-$12, and the number of people they were expecting was probably about an 
average of 800 or so, not too small but certainly not massive.  Wasn't 
January's Chrysalis somewhere in that number range?  However, from what she 
said it still sounded like it could be at the Acme, she mentioned there being 
three rooms (all you previous Acme-goers can visualize all the rooms!)  Coupled 
with the numbers they're expecting and the fact that historically they've been 
known to use the Acme, I'd say it's a definite possibility that this one'll be 
held there too.  Wayne also said he knew the girl throwing the party & would be 
attending, so I am assuming he would not support them if they weren't 
worthwhile to some degree.

Anyway, this party still sounds like it has some definite potential, albeit w/ 
a coupla drawbacks.  I'll probably check it out if there's nothing else going 
on that weekend.

Love,
Shawna

Whoa there!  Before going off on e killing brain cells or any others on the
list *** except alcohol does kill 'em - toxic stuff that it is ***
 best to get some good resource info which might include BUT not be limited
 to :

 Andrew Weil's book on drugs from A-Z  Chocolate to ??? ( can't remember it's
    exact title but it's easy to find )

 PDR - any discount book store has em

 Merck index - has lots of drugs & chemicals including LD50 toxic info

 Check the Hyperreal archieves for some info....

 Any user should have good info sources such as these to turn not - NOT
 data passed around from raver to raver... I much prefer Weil's book 
 to those of people like Eisner **who has far too much of an agenda to
 get out **  and Weil ( who I've personally met and is a wonderful man )
 is an MD with a passion for mushrooms of all varieties so I easily
 recommend his book...

 Mike  ****  wearing his chemist's hat - this time ;-)

 meclay@netcom.com          |  Alone & ecstatic

Hey there Mike. Sorry your stuff was either stolen or lost at the 
Gathering. It happened to me a long time ago, June 1993, Lower Haight, 
Your Sister's House..(open party, street people).  

SUGGESTION:  PAINT YOUR BELONGINGS

The following will not prevent theft, but perhaps it can deter it a bit.
And also this suggestion can add to a party's ambience.   Use black light 
paint to turn your backpack into a work of art.  So when you  set it down, 
or place it on a speaker, you will be ble to see it or keep an eye on it.
Also makes it a more obvious target...and one less likely to be chosen.
Same goes for jackets, purses, bean bags (mine has florescent green hands 
airbrushed all over it) etc.  

Oh, one other thing to do is hook up with a smilin' posse and ask 
them to keep an eye on your bag and you'll help out as well throughout 
the night or day...  --Maureen

Epherine (Ma Huang) were first used (abused) in diet products, massive 
doses sold in new age weight loss products....  my symptons ranged from 
intense nervousness to being completely spaced out, and often times 
mynegative emotions intensified as well.  Many remedies are meant to be 
taken in small doses.  This is a big IMHO, but I believe that lots of 
folks are taking advantage of the buzz some of our mother's plants 
produce without testing them properly and the result could very well be the 
illegalization of more natural herbs and plants.  Best to avoid Guinea 
Pig products....  --Maureen

On Wed,
 10 Apr 1996, Geoff White wrote:

> >
> >FDA Warns Against 'Natural' Euphoric Drugs
> >
> >WASHINGTON (Reuter) - U.S.  health officials warned Wednesday against
> >using diet supplements containing ephedrine sold as alternatives to
> >street drugs such as ``Ecstasy'', saying they posed serious health
> >risks.
> 
> 
> While T think it is silly and futile for the FDA to attempt to
> "ban" these  suppliments, it is my personal belief that Ma Huang
> is far more dangerous then MDMA itself, especially if you are prone
> to hypertension, eurythmia, or other cardiac problems.
> 
>

Well, the Celestine Prophecy theme at the Progress party that I went to
last summer was all it took for me to buy and read the Celestine Prophecy.
This was one of the things that kick-started my quest for spirituality.
With that in mind, I'd say that was enough of a Celestine Prophecy theme
for me, especially at a time where I was in no mood to be 'preched to'
about spirituality, but rather could be turned onto spiritual themes
one-clue-at-a-time, which is kinda how all this worked out in my case. If
it had been too much, I would have quickly rejected it all instead of
giving spirituality in general and the Celestine Prophecy specifically a
chance.


I also remember the voicemail message was REALLY REALLY long and it went on
and on about spirituality issues, the Celestine Prophecy and how her
parties fit in.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Apr 11 01:24:26 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id BAA27194; Thu, 11 Apr 1996 01:24:26 -0700
Received: from mh1.well.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id BAA27188; Thu, 11 Apr 1996 01:24:24 -0700
Received: from [206.15.64.109] (sf-tty10-ppp.well.com [206.15.64.109]) by mh1.well.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) with SMTP id BAA25839 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Thu, 11 Apr 1996 01:23:54 -0700
X-Sender: leftjab@mail.well.com
Message-Id: <v01510106ad927314ac28@[206.15.64.111]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Thu, 11 Apr 1996 01:27:54 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: leftjab@well.com (leftjab)
Subject: from chocolate to morphine
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Reagan Reid rightly pointed out that Andrew Weil & Winifred Rosen's 1993
version of "From Chocolate to Morphine" only has a page on MDMA, but it has
some good common sense advice about psychedelics in general (set & setting;
problems because of risk of fake drugs; "Psychedelics do not necessarily
produce any particular mood or state of mind.  They act as intensifiers of
experience.").  It mentions raves in part of what it said about
Methylenedioxymethamphetamine (yes, folks, ecstasy is an amphetamine
variation):

        Taken by mouth in reasonable doses (125 milligrams) and in good
settings, MDMA rarely causes bad trips.  It has gained a strong reputation
as an enhancer of empathy between people and an aid to psychotherapy and
counseling.  In other circles it has gained an equally strong reputation as
a party drug, being used especially in dance clubs that feature "acid
house" and wild dancing.  The acid house phenomenon has been growing in
Europe (particularly in the Netherlands and the U.K.) and in some American
cities.  A newer version, called "rave," features synthesized music and
light shows.  MDMA has also been very popular in the gay community and in
gay bars.
        For a number of years after its introduction MDMA was an
uncontrolled substance.  It became illegal when government scientists
suggested that it caused permanent damage to certain nerve cells in the
brain.  Research has failed to support this idea, but the drug remains
illegal, and strange stories circulate about it.  One is that it causes the
spinal cord to liquefy.
        There is no truth to those stories, but both MDA and MDMA can cause
bad reactions at high doses.  Some people snort them or (rarely) inject
them intravenously, intensifying their action and potential for harm.
Combining these drugs with alcohol or other depressants also increases the
possibility of adverse effects.  As sexual drugs, both compounds may
enhance the pleasure of touching, but they interfere with erection in men
and with orgasm in both men and women.  A few cases of dependence on MDMA
have been reported; they resemble cases of amphetamine dependence.
        MDMA remains one of the most popular illegal drugs in Europe and
America, and some physicians and psychotherapists are still trying to
convince the government that it should be made available for both research
and treatment.  The most common complaint about it from longtime users is
that sensitivity to day after fatigue seems to increase as people get
older.  Some enthusiasts have sworn off the drug entirely because they feel
so run down after using it and find themselves more susceptible to colds,
herpes outbreaks, and other infections.

The 12 Suggestions and Precautions for the Use of Hallucinogenic Drugs ("1.
Know your sources.  Many fake and adulterated versions of psychedelics are
sold on the street.") are also relevant, and I'll post them if people are
interested.

leftjab

>Well ... if you're going to choose a substance to ingest which will kill
>brain cells at ALL, why not choose to be happy and bouncy and full of joy
>and laughter instead of slurring and vomiting and getting pissed off
>easily and hating your fellow hunans and waking up feeling like someone's
>stuffed a red hot bag of nails into your head?

If alcohol makes you feel like that, then you're consuming too much of it.

Not to be anti MDMA or anything, it just surprises me how people tend to
become anti everything else when they find something new that they like.

Acid can make you slur and act more stupid than the typical drinker.

MDMA has caused some of the worse hangovers ever, much worse than red hot
nails in the head. And other times, you feel great the next day.

I think it's great that there is a variety of drugs (and I include alcohol,
caffeine and nicotine) that affect us. It's not as boring that way.

r

__________________________

my point was that if you consume enough alcohol to "equal" an e high, 
that's what you're going to get ... lets face it $40 worth of booze would 
set a lot of people flat on their asses pretty quick :)

and in the over 20 times i've taken e, i have never ONCE had an e 
hangover.  The only person I know in my circle of friends who tke e 
regularly who had a hangover also spent eight hours dancing without once 
stopping and barely drank any water during that time .... and i have a 
feeling she'd have felt just as awful the next day if she'd have been sober!

But i'm not against alcohol completely, i'm against the ABUSE of alcohol, 
which sadly is a common problem ... same as any other substance.  I just
prefer to take e and save my liver the trouble at least :)

k

Date: Thu, 11 Apr 1996 11:55:56 -0600
From: Andy Hawks <andy@cmac20.colorado.edu>
Reply-To: andy@cmac20.colorado.edu
Organization: CAUSE
X-Mailer: Mozilla 3.0b2 (Macintosh; I; PPC)
MIME-Version: 1.0
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Net-raver spirit
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I'm writing an article for Colorado's local scene zine about net-rave 
communities.

Since SF-Raves is the quintessential net-rave community, I'd like to get 
some feedback, if possible, and just how much sf-raves or another net-
rave community means to you.  

We have all met tons of people, some of us have even met life-partners 
over the various net-rave communities, we've all experienced a lot with 
net-ravers...but beyond that, more into the community itself, how has sf-
raves or another net-rave community impacted your life?  More than 
anything i'm looking for a few quotable phrases and sentences at this 
point.

I'd really appreciate your feelings on what these communities mean to 
you.

thanx, and have "a groovy, groovy day and a lovely evening"

plur

Received: from [17.127.18.103] ([17.127.18.103]) by ns.mauswerks.com (8.7.5/8.6.9) with SMTP id LAA03636; Thu, 11 Apr 1996 11:53:27 -0700

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hey there- (2 posts from me in 1 day- egad!)

If you don't think your stuff will get stolen from you at a rave, that is 
pretty naive. I went on an outdoor rave/camping trip in Pennsylvania 
where someone stole my wet, smelly clothing (4 shirts and a jacket). I've 
also had my wallet stolen. You always need to keep your wallet in a 
secure location on your person, thus the need for those chain/wallets 
that you see. My friend had a leather jacket stolen at a Wicked. My new 
tactic for jackets is to buy $5 vinyl jackets at thrift stores. Nobody 
wants these things, if anyone did take it I wouldn't care. If I put my 
backpack down, I take my keys and my wallet out first. Also it might be a 
good idea just to take your driver's license and whatever cash you need, 
and leave the rest of your wallet at home. 

I used to think I could trust *everyone* at raves, but my experiences 
have proved otherwise. It's a good idea to be careful. 

Love-
Amy




>On top of that I lost my backpack with *both* my jackets. It's like 
>losing your best friend. And it's not like I'm one of those people who 
>just carelesslly drops it on some random place on the floor. I put it on 
>top of the speakers, so that it can be seen from most corners of the 
>room. First time this has ever happen to me. Sun had his backpack gone 
>through and his jacket & cash taken. Spent 60 mins. afterwards looking 
>through the homebase with no luck & according to security at the lost & 
>found some 8 different people also came up with missing possision stories.
>Thank you Oakland.

Subject: Re: Alcohol vs. E (fwd)
Date: Thu, 11 Apr 96 12:23:51 -0700
From: Amy Felix <msphink@ns.mauswerks.com>
To: "Karen Hardie" <eidrah@vanbc.wimsey.com>, <sfraves@hyperreal.com>

Precedence: bulk

Hi-
Just like everything else, moderation is the key.

If you have ever seen a person who has consumed too much E, they don't 
act much more intelligently than a drunken person. In fact, they may be 
vomiting as well as lying around on a floor all night, talking nonsense. 
At least they don't act as obnoxious as drunk people... (unless you 
consider someone blathering about how much they love you to be annoying). 
Then there is also that depression which can sometimes accompany E, and 
makes it less than a bowl of friggin' cherries. 

I think one or two beers is great for chillin' out at Sunset or 
something... but I have cut down greatly on my alcohol consumption 
because it makes me so dehydrated. 

How about endorphins, the natural high? I have a theory that since E 
causes changes in your brain's neurotransmitters, it is quite possible 
for you to do this yourself in some mind/body connection. Witness the 
phenomena of the 'contact high' you get from being in a room full of 
people on E. It is within your power to realize this kind of love and 
happiness... just make it happen! I know endorphins are really powerful 
things, I have been hiking in the woods and literally stopped to hug a 
tree (sorry for this bit of sappy stuff). 

Love ya-
-Amy



>> Was just wondering, does anybody have any facts regarding the number of 
>> brain cells killed from e versus the number killed by alcohol?  
>> Assuming equivalent doses of course (do you suppose two hits of e would 
>> be the equivalent of getting fairly drunk?).  I had heard somewhere 
>> that out of such items as alcohol, cocaine, pot, & a coupla others, 
>> that alcohol killed more brain cells than any of these others.  Don't 
>> know how factual that is, but got me curious nonetheless....
>
>Well ... if you're going to choose a substance to ingest which will kill 
>brain cells at ALL, why not choose to be happy and bouncy and full of joy 
>and laughter instead of slurring and vomiting and getting pissed off 
>easily and hating your fellow hunans and waking up feeling like someone's 
>stuffed a red hot bag of nails into your head?  The choice is clear to me ...

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Ethan Miller <ethan@bass-station.com>
Subject: MAD
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Greetings Friends!

As many of you may know, MAD was shut down early last week. For numerous
reasons, some of them old, some of them new, this represents the end of the
line for MAD at the Bahia.

While we have certainly enjoyed ourselves there, the management has been
extremely difficult to work with at times, in addition to which, there is a
60 room hotel directly across the street, most of whose inahabitants are
poeple coping with terminal diseases, who are well sick of us cracking
their plaster every monday, resulting in numerous call to the authorities,
permit hassles, etc.

None of which we begrudge them - we sincerely hope that our absence brings
them peace (and quiet!) and accelerates their healing. As noted above
however, it's definitely time to move on.

The good news is, we have a wonderful place to move to: "V" which is a new
club at the corner of 11th and Folsom (formerly the Oasis).

The space has been radically renovated and is, quite honestly, gorgeous
inside. The pool has been replaced by a beautiful blue wood dancefloor -
the real kind. There is an amazing lighting system, and an *awesome*, and
I do mean awesome, EAW Surround Sound System. Truly sick =)

There is also a second room which we will be doing ambient stuff in, as
well as an outdoor rooftop with lots of comfortable seating, plants, trees,
etc. which will be great as summer rolls around.

Another real plus are the people that run place who, beyond being friendly
and very easy going, are also *conscious*; socially and politically active
and aware poeple.

The bad news is MAD will now have to be 21+.

I think those of you that know myself, joe, alex, and jon, as well as the
numerous other people who have helped MAD be what is, know that, as
individuals and as a group, we go well out of our way to avoid drawing
arbitrary and unsavory lines like this; it *is not* what we would have done
if we had a choice. Unfortunately it came down to stopping MAD altogether
or doing what we have decided to do. We offer our most heartfelt and
sincere apologies to those of you that this change in venue will exclude.

Please know that as individuals, and as a group we remain committed to
throwing underground, all ages *Everyone Is Welcome* parties including
MADNESS one offs, Friends & Family, and Justice League events to name just
a few.

We'll be taking next week (April 15th) off and return on April 22, at our
new location, with Alex, Ethan, and the Red Man himself Dave Clarke.

Pricing remains the same: $2 before 11, $3 after (though for Dave Clarke,
as with other "big name" guests) it will be $3 all night. Up-to-date info
is always available at:

  http://www.bass-station.com/fnf/events.html#MAD

  As well on our voicemail line: 415 281-9432


                                    ***


It is our sincerest desire and our firmest intention that MAD continue to
be a thriving, weekly home for the amazing and diverse collection of energy
and talent that comprises this wonderful community of ours. None of us are
doing this for fame, glory, ego, or The Money (that's a good one!) We all
have full-time day jobs that we go to exhausted every tuesday. We need your
energy, we need your enthusiasm, and we need your support to keep making
this work.

So we invite you to join us in taking MAD into its next iteration; so
please, come down on mondays and join us in dancing together, in laughing
together, in celebrating, together.

Your input is *always welcome*. You can reach us online at:

ethan@bass-station.com      (ethan)
ambient@netcom.com          (joe)
jon@netnoir.com             (jon)

Alex doesn't have email (yet!) but feel free to bug him at the club =)


warmest regards

ethan, alex, joe and jon

MAD



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Apr 11 14:11:59 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id OAA15465; Thu, 11 Apr 1996 14:11:59 -0700
Received: from worm.hooked.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id OAA15449; Thu, 11 Apr 1996 14:11:53 -0700
Received: (from moonpup@localhost) by worm.hooked.net (8.6.12/8.6.12) id OAA02436; Thu, 11 Apr 1996 14:11:55 -0700
Date: Thu, 11 Apr 1996 14:11:55 -0700
From: Milton Cecil <moonpup@mailhost.hooked.net>
Message-Id: <199604112111.OAA02436@worm.hooked.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: minimize risks !!!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

The way I look at losing things at a rave or club, is that you have to 
carry with you your possesions, thus when you see me at a place, I will 
have my backpack on.......  
  
it's been proven all too often, that if you leave a jacket, or a backpack, 
or whatever, chances are eventually something will happen, it may take 
months, even years if your lucky.....but sooner or later the odds will get 
ya.....  
  
.......now I do from time to time have major trust in my fellow humanity, 
and leave something somewhere, (as I'm a DJ, I usually will stash it by the

Dj booth somewhere)  
and overall my luck or intuition has been good.......  
  
.........intuition plays a major roll in my even staying at an event, let 
alone tempting fate by leaving my shit unprotected somewhere.......I 
recently left a small underground party because I was vibed out by some of 
the people.........I didn't feel comfortable somehow, and I left shortly 
after arriving, only to hear days later that a nasty fight broke out and 
the police showed up and busted the party...........  
  
so you have to look at what you yourself can do to protect yourself and 
your property.  
Fortunately, it's been a long time since I've had more than a few tapes 
stolen out of my backpack when leaving it somewhere.  
  
unfortunately, when you wear a backpack in the busy club, you are taking up

valuable space, and you bump everybody over trying to get through the 
crowd.......  
  
heres a typical list of what a prepared raver needs:  (typical moonpup 
backpack)  
  
1.)    wallet/money..........  
2.)    keys   
3.)    pipe/lighter/backup lighter/kgb/small container/     /etc....(fill 
in the blanks)  
4.)    lazer pointer  
5.)    flashlite  
6.)    cassettes.......(DJ's only)  gotta have your latest tape to give out

to   
                                                            people with the

vibe                                      
7.)    jacket  
8.)    ski cap/gloves..........(outdoor events)  
9.)    pen  
10.)  dat machine (optional....if DJ-ing) + connectors/blank dats etc....  
11.)  room for flyers  
12.)  camera......(special events)  
13.)  water  
14.)  fruit/food....... (optional)  
15.)  toys.........things to amuse  
  
well you could add blankets, beanbags, etc........depends how serious a 
raver you want to be..........  
                                    .................moonpup        
......ramblings of a lunatik

(Sorry, accidentally erased who wrote these two things:

>
>>> Was just wondering, does anybody have any facts regarding the number of 
>>> brain cells killed from e versus the number killed by alcohol?  
>>> Assuming equivalent doses of course (do you suppose two hits of e would 
>>> be the equivalent of getting fairly drunk?).  I had heard somewhere 
>>> that out of such items as alcohol, cocaine, pot, & a coupla others, 
>>> that alcohol killed more brain cells than any of these others.  Don't 
>>> know how factual that is, but got me curious nonetheless....
>>
>>Well ... if you're going to choose a substance to ingest which will kill 
>>brain cells at ALL, why not choose to be happy and bouncy and full of joy 
>>and laughter instead of slurring and vomiting and getting pissed off 
>>easily and hating your fellow hunans and waking up feeling like someone's 
>>stuffed a red hot bag of nails into your head?  The choice is clear to me ...
>
>
The key is moderation and knowledge of what a substance does to you!
Not everyone who has a beer or 2 gets all pukey and pissed off. It's true,
alcohol kills quite a few (like about 100,000) neurons per drink or so (no
one knows exactly how many) but we lose about 100,000-200,000 neurons per
day already, just cause thats how nature works and neurons dont reproduce.
So, yes, alcohol would enhance the mass death, but that is all up to the
person who chooses to drink.  Theres nuthin like having a nice cold brewski
in my backyard during the middle of summer.

But, let me tell ya, I have felt like someone not only stuffed a red hot bag
of nails, but nailed each one of them into my skull with a meat cleaver
after some hits of E. And I know lots of people who are happy and bouncy and
full of joy after a couple of beers. It all depends on what you choose as
yer poison... 

Lemme just say, I am only a light drinker (a nice J. Lohr estates 1993
cabernet is my fave) and a light E kinda guy (like once every 6 months or
so). But when I take either, I enjoy it. 

Courtney

Just had to add one more thing re: alcohol: 
I think it depends a lot on the quality of the alcohol. We all remember
puking back in High school because all we could afford was crap like
Budweiser or Blatz or Lucky or if we wanted to splurge we would get Miller
Genuine Draft! (yuk)And for some people, I believe that that's why they hate
alchohol so much. There is a difference between Budweiser and Pete's wicked
Red, and there is a difference between St Supery 1993 Merlot and Grape
flavored Cisco.
 Other people are true alcoholics, and they should stay away from it, no
exceptions. (my friend's father has Korsakoffs syndrome from too much
alcohol- which is a result of malnutrition from drinking too much and the
liver not being able to work properly, therefore the brain does not get it's
fuel and starts dying in the form of lost memories which are replaced by
memories that are made up by the individual's brain and cause a big mess).
        Other people are well educated about what they are doing, and have
no problem with it.
Just my opinion 
Courtney

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Hi everyone!

I've been lurking on SFRaves for a couple of weeks now and
thought I'd keep that delurking trend going!

I'm pretty new to the whole rave thing, my first rave was the Gathering
back in December, so it's really cool to hear what you all think
and feel about the scene.  Although some of my friends went to raves
back when I was going to school in SoCal, I was too caught up in the
hell that was my life back then to go along... ah, if only I had
known ;)

I remember one time when I was sitting in the lounge of our dorm when
everyone was coming back from some rave in LA.  One guy, who usually
had a big chip on his shoulder, snuck up behind me and gave me
a big bear hug.  I am ashamed to say that I was so surprised that this
huge guy who usually seemed to have something against me, was hugging me
that I didn't hug back.  I guess that he figured that he had crossed some
line and said "What are you looking at?" and then left.  I stood there
for a sec, having no idea what had just happened.  Of course, now it
all makes sense.  :)  But a missed opportunity :(  I guess that's a
strange thing to all of a sudden pop into your head three years after
the fact, but I guess that's why they say that writing is an act of
exploration, right?

Anyways, finally this december I decided to check out a rave.  I admit that
I was pretty skeptical.  I mean, hey, it's just a party; music, dancing,
lights, yadda yadda, right?  But by about 30 minutes later, I realized that
raves aren't about black lights, or laser shows, or drugs, or even
necessarily (Blashphemy ahead !) about the music, it's about the PEOPLE.
The VIBE.

And, regarding the big-party vs. small-party vibe question, I've since
tried a smaller party and found it more to my liking, but an important
thing to remember is that hey, maybe the vibe at big parties isn't as
consistent as at the smaller ones, but compared to the rest of the world
it's still AMAZING!  I remember just walking around astounded at the
contact high I was getting off of people!

Anyways, i've blathered on long enough, but I plan to be at Harmony
tomorrow, if anyone would take the time to introduce this newbie
around I'd greatly appreciate it!  I don't know what I'll be wearing
but if you see a chinese guy, about 5'6-5'7, crewcut and maybe wearing
a banana-in-pajamas, please say hi!

                        Peace,

                                Chin

P.S. Oh yeah, I live in Sunnyvale but spend most of my free time in
Santa Cruz, if anyone wants to get together or car pool to a rave or
something, drop me some e-mail!
