To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: little drummer people
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Forgive me if this topic has already been hashed out on sfraves, but I feel
the
need to address this almost uniquely San Franciscan phenomenon.

How do people feel about those folks who cheerfully lug their drum collections
along to just about every mid-to-large sized party, plunking themselves down
either in the middle of the dancefloor or near the dj in order to bang out
their own accompanying tribal rhythms for the duration of the evening?

As you may have guessed, I've already made up my mind on this issue and
generally find their presence annoying for the following reasons:

1.  I don't like to hear every track, from acid to new york house to trance,
turned into a "tribal remix".

2.  Something that I doubt any of these drummers realize is that no matter how
skilled and precise their drumming may be, if you go about 15 - 20 feet away
from them, the drumming sounds *completely* off rhythm from whatever the dj is
playing, due to such factors as the echos created by high ceilings and
concrete, the fact that there are 2 - 4 groups of speakers versus one drum
(which is often off to side, outside the "cone of sound" described by the
speakers).

3.  I understand that not every dj may feel this way, but I tend to think of a
dj's set as *his* or *her* own personal performance.  Some djs are true
masters
of control, able to hypnotize a crowd and then work it into a frenzy.  When
there are other performers besides the dj, he loses that control, and unless
they are working in synergy, the result is weak.  For the same reasons, I even
think that it's a little rude for someone  to assume that everyone is as
excited about  bongo drums as they are.  I mean, drums are loud; you can
usually hear them throughout an entire party.  Would people feel the same if
someone brought their bass guitar and amp, plugged in, and started jamming
along, or if an aspiring vocalist brought along a microphone and amp and starte
d their own vocal accompaniment?

I know there are probably some djs who would welcome it.  Derrick May, when he
played at that party (I forget the name), brought along his own drummer.  So
if
these freelance drummers are so eager to perform, why not approach djs or
promoters and be a real part of everything, get hooked into a mic that goes
through the dj's mixer so that everyone can hear their precision and skill,
and
then after a two hour set, put down the drum and go dance or something.

I'm curious to hear other people's points of view on this, especially djs.

By the way, I honestly don't have any real hostility towards drummers or
anything, just spouting off.

inhuman@ghetto.love

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: epaul@Synopsys.COM (Eric P. Peterson)
Subject: Re: little drummer people
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

If someone wants to accompany a dj, my opinion is that the performer should
work it out with the dj and promoter in advance.  I play bass guitar, and
was asked to accompany a dj to an upcoming party.  Sounded like fun to me.
Since I knew one of the people who put on this event, I asked him what he
thought, and he rejected the idea.  So, I cast aside all the musical
inspirations I had and decided that I would be an attendee at this party,
not a participant.  I have no idea why I was denied, but I'm not gonna
argue.  If other people anticipate performing at a party, and are asked not
to, I hope they won't be offended, but will take the opportunity to enjoy
the party.
Maybe some future events could be set up that feature live instrument
performance as a set, part of a set, or a whole party.  Does this happen?
Should it?

Peace and Harmony,

- E

are 50 miles apart....   Arghhhh!!

Perhaps Sven Vath might be spinning at some other gig while he's out
here,   I don't know,  but I did look at the calander and didn't see
him on any other lineups.

Crunchman

Harmony and out-a-sight on Friday usually do good parties, and Sven Vath
swings by 1015 Folsom that night too.  Saturday has some larger events;
Kundalini has gotten mixed reviews, and I don't know much about Iner Sircle
except that they have a funny way of spelling things.  Tonight's 
Negativland show might be a good place to start the weekend...

New in the weeklies: the Beat at Big Heart City and the Light'n'up Lounge
at 111 Minna.


                                THE SFR CALENDAR
                                       
    http://www.hyperreal.com/raves/sf/calendar/gencal.cgi

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Sunday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. KZSU
       90.1 (Stanford)
     * Thursdays 9:30pm-midnight - "Aurora Borealis" Beats and
       atmospherics w/DJ Seth. KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Ambient, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, Acid Jazz
       and noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night midnight - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 47 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@netcom.com
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday morning - "The Uncle Noah TV Show" 6-9am, KDVS 90.3,
       Davis.
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday night - "Saturday Night Spin Out" w/Ronnie Libido. Trip
       hop, Jungle, Ambient, Experimental Sounds. 10pm-2am. KFJC 89.7 -
       Los Altos Hills

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

i thought you presented this very well...altho, i've never seen this
happen at a big party but a friend of mine had a small gathering in which
he invited a bunch of drummer people to have a drumming session before we
started spinning and they just kept drumming!  i think drumming is really
cool and even like to do it myself but it made dancing confusing for my
body with the echo factor.  my poor bud was spinning with this kind of
erked look on his face and he's such a sweetie he just grinned and bore
it!

so, i think it's something to think about...

peace out,

bren




On 11 Apr 1996, Michael wrote:

>
> Forgive me if this topic has already been hashed out on sfraves, but I feel
> the
> need to address this almost uniquely San Franciscan phenomenon.
>
> How do people feel about those folks who cheerfully lug their drum collections
> along to just about every mid-to-large sized party, plunking themselves down
> either in the middle of the dancefloor or near the dj in order to bang out
> their own accompanying tribal rhythms for the duration of the evening?
>
> As you may have guessed, I've already made up my mind on this issue and
> generally find their presence annoying for the following reasons:
>
> 1.  I don't like to hear every track, from acid to new york house to trance,
> turned into a "tribal remix".
>
> 2.  Something that I doubt any of these drummers realize is that no matter how
> skilled and precise their drumming may be, if you go about 15 - 20 feet away
> from them, the drumming sounds *completely* off rhythm from whatever the dj is
> playing, due to such factors as the echos created by high ceilings and
> concrete, the fact that there are 2 - 4 groups of speakers versus one drum
> (which is often off to side, outside the "cone of sound" described by the
> speakers).
>
> 3.  I understand that not every dj may feel this way, but I tend to think of a
> dj's set as *his* or *her* own personal performance.  Some djs are true
> masters
> of control, able to hypnotize a crowd and then work it into a frenzy.  When
> there are other performers besides the dj, he loses that control, and unless
> they are working in synergy, the result is weak.  For the same reasons, I even
> think that it's a little rude for someone  to assume that everyone is as
> excited about  bongo drums as they are.  I mean, drums are loud; you can
> usually hear them throughout an entire party.  Would people feel the same if
> someone brought their bass guitar and amp, plugged in, and started jamming
> along, or if an aspiring vocalist brought along a microphone and amp and starte
> d their own vocal accompaniment?
>
> I know there are probably some djs who would welcome it.  Derrick May, when he
> played at that party (I forget the name), brought along his own drummer.  So
> if
> these freelance drummers are so eager to perform, why not approach djs or
> promoters and be a real part of everything, get hooked into a mic that goes
> through the dj's mixer so that everyone can hear their precision and skill,
> and
> then after a two hour set, put down the drum and go dance or something.
>
> I'm curious to hear other people's points of view on this, especially djs.
>
> By the way, I honestly don't have any real hostility towards drummers or
> anything, just spouting off.
>
> inhuman@ghetto.love
>

		        http://www.teleport.com/~shakti

moonpup's list was great!  and the sunglasses are important too..

here's my list...

money
 i.d.
pipe and fixin's
 sunglasses
 candy (lollipops, lifesavers, gum) to share with everyone (come and ask!)
flashlight
cigarettes (again, plenty to share, and yes I know it's a nasty habit)
toys (I've got cool kalaidescopes for this weekend to the first 3 wonderful
people!)
bandaids and ibuprofen
...and most important (esp if you're going anywhere near the Wicked sound
system!)  .... earplugs!  be nice to your ears!

And I stow them all in a clear plastic backpack with outside pockets, the
doormen/security people love it, but it's falling apart!   waaah!

Bye!   Leslie  : )

To: Michael <Michael.Minnich@bankamerica.com>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: little drummer people
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

   Just so you know, some clubs and a couple of particular dj's have rules 
   about what types of drums are allowed to come into a club.  And 
   sometimes the motivation to bring a drum is that you can get into a gig 
   for free 'cause you're helping out with the vibe (it helps if you're a 
   scenester and a good drummer)...but then again, it all depends on how 
   you look at it.
   
   I know sometimes drumming can be a drag if the drummer is off but 
   sometimes it's fun to find the syncopating rhythms dragging or rushing 
   the beat--playing with movement/dance off of that and the music.
   
   Bottom line is if you don't like drumming, 1)  don't dance near them; 
   and 2)  try to find gigs that don't allow drummers...but then again, can 
   we ask this of a fellow raver since we don't restrict ravers with 
   annoying whistles, shakers, vocals, etc.?
   
   There's a few clubs that don't have drumming and on the flip side, 
   sometimes there's raves or parties w/opening percussion circles.  To me 
   it's all out there, and it's all good...probably 'cause my basic rhythm 
   pulsates through my veins and that's what initiates my movements.
   
   Diane
   
   


______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
Subject: little drummer people
Author:  	Michael <Michael.Minnich@bankamerica.com> at beluga-mail
Date:    4/11/96 3:34 PM


   
Forgive me if this topic has already been hashed out on sfraves, but I feel 
the
need to address this almost uniquely San Franciscan phenomenon.
   
How do people feel about those folks who cheerfully lug their drum collections 
along to just about every mid-to-large sized party, plunking themselves down 
either in the middle of the dancefloor or near the dj in order to bang out 
their own accompanying tribal rhythms for the duration of the evening?
   
As you may have guessed, I've already made up my mind on this issue and 
generally find their presence annoying for the following reasons:
   
1.  I don't like to hear every track, from acid to new york house to trance, 
turned into a "tribal remix".
   
2.  Something that I doubt any of these drummers realize is that no matter how 
skilled and precise their drumming may be, if you go about 15 - 20 feet away 
from them, the drumming sounds *completely* off rhythm from whatever the dj is 
playing, due to such factors as the echos created by high ceilings and 
concrete, the fact that there are 2 - 4 groups of speakers versus one drum 
(which is often off to side, outside the "cone of sound" described by the 
speakers).
   
3.  I understand that not every dj may feel this way, but I tend to think of a 
dj's set as *his* or *her* own personal performance.  Some djs are true 
masters
of control, able to hypnotize a crowd and then work it into a frenzy.  When 
there are other performers besides the dj, he loses that control, and unless 
they are working in synergy, the result is weak.  For the same reasons, I even 
think that it's a little rude for someone  to assume that everyone is as 
excited about  bongo drums as they are.  I mean, drums are loud; you can 
usually hear them throughout an entire party.  Would people feel the same if 
someone brought their bass guitar and amp, plugged in, and started jamming 
along, or if an aspiring vocalist brought along a microphone and amp and starte 
d their own vocal accompaniment?
   
I know there are probably some djs who would welcome it.  Derrick May, when he 
played at that party (I forget the name), brought along his own drummer.  So 
if
these freelance drummers are so eager to perform, why not approach djs or 
promoters and be a real part of everything, get hooked into a mic that goes 
through the dj's mixer so that everyone can hear their precision and skill, 
and
then after a two hour set, put down the drum and go dance or something.
   
I'm curious to hear other people's points of view on this, especially djs.
   
By the way, I honestly don't have any real hostility towards drummers or 
anything, just spouting off.
   
inhuman@ghetto.love

Hi!
 I tend to not like drums in a small space unless it is worked out in 
advance and respect is paid to the DJ. Generally I really love drums at 
outdoor parties and if it is worked out drum circles can be a lotta fun! 
Once again the key is cooperation and communcation with a healthy dose of 
respect; not just taking advantage of a captive audience to drum to. 
However the spontaneous is sometimes special at times.
 Is it just me or is there an anti-drum vibe in the air? What with 
this thread and the Santa Cruz city council shooting down public drumming...

 >>Hello trainspotters...
>juliet.. i've seen "trainspotters" used before, but haven't a clue as to
>what it means. could you please fill me in? :)
>
As far as I know, the original trainspotter is someone who's hobby is watching
out for every train and marking it in a little book or schedule. They also
know every little detail about the different trains and lines. The term
comes from England and they are usually males and perceived as slightly
geeky and antisocial.  It is also used as a term for people who are so into
music and records that they know every detail of every record, label,
artist, etc.that exists. I think XLR8R mag had a good description a couple
of issues ago. It's also the title of a great book and new movie.  I was
hoping someone who knew a lot about records could help me look for the one I
can't find anywhere.

Hope that helps  :)

juliet

>
>

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: leftjab@well.com (leftjab)
Subject: Suggestions/Precautions for use of hallucinogens
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

By request & FYI, the following is a list of "Suggestions and Precautions
for the Use of Hallucinogenic Drugs" in "From Chocolate to Morphine."  The
chapter on psychedelics discusses both "indole" hallucinogens (containing
the "indole ring" on a molecular level; related to pineal gland-made
hormones) such as LSD & shrooms, and amphetamine/andrenaline-like
hallucinogens including peyote, MDA & MDMA:

1. Know your sources.  Many fake and adulterated versions of psychedelics
are sold on the street.

2.  Do not attempt to pick wild psilocybin mushrooms without knowing what
you are doing.

3.  Cultivated psilocybin mushrooms vary greatly in potency.  Get advice
about dose before eating any.

4.  Do not take psychedelics unless you are in good physical and
psychological shape.

5.  If you are trying one of the hallucinogenic drugs for the first time,
take it with an experienced companion.

6.  Take psychedelics only in comfortable settings on occasions when you
have no responsibilities for at least the next twelve hours.

7.  Remember that you may feel tired and drained of energy the following day.

8.  Do not psychedelics on a full stomach; you are less likely to feel
nausea or other discomfort if your stomach is relatively empty.

9.  Do not combine psychedelics with other drugs.  However, the interesting
effects of psychedelics sometimes wear off while their stimulation
continues.  If you feel agitated, restless, and unable to sleep at the end
of an experience with one of these drugs, it may be appropriate to take a
hypnotic dose of a sleeping pill or minor tranquilizer.

10.  Remember that hallucinogenic drugs can affect perception and thinking.
Do not drive, operate machinery, or engage in hazardous activities while
under their influence.

11.  Take psychedelics by mouth.  They are more likely to cause bad
reactions by other routes of administration.

12.  The best experiences with these drugs result from saving them for
special occasions and the right circumstances.  Taking psychedelics just
because they are available is less likely to produce valuable results.
Taking them to get out of bad moods may intensify those moods.  Taking them
frequently and carelessly reduces their potential to show you interesting
aspects of yourself and the world around you.
END LIST!


and drink your water and take your vitamins . . . : )  and think for yourself!

the book also includes this quote from Peter Furst's "Flesh of the Gods":

>You get out of the drug experience only what you put into it.  The
>"Otherworld" from which you seek illumination is, after all, only your own
>psyche.


happy & safe raving & living,

leftjab

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Apr 11 21:52:25 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id VAA25435; Thu, 11 Apr 1996 21:52:25 -0700
Received: from uclink4.berkeley.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id VAA25425; Thu, 11 Apr 1996 21:52:23 -0700
Received: from [128.32.160.187] (wmf63.Berkeley.EDU [128.32.160.187]) by uclink4.berkeley.edu (8.7.4/8.6.12) with SMTP id VAA30215 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Thu, 11 Apr 1996 21:52:26 -0700 (PDT)
X-Sender: nancys@uclink4.berkeley.edu (Unverified)
Message-Id: <v02130500ad93731df417@[128.32.160.64]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Thu, 11 Apr 1996 21:51:04 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: nancys@uclink4.berkeley.edu (Nancy)
Subject: (Long/NRR) Beasties/Bondage
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Thought a tale of my adventures in the City last night might be somewhat
relevant; each caused me to reflect on some aspects of our scene...

Beastie Boys at Bottom-of-the-Hill!  Now _this_ was a _super_underground
party!  I was told about it and given five minutes to jump in the car.  I
looked at my books spread in front of me, and jumped!  We get to the club
close to 10PM and encounter a bad scene.  The club is packed inside
(apparently), there are a hundred desperate people crowding outside, and
the cops in their infinite wisdom have decided this is a dangerous
potential riot.

We manage to elude the piggys (for the moment), wiggle our way to the front
of the line (with the help of my super-flirtatious friend), and meet the
doorman.  The doorman, for his part, thought the crowd situation was a
great opportunity to be the biggest asshole imaginable.  He favored the
crowd with sentiments like, "get the fuck away from _my_ door!  Why are you
touching _my_ door?" and "You all are pretty fucking stupid to think you're
getting in here!" and "Give me a blowjob, maybe then you'll get in!"  Ahem.
I couldn't help but reflect on the vibe being created around this club by
the attitude of their workers.  The ones who got inside were lucky, the
rest of us were fucked, get out of our face and go home.   No compassion or
friendliness, but then, what did I expect, a rave? ;)  My friend (who
raves) offered him a big plastic blinky ring as a present to "make him feel
better."  He announced, "you can't bribe me!"  She said it wasn't a bribe,
just a present to brighten his day.  He sneered, "Impossible!"  In his
world, no-one just gives anyone a little present out of love.  At raves,
this is common.  (big happy face).

Then the riot brigade of thirty cops arrived to clear the people out from
the front of the club.  Now, this was disturbing.  I'm from L.A. and have
observed many disgusting police brutality incidents.  In fact, the only
time I was ever hit by a man it was a fucking cop (at a demonstration for
women's rights! symbolic, eh?).  I thought San Francisco police would be a
lot more laid back, but I guess it's true about power corrupting... These
cops were unnecessarily aggressive, rude, mean and totally infuriating.  My
friend got stuck behind the police line, alone on a scary unlit street.
The line of cops moved down the street, pushing the rest of us like cattle,
screaming, "MOVE! MOVE! MOVE!"  I stopped and pointed behind them, saying
my friend was trapped around the corner on that street by herself, let me
please go to her, instead of up and around the block out of her sight
(where the cops were forcing the rest of us to go).  The response was a
reddening face screaming at me, "MOVE! MOVE! MOVE!", then threatening me
with arrest.  I ran around two blocks and finally met up with her, thank
God.  Basically, the San Francisco Police Department saw fit to jeopardize
the safety of my friend and the rights of all of us because...why? oh,
yeah, we were standing peacefully on a sidewalk outside of a club. :(  (And
they wonder why the rave scene doesn't cooperate with the nice
authorities...)

To salvage the night we headed over to Bondage-a-Go-Go.  Woo!  _This_ made
us forget the previous unpleasantness in a wonderland of fishnets, leather,
gyrating dancers, and live bondage sessions.  I was a Bondage virgin (so to
speak) and was put-off at first by the (club) environment.  Loud, grungy,
metally industrial techno, red lights, and lots of black, spikes,
deathrockers, and goth queens.  It was all so _dark_, and got me to
thinking about the whole dilemma about sexuality at raves (yes, I know this
was a recent thread topic).

I think of raves in terms of pink and baby blue.  It's Disneyland, full of
toys and happy children, with many psychedelic rides.  It's innocence.  It
allows us to get in touch with that inner child, that freedom, spontaneity,
joy, self-confidence.  But shouldn't this process of getting more in touch
with ourselves _also_ include sexuality?  In other words, is raving an
experience that actually only connects us with _part_ of ourselves, not the
whole?

Bondage is a club celebrating sexuality.   What I originally thought of as
alienating darkness became a necessary element for a realm of fantasies:
people exploring the "dark" side of their natures, the "sin", with all its
fetishized latex and nudity and harsh edges.   Upstairs volunteers waited
in lines to be dominated in front of an audience - whips, chains, clamps
and mindfucks -- the binary division into dominant and submissive/master
and slave.  It made me wonder (not for the first time) if sexuality is
dependent for its thrill on appealing to the taboo, the dark and nasty
side.  Is this dialectic of light/darkness in all of us?  I suddenly
imagined a whole person as a human yin-yang: baby-dressed happy raver with
teddy bear and big hugs on Friday, black-corset-wearing, red-lipsticked
night goddess on Saturday.   Just as people are freer with sweetness at
raves, I noticed people acting differently at Bondage.  No silly laughter,
just smoldering gazes.  Or maybe all of these experiences (raves, bondage)
are one-dimensional, made more intense for their singularity, easier to
explore only particular aspects of our selves.

Random thoughts...
until tomorrow, everybody!
Love, Nancy

The problem with a lot of those books (Chocolate to Morphine, etc.)
is that their information is just too old.

I would recommend that you check out this organization:

MAPS
1801 Tippan Ave
Charlotte, NC 28205
(704)358-9830


They're an organization devoted to psychedelic research an have a
monthly publication you can subscribe to. I think you can also buy
back issues related to topics you are interested. They do a lot of
research on E, acid, shrooms, GHB, etc. and their info is far more
current. Check it out.

                                            Hugs,
 
                                             CT

OK everyone,

  i know that for some of you this might be a trip but Ultraworld 
Productions based in Baltimore MD  is planning to throw their biggest
and most ambitious party ever called ECLIPSE on Saturday April 27th. at
the DC Armory in Washington D.C.

   Ultraworld Productions has been throwing the best raves on the 
East Coast since 1992.  I have never been let down by one of their parties
ever.  I am planning on attending it and encourage any
of you who have the ability to make the trip to ECLIPSE also do it.
If anyone is going let me know. =)  Maybe Ill have a suprise for you

Now Let me tell you about this party


   E C L I P S E  - Ultraworld  - April 27, 1996


	In the beginning there was darknes...
	And the forces of the universe looked upon the darkness and 
said, "What a great time to celebrate!"  And many parties were had in 
the darkness, and they were good.  Then light was created, and it was 
really bright.  And so dancing continued in the darkness until one day
a force known as Ultraworld decided to brave the light, to call everyone
together for an event of  great illumination.  The event is called ECLIPSE.
	The space is the massive DC Armory, with its super high ceilings,
all wooden dancefloor, safe parking, and clean facilities.  The space is
so good, that when they told us we could only go until 2 a.m., we decided
to go ahead and do it.  Bringing you a full 12 hour event, Eclipse will
start at 2 p.m. and go until 2 a.m.  We urge everyone to get there at
the start, there is no "opening" dj.  This event is going to kick ass
from the first record to the last, and everything in between.  This is
not some overhyped commercial event thrown by people you don't even know.
This is the real thing, only bigger!  All the quality and vibe you've
come to expect from Ultraworld  will be in full effect like never before.
	Imagine the sight of the massive armory: Dj in the center, each
live act on its own stage around the perimeter (forming a huge X), 
4 lasers crossing overhead, lights flashing, bass pounding, and of course,
thousands of smiling people dancing to the music we all love.  When the 
first beat drops, there will be no day or night, only here and now...

			DJ's Spinning Center Stage

HippE (Denver) Adam X (Sonic Groove,NY) Kemistry & Storm (Metalheadz, U.K.)
           Scott Henry (Fever/Buzz Balt/DC)  DJ Sun (Ultraworld)

			Stage 1 - Performing Live

	Rabbit in the Moon (Hallucination Orlando)
		with projections by Lightworks

			Stage 2 - Performing Live

	Prototype 909 (Instinct Records NYC)
		with projections by OVT Visuals

			Stage 3 - Performing Live

	All Mighty Senators (Dog East Dog Records/Baltimore)
		with projections by Double Helix

			Stage 4 - Performing Live

	Dubtribe Sound System (Imperial Dub/Organico Recordings - SF)
		with projections by Optical Delusion

Turbo Sound Audio 
Centrak Lasers
Supercal Lighting

If you need a Flight or Hotel for this event call:
	703.719.9700 - Travel 2000

$25 after March 31st
$30 at the Door
Info:  410.637.7056
	u8x@access.digex.net

The Line-Up is as follows:

Thats the info folks!!  See ya there!!

Cassandra said....
  "With a new dance dance ensemble I am helping found in the city, we are
considering
playing with the idea of making light another dancer and cheoreographing
the dancers to react to the light.  With the right kind of lighting board
and lights perhaps sequences couls be programmed which flashed light
around and hence create a sense of space that is not so focused on the dj."


A friend told me last night about seeing Sven Vath spin once, and he had a
dancer who was wearing an amorphic michelin-man indeterrminate body suit wired
with lights -- and he came rolling onto the stage (i guess it was a stage) and
did a performance that ended up with him being surrounded by other lights -- he
said it was really cool and totally different - (he said that same night Moby
did a set that ended up with him stripping naked, which apparently is not
unusual, true Moonpup? --- I like seeing performance-based stuff when the space
allows it == (have a great preference for using electric lights rather than the
torches and fire I've seen used at several parties by dance performers... am I
the only one who has visions of us all going up in flames?)

Leslie  : _


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Apr 12 09:57:58 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id JAA05218; Fri, 12 Apr 1996 09:57:58 -0700
Received: from xanadu.cyborganic.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id JAA05211; Fri, 12 Apr 1996 09:57:54 -0700
Received: (from tsheets@localhost) by xanadu.cyborganic.net (8.7.5/8.7.1) id JAA26827; Fri, 12 Apr 1996 09:58:57 -0700 (PDT)
From: Troy Sheets <tsheets@xanadu.cyborganic.net>
Message-Id: <199604121658.JAA26827@xanadu.cyborganic.net>
Subject: Negativ
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Fri, 12 Apr 1996 09:58:57 -0700 (PDT)
Cc: sf@cyborganic.net
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL24]
Content-Type: text
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I was kind of disappointed with the negativland show at the Troc.  I think
the worst part about it was that people were not DANCING.  This was
mostly due to the fact that the music was not DANCABLE.  I guess
there can be shows where people don't dance... but I just don't enjoy
those types of shows.

It seems funny that Negativland, who seem to be into the whole "the entire
country is programmed by television" would do a show where everyone is just
standing there mezmorized, hypnotized, zombified watching them.  You 
could stay at home stare and a tv and be brain-dead... or you can go to the
troc, stand around and stare at Negativland and be brain-dead.

This is in contrast to a band like say, Front 242 who combats television
complacency with driving body-gyrating sounds.  It seems like Negativland
wants to battle complacency with.... more complacency.

Okay, okay, I know that is just their "sound" and it is not meant for
dancing.  But, many times I thought they were pretty unprofessional
and unorganized on stage... there were LONG, boring pauses in which they
were trying to get things fixed or setup or whatever.

Then, on top of all this, you are in "the troc", a club where it seems
nobody ever has a good time.  Too many people, all standing around... 
drinking, smoking... I guess I just expected something else.  I think
this whole event would be VERY COOL if it took place in a movie theater
or planetarium.

The film projections were really cool.  Lots of old EE movies and stuff.
Did you see that one movie where they were explaining orders of magnitude
by zooming in on this guys's hand... to his skin texture, to his cells,
to his chromosomes, to his DNA, to the atom, through the electron shells,
and finally into the nuclius...  with the order of magnatude (in meters)
displayed on the screen too.... then they zoomed out into the universe,
with orders of magnatude going up.  I saw that film in a physics class
in college... very cool.

We left early from negativland becuase we were not having that much fun.
They should really consider doing these non-dancing events in more
relaxing, non-dancing venues.

-troy

> money
>  i.d.
> pipe and fixin's

>  candy (lollipops, lifesavers, gum) to share with everyone (come and

Yup -- all these are kept in my raver's kit. I usually leave my
sunglasses in my car, and bear the gremlins in my head yelping,
"Bright Light!" as I walk out of the venue.. 

> flashlight

Hmmm...this is a good one to add for future events. I especially like
those mini mag-lites.

> cigarettes (again, plenty to share, and yes I know it's a nasty
> habit)

Well, I don't smoke tobacco, so I omit these... Sometimes the clove
variety are pleasant to smoke, though.

> toys (I've got cool kalaidescopes for this weekend to the first 3 wonderful
> people!)

I have neglected to bring toys to raves. I see the value in them --
especially feathers, koosh balls (especially the day-glo kind), and
visual aids. [My girlfriend brought her feather boa to The Gathering,
and it was a big hit in the chill space.]

> bandaids and ibuprofen

Bandaids? Are we raving, or slamming?

> ...and most important (esp if you're going anywhere near the Wicked sound
> system!)  .... earplugs!  be nice to your ears!

Yes! 

A few additional items I like to bring:
	lip balm
	eye drops (especially for my contact lenses)
	kleenex
	business cards, so the new friends I meet can contact me
	menthol & euclyptus oil -- especially yummy at hot parties
	massage oil or body lotion :)
	
> And I stow them all in a clear plastic backpack with outside pockets, the
> doormen/security people love it, but it's falling apart!   waaah!

I've discovered that fanny packs are very convenient for carrying my
kit.  They are often innocuous enough to evade the prying eyes and
fingers of the security guards (especially the black ones). In
addition, you can easily wear it around, allowing for security
and freedom from the weight and bulkiness on  your shoulders.

-G

Here's a riddle I came across and thought I'd share


Ralph had it once, Len and it before, Paul had it afterward, and Bryan never
did have it. Girls have it once, but boys can't have it at all. Mrs.
Mulligan had it twice in a row, and DR. Lowell had it before and afterward,
but he had it twice as bad afterward as he had it before. What is it?

The answer will be given at 2pm or around there.

Sometimes I carry my goodies in a black leather sporran (Class?  Who can
tell me what a sporran is?).
It's usually a good place to carry stuff, but at the first Tribal Funk I
went to (SF, Cow Palace), they took the leather-and-chain strap and held it
till I got out (could be used as a weapon, I guess...like I'd use a
weapon).  Fortunately I have friends who are happy to stuff my sporran
inside their daypacks, but unfortunately that means that I have to track
them down whenever I want to get something...
So, now I usually just stuff my pocketses with my precioussssss...

- E

I'm pretty sure they are only targetting drummers downtown on Pacific Street
after 10pm.  I read an article in the paper (same one?) that said the police
get a lot of noise complaints from elderly people trying to sleep in the
apartment buildings across the street from the main sidewalk hangout area.

So... the ban seems reasonable to me.  I mean, people can still drum
until 10pm, which I often enjoy while walking downtown in the afternoon,
and then they just have to move away from the downtown area to let people
sleep.  They could go to the beach...

> 
> and their caling the measure "Bedtime for Bongos".  It brings up the

I personally go for the minimalist look with my drivers license and ATM 
card (for emergencies) and a enough dollar bills (no change pleeze) in 
one pocket and the key to my front door in another.  If I'm feeling 
really amibitious I might bring a water bottle.  This way I can dance free 
and unattached all night long...no gear to worry about.

yours in zen-like bliss,   Jess

On Apr 12,  9:58am, Troy Sheets wrote:
>
> I was kind of disappointed with the negativland show at the Troc.  I think
> the worst part about it was that people were not DANCING.  This was
> mostly due to the fact that the music was not DANCABLE.  I guess
> there can be shows where people don't dance... but I just don't enjoy
> those types of shows.

	that's interesting.  there was a guy in the very very front
	of the crowd who was heckling, just about screaming very
	clearly pronunced phrases like "that drum rhythm is very
	boring"  and "i payed eleven dollars for THIS?"  he diddn't
	want danceable music, and was unable to accept the hybrid
	that was on his plate.  to much jonah for him.  too much
	-land for you, it sounds like.

	first off, negativland's music has never tried to be dancable.
	their early albums are just cut-ups.  and for a -land show,
	this *was* very dancable.  jonah and those other dudes did
	a good job of popping some rhythm into the fray.

> It seems funny that Negativland, who seem to be into the whole "the entire
> country is programmed by television" would do a show where everyone is just
> standing there mezmorized, hypnotized, zombified watching them.  You
> could stay at home stare and a tv and be brain-dead... or you can go to the
> troc, stand around and stare at Negativland and be brain-dead.

	wow. i'm sorry, but i feel like you are just gravely missing
	the point.  also, if you were braindead there, it's your own
	fault.  "i stood there barely able to manage cohesive thought"
	is something i would be ashamed to admit on a huge mailing list.

> This is in contrast to a band like say, Front 242 who combats television
> complacency with driving body-gyrating sounds.  It seems like Negativland
> wants to battle complacency with.... more complacency.

	*sigh*
	doyou have any idea of the history behind -land?
	have you ever seen them before?
	were you expecting a rave?

> Okay, okay, I know that is just their "sound" and it is not meant for
> dancing.  But, many times I thought they were pretty unprofessional
> and unorganized on stage... there were LONG, boring pauses in which they
> were trying to get things fixed or setup or whatever.

	no rehersal, five hours of improvisational collaboration...
	the weatherman has not performed with them for TEN YEARS.
	what you thaought was "unprofessional" was art, and you
	really cannot justify your opinion otherwise, not to me
	anyway.  besides, pauses, even silence, are an important
	part of a performance.  but i guess when you get used to
	teevee you get kind of scared when there is a pause, at
	least without a colorful logo in it.

> Then, on top of all this, you are in "the troc", a club where it seems
> nobody ever has a good time.  Too many people, all standing around...
> drinking, smoking... I guess I just expected something else.  I think
> this whole event would be VERY COOL if it took place in a movie theater
> or planetarium.

	i definately agree here, that was a show that had not enough
	breathing room at least.  sit down would have been cool.

	last i saw -land was at the oasis in san jose.  it was crowded
	but not packed, they were easier to see. in a way it was a
	better show - though the collaborative, improvisational nature
	of last nights event was fantastic.  that's art in realtime,
	by the seats of their pants.  many aspects of my own musical
	group were visible on that stage last night - improv, live
	radio scanning... for which of course we bow in deference
	to those pioneers who came before us.

> The film projections were really cool.  Lots of old EE movies and stuff.
> Did you see that one movie where they were explaining orders of magnitude
> by zooming in on this guys's hand... to his skin texture, to his cells,
> to his chromosomes, to his DNA, to the atom, through the electron shells,
> and finally into the nuclius...  with the order of magnatude (in meters)
> displayed on the screen too.... then they zoomed out into the universe,
> with orders of magnatude going up.  I saw that film in a physics class
> in college... very cool.

	who did the visuals, anyway?

> We left early from negativland becuase we were not having that much fun.
> They should really consider doing these non-dancing events in more
> relaxing, non-dancing venues.

	we left after about 1.5 hours.  that lummox heckling kind of killed
	it for me early on, but the main factor was that we were were just
	plain bushed.  that and the big crowd just made it too exhasting.
	i'll just get the show tape, that's music you have to focus on
	anyway...

[ to sfraves list ]

 Opinions of the Negativland performance

 My anticipations of the audience mix were verified by the comments made
by two guys who were standing behind me in line:

 ( Looking at show poster on telephone pole ) 
 Guy 1: "Whos this Hard Kiss band? And Jonah Sharp?"
 Guy 2: "Hardkiss Brothers. Them and Jonah Sharp are DJs"
 Guy 1: "Huh ..."

 This was a NEGATIVLAND concert , with "special guest" support by the
great "Hard Kiss" brothers and Mr. Sharp . So , I knew right at the 
beginning that it was going to be more of a sound collage / ambient
industrial show than a rave. 

 Inside , it was hard-core Negativland fans and ravers in the audience
mix. I like old school ambient industrial as well as techno and breakbeat,
so just about anything coming off the stage was OK by me! There were
times that I thought the uncharted jam between all invovled had a 
"train wreck" effect, at other times all meshed together quite well.
Some times , I actually thought the Hardkiss bros and Jonah Sharp were
turned up too high!

 The Troc was the Troc , albeit with no chill rooms or basement open. 

 I wonder if there was any cross-pollination of fans between the two
groups in the audience? I know there must have been more folks there
than just me who could appreciate both styles that collided/collaborated
last night.

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

 This is just a request to you folks out there in SFRaves land. Does
anyone here use speakers for mixing music that they would like to 
recommend to me? I am dabbling in audio manipulation and creating
music with my home computer. I have a Digidesign Audiomedia II card
in an accelerated Mac II. So far , I'm just using a boom box as my
amplification and speakers, with Sony MDR v6 headphones to hear any
real low bass.

and post them to SFRaves.

try this riddle...
Three men go to a hotel because they're sleepy. The night manager tells them
the room will be $60, so they divide it three ways and each pay $20. As
they're on their way up to their room, the manager realizes the room was
only supposed to cost $55, so he sends the bell boy up with $5 to give
them. Realizing that three does not divide five evenly, the bell-boy
gives them each a dollar, and keeps two dollars for himself, so each man
winds up paying $19, and they payed $57 total. Since the bell boy has the
other two dollars, and $57 + $2 = $59, what happened to the other dollar?????

-------------------------------------------------
Catherine Chang
http://www.best.com/~catherin
things are changing...
-------------------------------------------------

> gives them each a dollar, and keeps two dollars for himself, so each man

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Apr 12 13:15:36 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id NAA27724; Fri, 12 Apr 1996 13:15:36 -0700
Received: from dub-img-1.compuserve.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id NAA27695; Fri, 12 Apr 1996 13:15:28 -0700
Received: by dub-img-1.compuserve.com (8.6.10/5.950515)
	id QAA21159; Fri, 12 Apr 1996 16:14:48 -0400
Date: 12 Apr 96 16:10:54 EDT
From: Leslie Ayres <71165.755@CompuServe.COM>
To: "sfraves@hyperreal.com" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Re: more on: raver's packing list!
Message-ID: <960412201054_71165.755_GHL73-2@CompuServe.COM>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

George added great stuff to the list, some of which I carry all the time....  

The flashlight is for finding stuff that dropped, as well as checking out the
port-a-pottie situation (I'd rather see it before it gets me!) and the kleenex
comes in handy there too..  I keep a little keychain type squeeze light on the
zipper of my pack, and a bigger one inside...

Toys can be great .. my friend Keith has this cool plastic toy for babies that
is a ball with bumps on it, and it vibrates ...  

"Bandaids? Are we raving, or slamming?" Honey, we're dancing all night, and our
feet might get a little blister! Or any kind of boo-boo

Hand cream ... yep, especially helpful to "freshen up" funky hands, too -- I
ought to get some of those little wipe things in the foil packs, too..

Business cards -- yes!  I carry cards that just have my name and home phone on
it (with other cryptic glyphs only some people can decipher) --and add a pen and
some paper to that too ... I get asked for that all the time....

I also try to carry a light funky shirt or something I can put down to sit on in
questionable places -- I was glad I did that at that Deli place one night,
'cause the funky sweater got hella gum on it, and protected my nice satin
skirt...

I know people get their stuff stolen sometimes, which is why I like to either
have a very distinctive backpack that I can also stuff my coat into (like my
plastic one) or a black pack with some distinguishing mark (mine has a Giants
patch) that I can cram into a dark corner -- and I never leave it out of my
sight...

I know all about negativlands history and used to be pretty into them.  I
thought last nights show was pretty boring and uninspired. Nice idea, but
after witnessing an hour of so of it I would have to say it was a failed
experiment, at least imo.  It seemed like a pretty random mishmash, and I
saw some pretty frustrated expressions on stage at times...

I saw them live on their last tour in socal and thought that was pretty
weak too, I don't think their material goes over live very well.  And
their brand of humor doesn't do much for me these days, the same routines
just aren't very funny anymore.  I think they should stick to radio... 

I personally wasn't expecting it to be very "ravey", but I thought I'd
give it a chance on the slight posibility that it would be cool, it
wasn't.  The last time I was at the troc (lame ebn/banco de gaia show a
couple months back) I promised myself I wouldn't go back, no matter what. 
I should've stuck to that promise and gone to pack-a-bowl instead. Live
and learn... 

Andy

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Rick Riffle <rdriffle@ucdavis.edu>
Subject: Re: try this one...
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

At 12:55 PM 4/12/96 -0700, you wrote:
>try this riddle...
>Three men go to a hotel because they're sleepy. The night manager tells them
>the room will be $60, so they divide it three ways and each pay $20. As
>they're on their way up to their room, the manager realizes the room was
>only supposed to cost $55, so he sends the bell boy up with $5 to give
>them. Realizing that three does not divide five evenly, the bell-boy
>gives them each a dollar, and keeps two dollars for himself, so each man
>winds up paying $19, and they payed $57 total. Since the bell boy has the
>other two dollars, and $57 + $2 = $59, what happened to the other dollar?????

                         ^^^^^^^^^^^^^  
This logic in this equasion is incorrect for the circumstances.  They paid
$60, got three back, wich equals $57, and the bell-boy kept two, which
equals $55.  It should read $60 - 3 = 57 - 2 = $55.

Rick

>Catherine Chang
>http://www.best.com/~catherin
>things are changing...

On Mon, 8 Apr 1996, Geoff White wrote:

> 
> Having the DJ on the dancefloor (at the same level as the dancers) is sort
> of traditional here in SF.  It is symbolic that this is not a rock concert
> and that the DJs are not to be worshiped as rock idols, they are just like
> everyone
> else and above all, there should be no "spectators".  've found that in practice

Unfortunately i dont think this worked.  Especially at the Gathering where
there was a five deep crowd of people watching the dj's.  I think that 
the problem with this set-up was that if the dj is supposed to be the
"center" of the party then you should at least be able to see him without
having to stop and crowd in close and look over three other people.

  Its always nice to know that the dj's is there and having them a few
feet above the crowd would allow me to see them while in front of a 
speaker 100 feet away

doug ) ( doug@hyperreal.com


> this seems to work well, most DJs I know seem to prefer this arrangement in that
> you can feel the crowd and the crowd can feed you energy (especially the folks
> down front :).  Sometimes it opens you up to unexpected attacks (like when some
> dude who has had too much of whatever and decides the DJ is Satan and must be
> destroyed, or when God speaks to some gal and tells her to lift the tone arm
> so she can deliver his message) but in the long run many wounldn't have it
> any other way.

Hello all,
	I haven't gone out in over a month whilst preparing for a grad 
school exam.  I have always been the epitome of self-control when it 
comes to things like this, but about now I am starting to feel like a 
caged rat!!

	Anyway, tomorrow is the big day and afterwards I am going to finally 
cut loose.  I think it will be to State of Divinity basically because I am 
too wary of Kundalini, and I also really want to hear Tracy.  It sounds like 
it is going to be a big affair, but I am taking a few of my best friends 
who have never gone, and I think they will enjoy a big production.  
Anyway, I am hoping Inner Circle does good, but also I am in such great 
spirits just at the thought of finishing my test, that I am 
full of great vibe and will have a marvelous time wherever I am!!  If 
anyone thinks this is going to be a terrible party, please let me know!!

I would love to meet anyone who ventures to this party.  I don't really 
have any funky hat or clothes that would make me stand out.  I will have 
a ladybug puppet that is really cool. Also, I have earrings with my name 
in rainbow colors-kirsten.  If you get close enough to see these, you 
_better_ introduce yourself! :)  Anyway, I am 5'4", 120 lbs, shoulder 
length brn hair, brn eyes.  

Send me vibes tonight so that they will permeate my brain and help me do 
well tomorrow!!  


Wishing everyone the best...

kc

kirstenc@uclink.berkeley.edu

From: ascend@ix.netcom.com (Gregory Sandler )
Subject: Harmony has been postponed :(
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello everyone,

    Well, as some of you might have heard, Harmony has been postponed 
for a couple of weeks. To make a long story short, we had contracts 
signed for a space in the south bay. However, the management of the 
facilities decided to not go through with the party leaving us without 
a space, two days before the party. So, we tried to get another, but 
came up short, and decided it would be a better idea to postpone the 
party and do it with careful planning and consideration, rather then 
bring you a quick, "throw-together" production. We feel it is important 
to have everything as perfectly planned as possible. 

    So, on a sad note, we have to postone tonights party. On a happier 
note, we are going to try to set up a FREE PARTY on Saturday (April 
12th). It will be somewhere in or by Santa Cruz, and will start as soon 
as we get there (noonish), and go until sunset. Call the Harmony lines 
@ (408) 486-9591 and (408) 450-3044 for more info. 

    We would really like to see all of you there to show your support 
and join us to create harmony...

Peace, love, and harmony to all,

Greg :)

Think of it...

Harmony does a daytime party on the beach in Santa Cruz on Saturday,
everyone piles into cars and heads down to the beach in Santa Barbara
Saturday night/Sunday morning, back into the cars and we all head up to
Santa Cruz where we find out Sunset is having a beach party on Sunday!!

hope for.

Maybe others will join?  ;^)

Subject: Harmony/Lack of Spaces

:( :( :( :(

Was _really_ looking forward to this one!  A couple of friends of mine
(newbies, but with open hearts and minds) wanted to see what it was all
about.  I've made them wait a little while for Harmony.  A great crowd of
five of us were hyped for tonight...  But I guess anticipation just makes
it sweeter, right?  Only thing is, four weeks from now is finals, and this
was to be our last pardy-hardy week-end before term papers and finals kick
in.  And after finals, everyone disperses out of the Bay Area - three of
the newbies I was to bring tonight are actually leaving the country for a
year.

Much sympathy and thanks out to the Harmony crew for what I'm sure was lots
and lots of preparation, just to be screwed over by the owners of the
space.  It is especially nice of them to offer a free party to make it up
to us, when it was not their fault _and_ none of us have bought tickets
yet.  You all are the best!

We really need to work on the location issue!!  This is, from what I
understand, the only reason we have not had the number of Friends &
Family's, Chrysalis', and Harmony's that are possible...

Could some party planners list suggestions for how to go about finding
spaces??  Then maybe the 400 of us on this list can put our collective
energy to work and help find our party spots!!

Love, Nancy

Subject: BSP(SF) -- a completely differrent friday entertainment

From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>

in another kitchen!

Happening again tonight and for the following few weeks...

10PM 
Josie's Cabaret 16th/Market

another episode of Heather Woodbury's performance novel on the topic of
"jazz, rave, and brussels sprouts". One woman, one hundred characters
--  partially inspired by her and Dudley Saunder's journey to
Kalifurnya during prime beachtime raving season -- attending SF Raves's
and perhaps the bay area's first rave at bonnie doon. 

Below is someone's comment on this (author name is call by reference):

|i cannot recommend this more highly. the woman is incredible. i only saw a
|couple of episodes, back when it was a weekly show at a bar in the e
|village (which then became a much shorter, tighter series at PS 122--i
|think that's what she's doing at josie's) but she's got an incredible ear
|and is a kickass storyteller and delightful actress. old ladies and little
|ravers and pimps and prostitutes and yuppies all coexist and cross paths in
|this incredibly coherent universe she creates. it's very satisfying. you
|needn't catch all 8 episodes (whittled down from like 32!)--you can drift
|in anywhere and immediately get your bearings. but GO GO GO GO!!!!

--------------------

Original annoucnement:

To: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@HYPERREAL.COM>
Cc: idm@HYPERREAL.COM, nm-list@XMISSION.COM, bpm@dhp.com
Subject: BSP -- The Heather Woodbury Report (one-woman performance novel)
Date: Mon, 01 Apr 96 14:04:10 -0800
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Resent-Message-ID: <"wIgrdC.A.exF.sLFYx"@dhp.com>
Resent-From: bpm@dhp.com
Reply-To: bpm@dhp.com
X-Mailing-List: <bpm@dhp.com> archive/latest/882
X-Loop: bpm@dhp.com
Precedence: list
Resent-Sender: bpm-request@dhp.com


				    The
			  Heather Woodbury Report
			       or what ever
	    A Living, One-Woman Performance Novel in 8 Episodes

One Woman 100 Characters... NYC's Cult Hit!

Jazz, Rave, and ... Brussel Sprouts

Catch it one episode per week at:
	Josie's Cabaret
	3583 16th St. (at Market)
	San Francisco

Reservations:
	(415) 861-7933

Times:
	Every Friday at 10PM....
	#1: "Salvation", April 5.
	#2 "Homemaking", April 12.
	#3 "Seeing Things", April 19.
	#4 "Quakes", April 26.
	#5-8 TBA...

--------------------

"Spectacular Characters"
	Sarah Schulman, New York Press.

"Nothing short of epic"
	Marc Raphael, New York Casting.

"Characters as fascinating & memorable as any created by Dickens"
	Chip Defaa, New York Post.

"Engrossing!! A narrative feat!"
	Harold Goldberg, The Village Voice.

"See it"
	Margo Jefferson, New Yrk Times Radio WQXR.

"Wildly diverse, captivating characters"
	Tom Murrin, Paper Magazine.

"Succeeds brilliantly -- Dickens with a dash of Armistead Maupin"
	Michael Yawney, Off-Off Broadway Review.

"Absorbing ... Seamless... Amazing"
	Cynthia True, Time Out NY.

--------------------

PS: Some of the inspiration in this
one-person-many-characters-performance was inspired by Heather's
positive experiences at the SF Raves "Connection"  rave at Bonnie Dune
Beach in Santa Cruz (damn, when was that 92? 93?). Heather came with a
friend who writes for Spin Magazine and he ended up writing a  1-pager
on SF's rave scene that predominantly mentioned an underground rave on
some unnamed california beach -- an early, accurate, and positive
accounting of the rave scene in the press... There's mention of this in
the early SFR archives.

NPM...

--------------------

search for that name (try alta vista off of http://www.search.com/ and
use the proper capitalization for a name) -- some of the early sfraves
archives are on the web so you should be able to get a search hit.

Then look at the date of the message and that should give you a pretty
good idea of the timeframe of that article ...

I quite frankly don't remember the dates, but vaguely recall that this
article was published in november-december-january-february-march
timeframe after that connection rave. Since I just moved and
undoubtedly threw away any nonessential paper encumberances, I doubt I
have that article any more.

-- NpM.

At 01:43 PM 4/12/96 -0700, you wrote:
>At 12:55 PM 4/12/96 -0700, you wrote:
>>try this riddle...
>>Three men go to a hotel because they're sleepy. The night manager tells them
>>the room will be $60, so they divide it three ways and each pay $20. As
>>they're on their way up to their room, the manager realizes the room was
>>only supposed to cost $55, so he sends the bell boy up with $5 to give
>>them. Realizing that three does not divide five evenly, the bell-boy
>>gives them each a dollar, and keeps two dollars for himself, so each man
>>winds up paying $19, and they payed $57 total. Since the bell boy has the
>>other two dollars, and $57 + $2 = $59, what happened to the other dollar?????
>
>                         ^^^^^^^^^^^^^  
>This logic in this equasion is incorrect for the circumstances.  They paid
>$60, got three back, wich equals $57, and the bell-boy kept two, which
>equals $55.  It should read $60 - 3 = 57 - 2 = $55.
>
>Rick
>
>
>
 2+2=4.

Subject: Re: Negativland
Cc: larryc@netcom.com (Larry Ching)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> Inside , it was hard-core Negativland fans and ravers in the audience
>mix. I like old school ambient industrial as well as techno and breakbeat,
>so just about anything coming off the stage was OK by me! There were
>times that I thought the uncharted jam between all invovled had a
>"train wreck" effect, at other times all meshed together quite well.

At the end of it all, they said "thanks for taking part in this experiment.
We think some parts of it worked well, others didn't work at all."

But it was cool for me to be part of the experimental process... almost
like hanging out in the studio with them.

>Some times , I actually thought the Hardkiss bros and Jonah Sharp were
>turned up too high!

The mix was a lot better if you were right near the stage and not in front
of the speakers.

> I wonder if there was any cross-pollination of fans between the two
>groups in the audience? I know there must have been more folks there
>than just me who could appreciate both styles that collided/collaborated
>last night.

Yes, there was cross-pollination! Kind of cool to see some
industrial/grunge fans dancing to the Hardkiss beat. Cross pollination is
important, if you spend too much time doing one thing, you lose the
opportunity to find new things you might like.

Also, everyone I talked to agreed that the visuals were excellent. "Rave"
party promoters take note: visuals on this level could really make a party
stand out.

PS- I heard an interesting comment that night. "For a group that is acting
all anti-corporate / anti-media-conglomerate, they sure are merchandising
themselves well."

--
Rusty
http://www.soma.net

On Friday, April 12, 1996 8:19 PM, Courtney Nielsen wrote:
>Does anyone have any legit info as to how long T H C stays inside the human
>body?

from the alt.hemp CANNABIS/MARIJUANA FAQ (available: http://hyperreal.com/drugs/faqs/FAQ-alt.hemp)

    The part of marijuana that gets you high is called
    `Delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol.'  Most people just call this
    THC, but this is confusing: your body will change
    Delta-9-THC into more inert molecules known as
    `metabolites,' which don't get you high.  Unfortunately,
    these chemicals also have the word `tetrahydrocannabinol' in
    them and they are also called THC -- so many people think
    that the metabolites get you high.  Anti-drug pamphlets say
    that THC gets stored in your fat cells and then leaks out
    later like one of those `time release capsules' advertised
    on television.  They say it can keep you high all day or
    even longer.  This is not true, marijuana only keeps you
    high for a few hours.

B E N   C H U N
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
H O M E:                              W O R K:
ben_chun@community.net                webmaster@platform-horizons.com
http://community.net/~ben_chun/       http://www.platform-horizons.com

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Sat, 13 Apr 1996 04:37:43 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Marginally 99 <erase99@sirius.com>
Subject: out-a-sight, hindsight (review)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

well.. it's 4am and i just made it back to my house.. and here i am, eating
cheerios :)
the party was not held at acme, it was held on a warehouse on minna street.
i got my ticket from acme about 12:30ish, and got to the warehouse pretty
quickly (it's just down by 10th). there wasn't a line outside, but as soon
as i got in the door i found myself in a small corridor, with people on both
sides waiting to get in, while people were trying to get out through the
same corridor. i couldn't wait to get out of the line and into the party.
inside the party was just as bad as the waiting line. it was packed!
it was very difficult to find a place to dance. i eventually did, met a
couple people, and shed a couple pounds of water.
the place was hot and humid. there were no fans, and no effective
ventalation. the floor was slippery with condensation and i got hit by a
couple drops of water from the ceiling too.
for the hundreds of people there, there was _one_ bathroom. i waited in line
for about 45 minutes so i could get in just to fill up on water. completely
ridiculous. the organizers were selling bottled water. i didn't bother to
check the price, tap water's good enough for me, and water should be free,
anyhow. The organizers really should have provided a more accessible water
tap, especially because of the intense heat and humidity.
as to the vibe. what vibe? i didn't really sense anything in the way of vibe
here. ran into many people who were nice (especially after i offered them
water), but as a general feeling, the party just didn't have it. some bad
vibe being churned out by a few guys who were drinking 40oz'ers of malt
liquor. manly acting up and such bravado. woo hoo. i didn't see them after a
while, or maybe one of them was the guy who was leaning his head up against
the speaker ... (he'll regret that in the morning!)
oh yah. there was no chill space either. just one big room.
*sigh* too bad harmony wasn't on tonight instead.. :(
oh well. it wasn't a terrible time, just not a memorable one.

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Sat, 13 Apr 1996 15:20:09 -0500
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: ecto@citenet.net (ecto)
Subject: Brad's birthday! :) (from shawna)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hey all, I'm back again, just gotta make a quick note to all to wish Ecto a
happy 24th birthday!!! :)  Doin my best to bring a little bit of SF to
Montreal & give him a happy birthday!

Well, went to my first party last night, it was actually a small house
party.  There really are a lot of differences between raving in SF and
raving here.  All the beautiful decorations that parties such as Chrysalis
are almost entirely missing, there are a few visuals, but full-on
decoration & black lights with the black light art & altars & all that
groovy stuff is completely missing.  The chill room is very different too,
in sf I'm used to big old piles of love pretty much filling up the whole
room, here people just sit by themselves & lay there, or if there is
interaction with other people, they just sit there individually and discuss
things.  It was kinda weird.  Apparently this is totally standard for
montreal, people just don't get like that, they all keep to their own
defined personal space which is totally alien to me for a rave.  They were
nice, I met several of Ecto's friends.  And this was considered to be a
really good party!  Most, if no all, parties here, are MASSIVE events with
huge 11x17 flyers that have huge 15 dj lineups, that cost $25 or more.
We're probably gonna attend one of those tonight, I'm sure I'll have an
interesting review of that one! ;)  I had a lot of fun at last night's
party, it was very mellow & relaxed, gave me a chance to have some quality
hanging-out time with Brad, it was just really weird to observe the many
differences.  One big difference (!!) was that this was a private party,
someone's house party, yet they were asking $10 donations.  Is this a
common thing that I just haven't seen in SF?  Usually, aside from paying
for e if you get it, I don't remember people charging for house parties.
And really, it was a charge, not a donation, even tho they said it was a
"donation", cause they were prepared to not let you in the door if you
didn't pay your money!  Definitely a different mentality up here, maybe
it's just me, but if I invite a bunch of people to my house for a party,
I'm not gonna require them to pay $10 each!  Nobody dresses up here either,
no fun outfits to look at!  In fact, there was one guy (whom everybody else
called the "Miami Vice guy" due to the way he dresses)  who dressed in a
suit!  Now who on earth would wear a fucking suit to a rave?  He had the
pants, jacket, tie, shoes & the whole shebang.  It just doesn't make
logical sense to me to wear anything other than something fun &
comfortable.  It's just funny the perspective one has, to Brad this was a
really great party, a lot closer to the kind of party he looks for, while
to me (even tho I enjoyed myself) it was really lacking that which really
gives a rave its soul.  Boy, I can hardly imagine what the massive is gonna
be like tonight!  Definitely an experiment in different cultures.  Well, at
least the music'll probably be good, hard techno & some goa! :):)

Well gotta go, time to take a shower & figure out what to do with the day.
So all you guys out there in SF, hello to you, I love you all (& appreciate
you more than ever! ;), and like I'm sure you actually do, "APPRECIATE
THIS!!" :)

Love,
Shawna

Encyclopedia and other books (available at better book shops) have the 
exact info and refrences.

>> The film projections were really cool.  Lots of old EE movies and stuff.
>> Did you see that one movie where they were explaining orders of magnitude
>> by zooming in on this guys's hand... to his skin texture, to his cells,
>> to his chromosomes, to his DNA, to the atom, through the electron shells,
>> and finally into the nuclius...  with the order of magnatude (in meters)
>> displayed on the screen too.... then they zoomed out into the universe,
>> with orders of magnatude going up.  I saw that film in a physics class
>> in college... very cool.

>        who did the visuals, anyway?
>
The visuals were by Craig Baldwin, of Artists Television Access.  He is
quite a master of found footage collage, and he also made a documentary
called "Sonic Outlaws", about Negativland, John Oswald, and other
musicians working with "appropriated sound"....

If any promoters got him to do visuals at an event, I would be *very*
excited!  especially after seeing what he did at the Negativland show.

-Brian

To sfraves...

This is a "dumb" (basic) question, but as a fairly new user of e-mail, etc
I'm not sure and thought it better to just ask.

If I'm writing a response to a posting on sfraves, how can I tell if the
response should be sent back to sfraves or directly to the person's e-mail?
Also, how can I tell if a response to one of my postings has come directly
from the person or was posted back on sfraves and came to me that way? Does
this question make sense?

Confused in sf


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Apr 14 13:09:22 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id NAA14582; Sun, 14 Apr 1996 13:09:22 -0700
Received: from moon.sirius.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id NAA14572; Sun, 14 Apr 1996 13:09:18 -0700
Received: from erase99.sirius.com (ppp040-sm0.sirius.com [205.134.229.40]) by moon.sirius.com (8.6.12/8.6.9p) with SMTP id NAA14153 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Sun, 14 Apr 1996 13:09:18 -0700
Message-Id: <2.2.32.19960414200905.0071b8b0@moon.sirius.com>
X-Sender: erase99@moon.sirius.com

Date: Sun, 14 Apr 1996 13:09:05 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Mingled 99 <erase99@sirius.com>
Subject: kundalini review
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

managed to make it out to kundalini last night. picked up krishna on my way
to san jose (melissa had a sudden attack of alergies and was a mucous
monster). drove quite a ways to get to the party. the voice message said it
was going to be 50 minutes south of SF, which it was not. :(  as well, it
was held at a virgin space, which ended up being a roller rink in sj. i'm
sure there are lots of roller rinks in the bay area, are we going to have to
hear about a virgin space everytime one gets used? since all roller rinks
are pretty much the same, the feel of the location isn't new, even though
the building might be..
we got there and there was a pretty big line waiting to get in. An
interesting crowd. Lots of gangsta types.. I went back to the car to take
some ginseng, and by the time i got back, krishna had met some people (who's
names i've forgotten :( -all except sparkles, who gave me some sparkly
spinkles for my face) and we chatted with them while waiting for the line to
go in. after a bit of waiting, the line moved a little bit, and then one of
the promotors (or someone in charge) came out and said that there would be
no smoking or guns inside (gum? no gum?? one of our newfound friends was a
little concerned for a second. <g>). the fact that they had to mention that
there were no guns allowed inside seemed a little scarry to me. after a
little while longer, someone came out and told the line to split up into two
lines - "girls against the wall, and guys right here". yep. they segregated
up. how about the male/female issue at raves. apparently we aren't equal. :(
apart from many line-jumpers who slipped in during the confusion of
splitting up the line, the line moved pretty quickly. when we got to the
door, i saw it was lyon securities (of lucky charms fame). to their credit,
they were very efficient and courtious. the guard even let me bring in my
camelbak! i'd folded up the bladder inside it and i don't think she had any
idea what it was (maybe some fancy bong of some sort??). big ripoff that
noone could bring in their water bottles though.
inside, krisha bought a water bottle for $2.50 (highway robbery). you could
refill it in the washroom and a water fountain, good news for me since i
dumped my water to add the mysterious element to the nature of my camelbak.
the washrooms were big enough to handle everyone, which was a big plus after
out-a-sight. :)
the vibe was pretty non-existant. our new friends were radiating it, but the
bad was oozing out of a few circles. lots of circle dancers there, krishna
remarked once we were in that it was like a high-school dance (albiet more
expensive). krishna met some of his breakdancing 'friends', ("yo, wassup!
gonna do some dancin', or wat?") and did some breaking at the end of the
night. krishna can do some pretty amazing stuff! if you see him, definately
ask him to do some breaking. he can do some pretty crazy spins and flips,
and he makes it look so easy!
just after we got there, spun started to play. it was terrible. it was like
spun was trying to play every single song he had. he'd start up one tune,
keep it going for about a minute, then stop the beat and start up a new
track! it was like he was practicing all the new starts he could do for his
sets. really disruptive to dancing. at one point, he had this cool scratch
going with this awesome (electro?) beat that was really moving me, but he
just stopped after about 20 seconds. and stopped literally. the music just
hit a wall, stopped, and then started on a new song. it was awful. dj dan
came on next, and he was _much_ better. he was playing better music, and he
kept it going long enough to dance to.
it cost $20 to get in. someone was definately making money off this one..
there were only two video screens, two strobe lights,  one bank of lasers,
and a few hangings lit up by some black lights. the money certainly wasn't
spent on a good light show. or the sound system, which consisted of two
speakers at one end of the arena. again, there was no chill room. :(  the
speakers were so far away that you could have a conversation.
the vibe improved as time went on (krisha attributed this to the fact that
everyone started to peak on their e high <g>) and people started to get more
friendly. i was just dying for the dj to play some gabba, just to see what
all the breakdancing kids would do. ;)
krisha said that when he went to his last kundalini, he promised himself he
wouldn't go to another. i'm going to make the same promise to myself now, i
recommend everyone else stay away too.
brendan
