>
>    Citizens Internet Empowerment Coalition Trial Update No. 8
>              Pre-Trial Update -  April 11, 1996 12:00 noon ET
>  -----------------------------------------------------------------
>                     http://www.cdt.org/ciec/
>                        ciec-info@cdt.org
>  -----------------------------------------------------------------
>   CIEC UPDATES intended for members of the Citizens Internet
>   Empowerment Coalition. CIEC Updates are written and edited by the
>   Center for Democracy and Technology (http://www.cdt.org). This
>   document may be reposted as long as it remains in total.
>  ------------------------------------------------------------------
>
>          ** 40,000 Netizens Vs. U.S. Department of Justice. **
>                 * The Fight To Save Free Speech Online *
>  Contents:
>
>  o Pre-Trial Update - Government To Present Its Defense of CDA
>    Beginning Friday April 12
>      * List of Government Witnesses Expected to Testify
>      * Schedule for Remainder of Trial
>  o Transcripts of the Frist Two Days of Testimony Now Online!
>  o Subscription Information
>  o More Information on CIEC and the Center for Democracy and Technology
>
>----------------------------------------------------------------------
>
>(1) GOVERNMENT TO BEGIN ITS DEFENSE OF CDA BEGINNING FRIDAY 4/12
>
>The fight to overturn the Communications Decency Act will enter its second
>phase on Friday April 12 with testimony from witnesses called by the
>Government in defense of the CDA.  The government is expected to call
>several witnesses (listed below) who will argue that the Communications
>Decency Act is necessary and is the "least restrictive means" of protecting
>children from "indecent" and "patently offensive" material on the Internet.
>
>
>Although the government has given some indication of its strategy for
>defending the CDA during the first three days of testimony (see CIEC Trial
>Bulletin No.7, 4/1/96), over the next two days we will learn a great deal
>more about the government's position.  The government is also expected to
>conduct its own Internet demonstration, and is likely to try and show the
>court examples of sexually explicit material available on the Internet.
>
>Witnesses scheduled to testify on Friday April 12 and Monday April 15:
>
>* Howard Schmidt, Supervisory Special Agent, Director of Air Force
>  Office of Special Investigation, Computer Crime Investigations
>  (Government Witness)
>
>* Dan Olsen, Professor of Computer Science, Brigham Young University
>  (Government Witness)
>
>* Albert Vezza (Associate Director, MIT Laboratory for Computer Science and
>  Chairman of the World Wide Web  Consortium), on behalf of the Citizens
>  Internet Empowermnet Coalition. Vezza was unable to testify at the April
>  1 hearing due to scheduling conflicts.
>
>Government witnesses will be cross examined by CIEC and ACLU lawyers. CIEC
>and ACLU lawyers will also have an opportunity to present rebuttal
>testimony during a hearing scheduled for April 26, and again in closing
>arguments scheduled for June 3.
>
>OVERVIEW OF EXPECTED TESTIMONY FOR APRIL 12 AND 15
>
>Albert Vezza, the last witness to be called on behalf of the plaintiffs,
>will explain to the court how PICS works and why it offers parents the
>ability to protect children from unwanted material in a less restrictive
>means than the CDA.
>
>Howard Schmidt is expected to conduct a live Internet Demonstration in
>which he will show the court some of the 'good' material on the Internet,
>as well as some of the sexually-explicit material available to minors.
>
>Dan Olsen is expected to testify that the PICS standards (which enable
>multiple, third party labeling and content selection) are too cumbersome
>and will not be effective.  Based on his declaration, Olsen will instead
>propose his own system under which content providers would tag material
>with a code (-L18) indicating that the material is not appropriate for
>those under 18.
>
>The government is expected to argue that such a content labeling system
>would be an appropriate "good faith defense" to prosecution under the CDA.
>Interestingly, it is not clear from the language of the CDA that such
>system would constitute a "good faith defense" to prosecution, or what
>material would require a tag. These issues will be raised by CIEC and ACLU
>attorneys during cross examination.
>
>SCHEDULE FOR REMAINDER OF THE TRIAL
>
>April 12 - 15   Government Witnesses (and final CIEC witness)
>April 26        Plaintiff's Rebuttal Testimony
>May   13        Post-hearing briefs and proposed findings of law and
>                fact from both sides will be filed
>June 3          Closing Arguments (each side is given 2 hours)
>
>CDT will post a summary of Friday's testimony shortly after the testimony
>concludes for the day (and after we travel back down to Washington DC).
>Previous issues of CIEC Trial Bulletins are available on CDT's world wide
>web page (http://www.cdt.org/)
>
>-----------------------------------------------------------------------
>(2) Transcripts of 3/21 and 3/22 Hearings Available Online
>
>Transcripts of the first two days of testimony are now available online.
>Transcripts of the 4/1 hearing will be posted soon.
>
>To view the transcripts, visit:
>
> http://www.cdt.org/ciec/transcripts/index.html
>
>-----------------------------------------------------------------------
>(3) Subscription Information
>
>As CIEC members, you have been invited to join this list in order to
>receive news updates and other information relevant to the CIEC challenge
>to the Communications Decency Act. To subscribe, visit
>http://www.cdt.org/ciec and join the Coalition.
>
>If you ever want to remove yourself from this list, send email to
>
>   ciec-members-request@cdt.org
>
>with 'unsubscribe ciec-members' in the SUBJECT LINE (w/o the 'quotes').
>Leave the body of your message blank.
>
>-----------------------------------------------------------------------
>(4) For More Information
>
>For more information on the CIEC challenge, including the text of the
>complaint and other relevant materials:
>
>* World Wide Web                      --        http://www.cdt.org/ciec/
>* General Information about CIEC      --        ciec-info@cdt.org
>* Copy of the Complaint               --        ciec-docs@cdt.org
>
>* Specific Questions Regarding the
>  Coalition, incuding Press Inquiries --        ciec@cdt.org
>
>* General information about the
>  Center for Democracy and Technology --        info@cdt.org
>
>--
>end ciec-update.8
>4/11/96
>

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Fri, 12 Apr 1996 10:46:50 -0700
From: Jon Drukman <jsd@cyborganic.com>
To: Troy Sheets <tsheets@xanadu.cyborganic.net>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Cc: sf@cyborganic.net
Subject: Re: Negativ

At 9:58 AM 4/12/96, Troy Sheets wrote:
>I was kind of disappointed with the negativland show at the Troc.

Me too but not for the reasons you cite.

>  I think
>the worst part about it was that people were not DANCING.  This was
>mostly due to the fact that the music was not DANCABLE.  I guess
>there can be shows where people don't dance... but I just don't enjoy
>those types of shows.

That's a pretty narrow attitude and will get you nowhere in life.  I've
been to many enjoyable shows where the point was to WATCH the spectacle
being presented.

Hell, The Residents did a gig in an auditorium where there were SEATS...
imagine that... I sat down THE WHOLE TIME... and it was one of the best
experimental music shows I've ever been to...

>It seems funny that Negativland, who seem to be into the whole "the entire
>country is programmed by television" would do a show where everyone is just
>standing there mezmorized, hypnotized, zombified watching them.  You
>could stay at home stare and a tv and be brain-dead... or you can go to the
>troc, stand around and stare at Negativland and be brain-dead.

The difference is that Negativland (on a good day) give you something to
THINK about while you "stand around and stare".

(Last night was not a good day for them... I'll get into why later.)

>This is in contrast to a band like say, Front 242 who combats television
>complacency with driving body-gyrating sounds.

F242 are about as pre-packaged and formulaic as Madonna, in their own way.
You could quite easily say that Madonna combats TV complacency with
driving, body-gyrating sounds.  People do dance at Madonna shows as well...

>It seems like Negativland
>wants to battle complacency with.... more complacency.

That is totally false and pretty much antithetical to the whole spirit of
the band.  See http://sunsite.unc.edu/negativland/ for info.

>Then, on top of all this, you are in "the troc", a club where it seems
>nobody ever has a good time.  Too many people, all standing around...
>drinking, smoking... I guess I just expected something else.

I've seen Negativland twice before last night.  First time was at a
cafeteria at Hampshire College, second time was at a small club in San
Jose.  Both times were pretty spectacular and mind-blowing.  I think when
Negativland are left alone to be themselves, they are godlike.  I don't
know whose idea it was to shackle them with the Hardkisses and Jonah but it
was really lame.  Scott and Jonah's ideas of collaboration seemed to be
"play music as if DJing or performing live and ignore everything else
that's happening."  Neither of them seemed to show any sort of sympathy or
involvement with Negativland, which was a real shame, but it was pretty
much what I expected.

At least I got to see The Weatherman live finally...

ReSent-To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

I just thought I'd pass on a note to those of you wondering why I might ask
$10.00 for a cassette, or just in general let you future DJ wanna be's know
what your in for.... 
 
I just calculated how much I have spent on records, cd's and cassettes so
far this year. 
 
(thats 100 days.....) 
 
on cassettes I have spent     $ 767.97 
 
on 12" singles                        $1123.51 
 
for a total of                           $1891.48                    thats
approx $600.00 per month 
                                                                           
                            or $150.00 per week 
 
that doesn't include the $200.00 I spent on mailing my tapes to the U.K. 
 
and I don't even consider myself a working DJ, it's more of a hobby, 
 
well not entirely, I've recieved at 4 parties (out of about 20 gigs so far)
a total of $320.00 this year to date........ 
 
I hadn't noticed till I got layed off from my job........so folks next time
you see a dj (like me) hawkin tapes, help spread the music, the vibe and
the wealth.......cause I'm goin broke givin out too many free
tapes............ 
 
                                                                           
        thanks...........moonpup

--- Nancy wrote:
I think of raves in terms of pink and baby blue.  It's Disneyland, full of
toys and happy children, with many psychedelic rides.  It's innocence.

<snip>

Or maybe all of these experiences (raves, bondage) are one-dimensional, made
more intense for their singularity, easier to explore only particular aspects
of our selves.
--- end of quoted material ---

Hmmm. What, then, do you think of hardcore/evil (not happy) gabba and
rotterdam? Of Lenny Dee and DJ Skinhead? Of giving tracks names like "Kill More
People" and "The Realm of Darkness"? (Not to mention "Cocksucker," "I'm the
Fuck You Man," and "Fuck Them")

I think maybe in the global "rave" scene, there's a harder, darker, or more
aggressive side that's not as apparent on the west coast, or in SF, at least. I
mean, having events called "Nightmare" and "Terrordrome" says something,
doesn't it?

Just a thought. (Please don't shower me with flames about negativity...)

--- Jess Fogler wrote:
Thanks for the feedback but I can't quite figure out how you know what 
style it is if you haven't heard the disc or Sasha......raver's intuition??
--- end of quoted material ---

Well, it was just a guess, the same way I'd guess that if you heard Mars (the
F-8 one, not the NJ one), you probably heard cybertrance, even though I haven't
heard Mars spin before (and I'd have a harder time defining cybertrance). And
if you heard Ron D Core, it was probably acid. Derrick May and techno. Lenny
Dee and hardcore. DJ Rap and jungle. Keoki and a bad attitude. =) Just like how
people on this list who've never been to (and now maybe never will) Acme might
associate it with the image of a hot, sweaty deathtrap. It's not raver's
intuition, they've just heard and read about things from other people. But one
time I was at Acme, downstairs watching Astral Matrix perform (I think), and
the crowd was fairly sparse, so it didn't seem too hot to me. Does that make
all those people who think Acme is unbearably hot, wrong?

I would have to totally disagree with you. I spent at least 5 hours working
there, and there was a big fucking chill room in the back, we created a
tunnel that feel apart, but there was a ton of bean bags and feathers and
stuff. Spun didn't go on until after tony, and Donald Glaude, Dan, and Tony
and Spun and every other Dj there went off! The Music was fucking amazing.
The 2.50 water was being sold by the skate rink. There rules not Kundalinis.
They didn't want cigs or whatever else. The music was low because it would
have been shut down if it was louder, there were apartments 20 feet from the
building. The lazers were amazing too. I really enjoyed the light show... I
talked to the guys doing it and they were totally going off! I thought the
vibe was cool...Everyone was real friendly. I wasn't down with the circle
dancing but some people felt the need to show off, (anyone check out the
karate guys?) Well anyway, I think Jeff and Rich should be commended, they
both threw a really good party. If you all could hear what Jeff was thinking,
about the party meaning so much to him, and people enjoying it.
Peace,
Jonathan
I 'm so gone...I have been awake since 12pm two days ago, and i think I lost
my mind....

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Apr 14 16:14:50 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id QAA29149; Sun, 14 Apr 1996 16:14:50 -0700
Received: from cti02.citenet.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id QAA29137; Sun, 14 Apr 1996 16:14:39 -0700
Received: from [206.123.34.212] (g34-212.citenet.net) by cti02.citenet.net (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA23507; Sun, 14 Apr 96 19:14:32 EDT
Message-Id: <v01510100ad971017b446@[206.123.34.196]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Sun, 14 Apr 1996 19:23:24 -0500
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: ecto@citenet.net (ecto)
Subject: quebec massives (from shawna) (long)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hey again all!

Well, went to my first actual quebec rave last night, quite large!  Not
quite as big as the Gathering I went to in december, but over 1000 people
I'm sure.

Main most annoying difference:  these people love to buy Vicks vapor rub
and slather it all over themselves and run around like that!  Boy does that
stuff stink, and since everybody's into it there's no escaping it.  After a
while the smell starts to burn your eyes and you have to go in search of
clean air.  They use it like we use lotion, giving each other massages with
it, I dont know how they can deal with the bad smell and burning eyes.
They really should discover plain ol ordinary lotion!

Anyway, the vibe is completely different.  The vibe we're all familiar with
from sf is definitely not there, this is not a warm & mushy bunch of
people!  The whole thing is very hard-edged, actually.  People chill a lot
less in the chill room, people don't really smile, & they certainly don't
just start talking to you (unless they're trying to hit on you or
something).  That entire vibe is definitely not a Quebec thing.  However,
having been a little forewarned by Brad as to how raves here operated, I
wasn't really expecting it anyway, so I was not disappointed by not running
into happy smiling ravers who'd spontaneously give you a hug.  And
actually, I had a really kick-ass time at this party, because one thing
they do have here is HARD music!  This includes all genres, hard trance,
techno, house, and I'd swear they had hard ambient!  I really don't hear
enough of this stuff in SF, this was a real treat! :)  I couldn't stop
dancing all night, I would literally have to make myself stop so I could
rest & get water (party done without "indulging" incidentally).  Basically,
the music was so good (imho) that even after the fact that all I had eaten
the previous day was 1 muffin, and I had partied & indulged the night
before, I still kept going hard till about 6-6:30 the next morning!  Now if
music can do that alone, I'm *very* impressed! So now I've just gotta
figure out how to get the sf vibe here and the montreal music to sf! :)  I
didn't like the ambient room so much tho, like I said I swore it was hard
ambient, which wasn't what I wanted in an ambient room.  When I needed to
make myself stop dancing, & would go to the chill room, what would I
encounter but more music that'd make me dance again! Not what I was looking
for.  One thing that really sucked was having to stand out in line for 1
1/2 hours while it snowed! :(  That was really obnoxious.  Only the music
made any of the rest of the party worthwhile, & it did a fantastic job of
it, but I still definitely prefer sf parties!  They had one of those
shuttle buses too, like the Gathering.  This was nice to not have to drive
there & back, as I don't like driving in other countries cuz I don't know
the rules very well (esp since it was snowing), but apparently this is the
only way they do things as far as actually getting to the party is
concerned.  I hafta agree with Brad that it is definitely missing a certain
element of surprise & adventure when you just walk out your door, hop in a
bus, and are deposited at the rave.  No having to find map points, make any
phone calls to find where the party's gonna be, no frustrating ordeal
trying to follows incorrect directions given thru the party's voicemail,
etc.  While these things may sound negative, I still kinda enjoy having to
actually put a little work into getting to a party! Like with that Harmony
party a month ago or so, where you had to get a presale ticket which was
only to the map point, and then you could get to the party from there, this
did ensure that only people who *really* wanted to go would be there, not
just bored people who don't know what to do with their friday night, which
is what last night's rave was filled with.  People who rolled outta bed,
thought "Hmm.  Wonder what I'll do tonight. Oh there's that bus, guess I'll
go check out whatever rave that is."  Altho I do have to comment, there is
definitely a vibe at the party I went to, albeit a very different vibe from
what I'm used to.  This was the vibe of a huge crowd of people who were
*really* enjoying the music & boogying their asses off!  Even if these
people were a bunch of assholes, I still really enjoy watching other people
really enjoy themselves.  The bored people who hopped on a bus to see
what's going on sat on the sidelines looking bored, but the people on the
dance floor emitted this very powerful, kind of hard-edged vibe that I
actually enjoyed.  Makes you even more likely to get off your ass and dance
that much more.  Definitely a crunchy party.

anyway, I've blithered enough, hope to attend a nice vibey sf party soon,
but I've just gotta figure out how to get this music back to sf with me!
Anyway, see y'alls later!

Love,
Shawna


p.s.  Despite the size, an incredibly small amount of rave drek!  One point
for Montreal on that one!

>I think of raves in terms of pink and baby blue.  It's Disneyland, full of
>toys and happy children, with many psychedelic rides.  It's innocence.
>
><snip>
>
>Or maybe all of these experiences (raves, bondage) are one-dimensional, made
>more intense for their singularity, easier to explore only particular aspects
>of our selves.
>--- end of quoted material ---
>
>Hmmm. What, then, do you think of hardcore/evil (not happy) gabba and
>rotterdam? Of Lenny Dee and DJ Skinhead? Of giving tracks names like "Kill More
>People" and "The Realm of Darkness"? (Not to mention "Cocksucker," "I'm the
>Fuck You Man," and "Fuck Them")
>
>I think maybe in the global "rave" scene, there's a harder, darker, or more
>aggressive side that's not as apparent on the west coast, or in SF, at least. I
>mean, having events called "Nightmare" and "Terrordrome" says something,
>doesn't it?


I haven't heard any of that kind of music.  ("Terrordome?"  Yuck.  All of
our parties have names like Harmony, Family, United...)  Maybe the Bay Area
is an oasis - it definitely is all about peace, love, positivity and
respect out here.  But the Bondage experience did get me to
ruminating...seeing all these people glorying in darkness and evil --
everywhere was black, metal, hard hard music.  Perhaps that side needs
expression, just as the innocent child needs expression.

But expressing it in the rave atmosphere is sacriligious to me.  Negative
lyrics, I think, would just be so
jarring, so out of place.  The music induces a trance, and it has always
amazed me that there are no real lyrics, no silly superficial story being
told.  If there are words, they are things repeated, like "deeper" or "feel
the love" or some sentiment so deep, so real, so spiritual...  "Fuck you
all" just would not fit with vibe created at all!

>
>Just a thought. (Please don't shower me with flames about negativity...)

Now why would I do that? ;)

Love from the left coast,
Nancy

>stuff. Spun didn't go on until after tony, and Donald Glaude, Dan, and Tony

spinning because they just saw his name come on the screen. i guess they
were mistaken.
however, i felt the music was only average. maybe it's just because i'm used
to another sort of music. read shawna's message (via ecto) today and you'll
see what i mean. music so hard it pounds your body like a jackhammer, and
you can't help but move. 

>The 2.50 water was being sold by the skate rink. There rules not Kundalinis.
>They didn't want cigs or whatever else. The music was low because it would
>have been shut down if it was louder, there were apartments 20 feet from the
right. i should have mentioned that the people selling the water were
wearing roller-rink shirts.. obviously kundalini wasn't making the money off
the water. i thought it was great that no one was smoking inside! it helped
keep the air much more breathable. :)
as to the music, my point about the speakers is that it was inadequate to
only have one bank of speakers for such a large space. if you have more
speakers, you wouldn't have to blast the music as loud to reach all areas of
the location, etc.. at one point i was up close to the speakers and the
treble was painfully loud, i had to move back. most of the night the volume
level was perfect (for dancing) if you were in the front 1/3 of the building.

>building. The lazers were amazing too. I really enjoyed the light show... I
>talked to the guys doing it and they were totally going off! I thought the
the lasers had some good effects going on. i liked them too. the point i was
trying to convey was that with a $20 ticket price, there should have been
more visuals.

>karate guys?) Well anyway, I think Jeff and Rich should be commended, they
>both threw a really good party. If you all could hear what Jeff was thinking,
>about the party meaning so much to him, and people enjoying it.
well, i agree. kudos to jeff and rich for putting on the event. even though
it wasn't the greatest for me, it obviously did give a great experience to
others, and that's what it's all about.

brendan

On Sun, 14 Apr 1996, Brian Salter wrote:

> >> The film projections were really cool.  Lots of old EE movies and stuff.
> >> Did you see that one movie where they were explaining orders of magnitude
> >> by zooming in on this guys's hand... to his skin texture, to his cells,
> >> to his chromosomes, to his DNA, to the atom, through the electron shells,
> >> and finally into the nuclius...  with the order of magnatude (in meters)
> >> displayed on the screen too.... then they zoomed out into the universe,
> >> with orders of magnatude going up.  I saw that film in a physics class
> >> in college... very cool.
> >

> >

hey there everyone,
	Boy i5t has been a long time since I have posted here but finally 
pulled myself away from the schoolwork and my computer and decided to go 
out and see sven vath at 1015 folsom last friday...WOW, that guy really 
kickedc my but, i danced harder and faster than I have danced in a long 
while! It was such a great release, the hard pounding technoo...whew! I 
went there with a good friend of mine, we hung out and had a beer then 
once sven came on  we chilled out for a while just listening and getting 
into his groove, after a little while, he really just started pumping in 
the juice and I couldnt andnd it anymore and completely lost it and had 
the time of my life dancing until my jeans were soaked with sweat:p...
	Unfortunately, once sven weas done we couldnt make the transition 
to the slower sf house groove and we decided to call it a night...well 
that is my review I hope you enjoyed it.

FASTER FASTER! tony rose

From: nancys@uclink4.berkeley.edu (Nancy)
Subject: Ravers In Love
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Here is a tale of ravers in love...of a boy and girl going to a rave
together with a mutual friend...and the boy warming the girl's heart with
his floppy hat and big happy smile, and how he ran all around the party in
glee and bounced up and down on the dance floor...and the two then going to
Sunset, and Mad, and Chrysalis...of sitting in a car the morning after for
four hours, still soaked in sweat and covered in sparkles, discovering that
the love they shared for raving was based on their deepest personal beliefs
and experiences, and the bond that created between them...of touching each
other for the first time with Orbital playing softly in the background...of
knowing that they found each other because of the openness of their hearts
and the willingness to give love a chance...

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Apr 14 20:26:01 1996

X-Sender: nancys@uclink4.berkeley.edu (Unverified)
Message-Id: <v02130501ad977ad20b6a@[128.32.91.99]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Sun, 14 Apr 1996 20:25:22 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: nancys@uclink4.berkeley.edu (Nancy)
Subject: My Weekend/Rave Drunk?
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Friday:  With greatest disappointment that we would not spend the evening
at Harmony, we did the usual: co-op party in Berkeley.  Heard killer ska
band; got injured in the pit (I am perversely proud of my bruises).  DJ's
spun hip-hop - I stayed out of the dance room.

Saturday: The usual, again: a party at a different co-op.  DJ spinning
happy house in a room appropriately called "the Dungeon."  Its heat and
tiny size drove us out, though we wanted to dance.  Outside a band dressed
as astronauts with capes and tin foil on their heads ground out some
noisecore as drunken punk rockers looked on and screamed.  We decided to
head out to a little private warehouse partee.

I hadn't planned on going to this get-together precisely because of the
atmospherE.  Not that I mind that type of thing at all ;), but I didn't
want to partake this particular evening and at this point I was pretty
buzzed off of a stronger substance - alcohol.  I have never mixed alcohol
and raving, and in fact have come to believe that the primary reason our
vibe is so special is the ABSENCE of alcohol.

But we went anyway, and when we got to this party the music was going OFF!
I love dancing to trance, I love dancing drunk, and this was the first time
I had both together - and it was GREAT!!  We were in a fabulous mood, the
music sounded unbelievably intense, and we danced and danced and danced.
My friend turned to me and yelled, "We should rave drunk!!"  Before last
night that would have been heresy, but now...?

Often I have encountered the problem of choosing between a very intensE
experience or utter sobriety.   But e's too expensive, acid lasts 24 hours,
speed's addictive, sobriety makes you sleepy...Maybe now I'll bring some
beer bottles along with my water bottles...?

Subject: Kundalini review 2

Precedence: bulk

I had mixed feelings about this one =3D 20 bucks :(
Well there was no bass at all. It sounded like there were pillow over the
speakers.  It just wasn't loud enough for me to get into the music.  I
thought Tony, Dan and Quest did a really good job.  I liked the effect of
the lasers in this big rink.  A little too big for a good vibe.  Everyone
was so spread out there was no interaction.  People seemed to be too far
away to make body/eye contact, which too me helps to create a good energy
between the people and a good vibe.  I met a lot of friendly people - no
sfravers though :(.  I would say there was about 700 - 1000 ppl there.
This was a good party just not a memorable one.  I don't think I want to
bay this much for a massive again untill maybe Gathering again.  Ohh yeah!
one thing that really bugged me was Bagok tribe recruting partiers for
their mailing list.  I got bombarded for an hour in the beginning by 3 guys
with clip boards =3D "Did you go to Lucky Charms, bro?" 'No' "OOH man you
missed out - It was phat.  You wanna get on our mailing list for our other
parties." 'No, sorry bro.'  "Come on, were gonna have a free party soon."
Well sorry but I will pass.  I got this solisitation for about an hour and
got really anoyed with it.  Come on, Recruting at another party. Well I
would talk mo' but I have to work.  See ya soon

I had mixed feelings about this one.  For one thing it was 20 bucks.
Well, there was no bass at all. It sounded like there were pillow over the
speakers.  It just wasn't loud enough for me to get into the music.  This
is what we pay for and go to hear(well at least I do).  You can't book a
party next door to an apartment complex and have satisfatory sound levels
to please and move the crowd.  I thought Tony, Dan and Quest did a really
good job and I danced mostly during their sets.
    I liked the effect of the lasers in this big rink.  A little too big
for a good vibe though.  Everyone was so spread out there was no
interaction.  People seemed to be too far away to make body/eye contact,
which too me helps to create a good energy between the people and a good
vibe.  I met a lot of friendly people - no sfravers though :(.  I would say
there was about 700 - 1000 ppl there.  This was a good party just not a
memorable one.  I don't think I would pay this much for a massive again
untill maybe Gathering.
   Ohh yeah! one thing that really bugged me was Bagok tribe recruting
partiers for their mailing list.  I got bombarded for an hour in the
beginning by 3 guys with clip boards saying =3D "Did you go to Lucky Charms,
bro?" 'No' "OOH man you missed out - It was phat.  You wanna get on our
mailing list for our other parties." 'No, sorry bro.'  "Come on, were gonna
have a free party soon."  Well sorry but I will pass.  I got this
solisitation for about an hour and got really anoyed with it.  They were
promoting a big free gathering and I think they will have way too many
people show up at this free gathering to accomodate the space(assuming of
course it is outside).

I heard about a bay area underground sat 27th. called Meridian.  anyone
want the number? =1B (I was told not to post it directly to the list though,
so anyone interested email me)

Peace

______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
Subject: little drummer people
Author:  Michael <Michael.Minnich@bankamerica.com> at Internet
Date:    11/04/96 15:12


Forgive me if this topic has already been hashed out on sfraves, but I feel 
the
need to address this almost uniquely San Franciscan phenomenon.
     
How do people feel about those folks who cheerfully lug their drum collections 
along to just about every mid-to-large sized party, plunking themselves down 
either in the middle of the dancefloor or near the dj in order to bang out 
their own accompanying tribal rhythms for the duration of the evening?
     
As you may have guessed, I've already made up my mind on this issue and 
generally find their presence annoying for the following reasons:
     
1.  I don't like to hear every track, from acid to new york house to trance, 
turned into a "tribal remix".
     
2.  Something that I doubt any of these drummers realize is that no matter how 
skilled and precise their drumming may be, if you go about 15 - 20 feet away 
from them, the drumming sounds *completely* off rhythm from whatever the dj is 
playing, due to such factors as the echos created by high ceilings and 
concrete, the fact that there are 2 - 4 groups of speakers versus one drum 
(which is often off to side, outside the "cone of sound" described by the 
speakers).
     
3.  I understand that not every dj may feel this way, but I tend to think of a 
dj's set as *his* or *her* own personal performance.  Some djs are true 
masters
of control, able to hypnotize a crowd and then work it into a frenzy.  When 
there are other performers besides the dj, he loses that control, and unless 
they are working in synergy, the result is weak.  For the same reasons, I even 
think that it's a little rude for someone  to assume that everyone is as 
excited about  bongo drums as they are.  I mean, drums are loud; you can 
usually hear them throughout an entire party.  Would people feel the same if 
someone brought their bass guitar and amp, plugged in, and started jamming 
along, or if an aspiring vocalist brought along a microphone and amp and starte 
d their own vocal accompaniment?
     
I know there are probably some djs who would welcome it.  Derrick May, when he 
played at that party (I forget the name), brought along his own drummer.  So 
if
these freelance drummers are so eager to perform, why not approach djs or 
promoters and be a real part of everything, get hooked into a mic that goes 
through the dj's mixer so that everyone can hear their precision and skill, 
and
then after a two hour set, put down the drum and go dance or something.
     
I'm curious to hear other people's points of view on this, especially djs.
     
By the way, I honestly don't have any real hostility towards drummers or 
anything, just spouting off.
     
inhuman@ghetto.love


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Apr 15 05:48:23 1996

Jess-
 i've been a large sasha fan for the past four years.  i just got back fro the 
UK and i heard him a couple of times.  his style used to be more house related, 
hands-in-the-air music, mostly stuff with alot of piano breakdowns and the 
like, but like the music he has also progressed.  i've heard that essential mix 
CD myself and it's great.  
 sasha of late has been moving towards a more progressive style of music.  more 
melodic trance stuff(Brian Transeau-BT), less handbaggy, garage style music.  
personally, he's my favorite foreign DJ hands down.  if you want more sasha mix 
grooves, check out the older stuff on moonshine records.  he did one half of 
the mix on the first stress release, he also worked with another great uk dj 
named john digweed on a 3-CD mix set from the Renaissance Club, and he mixed a 
wonderful track of 3 songs on BT's album Ima.  
 has anyone else heard sasha live?  reply's would be wonderful!
-todd

Alcohol?  Poisoning our scene?  Boooo!  Nooooo!  Please say it ain't so :(
It's so symbolic of American society, it's a wrecker of families, destroyer
of lives.  A drunk driver killed my father in a head-on collision four days
before my eighth birthday.  How I hate it!!!  And I've seen too many people
at raves trying to be cool with their beers in hand.  Security loves to
find ravers with beers, wait till they crack 'em open, and confiscate them
after just the first sips (that's what a security person told me this
weekend).  It is my strong belief that alcohol would corrupt the purity of
the scene.
Now, a little good wine, on the other hand, might be very joyous, though
harder to bring to a party...

Pass the water!

- E

At 5:08 PM 4/12/96, Le~ Steph wrote:
>This Friday night April 12th
>
>D.J. line-up (in this order)
>Simon
>Jeno
>Spun
>Narayan (from Phillidelphis)
>
>Doors open at 11:oopm Close at 6:00 am $10 zucks
>
>The party is NOT going to be at ACME, but the Map Point is!


I promised myself I wouldn't post until I got some serious work done, but
this just has to be said:

Where the hell did these guys find 400+ under-18 kids, and why the hell did
they stuff so many of them inside that hot, hot (as in heat, not "the bomb"
hot) space (is it 937 Minna?  Minna between 10th & 11th.)?  I shit you not,
they must have flyered all the high schools in the Bay area to find that
many kids willing (or not I guess) to wait an hour to go to the bathroom,
sweat profusely and pose.

Don't get me wrong, I love people of all ages (really I do), but I felt
sort of like a chaperone at a high school sweat-a-thon.  However, I just
pulled my hat down a little further and said "hella" a lot and no one
pointed and said, "Hey!  Who let in the 20 year old?!"   ;^)  I danced for
about 20 minuets and realized that it just wasn't going to work.

Fortunately a friend let me upstairs (thanks Sweety!) which was much nicer
and I stayed there for a bit and then split, weaving my way through the
bathroom line that I swear started somewhere near the sound system.

The real question is though...why was I there for an hour?

TR

P.S. Indicator #1:  If the kids working the map point weren't on speed,
I'll be missing you all this summer while I'm in Altanta on the US
Basketball team.  Eye contact was so out of the question, they had trouble
looking at Hamilton's face on my 10 spot.

;^)

Wow -- what a great story! It gave me such an awesome flashback to
those first magic moments with my girlfriend, lover, soulmate, and
life partner, Jamie. We had known each other for a couple of months
prior to last New Year's Eve. At a private rave, we, for the first
time, we touched and felt each other's warm energy.

The following weekend, at Wicked, we fell in love, drinking in each
other's pleasure. While we were on the dance floor, she revealed a
chocolate peppermint candy in her mouth, and we had the sweetest,
yummiest, most sensual kiss amidst the vibe set to the beat of Doc
Martin. It was very clear for both of us that we had surrendered our
hearts to each other very openly -- this was definitely not a
love-at-first-sight kind of thing.

-G

> From: nancys@uclink4.berkeley.edu (Nancy)
>
> Here is a tale of ravers in love...of a boy and girl going to a rave
> together with a mutual friend...and the boy warming the girl's heart with
> his floppy hat and big happy smile, and how he ran all around the party in
> glee and bounced up and down on the dance floor...and the two then going to
> Sunset, and Mad, and Chrysalis...of sitting in a car the morning after for
> four hours, still soaked in sweat and covered in sparkles, discovering that
> the love they shared for raving was based on their deepest personal beliefs
> and experiences, and the bond that created between them...of touching each
> other for the first time with Orbital playing softly in the background...of
> knowing that they found each other because of the openness of their hearts
> and the willingness to give love a chance...

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Apr 15 11:14:47 1996

Received: (from ausman@localhost) by soda.CSUA.Berkeley.EDU (8.6.12/8.6.12) id LAA19812 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Mon, 15 Apr 1996 11:14:40 -0700
Date: Mon, 15 Apr 1996 11:14:40 -0700
From: James Ausman <ausman@CSUA.Berkeley.EDU>
Message-Id: <199604151814.LAA19812@soda.CSUA.Berkeley.EDU>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Sunset review (sorta)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Another great Sunset at the Marina. It started sort of late (4ish), don't
know why. There where very few people there, even then: I thought I had gotten
the place confused or something when I walked up. People started drifting
in as the afternoon progressed and there were probably 3 or 4 hundred
by nightfall.

The music was loud enough this time. Pacific often is a little too quiet,
even for these sensitive ears, but this was juuust right. It was some sort
of undancable stuff early on (maybe this is on purpose?). Only one brave 
soul was dancing for the longest time. Finally, about 5:30, I decided
to join him just as the music changed to something a little easier to
dance to. After dark, it changed to housey dancable beat and everyone
left was out there dancing. I will let someone more knowledgable about 
out the music fill you in on DJs and all that. Before I realized it, it
was 10 o'clock, and we were still dancing. Maybe because we were all
having such a good time, maybe the daylight savings change, whatever
it was, the time snuck up on all of us, I think. 

A crack crew of us scoured the place for trash and things seemed mostly
finished up and out of there by the time I left at 10:30 or so. Still no
sign of The Man (park curfew is 10, right?). 

I was kind of low energy and this is the only thing I did this weekend,
but the vibe was in effect. If I only do one thing all week, I want it 
to be this. Thanks Pacific!

Peace Out,
Jim

From: sequoia1@ix.netcom.com (Chris Chervin )
Subject: Record reviews!  mostly trance.
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello again,

Just thought I'd finaly get around to reviewing some of the records 
I've picked up recently.  All of them were scored at Frequency-8 
records on upper Haight.

Platipus Records--Volume Two :  If you haven't heard this on yet than 
you are missing out!  I could be wrong but I think we will be hearing a 
lot of music off this set in the near future.  Features PHAT tracks 
from Union Jack and The Art of Trance as well as remixes by Man With No 
Name.  10 tracks on the record, I'm not sure how many on the CD.


Eat Static--Bony Incus :  Eat Static evovlves with the times and comes 
out with Jungle and Trance at one time!  This double set which only 
cost me $13 is splendid.  Man With No Name has a remix on the trance 
record and Mucor has a remix on the Jungle one.  Excellent music 
throughout.  

Flying Rhino Records--Green Nuns of the Revolution  :  HARD ACID!!! 
This stuff sounds great at 33 or 45 but when you get it going at 45 it 
will just eat your brain away with some seriously insane Acid sounds. 

Etnica--The juggeling alchemists under the black light  :  This is 
smooth trancy mellow music perfect for chilling and trancing to.  

Dragonfly Records--Experiments that Identify Change:  pretty hard 
trancy double set featuring "jack-in-the-box" by Man With No Name.  
This song is so smoothe!

A list of other good trancy records:

Koyote records--encens

Dragonfly records--Phreaky

Symbiosis records--Trancewave

Psychic Deli records--Subcouds

Love chris

Well, not quite worth 20$ IMO.  The music was melodramatic.  From about 1
to 3 the music would build for a few minutes then turn into sirins or stop
or something.  It was quite annoying and impossible to dance to without
getting frustrated.  But the music got increasingly better later on.

Jondabomb, those weren't karate guys-  They were playing capoeira, an
afro-brazilian martial art-- Capoeira is what originally inspired
breakdancing.

It was so wonderful to dance in a smoke-free environment.  This was the
highlight of the party for me.

Krishna

Perky boobs flying everywhere

From: epaul@Synopsys.COM (Eric P. Peterson)
Subject: Re: Female responses to compliments
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Kirsten,

        Thanks so much for your thoughtful response.  You are an amazing
person!  You reminded me of something of which I am deeply ashamed, and I
wanted to share it with you, and with everyone else, since you've made this
public.
        When my younger sister Wendi was becoming a young woman (we're five
years apart), she listened to my ignorant, narrow-minded, teenage boy ideas
of what was beautiful in a woman.  She has brown hair, and heard my MANY
offhand comments that blond hair was the best.  She would hear my comments
about what was and was not attractive in a woman's figure, make-up, etc.
So, she spent lots of time and went to lots of trouble to try to make
herself "more beautiful", unfortunately following what her big brother
thought.  She really believed that she wasn't beautiful, just because she
didn't fit my distorted vision.
        Wendi confided this all to me recently, and it nearly broke my
heart.  She arrived at a point herself along the way where she became more
comfortable with her natural self (as all people should, IMHO).  It has
occured to me that what I did helped to propagate the ignorant,
narrow-minded view that many people have of what constitutes beauty, and
that disgusts me, so I hereby apologize to everyone for being part of that.
I want it known that I love and accept everyone just the way they are, and
focus far more on someone's inner beauty than on the wrapper.  Thank you
for your attention.

Most humbly yours,

- E

u are very right about not all scenes globally being all love and 
happiness.  what i have discovered in my expeiences with the "rave scene" 
is that the further west u go, the nicer it gets.  not necesarilly better 
or worse, just nicer.  it depends on what u are looking for.  do u want 
hardcore intensity with a little bit of a chill?  go north.  how about 
everybody free dancing, but not really interacting with too many others 
that they don't know too well?  midwest.  and from what i can see here on 
sf raves, if u want a family unity and love style, go west.  it's all a 
matter of taste, or mood maybe.

just some thoughts....

luvz and sunshine,

sarah f.

On Mon, 15 Apr 1996, George Feil wrote:

> Wow -- what a great story! It gave me such an awesome flashback to
> those first magic moments with my girlfriend, lover, soulmate, and
> life partner, Jamie. We had known each other for a couple of months
> prior to last New Year's Eve. At a private rave, we, for the first
> time, we touched and felt each other's warm energy.
> 
> The following weekend, at Wicked, we fell in love, drinking in each
> other's pleasure. While we were on the dance floor, she revealed a
> chocolate peppermint candy in her mouth, and we had the sweetest,
> yummiest, most sensual kiss amidst the vibe set to the beat of Doc
> Martin. It was very clear for both of us that we had surrendered our
> hearts to each other very openly -- this was definitely not a
> love-at-first-sight kind of thing.
> 
> -G
> 
> > From: nancys@uclink4.berkeley.edu (Nancy)
> >
> > Here is a tale of ravers in love...of a boy and girl going to a rave
> > together with a mutual friend...and the boy warming the girl's heart with
> > his floppy hat and big happy smile, and how he ran all around the party in
> > glee and bounced up and down on the dance floor...and the two then going to
> > Sunset, and Mad, and Chrysalis...of sitting in a car the morning after for
> > four hours, still soaked in sweat and covered in sparkles, discovering that
> > the love they shared for raving was based on their deepest personal beliefs
> > and experiences, and the bond that created between them...of touching each
> > other for the first time with Orbital playing softly in the background...of
> > knowing that they found each other because of the openness of their hearts
> > and the willingness to give love a chance...
>

At 9:36 AM 4/15/96, Jess Fogler wrote:
>Fair enough.
>
>Oh and by the way, I happen to like acme too.  Does that make me strange?
>



Actually, I like the Acme myself, the two parties I went to there
(chrysalis & harmon) were amazing.  There's really two aspects of the acme,
how it's set up for the party, and the safety/heat issue.  For a party set
up, I think it's great, cause it has all those different rooms.  This way,
even with 900 people, every time you go into a room, there's a little rave
going on in it, rather than 900 people all in one huge room.  That way you
end up with several small vibey parties all interconnected into one big
party, and you can choose any one you want.  Also, every time I've been at
the Acme, they've decorated it absolutely beautifully!  Both chrysalis &
Harmony were gorgeous! :)  For these reasons, I find it tragic that it's
such an unsafe place and so overheated, along with owner problems, of
course.  I hope they can find another place with those qualities I really
dug about the acme without all the problems.  (altho oddly, I remember that
at chrysalis, I got so cold I had to put on a jacket. (!?)  Now if it's
possible to get that cold at the Acme, how is it they could never get it
that well ventilated other times?)

Shawna

From: noah@cadence.com (Noah Ruiz)
Subject: Re: Suggestions for mixers/turntables?
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Well I bought my tables used for $700.  And an MTX MX-35 mixer new. All
together about $840.  I suggest not getting the MX-35 I have had trouble
with the crossfader since I've had it.  Its on its second crossfader, and
thats already bleeding and getting scratchy.  I don't know about other MTX
mixers, but this one bites.  I'm saving up for a RANE MP-24. =)
If your just learning you don't need no sampler/effects/laser/fog machine
on your mixer.  Just go simple but get quality!

Late,

Noah

From: Michael <Michael.Minnich@bankamerica.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: out-a-sight: a positive spin?
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I guess I was the only person who had a great time at out-a-sight friday
night.  Sure, the space was hot and overcrowded, but I still managed to find
plenty of room near the front to dance.  One thing that usually drives me
crazy
at larger spaces with two or more rooms is that inevitably the main dance
floor
will lie in the direct path of some other destination such as the bathrooms or
the chillout rooms, so people are constantly plowing through the dance floor
to
get somewhere else.  That at least was absent at this party, since the dance
floor was at the far end of the space, farthest away from the entrance.
Personally, I thought the vibe was great; I met lots of people and saw lots of
smiles.  I think it was because everyone I ran into was on E, but you can't
really fault that.

Yes I was drenched with sweat all night, but that didn't stop me from
thoroughly enjoying terrific sets from Jeno, that guy from Philly, and Spun
(the beginning anyway).  Am I the only one who actually gets some pleasure out
of extreme physical exertion?

And this whole age thing is so ridiculous.  I've met asshole 16 year olds,
asshole 18 year olds, asshole 21 year olds, asshole 30 year olds, asshole 40
year olds, etc.  In my grand and elevated wisdom as someone who has survived
his teenage years, I conclude that age doesn't correspond to anything.  The
only thing that age seems to bestow upon people on this list is further
disenchantment with the rave scene.  A party is only as good as you make it,
no
matter what.  File this one under taking more personal responsibility.

Youth is wasted on the young?

Good parties are wasted on spoiled San Franciscans?

Don't make it true!

As usual, take this post as nothing more than my monday morning catharsis.

inhuman@cal.polemic.edu

(altho oddly, I remember that
>at chrysalis, I got so cold I had to put on a jacket. (!?)  Now if it's
>possible to get that cold at the Acme, how is it they could never get it
>that well ventilated other times?)


The doors, the number of people and fans.  Fans and number of people are
rather obvious, in that you need several big ones of the first, and lots of
little ones of the second ;^) (a little short joke there).  As for the
doors, it's hard to keep the small door open, when working the
line/entrance and stuff, sometimes the garage door can be opened, but
usually later in the party.  You being cold was most likely due to the
garage door being opened a bit.

It's a little out of the organizers control (especially when there are lots
of people in da house), much like the dance studio at 24th and Mission,
though they are working on better ventilation there.  Acme is moot at this
point, right?

Tony

At 8:02 PM 4/14/96, Nancy wrote:
>Here is a tale of ravers in love...of a boy and girl going to a rave
>together with a mutual friend...and the boy warming the girl's heart with
>his floppy hat and big happy smile, and how he ran all around the party in
>glee and bounced up and down on the dance floor...and the two then going to
>Sunset, and Mad, and Chrysalis...of sitting in a car the morning after for
>four hours, still soaked in sweat and covered in sparkles, discovering that
>the love they shared for raving was based on their deepest personal beliefs
>and experiences, and the bond that created between them...of touching each
>other for the first time with Orbital playing softly in the background...of
>knowing that they found each other because of the openness of their hearts
>and the willingness to give love a chance...



That's nice that that actually could happen!  I do the above-described like
*all* the time, but it never seems to have anything to do with love in that
respect (like "in-love" kinda love).  Hmm.

Shawna

Oh, the visuals!  Now they fucking rocked.  Very cool film projections were
being shown on the far wall, the whole wall, with a rotating color wheel
behind them lighting them up, making it look like a really cool sort of
moving trippy PhotoShopped design.  I was lucky enough to check his
equipment out and I was trippin' on the fact that he had film going from
one machine to the other unprotected and looped a couple feet down a wall.

At 1:49 PM 4/15/96, Michael wrote:
>And this whole age thing is so ridiculous.  I've met asshole 16 year olds,

You're right, and there wasn't a "thing" that I was trying to start.  I was
remarking on just how many younger individuals that were there.  In no way
would I ever want to project the image that the FACT that it was made up of
many younger ravers (and non-ravers alike) would have anything ANYTHING to
do with the vibe.  I didn't even say the vibe was bad (in a general sense,
for me it was too crowded and hot to get into MY vibe).  I firmly believe
that all the things I saw that were trouble spots with this party were in
the sheer number of people, and I've shared email with Stephanie about it
and hopefully, we are communicating clearly and honestly.

Please let this server as email nipping that thread in the butt.  Er, I
mean bud ;^)

To know me is to know that I feel raving, parties and the positive energy
we have to share should be spread to any memebr of our society that is
willing to accept it.  Young, old, I have raved with them all and loved
most every minute of it.  In fact, I was remarking to more than one person
(both ravers and non-ravers alike) about the amazing number of (amazing)
children (read: 5 year olds) at Sunset and how I love to see that.  Not
only are they honest ("You have no hair!"), cute, cuddly, funny, and fun to
play with, they help let people know that we are not some vagabond group of
drugs fiends, but rather made up of families, friends, and are responsible
contribting beautiful people that have much love to offer.

Peace Ya'll

Tone
:^)

	have travelled from Pekin to NY! SF is the only city where the
	streets are 4000kms large :-)

Hi!
 I tend to disagree with Eric on the drinking issue despite the fact that 
alcohol was a contributing factor to my fathers death (when I was sweet 
16 ;) ), and a direct cause of my grandmothers death (whom I was very 
close to) just a couple of years ago. Also my sister has a drinking 
problem which cause's her to give her boyfriend fat lips and scare our 
mother. And I basically don't like the stuff that much (I average about 
2 beers a month and a shot of tequilla once every 2-3 months)
 However I do not feel it is the drug that is the problem but the 
motivation for drinking and self control of the individual. Under the 
proper conditions, for certain people, booze can be a transcendent 
element of one's experience. Let's stop blaming the things we create for 
ourselves and take responsibility (and control) of our own personal 
experiences.

Ran @ Dionysus Dreams

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (San Francisco Raves)
Date: Mon, 15 Apr 1996 22:20:23 -0500 (CDT)

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hiya Guys!

It's been a few months since I had to unsub from sfraves and I have to tell
you it's good to be back and feel the warmth of the SF spirit.  I've been
gone for so long, probably a brief re-introduction is in order.

I am a musician/dj in Austin, Tx and I've been raving since 92.  What
brought me to raving was the music, what kept me coming back was the people. 
Never before in my life had I felt so free, content, loved, and complete
than in a rave environment, and all this from people who didn't even know
me. :)  But the scene in Texas was really not much compared to what you guys
have, but it was still better than anything I'd ever seen.

Finally, a friend of mine started Txraves and our small family grew and
grew.  We would have pre-parties for raves with 40+ people, all from the
net, many meeting for the first time.  It was such wonderful bliss.  The
scene grew and grew til we were having parties with thousands, not hundreds. 
Then there were those few parties that were just out to cash in on trusting,
innocent, adventurous souls and people began to mistrust what was happening. 

Peace, Love, Unity, and Respect were replaced by Cynicism, Apathy, Mistrust,
and Fear.  (CAMF!  Heh heh.  Anyway...:) ...Txraves soon began to mirror
this trend until finally it became everything that I started raving to get
away from in the first place.  COMPLETE lack of respect was the norm.  I
began to see posts with subject lines like "F*** YOU (person's name
here)!!!"  I never once tried to shake the notion of "PLUR" in anyone's
face, in fact, it became so bad that if you mentioned PLUR, some people
would post to the list that PLUR is a bag of sh**, and anyone who believes
in that crap is a fool.  I hated to leave.  I had stuck through literally 
dozens of ugly, ugly flame wars trying to hold my family together, but that
fight was just making me miserable.

So now I am reaching back out.  I have kept my closest friends and anyone
else who still had a desire to love and live life as one of the happy
people. :)  As it stands now, our closeknit group has taken it back
underground and is keeping to smaller parties (which I prefer most of the
time anyway.)  I believe too much of anything can be a bad thing.

Anyway, I've missed the openness that you guys share here.  I got used to
closing myself off from the world just trying to avoid those people who are
looking for *anything* to start a scuffle.  I just couldn't live like that
anymore.

Sorry this has been so long.  I didn't intend this to be therapy, but thank
you for listening anyway.  My purpose in sharing all this, was not to be
depressing... I just wanted you guys to know how special you are, not that I
feel like you needed me to tell you that. :)

vibrating at the speed of love

solarvibe
      .od8888bo.        solrvibe@bga.com  http://raves.com/solarvibe

Dear Randy:

I agree with you.  Addiction can be to anything.  Abusive
behavior runs through my family as well; however, unlike how it seems  in
your family, the addictions have ranged from cleaning to drugs to alcohol
to food to sex.  Pretty exhaustive heh.  We shouldn't criticize the use of
alcohol in the scene, only if it destroys the vibe.  However, I would
qualify the statement by saying that in my observation, the type of person
who has used drinking in the scene vs. other things or nothing has usually
not been the person I would hang with.  Too voyeuristic or detached from
the vibe for my tastes.  Only my opinion. ;)

Cassandra

  On Mon, 15 Apr 1996, Randy C
Cone wrote:

> Hi!
>  I tend to disagree with Eric on the drinking issue despite the fact that
> alcohol was a contributing factor to my fathers death (when I was sweet
> 16 ;) ), and a direct cause of my grandmothers death (whom I was very
> close to) just a couple of years ago. Also my sister has a drinking
> problem which cause's her to give her boyfriend fat lips and scare our
> mother. And I basically don't like the stuff that much (I average about
> 2 beers a month and a shot of tequilla once every 2-3 months)
>  However I do not feel it is the drug that is the problem but the
> motivation for drinking and self control of the individual. Under the
> proper conditions, for certain people, booze can be a transcendent
> element of one's experience. Let's stop blaming the things we create for
> ourselves and take responsibility (and control) of our own personal
> experiences.
>
> Ran @ Dionysus Dreams
>
>                                       (wow)
>                                         /
>                                     =*=/
>                                      ~
>

In reply to Michael's message, I have to say that getting the most out of
rave is our personal responsibilty as long as the promoters have created a
safe and welcoming environment.  The people who attend raves do need
somerthing to work with when trying to enjoy a personal experiance.

Cassandra

P.S. On the question of age, a group of my friends and I were discussing
the age at which someone should be introduced to consciousness altering
drugs.  One conclusion seemed to be that under 21 or even 25 was too young
because one's identity was not developed enough yet to derive the right
lessons from the experience.  What do you think?

Precedence: bulk

--------SVEN -------

Just had to add another note of how over-the-top Sven Vath's set was Fri at
Nikita. Except I can't find words to describe it! I had high expectations
after seing him salvage an otherwise abysmal ENIT festival at the Warfield
last August (high expectations can sometimes lead to dissappointment), but
the music and the vibe (at least near the front) were so much more than I
anticipated, I'm still digesting it.  Definately on my top 10 list! If you
were able to watch him you could see he was enjoying the evening as much or
more than everyone else.  It's great to see a DJ enjoying his job.
Hopefully he'll come back soon and do one of his famous 12hr sets (3 hrs
just left us wanting more). Thanks Spundae for great music (as always).

Did anyone go down and see him in LA Sat?

Did anyone else enjoy the visuals as much as I did? The Dimension 7 group
seems to outdo themselves each week at Nikita.  The giant balloons with the
projections seeming to come out from inside of them were sooo trippy..and
the laser with cool shapes and pictures were fun to watch (love the alien
face, the globe, and the messages that flash almost subliminally...was that
an ad for Progress?) I kept switching my attention between Sven and the
sights up above (those are the kind of dilemmas I can live with).  Keep up
the good work!

I'll remember this one a long time..... jd         :)   :)    :)

....

Whats up all...i ve waited a couple weeks to post, seeing that thats the
"nice" way to do things so here i am... My name is Mark from NYC, you might
now be asking why the hell is a east coaster on the Sf raves list.. well ive
djed out there twice in the last year ( most recently Lucky Charms on March
30th) from which i read was not to well recieved ( ill get to that soon)..
but being in many different cites in the US from spinnin..i totally fell in
love with SF, the people, the parties, the weather :) so i figured id sign up
 so i can trick myself into pretending im there. Now about Lucky
Charms...being that i dont "live" out there i dont think i have any right to
defend the "party" with the complaints i read about... but i will tell you
what i thought of it from my standpoint...First and foremost the Promoter of
the party was in no way "sceemin" for the money aspect..i know that..what
happened at the mappoint is hard to blame on anyone...I will tell you this..
he had no idea in hell that over 3000 ppl would show up so he was definatly
takin by suprise... thats all ill say on that..oh one more thing i know that
the cops showed up several times early in the night and that he didi
everything to keep the party goin.. in which he did.... so...also the "vibe"
aspect.. to me it seemed real good, people dancin their butts off and
smilin....but bein from the east coast any vibe is "good"  hee hee :)... i
spun After TONY at 2am til 3:15 am. tell me what ya thought if you
remember..:).. also talked to many promoters about bringin me out again so
hopefully ill see ya all soon...If you r interested in my newest mix tape
"STIMULATE" or my set from Lucky Charms let me know ill send a bunch out
there..just e-mail me at djmarkbee@aol.com OR NJUNDRGRND@aol.com.
Hope everyone is having a good sping so far.... talk to ya soon....

peace,plur..
Mark Bee
NJunderground....

ps.. is the weather nice?   :)

Hi everyone,
Synethetic Pleasures is coming to town with the SFIFF and lots of other
great movies.  Synthetic Pleasures should be an interesting commentary
on [modern] society.  Check out the little blurb below or the longer one
in the SFIFF catalog.  The sound track is layered with "trance and
Belgian disco" (yow what a combination!).  I'm going to the Sunday
screening with panel discussion.  Maybe I'll catch some SFravers there!!?!?!

BG

   
>HAPPENINGS
>
>Synthetic Pleasures SF Debut 
>
>Is reality obsolete? From low-tech function like body piercing and
>artificially-stocked fishing pools, to the latest in bionics and VR
>gaming,this cyber-age intellectual survey--call it a
>*.DOCumentary--downloads a Future Shockful of data and defines the
>parameters of advanced technologies that delete nature and reprogram
>mankind. Cryonics defy death; the Internet exists outside time and space;
>smart drugs and surgery upgrade the mind and body. But are we headed toward
>human optimization, or system crash? Timothy Leary, RU Sirius, Lisa Palac,
>John Barlow and others offer sound bytes against a mesmerizing screen
>display of cutting edge computer-graphics, location footage and archival
>clips. Exhilarating and disturbing, Synthetic Pleasures raises issues nobody
>today can afford to abort / retry / ignore. The film is showing at San
>Francisco's Kabuki Theater Friday, April 19 at 7:00 pm and Sunday, April 21
>at 3:30 pm. The Sunday screening will be followed by a panel discussion
>hosted by director Iara Lee and producer George Gund with RU Sirius, Lisa
>Palac, Douglas Rushkoff, David Pescovitz.
>

> I tend to disagree with Eric on the drinking issue despite the fact that

>2 beers a month and a shot of tequilla once every 2-3 months)

self-control; seems the more one drinks, the more control one loses, then
that person tries to believe her/himself still capable of doing routine
things, tries, and fails miserably oftentimes...it's serious business, and
should be handled seriously.

>P.S. On the question of age, a group of my friends and I were discussing
>the age at which someone should be introduced to consciousness altering
>drugs.  One conclusion seemed to be that under 21 or even 25 was too young
>because one's identity was not developed enough yet to derive the right
>lessons from the experience.  What do you think?

I was nineteen when I first experienced anything other than alcohol, which
my family introduced to me at about age ten, and I felt that I should have
experienced it sooner.  I think sixteen is the absolute youngest age that
someone should investigate, and then only if that person is mature and has
some understanding of her/himself within.

Subject: comments on SF and Sven... (fwd)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Tue, 16 Apr 1996 10:10:59 -0700 (PDT)

Hello, this is a forwarded message from Andy, a freind of mine from socal
who came to visit SF.  If you have comments, I am sure he would like
to hear from you at:

andy@intelenet.net


------------------------------------------------------


> Hey So/NoCAL...
> 
> I just had to comment on the SF scene thread on the list a few days 
> ago...
> 
> Well, I went up to SF for my first time (for pleasure) this last weekend
> with Zeke as my personal tour-guide.  :)  The primary reasons were to go
> shopping for records, and most of all, to catch Sven at 1015.
> 
> My first contact with the SF scene was some e-mail that I received from
> some very nice folx up there offering to get together for coffee, a
> place to crash, and just to say welcome to SF.  I thought if the scene
> consisted of people like this that it HAD to be good, and sure enough,
> my hunch was correct!
> 
> It's funny how everyone that wrote me before my trip up there warned me
> about the 1015 location, but I felt that the people and the vibe there
> was just fantastic!  Nothing like the Metropolis atmosphere that I kinda
> expected.  Maybe it was cuz Sven was playing that night, or if I was
> just immune to my surrounding environment, but whatever the case, I had
> no complaints whatsoever.  [Well, except for this one idiot bartender next 
> to the DJ booth who was a total asshole.  Kinda looked like a reject from 
> a bad Kung Fu movie -- he was probably from LA anyway.  :)] 
> 
> So, we grab some coffee and grub at Farley's, then head over to 1015
> around midnite -- Sven had JUST gotten on.  The place was packed!  Nice
> visuals and a decent sound system setup in the main room (I don't even
> know what was going on elsewhere).  Anyway, we weave our way to the
> booth to pay our respects to the Lord of Trance!  Zeke then goes, "hey,
> that's not Sven, it's some guy with spikey blonde hair."  Well, it
> actually was him -- just turns out that Sven now has hair!
> 
> He started off his set with some real minimal stuff for the first hour,
> then the rest of the night (til 3:30), he played some incredible music
> -- beats nice and hard, and the mixing flawless.  It's funny cuz he was
> just as much and audience as he was the DJ -- putting the next track on,
> taking off his headphones, then dancing his ass off with the rest of
> us!  He finished off his set to a massive applause from the crowd, then
> gave it up to Simon, who was spinning some magnificent house (definitely
> won't be putting me to sleep) when we left.
> 
> Anyway, I wanna keep this relatively short, so I'm gonna wrap this post
> up by saying the following...
> 
> First, THANK YOU to all sf-ravers (and the SF scene in general) for
> making my first experience a most enjoyable one!  I wanna say hi to
> everyone I met there:
> 
> Carol S. -- hey, maybe we'll hook up next time at Farley's
> her friends (sorry, I forgot your names) -- wish I coulda danced
> 	with you guys a little longer
> Juliet -- it was great you actually found me there, and hope you
> 	have a wonderful time in Europe!
> Leslie -- too bad we couldn't hook up, but I think I saw your
> 	friend Bill
> Crunch -- it was great grooving in front of the DJ booth with
> 	you for a little while
> Vivian -- she was too busy causing trouble on the list... just kidding.
> 	:)  We'll hook up next time for sure
> John (from Wisconsin) and passenger (sorry, forgot your name) -- thanks
> 	for the near-death experience  :)
> Tom and Brad -- hey, you passed up some good Goa... the offer's still
> 	good if you change your mind.  Thanks for the cool ODP north.
> Adam (from F-8) -- can't wait for you to come down for Ohm and
> 	Heliotropic.
> Troy -- thanks for posting my messages, and hope we can hook up up there
> 	next time.
> Zeke -- thanks for putting up with me and being my tour-guide.  Hope we
> 	can go again soon.
> to everyone else I met -- sorry if I forgot you.
> 
> and finally, a BIG BIG BIG THANK YOU to....
> 	Superstar Hosts Wayne and Marcie!!!  EXTREMELY cool people who 
> let us crash at their place and experience the one and only Wayne's
> World!
> 
> Can't wait to head back there again!
> 
> PLUR the SF style!
> Andy
>

From: Milton Cecil <moonpup@hooked.net>

Date: Tue, 16 Apr 1996 11:05:16 -0700 (PDT)
Message-Id: <199604161805.LAA26165@also.hooked.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: too many choices
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

you know I'll get flamed for this but here goes anyway......... 
 
.........trance music is cool, but.........it's not my favorite, so I don't
go where I know thats what will be played. 
 
on the other hand deep house with wailing diva's isn't to my liking either,
so I don't go where thats predominately what I'll hear......... 
 
..........I feel that if you like trance .....go to trance clubs, or create
your own trance outdoor party, but it gaulls me that here in San FRan where
we have so many choices of styles and DJ's, that people are compaining that
sunset parties etc....don't play enuff trance etc..... 
 
house music is and always will be the cornerstone of our scene.....it may
branch out into.........deep, techno, garage, acid, breakbeat, triphop,
gabber, jungle, happy hardcore, whatever........you should be so f*cking
lucky to have it ALL, we are one of the most diverse cities in the world,
and our music, and dj's reflect that........ 
 
jesus F*cking christ.......what the hell do you want....all trance all the
time.......boring, boring boring......... 
 
............just like triphop (my personal fav) all the time.....boring.
It's the variety that makes it so wonderful 
 
lets cut sunset some slack, I think it's one of the best vibes I've ever
seen. but people dis it because it's not playing "trance".........how
completely rude and insensative. 
 
I would venture to bet that those people who dis the music (within our
family) are the same people who might leave their garbage for the promoters
to pick up......no respect. 
 
.......I don't think it's all about the music, it's about the vibe that a
posse can create, and I give a round of applause to sunsets (and Galen) for
being able to pull off the parties with seemingly little hassle from the
authorities, and I feel it's about time we respect what is played.....even
if it's not our favorite "STYLE" of house........ 
 
I feel in addition that until you can respect that ALL the club and dance
music we hear is closely related (like a distant cousin) to the ORIGINAL
house music that came out of chigago back in the day.........it was gay
blacks making music for gay black audiences, and until a DJ can understand
and respect that aspect of history, you can not fully appreciate any kind
of music that is rave related.......a dj must understand what they are
playing and why............and fully respect the background and evolution
that brought us to styles like "trance" 
 
this is why guys like Garth, Jeno, Doc Martin, Markie Mark, and Thomas has
been around for so long, (yes they can all spin incredible sets) but if you
notice, they all have that cornerstone and understanding in their
music.......they have never abandaned the original history, and play to an
audience's sense of history...... 
 
........even I have had trouble understanding the vibe, and the styles, and
how I can manipulate the stuff, that only I like.  It has taken years to
respect and honor the tunes 
 
I still (in some peoples opinion) don't fully understand, and I've been a
DJ for over 10 years. maybe it will always be a growing experience, and I
will never get it, but you won't see me sitting here dissing other DJ's or
other styles of music that I may not particularily like, rather, I will
continue to buy what turns ME on. 
 
I'm lucky, as a DJ, I can program exactly the styles I like, and do. but I
would be bummed to sit here and listen to someone dis my shit because it
wasn't "trance" 
 
In short, (too late for that)........I would love to see more people take
charge of there own destiny and create a party that plays trance, rather
than dis someone elses succesful attemt to bring you the vibe as they see
fit...........(aka sunsets) 
 
in addition we are all different ages and at different places in our life,
and have different values and priorities, we have different reasons why we
like this or that,  
it's ok to like one style of house and not another, it's not ok to dis the
creators of a happy vibe.........more power to the sunset parties and more
power to you as an individual 
 
just imagine if we all liked the same thing how boring this world would
be........all the Dj's would still be playing elvis presley or big band,
etc.......evolution and diversity are the very freedom that allow us to
express ourselves as DJ's.......... 
 
i will stop my ramblings here, and I truly don't know (other than crunchy
dude) who is dissin the non trance vibe, but take a look at the bigger
picture............trance is merely another hybrid of house......wouldn't
it be boring to only hear trance all day and night everyday and
everynite......just as house can be boring all day long everyday etc.....it
is the variety that makes it so interesting.........and in SF you are lucky
to have a major variety of styles to pick from...............as well as
some of the best DJ's in the world who bring it to you.......be happy and
respect a posse for what it is.....not what it isn't 
 
                                                                           
        .....moonpup

On Tue, 16 Apr 1996, Eric P. Peterson wrote:

> I find it interesting that so many people regard house as the definitive SF
> sound, and yet (especially among members of "The Crew") so many people
> remark about how much they loathe it.  What's with the contradiction here?

different strokes for different folkes...

Basically in SF, HOUSE RULES, and this has pretty much always been the
case. Over the last couple of years things have diversified a bit (a good
thing imo), and now there are lots of alternatives for the non-house
crowd.  But as far as a "definitive SF sound", I don't think there is one. 
There's something for everyone, if you can't find it you probably just
need to look a little harder... 

The SF scene everyone knows and loves was built on House music, sometimes
I think people forget that.  Granted House isn't for everyone, but even
those people should understand and respect the enormous influence it has
had on the scene and "the vibe" in SF. Personally, I wouldn't want it any
other way...

Andy

Two unrelated topics in one concise post:

Sven Vath was outrrrrrrageous and 1015 looked amazing last saturday.  
Good visual, good vibe, danced with some lovely people.  However, the 
mixed crowd was weird for me.  It was strange to see people swaying to 
techno with margaritas in their hands.  I agree with others that it isn't 
the alcohol itself which changes the vibe, rather the people that tend to 
abuse it.
