Yep, moonpup, you'll get flamed for your ranting about trance etc....

but I have to agree with your points here ...  it's pretty amazing how spoiled
we all get! I'm catching myself getting more and more picky about music, and I
don't know how to move myself into a more open perspective, rather than a more
specific and refined taste....

... because when we limit our expectations, we miss a lot of good stuff...

.. many of you know I'm a big house-head --- I went to Club Universe last week
(yep, crazy cruisy gay club) because Little Louie Vega was spinning -- it was
four hours of the most wonderful, deep, funky, dance your butt off music --
awesome and totally a blast... 

... but I also go to occasional trance parties, partly because so many people I
like love trance, so I get to spend time with them, and I'm trying to open
myself up to appreciate the beat and energy of trance....

... and I'm trying to educate myself about other new kinds of music, too ..
because bottom line, I love music and what it does to me!

Yes, I know the feeling when you yearn for a different sound in the music... but
I have to agree about leaving the Sunset crew to create the party they want,
when they want, where they want ... and let them play the music that they feel
like playing at that moment!  The boat cruise showed the great repertoire of
styles they are happy to offer for our enjoyment, given the option of multiple
rooms ... but frankly, I'd much rather enjoy the gift they give us with their
outdoor parties!  Thank you Sunset!

Leslie  : )

hey all,

i have a humorous bit of prose for you all:

i work for a small DJ company that books lots of weddings, class reunions,
school dances, and the like.kinda boring because there is just a formula
to follow really when dj'ing those kind of parties. anyway.....

i called the owner today from my college dorm room. i told him i still wanted
to work for him this summer. he said great.  (this guy;s about late 30's)
he said "good news!  i went out and bought a 7000 watt JBL sound system
recently, also 55 feet of trussing for lights and a new array of intelligent
lighting."

i said, "that's wonderful, the business is really on the up and up!"

then he sorta whispers into the phone..." i was wondering if you would like
to do some semi-legal raves this summer when you come back."

*hahahahaha*

i chuckled, and said it sounded like a good idea. problem is, this man
has never been to a rave, he only believes they make tons of cash.
he is the nicest guy in the world but, if you were me, would you support
someone who doesn't understand.  his concept of a rave from what he's
told me is a teeny bopper dance party. i think i'd puke if i saw that.

well. good story huh?
(ugh, that kinda bombed........)


later all,
clinton
hoping the midwest has an earthquake and sinks into the sea instead of SF

I could have sworn we went through this crap last month. Sunset is great
"IMO"  Galen and the others are doing what they like to do. It is house
music. If people want to have Trance, gabber, ambient, jungle or whatever
then they should get everyone that has the same taste in music together and
throw there own parties. Why keep bringing up the Trance issue about Sunset?
Don't get me wrong, I like Trance myself, I actually have be spinning Trance
now for 5-6 months, but I also like House as well. Which I'm starting to get
more into and even spinning it alittle. Do you goto Wicked and complain that
they don't spin Jungle or Gabber? Wicked, correct me if I'm wrong, is about
house music. That's what they chose to spin and that what they choose to
spin at Sunset. So, if you want to hear YOUR favorite style of music, get
together with others and throw your own party.

Like the old saying goes, "You can please some of the people some of the
time, but you can't please all of the people all of the time."


Tim (knucklehead)

anyone expressing dislike for it, whether pertaining to a certain
environment, or to the form in general.  I guess I shouldn't be surprised,
and think of it the same way I think about more "popular" music: it's not
so much a regional thing as a matter of personal preference.

really the dominant form in this area, or was it just more exposed at a
certain point in time?

I would:

1) say "great! a semi-legal rave sounds like oodles of wholesome fun!"

2) take over all operations and planning while keeping your boss around as
an easy cash/equipment source.

3) Hire me to do a flyer (BSP! BSP!)

4) throw a ragin' party that establishes you as the
promoter-du-jour-and-beyond in the midwest

5) wake up and say "hmmm, what a nice dream that was. now back to the day job."

just my $.02...

but seriously, if someone has no idea what a rave _should_ be like, we end
up with ridiculous fiascos like LuckY Charms or Cyberfest...

>>>>>3 prescription pain pills and 1cc Ketamine.  He is said to not be
>>>>>scared of
>>>>>what will happen to him over the upcoming weeks.  He says death should
>>>>>not
>>>>>be feared.  To this end -- he is inviting everyone to tune in and
>>>>>watch him
>>>>>drop out.

Subject: I Think There's Something Wrong With Me...
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com

I think there's something wrong with me...  I like house music, trancy harder 
house is o.k. but not hard trance sets. I guess I just don't get it.  I like 
sunny days like last Saturday in the SF Persidio with happy dancin' people, 
friends, and conveniently located facilities.  I'm noticing that I don't make it 
through the whole night that often anymore but I still dance pretty hard whenever 
and wherever I go.  It doesn't freak me out to have to go to a club to hear a 
famous DJ nor that they serve ALCOHOL in such a club.  Heck, now that I think 
about it I think that given the choice I'd rather run into one of those Julio 
Iglesias no shirt with a jacket cocktail swillin' weirdos at a club at midnight 
rather than a speaker column speed freak with that far away look that can't stop 
at sunrise even though he wishes he could guys at a rave. Second thought they 
both pretty much suck but that doesn't make the music or MY vibe any different.  
I like running with my dog across the waterfront with a killer acidy house tape 
groovin' through my bones thinkin' how great it is to live here.  My dog loves 
house too I swear.  I'm happy that I make money finally and that I make it doing 
something that I like to do.  Hell I'm proud that I've been able to do both! That 
I took that shower and cruised into work the next morning and endured the torture 
rather than blow the day off and yet another opportunity. Heck, I like a lot of 
stuff!  

But I think there's something wrong with me...
  
Am I an SFRaver still or just a happy San Francisco raver?  Lately, it seems like 
the two are mutually exclusive. Maybe it's just me. Not quite sure if that makes 
any sense. 

- SUNNY
 (The Forest Gump of SFRaves)

On Tue, 16 Apr 1996, Milton Cecil wrote:

> you know I'll get flamed for this but here goes anyway......... 

	I don't know if this is going to a flame, but there is a 
statement in here that blankets a lot of people, and does 

> I would venture to bet that those people who dis the music (within our
> family) are the same people who might leave their garbage for the promoters
> to pick up......no respect. 

	I doubt this is the case because the two do not go hand in hand. 
After cleaning up after numerous sunsets, and watching the garbage that 
is left, way the garbage is I can make a few observations but none of 
them relate people saying that they would like to hear some trance on 
Sunday to leaving garbage. If people are coming out for the party even 
though they don't like the music, but instead to come see people, I would 
venture to say they are going to be a little more responsible for their 
trash as they are coming for a gathering of people instead of to party 
(see, its just as easy to draw the opposite conclusion based on the 
evidence at hand). I happen to find that a hell of a lot of trash comes 
from the picnic tables, from the trendy looking people's blankets (ok, 
that's a blanket statement and I probably offended a few, and I am sorry 
to those of you who don't litter and have the trendy fashion). I wouldn't 
mind hearing trance at sunset or even gabber when the sun went down I 
wouldn't even mind spinning that gabber (though the transition might be a 
little difficult). Now I have "dissed" Galen and the whole Pacific crew 
somehow because I have said I would like to hear something besides house 
I assume, but as many people can verify, I don't litter (anymore). 

> I feel in addition that until you can respect that ALL the club and dance
> music we hear is closely related (like a distant cousin) to the ORIGINAL
> house music that came out of chigago back in the day.........it was gay
> blacks making music for gay black audiences, and until a DJ can understand
> and respect that aspect of history, you can not fully appreciate any kind
> of music that is rave related.......a dj must understand what they are
> playing and why............and fully respect the background and evolution
> that brought us to styles like "trance" 

	Well, then, I think a DJ  had better understand disco and the early 
techno-pop... In fact, she or he better go back in time to experience it 
because one cannot get a full understanding unless they experience. 
Seriously though. Each DJ can spin whatever they want, and it is because 
we each take our own understandings and misunderstanding and wonderings 
and the like that each of us a different style. I don't spin house, and 
the vibe it tends to produce is one I like in the morning or at someplace 
where I am not going to dance because house does not bring out any forms 
of the energy that makes me move and why should I force myself to move? 
I don't see why Chris cannot ask if Pacific will vary their format, 
though I don't know if anyone from Pacific is on here so this may not be 
the correct place to ask. If Pacific does not want to have anyone play 
trance, it is their right. If they don't mind a second small system, then 
maybe I will talk to people about dragging a second on out. So that we 
can remain as a community all gathering on Sundays (eek... That is almost 
religious) but there will be something for everyone...

	I would still like to see multi-system parties with a 
house/trance area and a harder jungle and gabber area... I just need 
people to give the hard hard music a chance in the right environment...

dave

I split up these replies to make them more readable...

On Tue, 16 Apr 1996, Milton Cecil wrote:

> In short, (too late for that)........I would love to see more people take
> charge of there own destiny and create a party that plays trance, rather
> than dis someone elses succesful attemt to bring you the vibe as they see
> fit...........(aka sunsets) 

	Ok, here comes that whole, if you don't like the music, throw yer 
own party... And guess what, that does not work! Because it is too much 
of a shock to people here in SF it seems, to have both a new group of 
people throwing parties and a new style of music - ie, I could not come 
out and throw a party with gabber at peak hour AND have my brand new 
system pounding out tunes under a brand new name. It takes a lot of 
people to support some types of music, and you need an entry point to 
have lots of people. People who throw parties tend to not want to throw 
harder music out here because they don't know if the crowd will take it. 
So you are caught in a loop...


> ......trance is merely another hybrid of house......wouldn't
> it be boring to only hear trance all day and night everyday and
> everynite......just as house can be boring all day long everyday etc.....it
> is the variety that makes it so interesting.........and in SF you are lucky
> to have a major variety of styles to pick from...............as well as
> some of the best DJ's in the world who bring it to you.......be happy and
> respect a posse for what it is.....not what it isn't 

	Hmmm, SF does not seem to have this great variety ingrained too 
well. I have yet to go to a party besides Freinds and Family that has 
everything from house to gabber to electro... I have yet to go to a party 
in SF which ever has gabber and house in the main room in one night. SF 
has variety but it is not integrated and moving toward intregation at 
parties is something I would like to see, even if it at first it is with 
separate systems at the same party.
	And how do people work out what they want it to be WITHOUT saying 
things like "I wish sunset had some trance". If we all shut up and didn't 
say what bothered us, the scence would never progress and we would all be 
raver slaves with no input and soon, raves in SF would be house 
concerts... Well, that might be a bit of an exaggeration...

dave

On Thu, 11 Apr 1996, Nancy wrote:

>  It's Disneyland, full of
> toys and happy children, with many psychedelic rides.  It's innocence.  It
> allows us to get in touch with that inner child, that freedom, spontaneity,
> joy, self-confidence.  But shouldn't this process of getting more in touch
> with ourselves _also_ include sexuality?  In other words, is raving an
> experience that actually only connects us with _part_ of ourselves, not the
> whole?

	For many of us out here, raves are definitely not Disneyland. I 
know for myself and some of my friends, raves bring out a primal, 
primitive energy which is the same energy that comes out during some sex, 
though I must say the energy is not transfers as such, but it is what 
keeps us going through the night. It is a force that drives us to dance, 
a force which wells deep inside and makes a most intense experience. The 
faster, harder techno tends to bring this out the best, though if it is 
diluted with someone yelling "fuck you" or random swears it would really 
kill the effect. Its like this group release of the primal energy that we 
all have building inside somewhere. I think the last time I saw this was 
during Minor Minor's set way back in December at Chrylisis...

	There was this sound system in Edinburgh (ok I will make this 
quick) called Sativa that did a fortnightly club and some free festis 
(with a few other systems). In their club, for ~6 hours each Friday 
night, they ventured with you into that space and ended by 6 or 7 
drummers coming into the music and drumming on big bass drums, toms, a 
keg, and whistling, etc while the crowd gathered in closer and tighter 
and kept dancing....

dave

On Sun, 14 Apr 1996, shawna wrote:

> Anyway, the vibe is completely different.  The vibe we're all familiar with
> from sf is definitely not there, this is not a warm & mushy bunch of
> people!  The whole thing is very hard-edged, actually.
and then: 
>  Altho I do have to comment, there is
> definitely a vibe at the party I went to, albeit a very different vibe from
> what I'm used to.  This was the vibe of a huge crowd of people who were
> *really* enjoying the music & boogying their asses off!  Even if these
> people were a bunch of assholes, I still really enjoy watching other people
> really enjoy themselves.  The bored people who hopped on a bus to see
> what's going on sat on the sidelines looking bored, but the people on the
> dance floor emitted this very powerful, kind of hard-edged vibe that I
> actually enjoyed.  Makes you even more likely to get off your ass and dance
> that much more.  Definitely a crunchy party.

	Imagine that vibe on the dancefloor and the sf vibe in the chill
room, a great union of two worlds... And if we could get the bored people
(assuming they are bored and just not taking a break) into it, we would 
have a most wonderful situation...

dave

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Apr 17 01:00:44 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id BAA24700; Wed, 17 Apr 1996 01:00:44 -0700

Message-Id: <199604170800.BAA11579@netcom18.netcom.com>
To: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Fwd: roofies and rape?
Date: Wed, 17 Apr 96 01:00:52 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

yikes! comments?
------- Forwarded Message

ROHYPNOL

      1.  You DON'T need to take it with alcohol for the effects to work
      2.  It doesn't take 1-2 hours for it to take effect...only 10 minutes

RAPISTS SLIPPING VICTIMS MODERN-DAY MICKEYS

CHEAP PILL BLOTS OUT MEMORY OF CRIMES

MIAMI-Imagine all the fears of parents whose daughters have hit
dating age packed into one white pill the size of a dime.
It may be the mightiest Mickey Finn ever concocted.
And it is not the fiction of Sam Spade novels and Humphrey Bogart
movies.

These days, it costs about $3 at the high school water fountain.  It
is colorless, odorless and quickly dissolves in a can of Diet Coke.
In about 10 minutes, it creates a drunk-like effect that lasts eight
hours.  It enhances the effects of alcohol, causing loss of inhibition,
extreme sleepiness, relaxation and - perhaps worst of all for its victims -
amnesia.

The pill is made of a drug called Rohypnol (pronounced ro-hip-nol).
Your kids know them as "roofies."

  And police are concerned - particularly about roofie rape.

In Broward County, Fla., 10 men have been arrested on roofie-rape
charges in the past year.  The most recent came Feb. 1, when two brothers
and a friend were charged with repeatedly raping a 15-year-old girl after
they secretly put a roofie in her soft drink. A 26-year-old Broward County
man who pleaded guilty to roofie rape in a 1995 case - Mark Anthony Perez
of Plantation - told authorities he used it to rape as many as 40 women.
The problem has not been as prevalent in Dade County, where police
departments reported a handful of suspected sexual assaults related
to roofies in the past six months.

A 17-year-old Coral Springs girl raped Jan. 7, 1996 while she was
under the influence of roofies lost 10 hours between having dinner with
friends and waking up in a strange hotel bed.  Police are investigating a
29-year-old suspect who was at the dinner.

"Her panties were around her ankles and a condom next to her,"  said
the girl's mother.  "My daughter didn't know this guy.  She doesn't
remember a thing.  This man is a rapist and he's going around doing this
to other women," she said.  "I want people to know how dangerous this is."

"It's a big, big deal out there right now," said Bonnie Lashbrook, a
student peer counselor at Cooper City High School.  "Parents of teen-age
girls should be scared."

College officials also note a concern on college campuses.  Reported
sexual assault have increased and may be linked to Rohypnol.  Officials
estimate that this may just be the tip of the iceberg.  Since, the
victims suffer amnesia many women may have no idea that have been raped.

Rohypnol is a potent and hypnotic sedative used in some countries to
put out surgery patients.  They are prescribed as sleeping pills in
about 80 countries, but not the United States.  The emergence of the
once-obscure sedative has thrown police agencies for a loop.  Florida law
officers have seized tens of thousands of the pills in the past year.
Rohypnol is also easily available from Mexico and parts of Europe.
In one raid, the pills were packaged in vitamin bottles and labeled
in Spanish.  They were shipped from Colombia and distributed by two
suspects, said sheriff's spokesman Jim Leljedal.
It has proliferated to such a point that the Drug Enforcement
Administration and the Florida Department of Law Enforcement have
joined forces with police to have Rohypnol's status as an illegal drug
enhanced to make penalties equal to cocaine and heroin.

"It's just that we have a chance in law enforcement to get ahead of
this thing before it gets too out of control," said Cooper City police
Capt. Jim Harn, whose agency is investigating several roofie-rape cases.

The incident involving the 15-year-old from Cooper City happened in
June at a Sweet 16 party at the Merrimac Hotel on Fort Lauderdale Beach.
Charged with her rape are brothers Sidney Harmon, 19, and Scott Harmon,
17, of Pembroke Pines, and Moises Ventura, 18, of Miramar.  The Harmons'
mother has said her sons are innocent.  The Ventura family has declined
comment.  According to friends, Scott and Moises were inseparable friends
who like to start fights and cause trouble.  Sidney, who aspires to be a
paramedic, is a quiet, sensitive boy, friends say.

Erica Verriotto, 17, said she was good friends with all three boys
for over several.  "Scott was kind of a troublemaker sometimes, you
know?" she said.  "Nothing really serious.  He used to like, start fights.
You know, yell at people who cut him off in traffic and stuff." "But
Sid, no way," she said.  "trust Sid no matter what."

Cooper City detectives say several other girls have come forward
with similar stories about the group of boys, but no charges have yet
been filed.

"A lot of times the guys don't think they've done anything wrong,"
said Cooper City police Det. Kregg Lupo.  "This is not a rape in their
eyes They think if the girl is not awake or alert enough to say, `No,'
it's not rape."

Police say they were able to arrest the Harmons and Ventura
primarily because the rapes happened while the victim's best friend
watched - an eyewitness.  Another teen at the party said Scott and Moises
bragged about slipping the roofie into her soft drink.

Other roofie-rapes are more difficult to prosecute because of the
victims' loss of memory of the incident.  "It's very difficult making these
cases," said Dennis Nicewander, an  assistant state attorney in the Broward
sex-crimes unit.  "Usually these victims don't remember a thing.

"It's almost like the perfect crime,"  he said.  "Because they don't
have to worry about a witness testifying against them.  And don't think
these guys aren't figuring that out."


The drug also has the potential to make rapists out of men who
without the drug might not commit the crime, he said.
"Usually, they aren't the kind of guys who would force themselves on
someone for sex.  They seem to be the kind of guys you'd see at
happy hour with their buddies, the kind of frat-boy mentality that thinks
it's fun to get a girl drunk and have their way."

The drug also works it's way out of the human system usually within
24 hours, he said, which makes any delay by the victim a problem.
"Many of these kids start out in a compromising position to begin
with, then this happens to them and they are scared and embarrassed and
unclear as to what happened," said Stan Peacock, a Broward prosecutor.
"I have told my 17-year-old daughter never to accept a beverage of
any kind from anyone unless it is in a sealed container that she opens
herself," he said.  "Does that give you any idea how concerned I am about
it?"

------- End of Forwarded Message

think I'd want to hear gabber in the park, thank you very much. Perhaps
at a toxic dumpsite, but not Berkeley Marina (damn, i hate
contradictions)!

mucho, but couldn't put a label on it. Certainly not "house".

As I was hurriedly leaving at 8:40PM (arrgh -- i wanted to stay
longer!) I caught a phrase spoken by some clueless onlooker hanging out
on the sidewalk --  "I call this kind of music heavy metal techno"...
This made me laugh, because it was so completely off base.

>==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==
>=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=


Just more of the same.  There will always be someone somewhere who doesn't
lkike what is going on.  Whether it be too much house (a common complaint
here by some people), or too little house (a common complaint by some
DJ's), I've relegated myself to saying "Uh-huh" to both camps and let them
go their merry way.

I think there is plenty for everyone.  I also think some portions are
underrepresented musically (I won't even *GO* to the ethnicity; a flame war
every 2 months is about my limit), but think that if there was *really*
that much interest in a genre, if that can be easily defined, it would
start, and blossom into something  significant.

Techno? I always though FTT (Funky Techno Tribe), spun much harder shit
than other parties, I would even call it hard trance.  As for House music
(or deep house or whatever), there seems to be plenty of that as well.  The
real problem is music definition, which with house (i.e. house, garage,
techno, breakbeat, etc.) is even more difficult to define IMO.

At this point in my music appreciation, I just refer to things as
downtempo, uptempo, or use bpm's.  I have heard many a learned DJ say that
a track is 'deep house' when , to me, it is trance.  This stuff goes on and
on.  Tedious.  In the end either I like it, and buy it, or I'll pass.  I
could care less whther people call it Jungle, Jungle Sensibility, House,
Deep House, Trance, and all the flavors thereof, my rule is 'If I like it,
I'll buy it!".

Stuff I personally don't like is fast stuff (anything over 130 bpm's is
useless to me).  Yet I still like some of the Bass & Drums and plenty of
Jungle that is put out (some portions are well over 130 bpm).  Buy some of
it as well.  Music is good food.

If you like it play it, listen to it, etc.  If you don't, find someone who
is catering to your flavor and go for it.  If that still doesn't work, a
party of 10 close freinds is often good enough.  At least for me it is.

Outta here,
John

P.S.  This is the thread that will never die.  SFR list will always have
some people who don't like what is going on, or are unhappy with some
aspect of the scene.  I am no exception.  This thread though reminds me of
the BPM flamage that happens every so often.  So far though, even though
the discussion is cyclical, the flames have been kept to a min.  Is this
progress?  I'll wait and see.

Peace.

no flames moon :)

Why not? You never know what you might hear.
I used to be the exact same way...with house music. I used to hate it, with a passion.
Then one night i came down to a friends deep-phat-oldskool house night...i f*ckin loved 
it...the vibe was insane...I go every week now.
 
> on the other hand deep house with wailing diva's isn't to my liking either,

Well...no aruments there...but some ppl can have it go off for them...all the power i

House and Detroit Techno? Its a classic case of which came first...the chicken or the egg?
I had the opportunity (altho quite cloudy) to ask Derrick May about it when he came 
around...quite interesting. But to say House music started everything? Its a bigger picture 
than that.

        Heather Lynch <1LYNCHHE@UVSC.EDU>
Subject: Re: The welfare of ravers
In-Reply-To: <Pine.BSI.3.91.960410160349.26492g-100000@taz.hyperreal.com>

Dear Brian,

	I appreciate you taking the time to give me such a full 
response.  Since it is long, I will intersperse my comments with yours 
below...

My computer tells me that on Wed, 10 Apr 1996, Brian Behlendorf shared:

> On Wed, 10 Apr 1996, Starchild wrote:
> > Government authorities like yours have created a climate in this country 
> ...
> > You have created a bureaucratic process which deadens life
> ...
> > 	Well, despite your best efforts, there is a vibrant culture 
> > out here undreamt of in your commission studies, white papers, and 
> > environmental impact reports.
> ...
> > What you are engaged in is 
> > crimes against humanity -- not (yet) on the scale of those tried at 
> > Nuremburg, but crimes agasint humanity nevertheless.
> ...
> > 	Because we will always be with you -- even in the slave fields 
> > and the gulags we are with you. 
> ...
> > Hitlers and Stalins of the world 
> ...
> 
> Well, it's good to see we're opening a healthy dialog... er, wait, no, I 
> wouldn't exactly call that healthy... 
> 
> Seriously, Starchild, someone who took the time to personally respond to
> Heather has at least some sympathy and concern for her questions and this
> culture, and does not deserve the language you used on her. 

It may or may not be true that Susan Burke responded personally out of 
sympathy and concern for us.  Didn't she say she'd been asked to respond 
by someone else?  Also, I wouldn't be surprised if it was part of her job 
to respond to such inquiries.
	I agree that my language was strong, perhaps undeservedly so.  
But I stand by every single word of it.  While I could have communicated 
the same basic idea in a less confrontational manner, this does not 
detract from the truth of what I said.  Preventing people from enjoying 
themselves when they are hurting no one *is* a crime against humanity!

> If you really
> want to start a conversation, you have to start from understanding where they
> come from, what their knowlege of the situation and environment is, and not
> make any presuppositions of their intent.  In the above message you ascribe
> the many frustrations we have with a deliberate conspiracy to deprive us of
> happiness - which presumes an awful awful lot that just isn't substantiated. 
> 
I never intended to imply a conspiracy.  I'm saying that depriving us of 
happiness is the effect that the culture of government -- in which Ms. 
Burke is presumeably a willing participant -- has created.

> The tone of Susan's message, to me, was "play by the rules - get permits 
> - and you will be treated with respect from the government".  This is 
> true anywhere - you have to play by the rules to drive a car, you have to 
> play by the rules to do just about anything.  Sometimes those rules feel 
> pretty arbitrary or even just plain wrong, but sometimes they do make 
> sense, like limits on maximum number of occupants in a building.  I know 
> you are a staunch libertarian, and favor as few rules as possible, but 
> what will you tell me when the floor eventually caves in at the Acme 
> warehouse?  
> 
	This is a fair point.  Certain rules actually do follow common 
sense logic which when followed helps ensure safety.  But consider the 
reason *why* people get crammed into unsafe spaces like the Acme 
warehouse:  It is because government restrictions have made spaces in 
which to hold parties scarce, and because leaving the doors to the space 
open and allowing people to spill outside invites getting busted.  The 
Acme warehouse has a big garage door, and if this door remained open 
during parties it would alleviate much overcrowding and make the space 
safer, but that can't be because of the cops.
	Clearly having too many people in a building is unsafe, but we 
all know this, and are capable of making judgment calls for ourselves.  
There is no law against jumping around in your bathtub (as far as I 
know!) even though this activity would be extremely dangerous -- more 
people are injured in bathtubs than from accidental gunshot wounds.  But 
there doesn't need to be a law -- if you use your brain, you won't do it.

> The answer to this is to do what many people in different communities have
> done - approach the community authorities as equals, *respecting* their
> opinions and belief systems and mores, and working within them.  I do not
> feel that there is a fundamental disconnect between raving and the rest of
> the population.  I have seen too many cops come across a renegade party, see
> that it was safe, and decide to let it continue, to think that there is some
> biological switch that makes you one way or the other. 
 
I respect the opinions of people in authority, but I recognize them for 
just that -- opinions.  Not papal decrees informed by divine wisdom, or 
mandates that I must live by, just opinions which I try to follow when I 
think they are right and disregard when I think they are wrong.
	Of course cops do not bust *every* party.  Nor do I lump all cops 
into the same category.  Some cops are clearly worse than others.  But if 
one party gets busted for not having a permit, that's one too many.

> Show the Salt Lake community why raves have nothing to do with gangs (and 
> who knows, maybe in SLC there really is a problem with that - it was 
> certainly a problem in LA when I was there), why it is a safe 
> environment, etc.  Get a permit to have a daytime party on a Sunday in a 
> park in the center of town.  Go through the right steps to have at least 
> some of the parties 100% kosher with the local jurisdictions.  This has 
> *certainly* worked in many places, such as Richmond here in the Bay 
> Area.  
 
This whole thing with gangs is guilt by association.  It is punishing 
groups of people for the misdeeds of individuals, just like stereotyping 
African American males as criminals because some black males commit 
crimes.  There is no excuse for shutting down a rave due to gang activity 
nearby.  If the cops there were doing their job, they would deal with the 
individuals causing problems.  Closing down an entire party may be 
easier sometimes, but it is wrong.

> And it sounds like there is someone at the other end of the phone line 
> willing to listen.  Hey, if Susan can be convinced that having 100 people 
> dancing at a party leads to fewer acts of violence amongst the population 
> than having 100 people on the streets or 100 people watching football, 
> she might become a big supporter.  
> But don't fritter away the opportunity by comparing them to Hitler and 
> Stalin.
> 

	Maybe Susan and others like her will realize that they more they 
"crack down" on raves, the more people out there will agree with me.  On 
the other hand, the more the authorities loosen up, respect our right to 
party, and leave us alone, the more the rave community will tend to agree 
with you.
	So by seeing both our perspectives, and the type government 
action that reinforces each of them, perhaps she will make a decision as 
to who she would rather deal with, me or you, and then act accordingly.  
I hope she decides she'd rather have the rave community agree with you! 8)

Peace, luv & grooviness,
				<<< Starchild >>>

> 	Brian
>

I was goin to mention a condom, but 2 things entered my mind 
 
1.)    If I carry one it's because I believe I would need it, yet that
means I believe I'll be having sex with someone at or after a rave, and
that kind of goes against the thought process, that it's a non sexual
atmosphere. and besides....... 
 
2.)     If I carry a condom, I beleive that I will eventually need it, and
inveriably I will never need it, because I'm looking for it
(sex)..........I find when I'm thinking....."i need to take a
condom.....just in case I might get lucky",    thats when I will never get
lucky, I have condoms that I carried for months in my wallet, and never
needed them. It's like a kiss of death......something to do with the male
sexual brain disfunction 
 
then when you least expect it, (and you naturally don't have a condom),
thats when I find myself in a needy condom situation, and only because I
wasn't looking for it (sex)........it's a kind of cruel irony 
 
so my philosiphy has become.........carry a condom, never get lucky 
 
                                                                never carry
a condom, your chances improve.... 
 
does that make any sense, or am I just rambling another
thread.......moonpup

All this condom talk got me thinking...
As an RA I often get quatities of condoms from the Student Health Center 
so I can give them out to residents at STD awareness programs, etc.  
Because of this open kind of mindset about condoms, I started carrying a 
few around and would give them out to people from time-to-time...
So I guess to modify moonpup's statement:
	Carry a condom: you might not get lucky but you might be able to 
	help out the person who's chances were improved because they weren't 
	carrying one!

love, latex and life folks!
(and remember to use water-based lubes!) :)
--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+---

           "Mr. Kirk, you'd better come down to the station-house."

 doesn't "get lucky" it can be used for hand massage/rubbing.  :)

 organization is giving out free condoms/lube  (typically AIDS Awareness
 groups).  Could be a thought to consider for future events.

 Also, mentioning carrying condoms in wallets, I read at some time some
 where (there's an exact reference for you!) that this was not recommended
 as it could deteriorate the condom.  *shrug*  Might want to confirm that...
 the consequences may be unpleasant if you're using a condom in less than
 perfect condition.

moonpup said...
	so my philosiphy has become.........carry a condom, never get
lucky --- never carry a condom, your chances improve.... 


I hear what you're saying moonpup -- but here are a couple of other thoughts...

1.  I agree that sex really isn't part of the rave scene (exept for those who
occasionally get carried away in the chill room!), but we all go somewhere in
the morning, and sometimes it isn't our own house ... and I know I sometimes run
into people I didn't expect to see when I'm out, and my plans for the evening
change... [ he he ; ) ] 

2.  Hmmmm..   a dilemma ... carry a condom, never get lucky ...   to me, it's
not at all lucky to want to have sex when you don't have a condom, 'cause
frankly, unprotected sex is about the UNLUCKIEST thing I can think of ...   so
with your logic, assuming you would not have *unsafe* sex, then you'll never
have sex!  If you have a condom with you, you're jinxed, and if you don't have a
condom with you, you're not gonna do it because it wouldn't be safe!

Solution?  Ask me and i'll give you one when you need it!  

That way you aren't jinxed by being prepared (by the way, I carry one in my
wallet, so it's always there, to be replaced if it gets funky before it gets
used) so it's not like I make some special effort for parties... I just don't
leave home without it!  I carry the best too....  (Magnums, they rule, even guys
who don't like 'em, like 'em!)

(Maybe I better put a couple extra for this weekend since I'm making this
offer!)          

Leslie    : )

Sorry to jump in but I must also agree. Ahh nothing like just playing around
for a few hours. Specially in the morning when you are just waking up...
Hmm ok I'll shut up now.

	<3174BD4E.7E69@islandnet.com>
X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.2.1 10oct95)
To: solo@islandnet.com, Milton Cecil <moonpup@hooked.net>
Subject: Re: too many choices (quite long)
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Derrick May may have said that Detroit techno started long before Chicago
house did, and others may agree, and with MUCH due respect to Derrick May,
that's simply wrong.  As far as I can tell, and I've dug down into this
issue quite a bit, what we now call house and techno started roughly
around the same time.  You can hear them both in tracks from 1984 or
so, and both have emerged full-blown by 1986.  Detroit borrowed from
Chicago, Chicago borrowed from Detroit, and New York has a LOT to say
about ALL of that too!  

The precursors of both styles go as far back as you care to go.  Myself,
I agree with Ramon Wells, who was DJing WAY back in the day (in the early
1970s in Portland and Seattle), and is now the head of Bold! Records, who
said at the Billboard convention a couple of years ago and repeated to me,
"When you get down to it, it's ALL disco!"  And you know, he's right.
All of these forms have many influences, but disco is a dominant one.
If you look at it simply from the point of view of how it's made, disco,
house, techno and all the many variants are producer- rather than musician-
oriented production forms.  

Now, finally, on "Chicago versus Detroit."  Nonsense.  They are historically,
geographically and economically separate, and the musical scenes there have
always differed.  Chicago had the blues, Detroit had Motown.  Did anyone
talk about "Chicago blues versus Motown" in the 1960s?  No, they obviously
had differing styles but interrelated aspects.  Same as now.  

There has always been some interaction between Chicago and Detroit in
the development of electronic dance music.  That's obvious when you hear
Detroit house or Chicago techno, and both of those forms exist and have
their own interesting characteristics.  But the bigger issue to me is
*techno* vs. *techno* -- that is, what techno was when it started in
Detroit, the motivating forces and influences that underpinned it, and
what is has become.  Much techno I hear is soul-less, has lost the
very foundations of the music in order to focus on the forms while
losing the meaning.  The foundations of house too have been compromised
on the altar of commercial accessibility and pop sensibility.  

Just read the interviews or ask Juan Atkins or Mike Banks what they think
of what has happened to techno, or at least what people *call* techno,
over the last few years.  They'll just mutter and shake their heads.

It doesn't have to be from Detroit to be techno, in my view (and in the
view of the people from Detroit, I might add).  It has to be from the
*heart*, just like all great music.

phred

Dear Nancy,

	I loved your tale (the good, the bad, and the ugly)... As another 
raver who's been known to frequent Bondage-A-Go-Go, I've had some of the 
same thoughts as you:  Noticing the differences between that scene and 
the rave scene and asking "why?"
	Rave parties are not as asexual to me as they seem to be for many 
people, but they certainly are not sexy the way Bondage is.  On the other 
hand, Bondage is a very cold place -- people are not terribly friendly, 
and the smile factor is very low.  I think it is also falling into the 
dreaded "routine" syndrome of having found a successful formula and not 
trying anything new or creative at their parties (we can do better here 
as well).
	What I'm wondering is why can't we have more luscious, ripe, smiling 
girls and boys sucking on lollipops and toting teddy bears as they flirt in 
minimal attire at raves?  Betty Boop could be a good role model.  8)  
	I certainly don't want to see our scene become infused with a typical 
nightclub "meat market" atmosphere, but... is wanting the sex without the 
attitude asking too much?

On Thu, 11 Apr 1996, Nancy wrote:

> Thought a tale of my adventures in the City last night might be somewhat
> relevant; each caused me to reflect on some aspects of our scene...
> 
> Beastie Boys at Bottom-of-the-Hill!  Now _this_ was a _super_underground
> party!  I was told about it and given five minutes to jump in the car.  I
> looked at my books spread in front of me, and jumped!  We get to the club
> close to 10PM and encounter a bad scene.  The club is packed inside
> (apparently), there are a hundred desperate people crowding outside, and
> the cops in their infinite wisdom have decided this is a dangerous
> potential riot.
> 
> We manage to elude the piggys (for the moment), wiggle our way to the front
> of the line (with the help of my super-flirtatious friend), and meet the
> doorman.  The doorman, for his part, thought the crowd situation was a
> great opportunity to be the biggest asshole imaginable.  He favored the
> crowd with sentiments like, "get the fuck away from _my_ door!  Why are you
> touching _my_ door?" and "You all are pretty fucking stupid to think you're
> getting in here!" and "Give me a blowjob, maybe then you'll get in!"  Ahem.
> I couldn't help but reflect on the vibe being created around this club by
> the attitude of their workers.  The ones who got inside were lucky, the
> rest of us were fucked, get out of our face and go home.   No compassion or
> friendliness, but then, what did I expect, a rave? ;)  My friend (who
> raves) offered him a big plastic blinky ring as a present to "make him feel
> better."  He announced, "you can't bribe me!"  She said it wasn't a bribe,
> just a present to brighten his day.  He sneered, "Impossible!"  In his
> world, no-one just gives anyone a little present out of love.  At raves,
> this is common.  (big happy face).
> 
> Then the riot brigade of thirty cops arrived to clear the people out from
> the front of the club.  Now, this was disturbing.  I'm from L.A. and have
> observed many disgusting police brutality incidents.  In fact, the only
> time I was ever hit by a man it was a fucking cop (at a demonstration for
> women's rights! symbolic, eh?).  I thought San Francisco police would be a
> lot more laid back, but I guess it's true about power corrupting... These
> cops were unnecessarily aggressive, rude, mean and totally infuriating.  My
> friend got stuck behind the police line, alone on a scary unlit street.
> The line of cops moved down the street, pushing the rest of us like cattle,
> screaming, "MOVE! MOVE! MOVE!"  I stopped and pointed behind them, saying
> my friend was trapped around the corner on that street by herself, let me
> please go to her, instead of up and around the block out of her sight
> (where the cops were forcing the rest of us to go).  The response was a
> reddening face screaming at me, "MOVE! MOVE! MOVE!", then threatening me
> with arrest.  I ran around two blocks and finally met up with her, thank
> God.  Basically, the San Francisco Police Department saw fit to jeopardize
> the safety of my friend and the rights of all of us because...why? oh,
> yeah, we were standing peacefully on a sidewalk outside of a club. :(  (And
> they wonder why the rave scene doesn't cooperate with the nice
> authorities...)
> 
> To salvage the night we headed over to Bondage-a-Go-Go.  Woo!  _This_ made
> us forget the previous unpleasantness in a wonderland of fishnets, leather,
> gyrating dancers, and live bondage sessions.  I was a Bondage virgin (so to
> speak) and was put-off at first by the (club) environment.  Loud, grungy,
> metally industrial techno, red lights, and lots of black, spikes,
> deathrockers, and goth queens.  It was all so _dark_, and got me to
> thinking about the whole dilemma about sexuality at raves (yes, I know this
> was a recent thread topic).
> 
> I think of raves in terms of pink and baby blue.  It's Disneyland, full of
> toys and happy children, with many psychedelic rides.  It's innocence.  It
> allows us to get in touch with that inner child, that freedom, spontaneity,
> joy, self-confidence.  But shouldn't this process of getting more in touch
> with ourselves _also_ include sexuality?  In other words, is raving an
> experience that actually only connects us with _part_ of ourselves, not the
> whole?
> 
> Bondage is a club celebrating sexuality.   What I originally thought of as
> alienating darkness became a necessary element for a realm of fantasies:
> people exploring the "dark" side of their natures, the "sin", with all its
> fetishized latex and nudity and harsh edges.   Upstairs volunteers waited
> in lines to be dominated in front of an audience - whips, chains, clamps
> and mindfucks -- the binary division into dominant and submissive/master
> and slave.  It made me wonder (not for the first time) if sexuality is
> dependent for its thrill on appealing to the taboo, the dark and nasty
> side.  Is this dialectic of light/darkness in all of us?  I suddenly
> imagined a whole person as a human yin-yang: baby-dressed happy raver with
> teddy bear and big hugs on Friday, black-corset-wearing, red-lipsticked
> night goddess on Saturday.   Just as people are freer with sweetness at
> raves, I noticed people acting differently at Bondage.  No silly laughter,
> just smoldering gazes.  Or maybe all of these experiences (raves, bondage)
> are one-dimensional, made more intense for their singularity, easier to
> explore only particular aspects of our selves.
> 
> Random thoughts...
> until tomorrow, everybody!
> Love, Nancy
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
>

for those of us who grew up in the 80s,  I recieved this from the
SoCaliRaves List, and thought it brought back a few memories

Austin

------------Begin Forwarded Message--------------

>> Children of the Eighties
>>
>>       We are the children of the Eighties.  We are not the first "lost
>> generation" nor today's lost generation; in fact, we think we know just
>> where we stand - or are discovering it as we speak.  We are the ones who
>> played with Lego Building Blocks when they were just building blocks and
>> gave Malibu Barbie crewcuts with safety scissors that never really cut.
>> We collected Garbage Pail Kids and Cabbage Patch Kids and My Little Ponie=
s
>> and Hot Wheels and He-Man action figures and thought She-Ra looked just a
>> little bit like I would when I was a woman.  Big Wheels and bicycles with
>> streamers were the way to go, and sidewalk chalk was all you needed to
>> build a city.  Imagination was the key.  It made the Ewok Treehouse big
>> enough for you to be Luke and the kitchen table and an old sheet dark
>> enough to be a tent in the forest.  Your world was the backyard and it wa=
s
>> all you needed.  With your pink portable tape player, Debbie Gibson sang
>> back up to you and everyone wanted a skirt like the Material Girl and a
>> glove like Michael Jackson's.  Today, we are the ones who sing along with
>> Bruce Stringsteen and The Bangles perfectly and have no idea why.  We
>> recite lines with the Ghostbusters and still look to The Goonies for a
>> great adventure.  We flip through T.V. stations and stop at The A Team an=
d
>> Knight Rider and Fame and laugh with The Cosby Show and Family Ties and
>> Punky Brewster and what you talkin' 'bout Willis?  We hold strong
>> affections for The Muppets and The Gummy Bears and why did they take the
>> Smurfs off the air?  After school specials were only about cigarettes and
>> step-families, the Pokka Dot Door was nothing like Barney, and aren't the
>> Power Rangers just Voltron reincarnated?  We are the ones who still read
>> Nancy Drew and the Hardy Boys the Bobbsey Twins, Beverly Clearly and Judy
>> Blume, Richard Scary and the Electric Company.  Friendship bracelets were
>> ties you couldn't break and friendship pins went on shoes - preferably
>> hightop Velcro Reebox - and pegged jeans were in, as were Units belts and
>> layered socks and jean jackets and jams and charm necklaces and side pony
>> tails and just tails.  Rave was a girl's best friend; braces with colored
>> rubberbands made you cool.  The backdoor was always open and Mom served
>> only red Kool-Aid to the neighborhood kids- never drank New Coke.
>> Entertainment was cheap and lasted for hours.  All you needed to be a
>> princess was high heels and an apron; the Sit'n'Spin always made you dizz=
y
>> but never made you stop; Pogoballs were dangerous weapons and Chinese Jum=
p
>> Ropes never failed to trip someone.  In your Underoos you were Wonder
>> Woman or Spider Man or R2D2 and in your treehouse you were king.
>>       In the Eighties, nothing was wrong.  Did you know the president
>> was shot?  Star Wars was not only a movie.  Did you ever play in a bomb
>> shelter?  Did you see the Challenger explode or feed the homeless man?  W=
e
>> forgot Vietnam and watched Tiananman's Square on CNN and bought pieces of
>> the Berlin Wall at the store.  AIDS was not the number one killer in the
>> United States.  We didn't start the fire, Billy Joel.  In the Eighties, w=
e
>> redefined the American Dream, and those years defined us.  We are the
>> generation in between strife and facing strife and not turning our backs.
>> The Eighties may have made us idealistic, but it's that idealism that wil=
l
>> push us and be passed on to our children - the first children of the

Eric - there is a new kind of condom on the market made from poly* (I 
forgot the rest). There were begin test-marketed in California for a 
while, but are now available across the country. They are supposed to
offer better heat-sensitivity than latex, and can also be used with 
oil-based ludes, like Vasoline (if you'd really want to do that). I 
believe they are just as STD-resistant as the latex kind.
Anyway, my gf just bought some, but we haven't used them yet ... I hope 
they're good.

Dan

That's why you carry many with you.  A couple to give away & a couple for 
yourself.  You need two, just in case one breaks...or....;-)

I do think it would be cool if they were supplied at raves.  Some people 
don't like the association of Raves & sex, but unfortunately (or 
fortunately :-)) sex is a part of life anywhere you go.  Sometimes it's 
just more "in your face" at raves.  Instead of hiding it, I would rather 
have condoms be available & have people be safe...

Just my $.02...

Interesting choice of words.  :^)  Um, yeah, i think a bowl of condoms on
the juice bar or something wouldn't in any way ruin the mood of the party.
I think they would probably disappear pretty damn quick too.

And no, Eric, they can't go near the coffee station.  You know what a
leathal combination those two make.  Latex and caffeine!?  "Get me
started!"  :^)

As for Moonpup's original theory on pre-meditated possession of condoms
being inversly proportional to one's chances of getting a ride, I believe
that the same algorithm (do you think Al Gore has any rhythm?) holds true
for making one's bed before going out.  That is, the cleaner one's room,
the less chance one will have a visitor; the messier one's room, the more
chance one will have a visitor.

No condoms, messy room, carry half your houselhold possessions in a
knap-sack, have wild staring eyes and stickers on your face, hug people in
line at Safeway at 7AM, dress like a freak, uncontrollably bust a move to
the Muzak version of Stairway To Heaven...

Ah to rave and be raved...

Tone

Eric wrote:
>This is true!  I've been in situations before where I've had to be more
>creative in pleasing my partner.  This is where foreplay becomes "play", as
>it's not leading up to anything, but is the main event itself.

However, for the woman, foreplay is not "play," but IS the main event -
along with everything else.  Our sexuality is experienced as a totality -
all body, all sensation, from alluring looks to hardcore sex.  Many women
are extremely frustrated by the masculinized version of sexuality, which
emphasizes intercourse as the "main event," the focal point, the inevitable
conclusion which is often too quickly rushed toward (by men).

I know through speaking to many girlfriends, and in taking two classes at
Cal around women's sexuality, that women have a very difficult time
accepting their OWN sexuality, and stopping castigating themselves for not
responding to the same stimuli (i.e. media images) and
sexual-response-model as men.  It is difficult, but liberating for us to
reclaim our sexuality, by expressing what WE need in bed: which is often
more "foreplay" (a misnomer because the "fore" implies it is something
lesser than the "real" thing, and because of the term "play."  "Sex"
meaning intercourse is also a misnomer, for the woman "sex" comprises much
more).

Because women often don't ask for what would turn them on in bed, I have
heard many women express HAPPINESS that a condom wasn't available, because
that forced the man to pay attention to other aspects.
(Do NOT take this to mean women are anti-sex.  We just tend to have a
sexuality that responds, initially, to different stimuli than men - and
that is something that is hard for a lot of women to personally claim and
to ask for in sexual relationships).

I've solved this problem personally through honesty, communication, and
claiming my right to be pleased and to please.  And sex has gotten WAY
better since the days of passive frustration, for me and my partners.  When
foreplay becomes a main ingredient to love-making, you'll find worlds and
worlds of experience...what was once boring (i.e. no foreplay and
intercourse too soon) has become endlessly pleasurable.

I say leave the condoms aside from time to time.  :)

Nancy

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Apr 17 17:50:37 1996

Subject: what's the fuss about condems?
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Wed, 17 Apr 1996 17:47:38 -0700 (PDT)
From: lanima00 <lanima00@dons.ac.usfca.EDU>
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 1695
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

hello all-

within our "condommania" thread, i've seen 2 distinct modes of thought

either--

1)sex isn't really a part of the rave scene, and condoms at a rave
sexualize an encounter that shouldn't be

or

2)sex is part of existence, and raves being part of existence, sex is
still an issue.

i, matthew d. p. k. lanier, being of sound mind and body, would have to
agree with the second viewpoint.    when i go to raves, i go to hang out
with people, but i could never deny that there is a sexual element between
me and the people that i talk to, both male and female.  i have been in
circumstances at raves where i have, through choice of both parties, ended
up in a more intimate situation than i expected.  that's not what i go
for, but it happens occasionally.  i find it unhealthy, for me, to deny
the sexual component of raves as i find so many jumping to do.

i must aggree that, for me, sex has never been hurtful nor has it ever
been used that way against me, but there are some people who have had
experiences where sex was hurtful, and they might, or for other reasons,
not want their rave experience to be in the least bit sexual.

i respect people who don't enjoy a sexual element at raves, and hope that
they respect that i neither encourage nor discourage sexual energy at
raves, i just accept what happens.

perhaps, i should expand, saying that i have a rather broad definition of
sex, coming at it as a psych major.  study some Freud, and you'll
understand what i mean.


peace, love, and lots of other fun stuff, whatever that means to you!-

matt l

lanima00@dons.ac.usfca.edu
mdlanier@lynx.cs.usfca.edu
mdpkl@best.com
http://www.lanieraccounting.com/church.net/church.html

a 
>condom any more, therefor you'll get lucky.  But you wont have a condom. 
I 
>guess its a no win situation. 
> 
>-M 
> 
>

scene.....moonpup

On Wed, Apr 17, 1996 3:28:46 PM  at Fred Heutte wrote: 
 
>Derrick May may have said that Detroit techno started long before Chicago 
>house did, and others may agree, and with MUCH due respect to Derrick May,

>that's simply wrong.  As far as I can tell, and I've dug down into this 
>issue quite a bit, what we now call house and techno started roughly 
>around the same time.  You can hear them both in tracks from 1984 or 
>so, and both have emerged full-blown by 1986.  Detroit borrowed from 
>Chicago, Chicago borrowed from Detroit, and New York has a LOT to say 
>about ALL of that too!   
> 
>The precursors of both styles go as far back as you care to go.   
 
i agree with all of this, and I find the statement regarding losing the
soul, is especially deep to me, the music I like to hear and play has a
funky and (I suppose a soulful) cornerstone, this is why I like the
breakbeat so much, I often hear a trance song and think to myself "if only
this track had a breakbeat insteat of this 4 to the floor". 
 
it's as if a breakbeat can add a funky edge that gives off a soulful
ora........I find alot of the popular dance styles now (techno, trance,
jungle, happy hardcore, even house) lack that soulful/funktified ora to
it........just kind of formula music...... 
 
pleeeeeeeeease no flamage on the trance ..........moonpup

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Apr 17 18:27:25 1996

Subject: Techno film tonight
Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.91.960417181340.8275B-100000@taz.hyperreal.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I've just rejoined the list, so forgive me if someone has already 
written about this (hope to see you there - I'll be in a gray raincoat 
BSP Flux TV has a new SF airtime - details on tomorrow.):

tonight at 7:30 $4
April 17 at Yerba Buena media screening room

Techno: Space and Flow in the Radical Frame by Ian Kerkhof
Enter the world of South African filmmaker Ian Kerkhof as he traces the 
rise of techno music as a mass cultural phenomenon in Berlin and 
Frankfurt since the fall of the Wall. Sampling both experimental film 
classics, and interviews with premiere Euro dance producers and artists, 
the film is a visual and aural tour de force that muses, among much else, 
about the implication of a generation growing up without lyrics in their 
music, the role of drugs in pop scenes, and the increasing demand for 
trancedental melodic experiences.

On Wed, 17 Apr 1996, Starchild wrote:

> 
> Dear Nancy,
> 
> 	I loved your tale (the good, the bad, and the ugly)... As another 
> raver who's been known to frequent Bondage-A-Go-Go, I've had some of the 
> same thoughts as you:  Noticing the differences between that scene and 
> the rave scene and asking "why?"
> 	Rave parties are not as asexual to me as they seem to be for many 
> people, but they certainly are not sexy the way Bondage is.  On the other 
> hand, Bondage is a very cold place -- people are not terribly friendly, 
> and the smile factor is very low.  I think it is also falling into the 
> dreaded "routine" syndrome of having found a successful formula and not 
> trying anything new or creative at their parties (we can do better here 
> as well).
> 	What I'm wondering is why can't we have more luscious, ripe, smiling 
> girls and boys sucking on lollipops and toting teddy bears as they flirt in 
> minimal attire at raves?  Betty Boop could be a good role model.  8)  
> 	I certainly don't want to see our scene become infused with a typical 
> nightclub "meat market" atmosphere, but... is wanting the sex without the 
> attitude asking too much?
>  
Hi all!
 Just some thoughts to share here... As someone who has a great deal of 
sexual energy I have had to learn respect for others who do not. I feel 
that this has been a good (but very difficult, sexual feelings [for me] 
are so strong) process and I thank all the people who are sharing their 
perspectives on these issues. I do think that society in general could 
use a more healthy perspective of sex. Those of us who are members of society
have a responsibility to bring this perspective to other members (in a 
respectful way of course). I feel that raves are multi-faceted events 
that, at times, can include the all too human aspect of sexuality. If we 
learn and grow from our relativly safe rave enviroments, on how to 
deal with these issues in a sane and respectful way then we can bequeth 
our shared exoeriences to the rest of society through our daily 
interactions with each other. I feel that this would be a great gift to 
out society. However we do need to work out the problems between those 
who love sex =) and those who find it offensive at raves. Communication 
will help that process along.


Ran @ Dionysus Dreams 


                              (yours in peace)
                                    /
                                =*=/
                                 ~

>No, you're right!  This goes back to that "child's world" vibe thang, where
>sex would presumably have no place.
>Now, a sex party, on the other hand...THERE'S an interesting prospect!

Oh, they exist around here, no doubt about that.  The problem is, if you
think it's hard to get a good crowd of in-tune-with-the-vibe ravers, you
should try to get a good crowd of comfortable-with-nudity, non-pushy,
sexually-outrageous, exhibitionistic, respectful, safe people together
for a sex party!  Ain't easy.

Most of the sex parties I've been to require you to sign a form stating
that you've read and agreed to the party rules (which usually include:
safe sex only; no touching without asking first; no intrusive behavior;
etc., etc.) before you can enter the party.  It's possible to create a
safe space for public sex, but very tricky.

Rob Jellinghaus		robj@best.com

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Apr 17 18:34:09 1996

Received: from shellx.best.com (shellx.best.com [206.86.0.11]) by mail1.best.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id SAA10385; Wed, 17 Apr 1996 18:32:57 -0700
Received: (robj@localhost) by shellx.best.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id RAA18422; Wed, 17 Apr 1996 17:24:17 -0700
Date: Wed, 17 Apr 1996 17:24:17 -0700
From: Rob Jellinghaus <robj@best.com>
Message-Id: <199604180024.RAA18422@shellx.best.com>
To: Nancy <nancys@uclink4.berkeley.edu>, Starchild <star@sfsu.edu>
Subject: Re: (Long/NRR) Beasties/Bondage
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>girls and boys sucking on lollipops and toting teddy bears as they flirt in 
>minimal attire at raves?  Betty Boop could be a good role model.  8)  

Mixed signals.  The question is, what kind of social context are you
setting up?  What are the expectations?  Most ravers don't want to be
groped.  Most sex party denizens don't either, really, unless they say
"yes" first.  One big problem with combining rave energy with sex party
energy:  if you have to yell all the time, it's pretty hard to make your
desires--or boundaries--known... and if people are dancing wildly, where
do you go to lie down and make out?  Oh yeah, that's what the chill room
is for :-)

Is it too much to want the sex without the attitude?  Not at all.  But
if you _really_ want the sex, you need to go to a place where there is
a lot more space (and more social context) for it.  It takes practice
to be publically sexual; it ain't something most people have ever done,
and if there's a lot of clueless, bozo energy around, it destroys the
sex vibe WAY faster than you can blink.

> Is this dialectic of light/darkness in all of us?  I suddenly
> imagined a whole person as a human yin-yang: baby-dressed happy raver with
> teddy bear and big hugs on Friday, black-corset-wearing, red-lipsticked
> night goddess on Saturday.

You forgot jeans-wearing, net-surfing hacker during the weekdays :-)
Include that, and you just described my life!  I love San Francisco!

Rob Jellinghaus		robj@best.com

Hello...
	well, after much internal struggle and intrapersonal debate, I 
have finally decided cease my shameless voyuerism and jump into the mix 
here on the SF Raves list.  My name is Monty, some of you may know me and 
some may not.  I moved up to the bay area about 7 months ago from santa 
barbara, where I went to school, went deeply into debt, worked at a radio 
station, threw a few parties and paid some dues as a dj.  now, i live in 
berkeley with the man joe rice(among others) and am learning the ropes of 
life in no. cal.  
	it took me so long to actually post anything list-wide because 
i'm actually frightened by some the behavior i've seen.  people i know 
who seem mild-mannered in-person take on a different persona when on line 
.  why is this?  why engage in pointless rhetorical debates on issues the 
participants sould never ever really have any tangible impact upon(i.e. 
why trance isn't played @ sunset)?  Are my questions in fact rhetorical 
themselves?  then let me know in person, not via some lame flame.  i like 
most of you, really, and i'm a nice guy.  
	anyhow, overall i like being a subscriber.  interesting stuff.  
shout outs to my peeps who know me throughout this region of cyberspace.  
and those who don't know me, please feel free to communicate with me via 
anytime.  also, those of you who are gonna be in the haight on saturday, 
i'll be spinning @ ameba(happy b-day Andrew!) starting at maybe noon or one 
pm, so stop by and say hello.  in addition to that, i'll be playing in 
portland with ethan, joe, jon carel and frank minor next weekend at the 
gateway system party called gateway.  bye.
	p.s.-ethan! I can help out at Mad on Monday gimmie a call or mail 
me with more info

kk

>Eric wrote:
>>This is true!  I've been in situations before where I've had to be more
>>creative in pleasing my partner.  This is where foreplay becomes "play", as
>>it's not leading up to anything, but is the main event itself.
>
>However, for the woman, foreplay is not "play," but IS the main event -
>along with everything else.  Our sexuality is experienced as a totality -

anyone here ever read "out of the silent planet" by CS Lewis? (if you
haven't, read it. if you have, read it again :)

It's got a scene where dr. ransom is talking to a resident of mars about
sex and marriage and such, and the martian is shocked that humans can get
pleasure out of sex with many people. He patiently explains that among his
people, sexual gratification includes courting, marriage, foreplay, sex,
bearing, and raising children, all with just one person once in your life.

I'm not sure how this all relates, but it's an incredible book and after I
finished the trilogy i thought "gosh wouldn't it be nice if the real
universe worked like that?"

hmmm...

random thought for the day.

CS Lewis rocks.

-m.

Fred Heutte wrote:
> 
> Derrick May may have said that Detroit techno started long before Chicago
> house did, and others may agree, and with MUCH due respect to Derrick May,
> that's simply wrong.  As far as I can tell, and I've dug down into this
> issue quite a bit, what we now call house and techno started roughly
> around the same time.  You can hear them both in tracks from 1984 or
> so, and both have emerged full-blown by 1986.  Detroit borrowed from
> Chicago, Chicago borrowed from Detroit, and New York has a LOT to say
> about ALL of that too!

Actually...I could stand corrected...did I say Chicago copied Detroit?
I know they all came out vvvvvvery close to each other...I WAS hearing it straight from the 
horses mouth wasn't I :) or...one of them...
 
> The precursors of both styles go as far back as you care to go.  Myself,
> I agree with Ramon Wells, who was DJing WAY back in the day (in the early
> 1970s in Portland and Seattle), and is now the head of Bold! Records, who
> said at the Billboard convention a couple of years ago and repeated to me,
> "When you get down to it, it's ALL disco!" 

Welll.....thats what I actually was gettin at :)
I thought I too was getting a little long winded...but even still...many techno artists who we 
label as techno today anyway were making music before disco even...
Kraftwerk...Eno...Jarre...then it was called new age...today ???

> But the bigger issue to me is
> *techno* vs. *techno* -- that is, what techno was when it started in
> Detroit, the motivating forces and influences that underpinned it, and
> what is has become.  Much techno I hear is soul-less, has lost the
> very foundations of the music in order to focus on the forms while
> losing the meaning.  The foundations of house too have been compromised
> on the altar of commercial accessibility and pop sensibility.
> 
> Just read the interviews or ask Juan Atkins or Mike Banks what they think
> of what has happened to techno, or at least what people *call* techno,
> over the last few years.  They'll just mutter and shake their heads.

I have read many of them :) along with personally talking with Derrick and Stacey Pullen 
when they came to play at my party last month.
You couldnt have quoted them better.
 
> It doesn't have to be from Detroit to be techno, in my view (and in the
> view of the people from Detroit, I might add).  It has to be from the
> *heart*, just like all great music.

Did anyone say it *had* to be from Detroit?
I couldnt agree with you more Phred...good point :)
 
> phred

dj bill.e

From: Kyung Rok Lee <krok@uclink2.berkeley.edu>

Subject: Does Raving = (Long) Safe Sex? 
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9604171901.A15951-0100000@uclink2.berkeley.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; CHARSET=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Being that I was not an adult in the 70's, I was wondering what some of 
our older members of this list, who came of age in that decad(enc)e, feel 
about the relationship between the safe sex revolution, if you will, and 
the evolution of "raving."  I know this is a complicated question, 
one that might be better asked on a final exam, but I think that there 
may be something to it...  

(e.g. Question 96:  Would raving as such have come about without AIDS, 
and the attendant changes in sexual mores??)

Raving is a complicated phenomena, which has just as much to do, I 
think, with the economy, changing family structure, transcendance of 
the everyday (esp. among gays, but also among alienated workers), 
individualism gone amuck, popular music, religion lost/found, and a bunch 
of other junk, as it does with sex.  But since it's spring, and sex is in 
the air, can I get a witness?  

The sex drive (or vibe), quite simply, is one of the stongest around.  
My feeling is that in the 90's, if sex were as free, relatively 
safe, and multiply practiced as it was in the pre-A-bomb 70's, then 
we might be less interested in the "communual" vibe, and more interested 
in what some of us condescendingly refer to as the "meatmarket" or 
"clubby" vibe.  Perhaps we just wouldn't be able to help it?  
Actually, the "love" vibe is pretty strong, too.  

Am I the only one to ever think that raving was a form of safe (group) 
sex?  (I am conscious of perhaps having constructed raving as 
"heterosexual," even though there are obviously other sides of the 
triangle.  I just wanted to avoid making my question too complicated 
to handle in this medium, something I fear I may have already acomplished.  
Sorry for rambling.  It's late and i'm bored at work ;)

-Rok.

>Just an aside -- About the CS Lewis thing, He was a Christian and all=20
>his stories are supposed to be interprations of bible stories.

as long as we're on the topic: Lewis was born 1898, was an atheist =
throughout his=20
early life, he adopted theism in 1929 and converted to Christianity in =
1931. some of his early works were published under the pseudonym of =
Clive Hamilton (notably "Spirits in Bondage," a collection of lyric =
poems in 1919 and "Dymer," a book-length narrative poem in 1926). Lewis =
wrote prolifically in many genres: novels, poetry, children's =
literature, fantasy, science fiction, literary criticism, and =
apologetics. in addition, he wrote essays, sermons, and hundred's of =
letters. but you definately don't have to be a christian to appreciate =
his work...

  Oh yeah, technics turntables are actually satellite receptors that tap
into gaia-one and draw energy out through the conductive receptors in the
tone arm.  The disc (or vinyl/record/wax/UMMM THATS GOOD DRUGS I CAN KEEP
FOREVER!) is actually like a key or access node into the massive amounts of
energy in gaia-one.  The art of mixing comes from the dance the dj must do
in order to attract hyper dimensional space elves who are masters of
aligning musical energy.  The dance is done by holding your hand on the
pitch slider and moving it really slowly.  The elves decide when the beats
line up and you must put your faith in them.  Then if you take your time
and appeaze all the forces that be circling around the room as your mix, a
dimensional portal may be opened if the musics align properly (but nothing
will happen if they are not).  This dimensional portal gets created when
the energies flowing from one disc can find room to continue to flow as the
other disc gets louder.  If one disc pushes the other disc "off" it's river
of sound the effect is ruined.  Through this dimensional portal you have
direct access to the ear/energies of the gods and godessess of gaia (most
people call them aliens/angels)   Once you do this once they can reset your
internal compass so that your path goes to, hmmm, the happy place.  This is
how I mix.

  Watch out which records you play or you may end up in a dimensional of
beautiful busty bondage biker babes with bad additudes, whips and hmmm,
maybe I should just let you explore...

____________________/        ansiElf        \____________________
                    \   muchachamuchbassa   /

I agree entirely, except you don't need beats to make it happen.  The elves,
who I believe actually live in the vinyl (because each record is an entire
reality/consciousness itself) communicate with each other as the new record
is being cued up, and try to come into agreement as to how the mix will
work.  If they agree, the portal opens up between the two records even
before the new one is turned up.  Sometimes you can even hear sounds from
the new records seeping through even before it's turned up.  (this has
happened a few times to me, and I tell ya, it is totally wierd when it
does.)  Oh yea, it also doesn't take "technics" to make it happen either.
My tables are Numark.  Technics are probably just higher quality receptors.

list here.  It seems that a lot of people want to ban the use of ephedrine
saying how deadly it is  blah blah.  However, these news stories focus only
on the rave scene and the herbal E aspect ;  they never once mention weight
loss products as deadly even though they can contain ephedrine.  Just
another attack on us poor misunderstood ravers.......   Love Toy =)

From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)

Subject: Re: Does Raving = (Long) Safe Sex?
To: krok@uclink2.berkeley.edu
Date: Thu, 18 Apr 96 8:54:17 PDT
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <Pine.3.89.9604171901.A15951-0100000@uclink2.berkeley.edu>; from "Kyung Rok Lee" at Apr 17, 96 9:45 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> Being that I was not an adult in the 70's, I was wondering what some of 
> our older members of this list, who came of age in that decad(enc)e, feel 
> about the relationship between the safe sex revolution, if you will, and 
> the evolution of "raving."
> 
> (e.g. Question 96:  Would raving as such have come about without AIDS, 
> and the attendant changes in sexual mores??)

Speaking for myself as a young sexually active adult in the 70's, I
was never into the meat market, cocaine-fueled, egocentric, vibe of
the disco scene.  I went to clubs to see my favorite bands, and the
forms of music I was into (progressive rock, electronic, punk, some
new wave, and jazz fusion) did not really focus on sexuality all that
much.  Sex was something that took place in college dorms.  Since I
pretty much missed out on the 60's thing, what was lacking at the time
was a flourishing scene that supported a shared transcendental 
thing where people could connect to each other through some kind of
shared positive sensory-overload forward-looking technology 
influenced experience.  Back then, there was the choice of getting lost 
in the crowd at a Pink Floyd concert, or spacing out with a few 
hallmates in dorm room with blinking christmas lights and Frank Zappa 
on a cheap stereo.

In other words, I think that raving would have filled a void for
many people in the 70's.

> My feeling is that in the 90's, if sex were as free, relatively 
> safe, and multiply practiced as it was in the pre-A-bomb 70's, then 
> we might be less interested in the "communual" vibe, and more interested 
> in what some of us condescendingly refer to as the "meatmarket" or 
> "clubby" vibe.  Perhaps we just wouldn't be able to help it?  

I was able to help it, as were many of my friends.  There are people
who feel that there is much more to be gotten out of life than sex.
One thing that attracted me to raving was the lack of a pickup vibe
and more focus on music that had evolved beyond the superficiality
of disco.

> Am I the only one to ever think that raving was a form of safe (group) 
> sex?  

I don't know.  There *are* sexual undercurrents, but I think the
attractive part of raving from a social/sexual perspective is the
lack of pressure to *immediately* focus on sex in our interactions.
It just seems so much more freeing and (ironically) unrepressed.
But then what do I know?  I was already married when I started
going to raves.

Lee
_________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com  (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )  lee@hyperreal.com
