On Wed, 17 Apr 1996, moonpup wrote:

> i agree with all of this, and I find the statement regarding losing the
> soul, is especially deep to me, the music I like to hear and play has a
> funky and (I suppose a soulful) cornerstone, this is why I like the
> breakbeat so much, I often hear a trance song and think to myself "if only
> this track had a breakbeat insteat of this 4 to the floor". 
>  
> it's as if a breakbeat can add a funky edge that gives off a soulful
> ora........I find alot of the popular dance styles now (techno, trance,
> jungle, happy hardcore, even house) lack that soulful/funktified ora to
> it........just kind of formula music...... 

	And to others of us, a lot of "soulful" music is just too damn 
happy and lacks that tribalness, that force that pulls energy from deep 
inside. Again, it is a matter of tastes. Anyone can say that a certain 
type of music has lost its character, but labeling something as formula 
music is dismissing it and what experience does anyone have that would 
make them an "authority" on whether funky is better for everyone than 
primal, tribal beats? I might easily turn around and say "House lost its 
essence as soon as soul came out, well, no, as soon as that refined 
classical stuff came out because classical music was set in a restrictive 
era and the music was meant to move only certain aspects of your emotions 
while leaving you appearance unchanged. Ever since then we have simply 
been trying to get back to primitive forceful sound." So what's the 
difference? I have been involved with music since I was born, both 
performing and listening and in many styles. Does that make me an 
"authority"? Only to the extent that my ear is refined and I can play a 
whistle pretty well because of it, and it makes some things easier and 
some people tend to like to listen to me do those things. But that is the 
extent of it.

dave

On Thu, 18 Apr 1996, Lee Fogel wrote:
> I don't know.  There *are* sexual undercurrents, but I think the
> attractive part of raving from a social/sexual perspective is the
> lack of pressure to *immediately* focus on sex in our interactions.
> It just seems so much more freeing and (ironically) unrepressed.
> But then what do I know?  I was already married when I started
> going to raves.

One of the nicest things I ever got out of raving was the ability to go 
up to a total stranger and talk to them. No "I am just talking to you because 
I want to pork you" meat-market-thang. 

Putting bowls of condoms out like party favors changes the whole vibe. This 
is neither or good nor a bad thing, it just is a different. Personally, it's 
not the vibe I am looking for.  I like the freedom to talk to anyone 
without them wondering "what do you want from me" or visa-versa. 

I guess as with everything YMMV...

                                         Black Adder

toxic levels of ephedrine can be reached quite quickly.  A ban would likely 
reopen the attempts to regulate other dietary supplements (vitamins & 
herbs).  _That_ would truly suck :)

>throughout his
>early life, he adopted theism in 1929 and converted to Christianity in
>1931. some of his early works were published under the pseudonym of Clive
>Hamilton (notably "Spirits in Bondage," a collection of lyric poems in
>1919 and "Dymer," a book-length narrative poem in 1926). Lewis wrote
>prolifically in many genres: novels, poetry, children's literature,
>fantasy, science fiction, literary criticism, and apologetics. in
>addition, he wrote essays, sermons, and hundred's of letters. but you
>definately don't have to be a christian to appreciate his work...

not mistaken. They were all the rage in Glasgow a year or two ago because 
their buzz is supposedly just like alcohol but no stomache effects. Made 
people quite aggressive as well, so we saw a lot of fights due the stuff. 
Doesn't sound like gang rapes would be too far from that if you got a 
bunch of neds up on them wandering about with no one to fight and allow 
comes pretty little lassie.....

increased substantially in SF (I'm thinking around 100%) from 92-93 to
93-94.

On Wed, 17 Apr 1996, b e n c h u n wrote:

> >Just an aside -- About the CS Lewis thing, He was a Christian and all 
> >his stories are supposed to be interprations of bible stories.
> 
> as long as we're on the topic: Lewis was born 1898, was an atheist throughout his 
> early life, he adopted theism in 1929 and converted to Christianity in 1931. some of his early works were published under the pseudonym of Clive Hamilton (notably "Spirits in Bondage," a collection of lyric poems in 1919 and "Dymer," a book-length narrative poem in 1926). Lewis wrote prolifically in many genres: novels, poetry, children's literature, fantasy, science fiction, literary criticism, and apologetics. in addition, he wrote essays, sermons, and hundred's of letters. but you definately don't have to be a christian to appreciate his work...
>

Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id KAA11592; Thu, 18 Apr 1996 10:55:47 -0700
Received: from orion.sfsu.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id KAA11585; Thu, 18 Apr 1996 10:55:44 -0700
Received: (from star@localhost) by orion.sfsu.edu (8.7.1/8.7.1) id KAA01386; Thu, 18 Apr 1996 10:55:18 -0700 (PDT)
Date: Thu, 18 Apr 1996 10:55:17 -0700 (PDT)
From: Starchild <star@sfsu.edu>
X-Sender: star@orion
To: Troy Sheets <tsheets@xanadu.cyborganic.net>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com, sf@cyborganic.net
Subject: Re: Negativ
In-Reply-To: <199604121658.JAA26827@xanadu.cyborganic.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.SOL.3.91.960418102511.24871A-100000@orion>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


	Chikako and I were also at this show, and I feel about the same 
way Troy does.
	I wouldn't say the music was not danceable, because we did dance 
for a bit, but it didn't even come close to the groovability of the tunes 
at your average rave event.
	Knowing the reputation of the Hardkiss Bros., and having an 
appreciation for the campy creativity of the guys in Negativland, I felt 
this was a big let-down.  
	Part of the problem, IMO, was the mixture of musical styles 
without any effective means of coordination.  They described what they 
were going to do as an unplanned, five-hour freeform jam, and that's 
pretty much how it sounded, except we didn't stay for the full five 
hours, we got bored and left.  From what I heard, either the band or the 
DJs would have sounded better by themselves than they did together.  
	The main thing though was just a lack of vibe, minus any creative 
attempt by the promoters or the performers to create one.  After this 
show, I've come to the conclusion that I really don't like "concerts."  
When I go out, I want to party and interact.  If I just want to listen to 
music and be entertained, I'll stay home and save the $11.00 for someone 
like the Orb, where I know the atmosphere will be more like a rave and 
people will be dancing.
	By the way, I still think Negativland is a very interesting band, 
and I particularly recommend listening to the long, rambling track 
"Helter Stupid" for those of you who haven't heard it.  The best time to 
listen to it is in the car, when you can concentrate on the intricate 
nature of the recording and not be frustrated trying to dance to music 
not really suited for that activity. 8)

Peace, luv & grooviness, 
				<<< Starchild >>>


On Fri, 12 Apr 1996, Troy Sheets wrote:

> 
> I was kind of disappointed with the negativland show at the Troc.  I think
> the worst part about it was that people were not DANCING.  This was
> mostly due to the fact that the music was not DANCABLE.  I guess
> there can be shows where people don't dance... but I just don't enjoy
> those types of shows.
> 
> It seems funny that Negativland, who seem to be into the whole "the entire
> country is programmed by television" would do a show where everyone is just
> standing there mezmorized, hypnotized, zombified watching them.  You 
> could stay at home stare and a tv and be brain-dead... or you can go to the
> troc, stand around and stare at Negativland and be brain-dead.
> 
> This is in contrast to a band like say, Front 242 who combats television
> complacency with driving body-gyrating sounds.  It seems like Negativland
> wants to battle complacency with.... more complacency.
> 
> Okay, okay, I know that is just their "sound" and it is not meant for
> dancing.  But, many times I thought they were pretty unprofessional
> and unorganized on stage... there were LONG, boring pauses in which they
> were trying to get things fixed or setup or whatever.
> 
> Then, on top of all this, you are in "the troc", a club where it seems
> nobody ever has a good time.  Too many people, all standing around... 
> drinking, smoking... I guess I just expected something else.  I think
> this whole event would be VERY COOL if it took place in a movie theater
> or planetarium.
> 
> The film projections were really cool.  Lots of old EE movies and stuff.
> Did you see that one movie where they were explaining orders of magnitude
> by zooming in on this guys's hand... to his skin texture, to his cells,
> to his chromosomes, to his DNA, to the atom, through the electron shells,
> and finally into the nuclius...  with the order of magnatude (in meters)
> displayed on the screen too.... then they zoomed out into the universe,
> with orders of magnatude going up.  I saw that film in a physics class
> in college... very cool.
> 
> We left early from negativland becuase we were not having that much fun.
> They should really consider doing these non-dancing events in more
> relaxing, non-dancing venues.
> 
> -troy

> If you mean the recent case of the two high school girls been drugged and

Not very clever of a criminal to feed a person speed and then try to do
something to them, think of the WWII german soldiers who were given speed
to improve their courage, strength and relieve battle fatigue. I have a
hard time believing this to be honest, it's not the kind of drug that
puts people to sleep or renders them defenseless. One would have to give
someone a few grams to really put them out of business I guess.

> Fuck speed - I don't like placing value judgements on
> substances, but I've never seen anything good come out of speed use.

As with any drug it is the dosis and frequency of use that counts, not
the drug itself. Nevertheless speed is not a very interesting or safe
compound I would say.

> The Examiner reported the other day that methamphetamine related deaths
> increased substantially in SF (I'm thinking around 100%) from 92-93 to
> 93-94.

It's cheap and it seems to be an innocent stimulant. This country could
spend a bit more money in educating its people instead of putting them
in ever more jails.

Roofies have been popular by soccer hooligans in Holland, usually combined
with lots of alcohol etc. It usually made them very aggressive and strong,
tearing down places and the people in them, and inducing deep sleep and loss
of memory of the events subsequently. Also not a very nice drug I would say.

The Frying Dutchman.

friday in 1015?

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Apr 18 11:45:35 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id LAA16939; Thu, 18 Apr 1996 11:45:35 -0700

	id OAA13989; Thu, 18 Apr 1996 14:44:47 -0400
Date: 18 Apr 96 14:41:36 EDT
From: Leslie Ayres <71165.755@CompuServe.COM>
To: "sfraves@hyperreal.com" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Re: Dancing, Sex, Raving (from a mom)
Message-ID: <960418184136_71165.755_GHL48-1@CompuServe.COM>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

(warning, heartfelt semi-lecture to follow...   sorry!)


George Bernard Shaw said...

	Dancing is a perpendicular expression of a horizontal desire.

And I think he was totally right on with that, 'cause we should dance just like
we have sex (and vice versa) -- free and open, honest and sensual, happy and
uninhibited, expressing who we are.

Does sex belong at raves?  Personally, I think sex is a private thing, and I'd
never want to encourage public overt sexual behavior on the dance floor or in
the chill spaces. And like so many who have posted on this topic, one of the
wonderful things about raves is the lack of feeling like sexual prey, which so
often happens in cruisy club environments.

Like everything, sex is about choice.  Whether you're sexually active or choose
not to be, whether you have multiple partners or are monogomous, whatever,
that's your choice to make, and you need to follow your heart on that.

The most important thing is that people have the easy resources to make the
right choice.  And safe sex is *always* the right choice.  Unsafe sex is
*always* the wrong choice, but I know that it's a choice lots of people,
especially young people, make because it is a hassle to be safe.  No condom?  Oh
well, next time.  Hey, I've been there and I understand the temptation.

Solution?  Condoms discreetly and easily available.  Free.  Having condoms
available isn't about pushing sex on people.  It's about their safety and
health, and making it easy for them to do what's right when and if they choose
to have sex.

Someone was pondering on how raving may have been influenced by our safe-sex
restrictions in the 90s, vs. the free love of the 70s.  Having been part of
both, I think the peace-love-communal vibe in the 70s was a lot the same as
today's rave vibe, but the issue of deadly STDs has certainly squelched much of
the free sexual behavior.  I think that's good because it makes us think twice
about who/what/when/where of sex, and sexual communication is a very powerful
and sacred thing.  

But the sad side to me is when I talk to young kids who have just cut their
sexual side out of their life, because it's just easier that way.  

Somewhere there's a middle ground, and we all need to seek the spot that's right
for us.  I am the mother of an 18-year-old daughter, and I want her to make the
choices that are right for her, the choices that fill her with self-respect, and
choices that are safe.  I want the same for every one of you, too.  

Just don't start screwing next to me in the chill space, ok?  Geez, that makes
me uncomfortable!  ; )

Leslie  


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Apr 18 11:57:51 1996

Received: from netcom19.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id LAA18013; Thu, 18 Apr 1996 11:57:45 -0700
Received: from kencyr (palace.synopsys.com [204.176.20.17]) by netcom19.netcom.com (8.6.13/Netcom)
	id LAA15546; Thu, 18 Apr 1996 11:57:44 -0700
Message-ID: <317690A1.41C67EA6@netcom.com>
Date: Thu, 18 Apr 1996 11:57:37 -0700
From: Jeremy Nauck <nauckwj@netcom.com>
X-Mailer: Mozilla 2.01 (X11; I; SunOS 4.1.3_U1 sun4m)
MIME-Version: 1.0
To: SFRaves Mailing List <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Ephedrine epidemic?
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hi All!
Just thought I'd share some personal experiences I've had with pseudo-ephedrine
as of late...I first started taking "Mini-Thins" when I was in college.  My 
friends and I would take between 4-6, sometimes 8 before we would go out at 
as you can imagine, it did the trick!  The combination with alcohol was pretty
fun, except for the fact that we were doing HORRIBLE damage to our bodies, and
taking a lot of risks.  Ephedrine comes in many forms, Pseudo-Ephedrine, 
Ephedrine, and Norephedrine are chemically very similar.  Someone once told me
the molecule for Ephedrine and Pseudu-Ephedrine are mirror images of eachother,
same chemical formula, different arrangement.  Anyways, we did this for about
2 months every weekend, until it started really disagreeing with me.  Stomach
upset, and hot flashes were beginning to appear, so I reduced my dosage to 1 or
2 at a time. (Can't remember the MG equivalence).  So to make a boring story
short, it's gotten to the point now where 1 is too much, and the results are not
very predictable.  Just a word of caution!  This stuff, in any form, can 
seriously harm your cardiovascular system...We don't want anyone dieing!!!
	Love and hugs to all!
-Jeremy

                                             -William Shakespeare

>From:        Leslie Ayres, 71165.755@compuserve.com

>
>George Bernard Shaw said...
>
>	Dancing is a perpendicular expression of a horizontal desire.

I'm writing an article at this very moment (well, 1.3 moments ago, 
actually) about the energy behind dancing......And there definitely is 
that sexual element to it...But I think it's very easy for people -- 
especially people new to clubs and aprties -- to confuse the energy 
behind that expression as sexual, when it's so much more -- it's jsut 
mildly sexual on the surface...First and foremost, dancing is a means of 
communication as valid as a poem..It is part indvidual expression, part 
tribal identity, part art, it's a way of letting yourself and people 
around you know what you're thinking and feeling...Thus that's a very 
shortsighted statement by George Bernard Shaw....

>And I think he was totally right on with that, 'cause we should dance just 
>like
>we have sex (and vice versa) -- free and open, honest and sensual, happy and
>uninhibited, expressing who we are.

hell yeah, but ideally we'd live our whole lives this way....it's 
difficult to make the jump to that level when everyone else hasn't 
reached that point, it ends up doing more harm than good...

>or in the chill spaces. And like so many who have posted on this topic, one

sex on my backpack....and my water bottle (which I needed badly many 
times throughout the night =) was literally lodged between this girl's 
legs....I wouldn't've really cared, but, their whole attitude afterwards 
was pretty disrespectful and anti-PLUR....

At 9:45 PM 4/17/96, Kyung Rok Lee wrote:
>Raving is a complicated phenomena, which has just as much to do, I
>think, with the economy, changing family structure, transcendance of
>the everyday (esp. among gays, but also among alienated workers),
>individualism gone amuck, popular music, religion lost/found, and a bunch
>of other junk, as it does with sex.  But since it's spring, and sex is in
>the air, can I get a witness?

        I totally think you hit a lot of good points. The sex drive is one
of the most primal forces in humankind (and all the animal kingdom) and if
it can't find some sort of direction (as in typical sexual relationships;
and this process of typicality has been upset by numerous sociological
factors including AIDS and a general openening up of awareness of gender
identity and orientation) then this drive will cause us to evolve into
certain ways of living in which this energy can be channelled. I *totally*
think that raving is one of these manifestations of this energy.
        I think that a lot of people, from all disciplines, who are doing
'creative hobbies' like djing, flyers, making music, etc etc (both in and
outside of the rave scene) is another way for people to focus this energy.
It's cool to have EVERYONE seeing themselves as some sort of 'artist' (at
least for me, having gone through art school and really not liking the
intellectual heirarchy there). Anyways...
        Think of this equation: orgasm/intercourse based sex is to tantric
sex as clubs and meatmarkets are to raving. At least IMHO. :)
        A non-raver friend of mine who's never been to a rave described an
e-party he was at and tried to imagine a rave and said "it seems like it'd
be like a big orgy, but without the sex." HA HA HA
        True enough for me :)
                orgies of energy =),
                        brad

One of the things I like the most about raves is that the sex vibe is low
key - i.e. it's not being pushed in my face because people don't tend to
hit on me the way they do at clubs and because the writhing body in come
hither seduction isn't the main way people dance generally (exceptions I
know)

HOWEVER - SCARY PERSONAL STORY

I always seem to need a condom when I don't have one and last year found
myself crossing my personal safe sex boundaries in order to pursue more
fluid exchanging activities with an ex-heroin using, current womanizing
fling - knowing full well of his past but being WITHOUT CONDOM and carried
away in the heat of passion

one month of agonizing pregnancy scare and six months of even more
agonizing HIV/STD scare- all's well thank god.

I now carry a condom ALWAYS - EVEN TO A THREE YEAR OLDS BIRTHDAY PARTY 

BECAUSE YOU NEVER, EVER KNOW WHEN YOU'LL NEED ONE. 

Along those lines I also try and wear a decent pair underwear whenever I
go out... you never know who might be seeing them later on.

So please guys, whether you think of raves as being sexual or not, carry a
condom and be willing to use it.

It's just not worth the risk 

Jess

Andy said ... (about how the energy of dancing is more and different than
sex)...
	First and foremost, dancing is a means of 
	communication as valid as a poem..It is part indvidual
expression, part tribal identity, part art, it's a way of 	 	letting
yourself and people around you know what you're thinking 	and feeling...

I love that description of dancing, and I think sex can be like this too...

 -- don't get me wrong, if I had to choose between one or the other for the rest
of my life ... I'd think long and hard, but I'd probably pick dancing ...
because of the additional musical depth inherent in it and because of the
varieties of human contact and communication that aren't possible with sex
(after all, I love dancing with and around all kinds of people, but I'm way
picker about sexual partners!)....

He says....(about being free, open, honest, uninhibited when we dance, as well
as when we have sex...  in short, being ourselves).... 

	ideally we'd live our whole lives this way....it's 
 	difficult to make the jump to that level when everyone else
hasn't reached that point, it ends up doing more harm than 	 	good...

I'm not sure I understand what you mean here, how can we do more harm than good
when we open our minds and hearts?  Maybe my original post implied that open
sexual behavior was ok to me -- that was't what I meant to imply.  I just feel
that the same place that our sexual/sensual feelings come from is often the same
place our dancing vibes come from, and by keeping these open, we're more in
tuned with ourselves and we're more integrated.  

Last night, Jay-J played a song with a voice track that I loved, it said
something like "make an example of yourself" -- and that inspires me, because
that's the highest goal I think we can have, to make an example in our behavior
to other people.

And those people who had sex on your backpack at Wicked were either obnoxiously
self-centered, or way too high -- in either case, I think it's totally
reasonable to interrupt people who are behaving inappropriately and suggest that
a different time/place would be in order... in a respectful and gentle way, we
can still be assertive.  I don't want people screwing on my backpack either! 

Leslie   : )

frottage and tribadism are both the rubbing of ones genitals on someones
body part other than a hand, mouth or genitals.  There may be subtle
differences between the two but basically they are the same.  However I
have heard some men in the gay community refer to frottage specifically as
rubbing ones penis between anothers legs to get an intercourse-like effect
without the exchange of fluids

X-Mailer: Microsoft Mail via PostalUnion/SMTP for Windows NT
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Organization: Macrovision Corp., Sunnyvale, CA
Date: Thu, 18 Apr 1996 16:40:34 -0700
Subject: RE: Herbal E in the news.
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


>> Is Ma Huang the potent herb in herbal E? <<

I'm not a chemist or botanist, but here's what I know: Ma Huang is ephedra. 
 Similar to/identical to/converted to ephedrine, I'm not sure, but it's part 
of what gives you the go.  Gotu Kola is caffeine.  That'll also get you 
going.  I don't remember whatever else is in Herbal E.

 --Michael
(herb abuser)

[ to sfraves list ]

 Although I'm not a condom expert , here's my opinions anyway!

1. If you're not in a sex/love relationship with someone , then it makes 
   sense to me for a guy to bring a condom with him. Especially if he's
   the type of fellow who'll carry a pack of stuff with him - if you
   haul asprin or candy around with you , ya' mind as well carry around
   a rubber or two ( just don't confuse the candy and condoms in the 
   dark ! ).

2. If you are in a relationship , the implications are somewhat more
   complicated. If you bring a condom with you to an event that your
   significant other is not attending - is there a (sub)conciouss 
   intent to have a sexual experience with someone else? 
    I don't bring a condom with me when I go out, because I don't plan
   any interactions of that type .

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

and the UK, I believe they are perscription sleeping aids...

Lots of new names in the lineups this week, so it seems like a good weekend
for variety.  I'm not sure what to recommend, but at least you have lots of
choices!  Note MAD's new location this week.

I've updated the radio and TV section - thanks to those who have sent updates.
I think it's still a bit out of date, so please send me any new info.

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Sunday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. KZSU
       90.1 (Stanford)
     * Monday afternoon 12:30-3:00 pm - DJ Jerecho presents the best of
       the urban polyrhythmic experience jungle, acid jazz, techno,
       electro, breakbeat KDVS, 90.3 FM (Davis)
     * Wednesday night/Thursday morning 3am-6am - "Aural Fixation"
       experimental sounds of ambient and trip hop with a splash of hi
       nrg, from trance to jungle. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Thursdays 9:30pm-midnight - "Aurora Borealis" Beats and
       atmospherics w/DJ Seth. KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Ambient, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, Acid Jazz
       and noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday night - "Saturday Night Spin Out" w/Ronnie Libido. Trip
       hop, Jungle, Ambient, Experimental Sounds. 10pm-2am. KFJC 89.7 -
       Los Altos Hills

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

Hey fellow ravers and the likes.

i'm off to San Luis Obisbo this weekend(Friday) and I'll be in La Saturday
to see friends and attend a local underground party or two.  Kinda excited
cuz this will be my first LA party in 2 years (the last one left me with
bad thoughts about the LA scene so I hope this weekend is better). Have a
good weekend!!!

Re: condommania

Always were one, usually always carry one or two - for my girl friend and
I. Personally I wouldn't try anything sexual in/at a rave becaue the couple
of times I did I really got bitched at by some annoyed ravers.  I see were
they are coming from cuz this type of stuff is more personal and not to be
displayed or shown to those who don't wish to see it.  What I'm trying to
say is do it in private unless you can get the concent of 200 or more
ravers...

Re: Ravers in love

Cool story... This is the first time I found a person who enjoys partying
as much as me and is a raver.. Usually I meet girls in clubs or other
places that don't enjoy house/techno/trance.  Enjoy it while it lasts -
It's kinda cool.  :)

Bye-Bye

On Wed, 17 Apr 1996, Fred Heutte wrote:

> Derrick May may have said that Detroit techno started long before Chicago
> house did, and others may agree, and with MUCH due respect to Derrick May,
> that's simply wrong.  As far as I can tell, and I've dug down into this
> issue quite a bit, what we now call house and techno started roughly
> around the same time.  You can hear them both in tracks from 1984 or
> so, and both have emerged full-blown by 1986.  Detroit borrowed from
> Chicago, Chicago borrowed from Detroit, and New York has a LOT to say
> about ALL of that too!  
> 
> The precursors of both styles go as far back as you care to go.  Myself,
> I agree with Ramon Wells, who was DJing WAY back in the day (in the early
> 1970s in Portland and Seattle), and is now the head of Bold! Records, who
> said at the Billboard convention a couple of years ago and repeated to me,
> "When you get down to it, it's ALL disco!"  And you know, he's right.
> All of these forms have many influences, but disco is a dominant one.
> If you look at it simply from the point of view of how it's made, disco,
> house, techno and all the many variants are producer- rather than musician-
> oriented production forms.  
> 
> Now, finally, on "Chicago versus Detroit."  Nonsense.  They are historically,
> geographically and economically separate, and the musical scenes there have
> always differed.  Chicago had the blues, Detroit had Motown.  Did anyone
> talk about "Chicago blues versus Motown" in the 1960s?  No, they obviously
> had differing styles but interrelated aspects.  Same as now.  
> 
> There has always been some interaction between Chicago and Detroit in
> the development of electronic dance music.  That's obvious when you hear
> Detroit house or Chicago techno, and both of those forms exist and have
> their own interesting characteristics.  But the bigger issue to me is
> *techno* vs. *techno* -- that is, what techno was when it started in
> Detroit, the motivating forces and influences that underpinned it, and
> what is has become.  Much techno I hear is soul-less, has lost the
> very foundations of the music in order to focus on the forms while
> losing the meaning.  The foundations of house too have been compromised
> on the altar of commercial accessibility and pop sensibility.  
> 
> Just read the interviews or ask Juan Atkins or Mike Banks what they think
> of what has happened to techno, or at least what people *call* techno,
> over the last few years.  They'll just mutter and shake their heads.
> 
> It doesn't have to be from Detroit to be techno, in my view (and in the
> view of the people from Detroit, I might add).  It has to be from the
> *heart*, just like all great music.
> 
> phred
>

Dear Friends & Family,

My computer tells me that on 12 Apr 1996, Edwin shared:

> I think maybe in the global "rave" scene, there's a harder, darker, or more
> aggressive side that's not as apparent on the west coast, or in SF, at least. I
> mean, having events called "Nightmare" and "Terrordrome" says something,
> doesn't it?
> 
> Just a thought. (Please don't shower me with flames about negativity...)

Edwin, I think you're right.  Even here, tracks with what I feel are very 
negative lyrics are widely played.  I'm thinking specifically of a 
popular tune that went "I'm bigger and bolder and rougher and tougher in 
other words sucker there is no other/ I'm the one and only dominator/ I'm 
the one and only dominator."
	It had a nice beat, sure.  Fun to listen to -- but if I were 
DJing at a party, I'd find something more positive to play.  There's lots 
of great tracks out there.
	And I'm glad to see that the shirts Ameba Clothing on Haight 
Street used to have prominently displayed with mass murderer Charles 
Manson's face all over them seem to have been replaced with more friendly 
designs.  
	Really, if we want positivity in our scene, we need to be 
concious of the imagery and the content we bring to the scene.
	Or PLUR (peace/love/unity/respect) will remain just a slogan, not 
a way of life.  
	Shawna's recent posts from Canada should serve to remind us that 
the global rave scene needs our infusions of love!  8)

PLURally yours,
				<<< Starchild >>>

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Apr 19 16:40:25 1996

Received: from [128.32.160.181] (wmf57.Berkeley.EDU [128.32.160.181]) by uclink4.berkeley.edu (8.7.4/8.6.12) with SMTP id QAA15860 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Fri, 19 Apr 1996 16:40:16 -0700 (PDT)

Message-Id: <v02130502ad9c99c66b8f@[128.32.160.62]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Fri, 19 Apr 1996 16:38:52 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: nancys@uclink4.berkeley.edu (Nancy)
Subject: Orgies/Redefining "Sexuality"
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>On Wed, 17 Apr 1996, KaySEE wrote:
>
>[snippty snip]
>> > Now, a sex party, on the other hand...THERE'S an interesting prospect!
>> >
>>
>> Been to one. Excellent vibe.  The vibe was actually quite like a rave.


I went to this same "sex" party as Kirsten.  I had expected something
sleazy, but as it's a much-loved twice-yearly occurence among certain Cal
students, I wanted to check it out for myself.

I had originally envisioned greasy guys grabbing me without my consent or
enjoyment, and a repulsive gangbang-type environment of graphic sex with
every woman in the room.

Nothing was further from the actual experience.  With wine, grapes, and
chocolate sauce in great abundance, the only rule was that someone else
must feed you or pour wine in your mouth.  Shedding clothes, getting
together, and sex were all absolutely up to the individual.  The vibe was
intensely _sensual_, not sexual, as great soul music, soft red lights and
candles created a luxurious atmosphere.  What surprised me the most was the
fact that nudity became unbelievably LIBERATING, not exploitative.  The
atmosphere was one of total acceptance.  People (both sexes) shed their
clothes with abandon, moving freely on the dancefloor in beautiful
nakedness - it being a sensual celebration of their humanity, not
voyeuristic exposure.

People touching became an extension of the heightened sensual ambience of
the party.  Bodies moved together, people were lapping chocolate sauce off
of each other, and there was a lot of kissing and caressing.  It was erotic
rather than pornographic.  "Foreplay" rather than intercourse.  People
explored their new liberated sexuality in groups of three or more: women
together, men together, mixed, threesomes and couples.  The energy in the
room was absolutely intoxicating - group sexual energy, rightly channeled.

I think when people object to sexuality at raves (myself very much
included), what they are objecting to is the destruction of the open,
accepting environment of the party that mainstream "sexuality" would bring
us.  Mainstream sexuality - as opposed to what many of us experience
privately - is primarily a power hierarchy: the male objectifying and
subjugating the female body through leers, gropes, and an attitude of
conquest.  _That_ sort of "sexuality" is what many women unhappily
experience at clubs and on the streets.  The objectification of the male
leer, the anonymous hand groping you from behind on the dance floor, serve
as reminders of your status as sexualized OBJECT.  These sorts of
encounters are by no means consensual, nor are they meant to be.  They are
a warped type of sexuality positioning the male as negative sexual actor
above the female subject (who is further judged primarily by her physical
attractiveness) - a power play reminding women of their sexualized,
secondary status.

Objectification is utterly insulting, but it is also, IMO, a symbol of the
sickness of our society's attitude toward sexuality.  A different group
definition of sexuality is needed, much like the intense, respectful
sensuality of the "orgy" Kirsten and I attended.  If sexuality at raves
meant exploring this new form of relating to each other - of celebrating
the individual's sensuality, absolutely consensual, with the objective of
mutual pleasure and respect - then perhaps raving could serve to enlighten
on this other, very crucial plane.  I don't think this would mean doggie
style in the chill room!  It may just mean more passionate kissing, more
holding, than we see now.

The atmosphere will never be graphically sexual - but a critical element of
this new definition of sexuality may be the incorporation of SENSUALITY
into the meaning.  As this acknowledges women's sexual response*, it
nullifies the patriarchal power relation inherent in the contemporary idea
of "sex," and could evolve us into a more equitable, happier society.

*see my post entitled "Foreplay" for elaboration.

Nancy

>        	A  D  R  E  N  A  L  I  N     R  E  C  O  R  D  S
>	o Electro Phunk Vol.1 - New School Electro

>		      **8. AFRICA BAMBAATAA & THE SOULSONC FOURCE -

>		**NOTE - This is a Exclusive remix that was released as a

>			 public done by Electrik Music aka 1 member of the

Although it IS true that the remix was done by Elektric Music (Karl Bartos'
current group), it's not true that it was a promo only. It was released on
a COMMERCIAL CD called "Afrika Bambataa - the remixes" or something like
that. Other remixes on that CD include on from LFO. =)

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Apr 19 18:34:46 1996

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Fri, 19 Apr 1996 21:43:39 -0500
To: Starchild <star@sfsu.edu>
From: ecto@citenet.net (ecto)
Subject: a funny/sad/pathetic story of a lost city
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

At 2:35 PM 4/19/96, Starchild wrote:
>        Shawna's recent posts from Canada should serve to remind us that
>the global rave scene needs our infusions of love!  8)
>

        Yes, and this reminded me to give you a bit of a scoop on what's
happening in my 'soon to be ex-home' montreal. This is somewhat of a long
post saying 'appreciate your scene' (which is BEAUTIFUL, may i add :) Then
again, it's the people that make it cool, people like SFravers :).
        Anyways.  The past few raves here in montreal have had a large
influence of bikers in them. Either bankrolling the party (with the intent
of having a non-free market economy in place for their bad e :P) or just
dealing at the party.  I was told that a large percentage of Montreal's
illicit comestibles in the rave scene are provided by the Hell's Angels. :9
Yum!
        So, the situation has become rather tense, with eager partygoers,
frightened promoters and bikers asking for a 'cut' so that parties (if not
put on by them) won't get busted. I heard the figure was 200-$500 per party
that you'd have to pay them. Then you have to pay off the cops ;) Actually,
there's one security company here that everyone uses because they've
already paid off the cops so there's one less thing for you to do as a
promoter.
        Yes, so the tension has reached a point where on the 'Rant Line'
(which is like an alternative weekly papers "open forum" for calling in)
someone has called in to say the following:

        "First of all, let me say that if i find smeone at the next rave
telling me i can't deal my ecstasy, not only am i going to punch them, I'm
going to follow them outside and put a gun to their fucking head. I don't
care if it's a fucking Hell's Angel or a little punk. I have the best
prices, it's supply and demand, and if they want a fucking war, they're
going to get a fucking war."

        Whoa there rambo! Methinks this is one of the numerous "big guys
half naked slathered with vicks" i often see at parties. I think the
testosterone took a couple wrong turns with this guy and it's all backed up
somewhere.  Oh well, this is only one in a series of long rave-related
calls that the rant line has got (and oddity for montreal, as the
alternative papers are totally punk/grunge/whatever kind of nihilistic
self-effacing music is popular at the time.  Two weeks ago it was two girls
calling a promoter a motherfucker because he oversold a party (5000 people)
and had one water bar ($2.00 each, no refills) so they had to drink out of
a hose (?) and got really really sick. (Geez, didn't your mother teach you
never to drink from strange hoses at raves?).
        The week after someone else called to tell the girls that they were
'hosebags'. Ah yes, that punny canadian humour (?)
        Anyways, don't let this happen to your city. Man, that sounded like
something from a 60's propaganda film ;) Yes, so i'm moving out of here and
hopefully will be joining my SF brothers and sisters at some point in late
summer.

        Be good to yourselves :)
                        brad

>Hi!
> Thanks for the very enlightening post. The element of sensuality that 
>you hilight in your post is , I think, what I was trying to say in my 
>post asking for people to explore this aspect of humanity at raves and 
>then bring what we learn to the rest of the world.
>
>
>
>
>Ran @ Dionysus Dreams

Sorry, I wasn't trying to be mean to Nancy or anyone else. Her post was 
interesting and a lot of thought obviously went into it. It's just... 
reading that post and others about 'sex parties' makes me uneasy. What 
about AIDS and the host of other veneral diseases? Syphilis, gonorrhea, 
and herpes just to name a few. I am reminded of this cartoon I saw in the 
70's where there is a man standing in the middle of an orgy with a sign 
around his neck saying "Penicillin." 

I know there are a lot of youngsters on this list. I certainly don't want 
them to think that all of us are having group sex. You don't need to have 
engaged in intercourse to get a disease from someone. Even oral sex will 
do it. I admit I am somewhat of a prude... I guess it's a pretty uptight 
notion these days to say that sexual experiences are meant for people you 
care about. 

I'm not trying to impose my morality on anyone. I just want us to be 
careful. :-) The combination of drug use and casual sex= a weakened 
immune system. 

Love, Amy (<-- sounding like your Mom)

>Sorry, I wasn't trying to be mean to Nancy or anyone else. Her post was 
>interesting and a lot of thought obviously went into it. It's just... 
>reading that post and others about 'sex parties' makes me uneasy. What 
>about AIDS and the host of other veneral diseases? Syphilis, gonorrhea, 
>and herpes just to name a few. I am reminded of this cartoon I saw in the 
>70's where there is a man standing in the middle of an orgy with a sign 
>around his neck saying "Penicillin." 
>
>I know there are a lot of youngsters on this list. I certainly don't want 
>them to think that all of us are having group sex. You don't need to have 
>engaged in intercourse to get a disease from someone. Even oral sex will 
>do it. I admit I am somewhat of a prude... I guess it's a pretty uptight 
>notion these days to say that sexual experiences are meant for people you 
>care about. 
>

While it is true that the only truly "safe sex" these days maybe dancing :)
There are a lot of misconceptions about STDs and AIDS/HIV especially.  I just
went and got tested for HIV (I hadn't had a test in about 5 years and even
though
I haven't done anything that is considered _really_ risky...) Well after
I discovered that I was negative (whew!) I spent the rest of the time asking
questions about the nature of transmission, etc.  It seems that as far as 
risk factors are concerned the riskiest activity (from highest to lowest is)

        Unprotected anal sex on the receiving end
        Unprotected vaginal sex on the receiving end
        Unprotected anal sex on the sending end
        Protected anal sex on the receiving end
        Unprotected vaginal sex on the sending end
        Protected anal sex on the sending end
        Protected vaginal sex on the recieving end
        Protected vaginal sex on the sending end
        Unprotected felatio on the giving end
        Unprotected felatio on the receiving end
        Unprotected cuningulus on the giving end
        Unprotected cuningulus on the receiving end
        Protected felatio on the giving end
        Protected felatio on the receiving end
        Protected cuningulus on the giving end
        Protected cuningulus on the receiving end 

The reason some "protected" risk factors ar high is because there is a
moderate chance that the condom could break*

I was also told that HIV infection by oral sex is possible but unlikely
(The Center for Disease Control has only 2 recorded cases, both on the
giving end, one case had the person performing felatio 3 - 5 times a day
on multiple partners, 4 - 5 times a week AND the person had gum disease
and did not use condoms.

One is at risk for Herpes,and possible gonorrhea by having unprotected
oral sex, by and large it is a GOOD idea to use condoms when having sex with
_anyone_ with whom you are not absolutely sure of their HIV status. I would
include all strangers in this catagory. However I don't think that people should
shy away from sex because of these things no more then you should avoid riding
in a car because of auto fatalities.  Be careful, don't do things that are
stupid, be loving aware, and caring of your partner, whether you just met
them or are engauged      

>I'm not trying to impose my morality on anyone. I just want us to be 
>careful. :-) The combination of drug use and casual sex= a weakened 
>immune system. 
>
>Love, Amy (<-- sounding like your Mom)

Sex is great, it eliviates tension, releases endorphines, and helps th keep
people well rounded, just think what the world would be like if all of the
world leaders were getting their brains fucked out of them by someone
that they loved and loved them :) I tell ya it would be a different planet!


                                                G

Last night I was watching Channel 5 news, highly amused at what passes for 
"news" on Network television, and they had a "story" about "Mexican Black
Heroin", or some such drug horror.

They proceeded to interview some ex-junkies, with their stories, and talk about
how heroin can ruin your life, which I don't doubt.

But *then* they said:

"A lot of modern media images like to glorify the use of the drug to the 
teenage audience, such as its use in 'Pulp Fiction', and Kurt Cobain's death 
due to a heroin overdose"

Now correct me if I'm wrong, but as I recall, Kurt certainly *DID NOT* die of
a heroin overdose!!!  And I personally would like to say that Kurt never 
enamored the notion of shooting heroin in any shape or form!!!  What *are* 
these
bald faced lies!?!?!?!?!  To spread drug hysteria and propaganda... I guess I
shouldn't be so surprised...

And further, as far as I remember it, "Pulp Fiction" didn't even come close to
romanticizing heroin use.  Again, I watched a woman attempt to snort heroin, 
and
immediately keel over and almost die.  Gee, that looks like fun!

Did anybody else see this awful report on The Way Things Are With Kids Today?

Subject: sex & dance
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Now I know I've heard it all. From a benign topic such as sex & dancing all
the way to orgies and sex parties with chocolate.  Yummy, just what I want
to do, have anonymous sex (safe or not), with a bunch of people, whose
hygeine and sexual history I am completely unaware.  And I do not think
there IS a such thing as safe sex.  You can wear as many of those
semi-permeable membranes all you want.  They still break, and you can still
get nasty shit by fucking these days (like genital warts, which can be
on/near the area of sexual contact, places a condom doesn't cover).  And
there has been plenty of nasty stuff flaoting around our dance community.
I won't go into details. E-mail if you're really interested.

With that said...

I do wonder about those people who say that sex has little to do with
dance.  I dunno where this idea comes from that there should be sensual vs
sexual enegery at parties.  Geez, from time incarnate whenever men & women
have dnaced together it has ALWAYS been a sexual thing.  That sensuality
stuff IMO is just a coverup or made by people who are uncomfortable with
the overt nature of sexuality of dance.

I really cannot think of a dance that is divorced from sexuality.  Whether
that be Bavarians doing that lederhosen dance thing, or the polynesians
doing thier originla dances, to the dances of my ancient home of Africa.
Yes, there have been dances about the harvest (sexual), dances about the
seasons (sexual), and still I cannot think of any form or type of dancing
that does not involve sex & sexuality.

Rave is, IMO,  no different that any other form of dance where sexes meet.
It doesn't matter the intent, we are so westernized and have come up with
so many barriers, so many excuses, that somehow some of us might say aloud
that rave ain't about that.  But when you see that person, that special
person with some special vibe, the way they move, the way they look, the
way they are, to deny that you get some form of arousal is being naieve,
IMO.  Hell, I KNOW I'm in touch with my sexuality, and when I see the right
BBB (bra booty betty), who can shake it, sweat it out, smiling, in sheer
ecstacy from the music, there is only one thing going though my mind.  Of
course that's usually the only thing going through my mind, but that's
another story.

Anyway there should be a sexual tension when the exes meet.  G-d, I would
hate going out if its all about non-sexual, non gender vibe.  I'd feel like
a friggin robot or worse a eunich (is there anything worse than either?).
I like being human, and all of the complex things about being human,
including sex.

Anyway enough of my pontification.  Sex & dance...that is what I want.
That is what dance is about.  It wouldn't be called shaking the booty,
getting in the groove, feeling the vibe,  makin' it funky, if it weren't
about sex.

But then, I do have the most purient mind.

Peace

P.S.  BBB <-  I have been using this term for years, and have no plans to
stop.  It is not meant to denigrade or objectify.  It is an apt description
that refers to a time when it got soo hot in places that many ladies of
dance would shed their outer skin, to reveal their bras.  The booty comes
from what they were shaking, and betty's is what they were, very nice
looking (IMO) ladies.  Most recently at some UG called Sandbox (didn't see
anything about it on the list) here in the city, I got a chance to see
actual real breasts (not the first time mind you) at a rave.  They were
actually quite nice, but I did wonder, since it really wasn't all that hot,
why sister chose to shed almost everything.  Same for the fire dancer, fire
eater, no top just tips (read nips).  I just didn't get it.  I could
understand it if it was really overwhelmingly hot, and people had to shed
something, but I see that as a last resort almost.  There were no problems,
and after the initial shock, people just kinda ignored it.  As soon as she
noticed that she was being ignored she put her top on (or it coulda been
she got cold, it looked like it).

One other thing about Sandbox, since it was not reviewed here.  It is
something I have always despised, something that actually started happening
at Martin's parties a long time ago.  The pow wow, in the middle of the
dance floor.  At Sandbox, some nondancers, decided to build a sand altar
right in the middle of he dance space.  It prevented people from dancing
(the primary objective), and the girls set up some candles etc, etc.  It
was all I could do not to stomp on the whole thing, but I'm a nice guy.
After she built this, er, thing, she decided to trance out by sitting with
her legs folded, her and a couple of guys I guess, and that took up even
more space.  My g-d folx, please have respect for some of us who just want
to dance.  I am not trying tantric nonsense at raves, nor am I trying to
get in touch with my shakra, shakti, or my mufti.  All I want is to shake
my booty with some friends.  Can we all just dance together without the
altars?  If you DO want to pray and trance, can you do it so there is
minimal impact to the dance experience.  Same thing for stretchers (people
who have to warm up by stretching on the dance floor), same thing for
people who want to do yoga, same thing for calisthetics.

And people wonder why I don't go out anymore.  There's no place to dance,
that's why.







From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Apr 20 19:54:03 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id TAA21981; Sat, 20 Apr 1996 19:54:03 -0700
Received: from well.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id TAA21902; Sat, 20 Apr 1996 19:52:54 -0700

Date: Sat, 20 Apr 1996 19:52:50 -0700
From: Fred Heutte <phred@well.com>
Message-Id: <199604210252.TAA07835@well.com>
To: nw-raves@hyperreal.com, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Bernard Edwards
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

A moment of your thoughts, if you are so inclined, for the memory of
Bernard Edwards who passed from this life a couple of days ago.  He
was the ground-breaking bassist and co-producer for Chic, along with
Nile Rodgers.  They began producing dance music which both fully
partook of the disco style and went well beyond it, starting in the
mid-1970s.  Sure, many of their tunes were radio fodder and were 
overplayed, but I think most people would agree that even overexposed
tunes like 'Le Freak' set a standard for both production and feeling
that go well beyond the usual limits of dance music.

I played the awesome "Sometimes You Win" from Chic's 1978 album "C'est
Chic" last night during my chillout set in Eugene.  It's still as awesome
as ever.

Edwards and Rodgers fell out over creative and personal differences in
recent years, but what matters most to me is that when they were on,
there were none better.  

Next time you hear a particularly funky b-line that makes ya wanna get
up and sweat, remember Bernie Edwards.  He was all that.

peace out
phred

Here are a couple of numbers of mail order places I said I'd post before...

Pro Sound 1-800-945-9300

sales people I have come across.  They will match almost any price.

Venemans' Music Emporium 1-800-551-9742
        They arent the greatest sales people but have decent prices,
although I usually use their prices at Pro Sound to get it shipped faster
(they are in Maryland) and Pro Sound will almost always match their prices.

Sammans Electronics (ask for Adam ext. 240) 1-800-937-3537
        I ordered 1200's from here for $389 in September and a couple I
have given this numer to have ordered them for same price since then.  They
don't come with any cartridges (but most that do come w/Stanton 500's and
they suck anyway) but with the savings you might get you could buy Stanton
680's!  If they have jacked their price like everyone else and you call

On Sat, 20 Apr 1996, John S. Lee wrote:

[snippty snip] 
> I really cannot think of a dance that is divorced from sexuality.  Whether
> that be Bavarians doing that lederhosen dance thing, or the polynesians
> doing thier originla dances, to the dances of my ancient home of Africa.
> Yes, there have been dances about the harvest (sexual), dances about the
> seasons (sexual), and still I cannot think of any form or type of dancing
> that does not involve sex & sexuality.

Have you ever thought about trance-dancing -- moving in such a way as to 
release endorphins and Goddess only knows what other mind/body chemicals. 
Shamanic traditions abound with stories of dancing to get out of the body 
to find solutions to an individuals health problem or problem's 
confronting the tribe. Very powerful stuff.



> 
> Rave is, IMO,  no different that any other form of dance where sexes meet.
> It doesn't matter the intent, we are so westernized and have come up with
> so many barriers, so many excuses, that somehow some of us might say aloud
> that rave ain't about that.  But when you see that person, that special
> person with some special vibe, the way they move, the way they look, the
> way they are, to deny that you get some form of arousal is being naieve,
> IMO.  Hell, I KNOW I'm in touch with my sexuality, and when I see the right
> BBB (bra booty betty), who can shake it, sweat it out, smiling, in sheer
> ecstacy from the music, there is only one thing going though my mind.  Of
> course that's usually the only thing going through my mind, but that's
> another story.


I think that this a good picture of YOUR perspective, but certainly it is 
not the only world view out there.


> 
> Anyway there should be a sexual tension when the exes meet.  G-d, I would
> hate going out if its all about non-sexual, non gender vibe.  I'd feel like
> a friggin robot or worse a eunich (is there anything worse than either?).
> I like being human, and all of the complex things about being human,
> including sex.
> 
> Anyway enough of my pontification.  Sex & dance...that is what I want.
> That is what dance is about.  It wouldn't be called shaking the booty,
> getting in the groove, feeling the vibe,  makin' it funky, if it weren't
> about sex.
> 
> But then, I do have the most purient mind.
> 
> Peace
> 
> P.S.  BBB <-  I have been using this term for years, and have no plans to
> stop.  It is not meant to denigrade or objectify.  It is an apt description
> that refers to a time when it got soo hot in places that many ladies of
> dance would shed their outer skin, to reveal their bras.  The booty comes
> from what they were shaking, and betty's is what they were, very nice
> looking (IMO) ladies.  Most recently at some UG called Sandbox (didn't see
> anything about it on the list) here in the city, I got a chance to see
> actual real breasts (not the first time mind you) at a rave.  They were
> actually quite nice, but I did wonder, since it really wasn't all that hot,
> why sister chose to shed almost everything.  Same for the fire dancer, fire
> eater, no top just tips (read nips).  I just didn't get it.  I could
> understand it if it was really overwhelmingly hot, and people had to shed
> something, but I see that as a last resort almost.  There were no problems,
> and after the initial shock, people just kinda ignored it.  As soon as she
> noticed that she was being ignored she put her top on (or it coulda been
> she got cold, it looked like it).
> 
> One other thing about Sandbox, since it was not reviewed here.  It is
> something I have always despised, something that actually started happening
> at Martin's parties a long time ago.  The pow wow, in the middle of the
> dance floor.  At Sandbox, some nondancers, decided to build a sand altar
> right in the middle of he dance space.  It prevented people from dancing
> (the primary objective), and the girls set up some candles etc, etc.  It
> was all I could do not to stomp on the whole thing, but I'm a nice guy.
> After she built this, er, thing, she decided to trance out by sitting with
> her legs folded, her and a couple of guys I guess, and that took up even
> more space.  My g-d folx, please have respect for some of us who just want
> to dance.  I am not trying tantric nonsense at raves, nor am I trying to
> get in touch with my shakra, shakti, or my mufti.  All I want is to shake
> my booty with some friends.  Can we all just dance together without the
> altars?  If you DO want to pray and trance, can you do it so there is
> minimal impact to the dance experience.  Same thing for stretchers (people
> who have to warm up by stretching on the dance floor), same thing for
> people who want to do yoga, same thing for calisthetics.
> 
> And people wonder why I don't go out anymore.  There's no place to dance,
> that's why.
> 


If your ,IMHO, narrow perspective does not allow you to see the good and 
enjoy it at raves, then perhaps it is best you do not go out any more.



Ran @ Dionysus Dreams

drenalin@OREGON.UOREGON.EDU (drenalin):
> Pro Sound 1-800-945-9300
>         I've ordered speakers and lighting from them they are the best
> sales people I have come across.  They will match almost any price.

Well, I'd have to disagree. I think they're total assholes, and snotty
to boot. Their attitude put me off enough that I never bothered to
order from them. 

I recently ordered a Pioneer CDJ-500mkII rig from J&R Music World in
NY. THey seem to have prices that Pro Sound couldn't match (esp. when
you factor in the fact that you're not forced to pay CA sales tax and
that ProSound charges a lot for shipping). I knew the folks at J&R
weren't BSing me about the price or their delivery times because I've
ordered stuff from them before, and so have other family members.
They're rock solid (check em out if you're buying
computers/printers/audio/etc 1-800-221-8180). Of course, they don't
have a very broad range of Pro sound or DJ equipment, but they did have
the Pioneer CDJ-500MkII's, so who cares. (Plus they were extremely nice
and helpful).

Meanwhile the assholes at Pro-Sound are telling me that the J&R folks
are lying to me about their prices and delivery times and that ProSound
wouldn't and couldn't match J&R's prices. WHen I tried to put the
squeeze on them and tell them exactly the "out the door" quotation and
the delivery times that J&R had promised... the sales-guy even had the
audacity to go into a 5 minute rant about how little he cared whether I
ordered equipment from them and that it didn't personally matter to him
whether he completed a sale or not, etc. SO I'm like ok, I guess I
won't buy from you <<click>>. The first time I called this asshole, he
immediately went from giving me pricing information to asking me for my
address and my credit card #. I asked him why he wanted my credit card
# when I was still shopping, he said "because you want to order this
now, right? why wait..." and went into a long buy-now pressure tactic.
One of my basic rules of life is that when people pressure me, I
immediately apply equal and opposite pressure in return, so I started 
telling him that I had already gotten a lower quote from J&R and that
he had to match that quote. He tried more pressure... i didn't know
they hired car salesmen at pro audio shops.

I also sent e-mail to their address asking for pricing/ordering info,
plus I ordered a catalog. This was approx 2 weeks ago. No reply
to the e-mail. No catalog.

Too bad. I already dropped my $$$ somewhere else. I guess I wasn't
pro enough for the likes of Pro-Sound. Fuck them and their attitude.

PS: although their prices aren't great, Leo's Audio in SF are a very
nice/helpful set of people. They're straightforward about the prices
they can and can't match. Check 'em out.

PPS: if anybody's gonna give me shit about trying to squeeze the last
penny out of some mail order retailers lineup. Let me remind you that
these guys are typically marking things up 40-60% over their cost. This
may make sense if you're getting lots of service and showroom support,
but that's not what happens in most mailorder transactions. So when
somebody can't match a price it's time to <<click>> and go elsewhere,
especially if they come off like complete assholes like the folks at
ProSound.

PPPS: of course, I may have gotten the wrong sales droid, and all the
other sales droids at ProSound aren't assholes...

Hi folks!
 First let me say that I appreciate the feedback (despite my schorched 
hair) from Michael Clay and John. However I am in disagreement (still) 
about the inherant sexual nature of dancing. It may seem to some 
(including Masters) that the energy involved with dancing comes from the 
sexual chakra but that is not the base chakra (I believe there is one 
more lower?) and as I understand it the chakras do not generate energy 
they transmute it from the universe at large into personal energy. Myself 
I think that we get a lot of our energy from the planet and our sun and 
who knows where else. In leaning towards John and Michaels point of view, 
I would say , if anything that this vibe is not a sexual one (although 
one can certainly restrict one's view in that way) but an impulse to 
survive (which all life seems to have in some degree) that is typically 
recognised as sex (proceation). I feel that one can remain focused on the 
pleasure aspects of fulfilling the sexual drive in some way (daancing) or 
one can dig a little deeper to explore where this impulse of life is taking us 
(if anywhere) through trance and meditation.
 As far as trance goes, it does not need to be a disconnection from the 
day to day reality around us. My favorite game is to trance dance and not 
bump into people or things around me. The deeper into trance I go, while 
remaining in contact with the here and now, the happier the vibe for me 
and the longer lasting the effects of integrating my intuitive and 
rational modes.
 Also this equating dancing and sex as one makes me think of all those 
guru's who preached love, happiness, meditation, fastimg, world peace, 
whatever and just made phat bucks and fucked the cute devotee's.
 John I didn't address your sandbox problem for a variety of reason's. It 
seemed like a silly personal thing, I like feedback from people on events 
in order to get a feel of what is working. The sand alter was most likely 
an experiment for someone(s) and was probably very cool for some folk. 
I'm sorry but your comments sound more like whining than anything else. 
If you just want to dance there are plenty of clubs that cater to just 
that. I think of raves as more experimental and free form public art 
forums and I think experimentation is good. Again I REALLY appreciate 
hearing anybody's feedback but saying that you are not going to go due to 
something "relativly" minor sounds kinda like a lame threat.


Ran @ Dionysus Dreams

                                     (yours in peace)
                                          /
                                      =*=/
                                       ~

Mr. Cone's comments are prefaced by ">":

> John I didn't address your sandbox problem for a variety of reason's. It
>seemed like a silly personal thing, I like feedback from people on events
>in order to get a feel of what is working. The sand alter was most likely
>an experiment for someone(s) and was probably very cool for some folk.

However, it was uncool for many.  She could've had it on the side where
less people were dancing, she could have shown some consideration of
others, as she tries to with great space mind you, catch her own groove.
It really prohibited others from joining in dance.  But you were not there,
you would not know.

I am all down for experimentation, as long as it does not interfere with
the group groove.  And is not disrepectful of others want/will for dance.

As for being silly.  I will ignore that comment...for now.

>I'm sorry but your comments sound more like whining than anything else.

We JUST had an episode of this.  Discretion is the better part of valor.
I'll leave this jibe alone...for now.

>If you just want to dance there are plenty of clubs that cater to just
>that.

Really?  I didn't know there  were actual clubs that played house music.
And I can go there and there will be no tranced-out hippie (wanna-bee's)
making altars in the middle of the dance floor?  Kewl d0od, tell me where
the party's at and I'm there!

(chuckles)

Man, did you miss the point.  The point is , respect for others.  I try to
catch a groove, but I really try not to bump into people, I try to give
myself some room, but give others some as well.  If I need to move into a
crowd, I will always say excuse me as I pass.  I guess I just have too many
expectations.  I better get rid of those before they get me into real
trouble.

>I think of raves as more experimental and free form public art
>forums and I think experimentation is good. Again I REALLY appreciate
>hearing anybody's feedback but saying that you are not going to go due to
>something "relativly" minor sounds kinda like a lame threat.

A lame threat?  Naw, reality.  I am not going to go because it is far to
religious for me.  I mean, all these people have gotten into my little
scene, something I really loved, and turned it into a free form public art
forum. It distresees me that things aren't the way they were.  Before there
were chill rooms, there was music and a dance floor.  No Zamfir pan flute
music and a bunch of gropers on bean bags giving massages and reading tarot
cards by blacklight.  Before rave became a free form public art forum, it
was just there for the dance.  I guess I was limited in my thinking that
this would last.  The only constant is change, and you can expect certain
change with a free form public art forum.  No, I guess you're right, rave
is dead, long live rave.  Now we truly have a direction, a vector in which
our free form public art forum can go.  To flourish and blossom into a new
type of free form public art forum, where dance is no longer the purpose.
Where sex is an abstraction to be enshrined inside the wrappings of
psychobabble altar paper, to be used whenever the subject is broached so it
can be neatly presented, logical and clean.  And I can see now how these
very ideas can exist within the context of a free form public art forum,
can not only free us from the confines of limited thinking but free us from
the problems and intricasies of humanity, where everything has an
explanation, where there are a million answers to everything, where there
are no answers at all.  I am saddened at my loss of parties, rave or
whatever, but I do have some reassurance that the old ways have paved the
way to a new vista, a new adventure, a new free form public art forum.

cmon...

People go to parties to hear some good music, see some friends, dance and
have a good time.  Everything else is bonus.

This is all IMO of course.  I'm still looking for clubs with house music.
Forget underground, I can't stand to get dirty, I need a club that sells
booze and stays open till 2 a.m.  Where there are high heels and stockinged
legs.  Where sage & wood necklaces have given way to sparkling gold
apparel, and capped teeth.  Where I smell Gendarme cologne, instead of
stinky old arm & body hair sweat.  I need a night on the town, where I can
wear some good clothes, and meet some top drawer people.  Now this is REAL
house.  And that's what I want!  Dj of the evening?  DJ P.Como, slammin the
cold rock stuff from 12-2 (who listens to music before 12).  Martini's are
half price before 11!

People should respect everyones right to have a good time and catch a groove.


Out,
John

P.S.  One of the reasons I don't go out is that I am surrounded, even
harassed by trancers and trance energies.  I mean the brightness of the
auras, and all that vibe they send out is rather unnerving.  I can't
concentrate on BBB's while they are around, filling the air with their
energies, essence, reaching higher plateaus of hummus.  I just find it way
too distracting.  Once, when I almost kicked one, a while back before I was
in the know about these things, I would learn a lesson I would not soon
forget.  While trying to circledance, my foot was heading toward the back
of a trancers skull, my foot bounced off of some invisibile force.  I can't
explain it, it just bounced off like it hit hard rubber.  I got up from the
floor after losing my balance with that flying scissor kick rebound.  The
trancer then looked up to me, calm, serene, and said, "Did you knock?".  It
was like they were talking out of an echo chamber, "Hello, hello, hello!!!"
It was!, they were talking out of an echo chamber, but I didn't see one.
I knew then that I was dealing with something greater than myself.  Humbled
, I slinked away, into the dark confines of a corner, trying to put myself
together.  As I looked toward the dance floor, I couldn't see the trancer,
just a big blue ball hovering over the dancelfoor.  I knew then that I
witnessed the birth, at that very moment, so crystalline, so clear, it was
the start of a free form public art forum.  I knew then as I know now, that
I really was limited.  I start my juggling classes and General Ed.
requirements for Urban Attention Getting.

I knew then, to respect one and all trancers.  They do good stuff.  They
helped me get into juggling.

...


no more altars!, no more altars!, no more altars!, no more altars!,...

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Apr 21 20:25:11 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id UAA08745; Sun, 21 Apr 1996 20:25:11 -0700
Received: from vmar.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id UAA08713; Sun, 21 Apr 1996 20:25:04 -0700
Received: from [157.22.240.192] by vmar.com
 with SMTP (Apple Internet Mail Server 1.0); Sun, 21 Apr 1996 20:29:00 -0700
Message-Id: <v02130504ada09d539bb0@[157.22.240.192]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Sun, 21 Apr 1996 20:22:46 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Vince <vince@vmar.com>
Subject: Vibe in Vegas (long)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Haven't seemed to find it yet.

I've taken numerous trips to the Vegas area over the years, and searched
and searched for a nice place to dance. This trip I decided to really make
an effort. I checked my favorite coffee/cafe hangout Cafe Copioh. This is a
really cool spot on Maryland Parkway near UNLV. Nothing that even resembled
a Rave flier, I asked around and a few folks said Utopia. Hummmm, so I
flipped through a copy of SCOPE, (kinda the Vegas Guardian). I found a few
prospects, one a used clothing store called The Haight (gotta check that
out) the other a new clothing store called ECO Style. So I head up north to
check out the Haight, They are not open yet so I cruize the thrift store
accross the street and find a cool shirt (silver lamay $3.98). They are
still not open, so I check out the antique store downstairs, the lady there
says they usually open around 11:00, so I hang a few minutes, then wait
upstairs on the balcony. Julie arrives around 11:15, we immediately hit it
off. The store is way cool, and her prices are good. We go downstairs and
hang out with Holly next door who also has a cool used clothing store
called Rags. I hang around there for about 2 hours talking about Vegas and
the people there. Trying to figure out what makes them so uptight and
nervous. Julie couldn't believe my openess, and said thet most of the
people who find her shop from the SF area are all this way. It caught her
offguard, like "What do you really want ?" So anyway, I bought a Velvet
jacket from her, and a cool orange shirt and a VW toy from Holly. Oh Yeah,
I picked up a flier for "Utopia" its a weekly, club event down town, Sat
nights. Looks cool. Different DJ's each week, from all over, this week a
local, one from Chicago, and another from Austrailia. Next stop was ECO
Style. Nice shop, nice clothes, got a shirt there as well, marked way down
:)  (I'm becoming quite the little shopper these days). The girl there
asked if I was going to Utopia. I guess it's the only thing going. She
agreed. I asked if there are any UG parties, all ages?? outdoors maybe??
She said there used to be some but not any more, just Utopia. Hummmm, one
night a week, downtown, and over 21. Everyone was very enthusiastic, so I
decide to stick around another day to check this out.

Sat night, a cup of tea at Cafe Copioh, a bite to eat and I'm off to
Utopia, but first I decide to have a little fun with the tourists (and
locals) and take a stroll down the strip in the wackyest rave-ware I could
find. Much wispering and snickering as I wander down the street. I few
times I was almost confronted, by 5 or 6 very cleancut-American looking
college boys, but I think they decided it wasn't worth the effort. (good
for me) I arrive at Utopia, and wait in line, short, quick. A few cool
looking kids are floating around, we say Hi, and see ya inside. Once I get
inside, the place is done up really nice. The folks putting this together
really want it to happen. Great artwork, big chill room, big couches,
beanbags. The permanent looking artwork (sculptures) are nice as well. I
proceed to the fairly empty dance floor, and bop around with some of the
cooler folks from out front. Then I really start to notice that about 10%
(or less) are really into it. They are all decked out, in the coolest of
thrift store fashion, and dancing up a storm. The other 90% and hanging
around one of the 3 full bars dressed in black and high-heels. I might as
well have gone to the Shark Club. I thought, maybe it's just me, lighten
up, so I cruize around the place, just checking things out. I got stranger
looks inside the club than I did out on the street ?? Really sad. It was
like any BAR in town, except it had better music, great space, nice
visuals, but the same uptight crowd. I wanted to grab the 10 or 15 cool
kids there and bring them back here with me. We gave it our all, but the
room just wouldn't respond.

So to sum it all up. Has SF and SFRaves totally ruined my going out
experiences, once I leave town. Will anything ever measure up to the SF
scene ??  I couldn't wait to get home, and to think I almost moved to Vegas
!! Utopia was by far the best thing I've found in Vegas, but compared to
what I am used to, on an almost daily basis, it was really sad.

Sorry for the long post, I think it's rave related. I just needed to vent,
and tell you all that I miss you.

luv,

Vince



PS: I guess I shouldn't say there is no Vibe in Vegas. There is no Rave in
Vegas, I found some very vibey people, and some nice places to hang out.

VVVVVVVVVVMMMMMMMMMMMMAAAAAAAAAAAARRRRRRRRRR
vince@vmar.com           http://www.vmar.com
   707.257.8627          707.481.2320 cell
          http://www.club.net
RRRRRRAAAAAAAAACCCCCCCCIIIIIIIINNNNNNNGGGGGG

Hello!
I think that raving encompasses so much of life that to limit the 
acceptable topics on this list would be to limit our views. Whatever 
evolves on here is part of what people are thinking and projecting at 
parties, so should it be catagorized? Raving is one part of a complete 
life, so everything has its place....Talilla
