progress was quite nice. it lived up to my expectations quite nicely, even
though there were only minimal decorations.. i had expected it to be a bit
more "spiritual" in nature, because of all the hoopla they made about the
celestine prophecy. the jungle room was a bit too small, IMO, but there was
obviously nothing they could do about it, given the space they had (which
was very nice).
i went up with Jess and Renauld (i hope it's that. i'm so terrible with
names), who has an awesome pair of orange pants, and ended up meeting Nancy,
KC and some others (whos names i forget - sorry all. again, i'm just
terrible with names). everyone was really having a great time, and there was
lots of energy flowing around. however, i didn't experience any of that
sexual energy that everyone is talking about! surrounded by beautiful women,
and not a twinge. maybe i'm just an anomaly (sp?).
overall, a great party. it's just too bad i had to work the next day. :(

brendan

Dear Friends & Family,

	This strikes me as one of those instances when the spread of 
information might prove helpful... 
	Only a few days ago, Ethan tells us that due to noise complaints 
and other unspecified difficulties with management, MAD would no longer 
be happening at the Bahia on Mondays.
	Now Jim tells us there will be a new weekly event, same space, 
same night, different name.  I'm wondering, does Jim know what caused 
Ethan and crew to pack up and move?
	If he does, and decided to use the space anyway, is it because 
the problems have somehow been resolved?  Or has this new group of 
promoters somehow compromised in a way that the old promoters would/could 
not?  
	If it is the latter, I would like to know the nature of the 
compromise in order to determine whether Movement is a party I want to 
participate in.
	On the other hand, if Jim and his fellow Movement promoters don't 
know why MAD left (and let me add here that I don't know myself, or I'd 
be more than happy to share it with you all) I suggest that they find out 
but quick from Ethan or Joe Rice or someone in the know so that they 
will have an idea what's in store for them using the space.

Much love,
				<<< Starchild >>>

know, would be a VERY SERIOUS RAVE :) since a lot of my male friends 
spend their time enjoying the HUGE amount of females at raves there 
wouldn't be anyone to talk to so they'd all just dance grimfaced, face 
front. :)

on the other side of the coin, if all the WOMEN i knew had a rave only 
for women, it'd degenerate into a huge gab-fest .... or possibly 
grope-fest if i know a few of my friends :)

an interesting concept, but really, i hope the sexes remain equally mixed 
in this scene ... it's lots more fun ;)

>No sex vibe ????  but you DID notice that you were surrounded by in your
>words "beautiful women"...... now imagine a rave with ONLY men  attending
does beauty stem from sexuality though? i had original considered writing
"beautiful women and men" but since that didn't really apply to my sexual
orientation i didn't include it. still, men can be beautiful as well as
women, as can material objects. i could find a building aesthetically
pleasing - certainly no one would argue that i was sexually attracted to an
office complex... (hmm. better start alt.sex.fetish.architecture now..)

>Too bad that most US raised males think sex is ONLY about genitals or
>genital involvement - it's far more subtle than that and lots more fun 
proud to say i'm not a US raised male, and that i don't share that viewpoint. =)

anyway, why does dancing have to go hand in hand with sex? our whole body
works in rythm (cycles), not just sexual function. our hearts beat, blood
pumps, cells live and die. our whole existance is not only about sex! (well,
mine at least. hmmm.. does that mean everyone picking up these sexual vibes
is a nympho? uh oh.. i'm on a list full of deviants!! =) )
going back to the music style thing again, maybe everyone listens to a bit
too much house? ;)  IMO, house is a more "sexy" form that say, gabber or
acid trance. just imagine trying to have sex with gabba in the background.
those 240 bpm might make it a bit difficult...

and other thing about progress: i was drugless again, bringing me up to 100%
straight attendance at raves.

brendan

Hello everyone,

    Well, it's been a good week of relaxation, after we had to cancel 
the last Harmony (4-12-96). (Pretty disturbing, but you do what you 
gotta do!) So anyways, we are bringing all of our thoughts and energy 
together again for another party...

     On May 3rd, Harmony Productions presents... "Beautiful People"

    Djs:    Deaks   Ethan   Greg   Trent   Graeme   Shilo Maggi

            (408) 486-9591              (408)450-3044

    We have a space in the S.F. area that holds 1000, and has a.c.!!! 
But, we are only letting in 800, because we don't want everyone to be 
over-crowded. Our party at ACME was way to packed and we don't want to 
do that again!!! (And no, this party is NOT at ACME!!!) So get there 
early, to ensure that you get in!! Also, the first two-hundred people 
through the door get cool free stuff!!!!! :) 

    We want to see you there! So come out and help create a night of 
love, energy, and harmony!!!!!


Peace,

Greg :)

Subject: DANCING

Precedence: bulk

I just wanted to add my personal experiences about dancing and its 
relation to sex.

When I dance, I really feel the music move my body.  I used to not even 
know how to dance.  I was a bit intimidated by the dancing "form" at 
parties because I felt like such a clutz.  It took me many months to 
squelch my intimidation, but what did it was the music.  I have always 
been infatuated with music that made you want to MOVE and that gave you 
energy.  When I first heard house/techno, something clicked.  It took me 
awhile to truly appreciate the music, but when I did, I stopped caring 
about what I looked like when I danced.

Sporadically, I'd achieve movements that "felt" right.  I honestly don't 
know how to explain the movements, it's just that they evoke a wonderful 
feeling in my body that makes my body never want to stop.  I have no idea 
what I look like, and I guess I just don't care anymore.  I enjoy myself 
by moving my body, and that's all I care about.  

A friend of mine just recently admitted to me she was really nervous 
about dancing and how she looked.  I told her that if she worried in the 
least bit about what she looked like, she'd never really be dancing.  
After I told her that the only way to dance is to move your body until 
you reach this feeling where everything feels "just right," she tried 
it.  Now, I swear, her dancing has improved and she reaches times when 
she really enjoys herself.

Anyway, when I dance, sex is the last thing on my mind.  It isn't sexual 
to me at all, and I really hope someone doesn't see me in a sexual 
light.  I've run from that for a long time.  I'd rather be me, Kirsten, 
with all of my imperfections than a pretty object to look at. 

Although, I really do understand the beauty of dance.  Second to dancing, I 
LOVE watching other people dance.  It absolutely enthralls me to see people 
enjoying themselves in this way.  I love seeing all of the beautiful 
people (which is everyone) let down their barriers and dance in their own 
way.  If this is sexuality in a larger form, than it is a form completely 
unkown to me.  I feel completely devoid of sexual feelings while dancing.
But, maybe there is a level of sexuality that I have yet to reach!!!  

cheers,
kc

kirstenc@uclink.berkeley.edu
.*.*.*.*.*.*.*.*.*.*.*.*.*.*

"Talk is cheap..."

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Apr 22 13:51:11 1996

From: KaySEE <kirstenc@uclink.berkeley.edu>
Subject: Vibe in SF was Re: Vibe in Vegas (very LONG)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <1381990893-10152819@mail.bungie.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9604221252.O18714-0100000@uclink.berkeley.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello everyone,

It has taken me awhile to get to around to writing this post, but here it 
is.  It is just me writing about my experiences, but I thought it was 
something interesting to share!!

Last weekend I attended State of Divinity put on by Inner Circle.  
Knowing full well that I was running the risk of a terrible party (met 
all the requirements for the "you know it's going to be a terrible party 
when..."), I decided to be adventurous and check it out anyway.  

The dj line-up was amazing, the map point was at F8, and they only charged
$10.  At first glance it seemed like a nice party, everything seemed to 
be pointing towards that.  It was held at Pier 66 in the city.  I think 
there has been another party there, but I'm not sure.  The place it was 
held in was a boat storage place, I think.  It was a really neat place.  
There was lots of outdoor space.  They had built a fire and were 
projecting video clips (saw MLK once) on another building.  The darkness 
hid all of the industrial waste, and left, in its place, a serene night 
over a sparkling bay.  You could see city lights reflecting off of the 
water, and the dark imprints of the many boats surrounding the area added 
to the surreal effect.

The building where the party was had the main dance area opened to the 
water.  I imagine it's where they work on the boats because up above 
there was a balcony.  This dance area was like a huge hall and people 
kept walking through it, which was annoying because it was hard to 
dance.  But, seeing the water and the lights as you danced was really 
nice, albeit a bit cold later on!! Further back, there was a smaller, better 
lit room with more dj's.  There was also a wonderful chill room that they 
had decorated with lots of black lights and posters and a couch, and a cool 
oriental rug.  There was also a dj in the chill room, and the music was 
really nice.  In the two dance rooms, there were a couple lazers, and the 
sound system was good.

So, *physically* it had the makings of a nice party.  However, the party 
had no soul.  I guess you could call this "no vibe," but, honestly, no 
soul is what it felt like.  I knew this from the beginning when we heard 
one of the drug dealers say, "Cool, everyone is going to be high 
tonight!" as they supplied to the demand!

"Oh well," I thought, "a party is only what you make of it!"  I was with 
two female friends, and we were determined to have a wonderful time!  
However, as the night went on, that lack of soul really was hard to 
overcome.  

In the small room no one but a couple of breakdancers (admittedly very 
good!) were going off.  I really like that room better than the other one 
that was open to the outside because the music was better, and it was 
better lit.  But, it was the age-old dilemma of no one would dance 
because no one else is dancing.  The three of us just started dancing, 
and, sure enough, people trickled in.  It was fun being the first 
ice-breakers, but we were really determined to get some vibe going!!

As the party progressed, I looked around me for happy faces, but found 
NONE.  The place was filled with *takers*, people who demand a good time, 
but aren't willing to give of themselves to have a good time.  They just 
take and take and take, and expect to be entertained.  This was all a 
learning experience for me, and something I am happy to have 
experienced.  What they didn't realize, and maybe something that I 
didn't realize before this, was that you have to give of yourself to 
receive.  The more you give, the more you receive.  

Giving can be in the simplest way; all it takes is enjoyment and 
expression of your enjoyment.  I honestly felt sorry for the dj's because 
they were giving of themselves (the music), and putting work into their 
sets, and all the crowd could do was take, in a "give-me-more" kind of 
attitude.  Talk about no appreciation.  Seeing this around me really 
opened my eyes to this situation and I guess to "vibe" in general.  

Not willing to give up, and sure *I* wasn't trying hard enough, I went 
around trying to talk to people, or ask them for water, or anything.  I 
was just met with blank stares.  No one was friendly at all, no one 
wanted to chit-chat about the party or if they were enjoying themselves.  
It was really strange, and I felt a deep sadness for a group of people 
who couldn't reach in themselves to find what they were looking for!  (I 
hope I am not over-generalizing by saying "group."  If any of you folks 
were out there, I was desperately looking, but didn't find you!!!)

My experiences in the chill room are even worse.  I was hanging out with 
my two friends, and we were partaking in ordinary chill room type 
activities: hugging, talking, drawing on ourselves with flourescent 
markers!!!  All of a sudden, I felt a weird feeling, and I turned around 
because I was facing away from the door.  Looking behind me I saw 3 or 4 
*huge* men.  They were obviously gangsters, and not just the people  
who dress like that because it is in (please, excuse me again, I am not 
trying to stereotype or offend:).  One of them looked at me, and said, 
"Look, bitches!"  Now, if that isn't enough to frighten someone, I don't 
know what is.  We felt really threatened at that point, and quickly got 
our stuff together and found a small dark corner to hide in.  We didn't 
see those guys again, thank god, and we weren't willing to give up just 
yet, so we stayed.  One of the reasons they pointed us out in the chill 
room, is that we were the only people having fun.  We were lost in our 
own world, and I guess, in retrospect, were making somewhat of a 
spectacle of ourselves in that situation.  No one else was hugging, nor 
did it appear that they were having an iota of fun.  When you stand out 
in a chill room for appearing happy, something is wrong!!!

After that experience we went back to the small room to await Tracy, 
because that's who we had wanted to hear all night.  When she finally 
came on, she was able to get maybe 1/2 hour into her set, and then the 
electricity went out!!  I think the whole block went out!!  At that point 
all signs pointed to LEAVE, which we did.

The party had such potential, but the crowd was horrible.  Finally, I had 
seen an example of how intricate the relationship is between the music 
and the people.  This place had the former, but not the latter.

Anyway, I do have to say that *in spite of* everything, I still managed 
to have an amazing time with my friends.  It was an evening I wouldn't 
have changed for the world, and I actually enjoyed myself quite a bit.  
Besides, I love learning experiences!!

I had a great time at the 420 party (amazingly beautiful spot) and also a 
wonderful time sharing dances with Brendan, Jess, Sarah, Nancy, and some 
others at Progress.  The jungle room didn't seem to attract too many, but we 
gave it our all.  Right Jess?!  I'll most likely be at Mad tonight 
(Rok-do you hear me?!!) so I hope to see some of you there :)

luv,
kc

kirstenc@uclink.berkeley.edu
.*.*.*.*.*.*.*.*.*.*.*.*.*.*

"Talk is cheap..."

Subject: LA Blew my Mind - Much LOVE in the family
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I gotta say I had the best road trip to LA in a long time due mostly to
LOVE on Saturday night.

The last time I went to a party in LA was two years ago.  Bad vibe, lots a
speed and very acidy hard core music. No fun and since then I hadn't been
back because I love SF so much.  Well... this all chanbed Sat. night.

The saturday 420 party was postponed because the access road was, well,
unaccesable :(.  I got to Santa Monica and couldn't get a hold of anyone I
wsa supposed to met down there.  Stranded, I called Kevin on the SOCAL
RAVES list and hooked up with him.  Thanks Kevin, I don't know how I would
ever of found anything down there with out your help.  After dinner we went
to LOVE which combined with RaveRats to create a bigger party...

I felt like a newbie - strange town, new people, new location.. I didn't
know what to expect.  Went to a back alley map point for this one (I'm so
used to going to F-8, Housewares, established front door locations for
tix).  Right off, people were cool - wishing a good trip.  The location - a
mall.  WOW! the promoters for LOVE secured a section of a mall and set up
three sound systems - up stairs down stairs and the main love room- with
plenty of bass I might add - Yeah!  For 15 duckets you deffinetly got what
you pay for - Lasers, Lighting, good visuals, execllent space, great dj
line up, great people....It's monday and my mind is still flipped about
this.

Got there about 10:30 - 11  Most memorable Djs =3D Right when I got theere
Alison was upstains and just brought me home.  Her set reminded me of many
a SF styled dj's, great stuff.  Thomas Micheal was the shit - got me movin'
most of his set, Sky Lab 2000 (live) - excellent - I love to hear music but
when you see it created it's just that much better, Trance - heard him
before and he's never disapointed me, just great trance, and SF's own
Graeme was a fav of mine too.  There was so much more I just can't list
them all.

Vibe - couldn't be better. Left and right I was meeting people, shakin'
hands, givin' hugs, just reminded me of the old skool days in SF.  I say
old skool cuz only parties like Chrystalis, Harmony, Gathering and others
bring out such an excellent vibe now.  For the size of this party, it went
off.  Every one seemed like they belonged there and everyone was equil.  No
circle dancers, no showing off, no frontin', just great people having a
great time.

I met a lot of SOCAL RAVERS-
Kevin - thanks for helpin' me out and introducing me to soooo many people.
Keep in touch.

Kidee- you got so much energy, nice to met you,

Robert-  saw you blowin' those huge bubbles, and I love your mind gear.
Where did you get em'

Mason- excellent make up

uhhmmm... I know there's a few more but I can't remember sorry I guess when
you take in so much info, love and energy your head can only handle so
much.  This doesn't include all the wonderful people not on the list that I
met but LA's got their shit together.  Memorable stuff- ooohhh the whistes,
ooohhh the whistles, I know now what you guys mean about bass worshipers -
in SF everyone centers around the dj but at this party every one centered
around the speakers and hardly anyone crowds the dj - its all good you
might have seen me right up front too.

All in all excellent party. There's no place like home but i can't wait
till I go down again.

                Austin

 PS When I move down to San Luis Obispo I now have a very tuff decesion -
Do I drive 3.5 hrs to SF to party on sat or 3 hrs to LA?

Subject: MAD/Movement
From: Jim Grady <jim@aeonmedia.com>

I'd like to clarify a few things about Movement's entering the space that 
MAD is leaving.  First of all, I should say that I don't really know the 
details of this myself;  I'm speaking for my friend Julio Feferman (DJ 
Julio), who doesn't have an e-mail account.  I saw the posts from 
Starchild and Joe, so I called Julio to ask what was up.  This is what he 
told me:

It is unfortunate that MAD is moving out;  the reasons would best be 
explained by Joe et. al (I think Joe's post began to do that).  Movement 
is supportive of the scene as whole, and hopes that MAD will continue to 
do the excellent job they have done in the past.  Hopefully, this will 
just enrich the scene by bringing more variety.  The compromises were 1) 
don't play too loud and 2) maintain a good rapport with the house.  Bahia 
Cabana is a great space, and it should be preserved.

Let me just say personally that I hope Movement can live up to MAD's 
tradition at Bahia.  I don't know Joe Rice, but he did spin a few years 
ago at an event  called Overdrive at the Claremont Colleges (where Julio 
and I both went) organized by our friend Mark Stracha, and he kicked ass. 
 Best of luck to MAD at V/SF!

Jim

From: George Feil <george@unrrts.com>

Precedence: bulk

>  O.k. Mr. Jake- I have to ask what is 'frisbee golf' and how is it 
> played? I tried to get a mental pisture on this one, but.......here is my 
> post instead.........

Frisbee golf is similar to regular golf, except that you throws a
frisbee instead of hitting a ball with a club. You starts at a "tee",
and throw the frisbee towards the "hole", which is actually a round
metal basket surrounding a pole. Repeat until you land your frisbee in
the basket. Scoring in both games is similar.

Serious frisbee golf players use specially designed disks that are
somewhat heavier, and more wind-resistant, than your standard Whammo
Frisbee. They often have a collection of several disks they play with,
each having distinct travel, weight, and accuracy
characteristics. This is analogous to a golfer carrying a bag of
clubs.

The great thing about frisbee golf is that the low risk from being hit
by a flying disk allows golfers to share their courses more easily
with other park visitors. However, this can add to the number of
hazards you must face in play. :)

In-Reply-To: <v01530500ada11c5d4825@[153.37.82.88]>

 Austin - right on! _Love_ was a really, really fun party. I was in LA to 
visit my girlfriend, and it was the highlight of our weekend.
 The LA scene does seem to have a lot more 'speaker tweakers' than I've 
seen in SF, and they are so much fun! They are all really into the music, 
and help keep everyone's energy level way up all night. There is one guy in 
particular called "Baby Hardcore" that I've seen in action twice now; at 
_Dune_ and now _Love_. He's usually dangling off the side of the speaker 
stacks with his tongue hanging out, urging everyone on, and just 
generally going fucking insane. The best thing is that he's not at all 
interested in being the "show", just helping everyone get as crazy as he 
is. If I were a hardcore DJ, I would PAY Baby Hardcore to do his thing 
during my sets. In my mind, he is what all those("one two, one two") MCs who 
rap along with Jungle DJs want to be; minus the ego.
The image of these guys (and girls), their hands on each other's shoulders,
surging back and forth towards the stacks is one I'll always remember. It
almost looks like some crazy sport, except everyone's on the same team - 
and everyone wins! right on.

In short, the LA scene is one worth checking out. I've met some really 
nice, friendly SOCAL people, and the rave scene seems much less "LA" than 
most of Los Angeles.

-Dan

Date: Mon, 22 Apr 1996 17:23:51 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: nancys@uclink4.berkeley.edu (Nancy)
Subject: Is discussing sexuality offensive/NRR?
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I am very sorry that this thread ("Orgies/Redefining Sexuality") has upset
people.  But please read this because because I really feel misinterpreted.

The topic of sexuality at raves had already been raised.  The reason why I
brought up the "orgy" I attended (although I specified it was primarily
sensual, not sexual) was to illustrate what a healthier, more consensual
type of "sexuality" might look like in a group setting - to add a new
notion of sexuality to the questioning of mainstream values that goes on in
raving.

I strongly believe that what we are doing in the rave scene is exploring
our identities, our society and our notion of community.  Implicit in that,
I believe, is a questioning of the hierarchical gender order that
undergirds our society - ESPECIALLY evident in mainstream sexuality.  When
people express discomfort with "sex" at raves, I believe it refers to what
we have come to think of as "sex" - nasty come-ons, leering, casual sex
with strangers.  I was trying to bring up the idea of a transformation of
our idea of sex to include sensuality (rather than focus on
intercourse/objectification).  This concept of sex, I wrote in my post,
incorporates FEMALE sexuality (which I believe is more sensual, less
inclined to have meaningless encounters).  This new idea that is equal
female-male sexuality rather than the current male-oriented definition has
revolutionary potential for our society.

I did not feel this topic advocates overt sex or is NRR.  I did not mean an
orgy at a rave.  I was trying to expand the discussion of whether there is
sexual energy at raves, etc., to a new definition of sexuality - one based
on peace, love, unity and respect!

For many of us raving has been an all-encompassing journey where we have
learned MANY lessons about our lives.  How can we say our attitudes toward
sexuality are not affected by what we learn there?  This thread was not
pornographic - no-one offered graphic detail of sex acts or propositioned
people.  It was an exploration on the role of sexuality IN RAVING.

Peace to you all, and apologies again to any who are offended --
Nancy

To: KaySEE <kirstenc@uclink.berkeley.edu>

Subject: Re: DANCING 
In-Reply-To: <Pine.3.89.9604221240.L18714-0100000@uclink.berkeley.edu>
Message-ID: <Pine.A32.3.93.960422171816.163277D-100000@itsa.ucsf.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


>From my personal experience I seem to have two very distinct styles of
dancing.

The first would be a more self-conscious and more overtly sexual kind of
dancing. The kind of dancing when you go to a disco and do all the right
moves and try and be the most attractive and sexy person on the dance
floor - MTV style.  I
think I am able, at least in some degree, to pull off this kind of dancing
although I've never enjoyed it and until I discovered the Grateful
Dead and then Raves I considered myself someone who HATED DANCING.  It's
sort of marginally fun to attract sexual attention to oneself but in no
way compares to the ecstatic experience of dancing style #2.

The second kind of dancing which I do at raves is not exactly
devoid of sexuality but IS devoid of self-consiousness (at least when I've
caught the groove and things are flowing well).  I probably look stupid to
the uninitiated with limbs flying every which way and body writhing in a
seemingly uncontrolled fashion.  However, this is the kind of dancing that
made me change my mind and decide that I am in fact someone who LOVES
DANCING at least when there's enough room to and permission of the
group for me to truly let go. 

So the point is that my sexuality is probably present in both styles of
dance but in the second it is un-self-consious and so if someone perceives
me being sexual in my dancing then that's cool because that's the real
me and the uninhibited me.  We are all sexual beings and our sexuality
will show up in all our acitvities -especially ones which directly involve
us moving our bodies. 


Love Jess

smile on my face still... I hope it lasts until the weekend,

and I (although I may be alone in this) like minimal lighting.  A black
light suffices for me.   It helps me stay connected to the people and the
music when I'm not also being overloaded on the visuals even though that
can be fun too.  I like it when the main lighting event consists of
dancers in their glowing clothing.  

So... anybody going to F8's 1st beach party of the year?  I went to their
last of last year and it was really sweet.  We are so lucky to live in a
place where outdoor parties can happen so much of the year.  I want to go
and dance in the moon light with the sound of the waves mixed in with the
trancey beats.  Who's coming with me???


Jess

In Santa Cruz there is a frisbee golf course at De La Viega county golf 
course.  I think it's free, but I'm not absolutely sure.  If you want to 
find it, get a map of Santa Cruz or call information and then talk to the 
people at the clubhouse in the golf course. It's a nice course to play in 
and not that far from the Bay Area, well, sort of far, but it might be 
worth it.
				   Love,
					Matt 
 					   Da
					    Loaf

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Apr 22 18:45:36 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id SAA27910; Mon, 22 Apr 1996 18:45:36 -0700
Received: from uclink4.berkeley.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id SAA27904; Mon, 22 Apr 1996 18:45:33 -0700
Received: from [128.32.160.52] (hmfmac14.Berkeley.EDU [128.32.160.52]) by uclink4.berkeley.edu (8.7.4/8.6.12) with SMTP id SAA05779 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Mon, 22 Apr 1996 18:45:28 -0700 (PDT)
Message-Id: <v02130507ada1ebc3a7ea@[128.32.160.52]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Mon, 22 Apr 1996 18:44:00 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: nancys@uclink4.berkeley.edu (Nancy)
Subject: Progress Review
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Disclaimer: opinionated personal review to follow, including views on how
to throw a party and what sort of music I like.  Be forewarned!  ;)

I'm glad to see that so many SFRavers had such a good time at Progress.
That makes me feel a little guilty about this review, but in fact I thought
it was quite mediocre.  (I have come to have high expectations of a party -
maybe that's the culprit).

This was a minimalist rave.  The space was good, nice and clean, but it was
devoid of any decoration.  There were just dark, dark rooms with music (and
very little lighting).  There wasn't even a chill room! (Where water was
sold, there was a couch - but that's it!).  I was disappointed with that.
I like candles and incense and bean bags and posters.  I'm spoiled, yes.  I
want to see love in a party.   I _have_ heard good things about the woman
who throws this party, I mean no disrespect to her, and I like the
spiritual basis - but that part was only on the flier and voicemail.  There
was absolutely nothing at the actual party to remind people of the REASON
behind it all - I really was expecting a bit more emphasis on that.

Security was a bit tough, too - searching everything and projecting a
controlling vibe, and patrolling the party.  (I am ambivalent here - I
dislike the vibe this introduces, but do recognize the safety it brings).
Combined with the absolute austerity of the environment, the effect for me
was alienating.

So that left just music, and people.  Three rooms - hardcore trance (insert
orgasmic happy face here), jungle (tiny tiny room - testament to jungle's
underrepresentation in SF!) and house.  Nice to have variation - props to
Jane on that.  I stayed in the trance room.  Here I was piqued by the
scheduling of Ethan to end at 12:30, and the fact that Mars had gone on
first (at 9!).  (I  have become quite an opinionated little raver - even to
having definite opinions about when certain dj's should spin!)

Ethan and Mars are two of my FAVORITES, because they spin that incredible
energy trance.  I think they are two for the prime dancing hours, which in
the rave world are from about 1 to 4am.  I got there at 12 to hear the last
of Ethan, who absolutely went off (as usual).  The energy was building so
high, and then Jon Santos and Serge followed.  They are both very good at
what they do, but (until the end of Serge's set), the trance became
minimal, a lot of repetitive beats with some tripped out effects.  I found
a lot of this undanceable, but it WAS very enjoyable to LISTEN to.
However, I really wanted to dance and was frustrated by that.  There was
nary a hoot or a yell from the crowd for hours.  I didn't feel that group
vibe, that high energy, until Serge finished off with the driving, dancing
trance stuff.

I realize this is very personal taste which colored the party for me.  But
the crowd was not really responding either, and I have discovered that I am
absolutely dependent on the group high.  I fucking LOVE it when everyone
starts screaming and jumping up and down and the energy goes sky-high.
This is directly proportional to the music played.  I like a crowd-pleasing
dj, and I want one at the height of the night.  Is that too much to wish
for?

We left at five (unbelievably early for me).  Oh, we still had fun (ALWAYS
have fun at a rave!), but it wasn't special - the five of us were in
complete agreement.  Getting home in time to relax in the hot tub with my
raverboy as the sun rose was special, however :).

I was glad to meet more of you - hello Jess (great dancing!), Sarah,
Brendan ("drugless 99"), Renaud!   We will meet again (most likely on the
dancefloor!).  Hey Wayne, where were you?  Thought you were supposed to
work there...?

Bye all,
Nancy

Wow, I didn't expect to stir up such controversy my first week on the 
list.  Ethan, we put "Movement takes the place of MAD" for two reasons:  
First, we wanted people to recognize that the location was the same.  
Second, we wanted to make it clear that MAD wasn't there anymore, so we 
wouldn't be doing what you're saying the club owner is doing--making it 
ambiguous as to whether MAD is still there so he can ride off of what you 
built.

I've never met the club management--if they won't change their ads, 
that's bullshit.  One thing I do know is that Julio is for real and you 
should meet him before calling him sleazy.

Jim

Subject: Re: progress/dancing/the sex thing
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>anyway, why does dancing have to go hand in hand with sex? our whole body
>works in rythm (cycles), not just sexual function. our hearts beat, blood
>pumps, cells live and die. our whole existance is not only about sex! (well,
>mine at least. hmmm.. does that mean everyone picking up these sexual vibes
>is a nympho? uh oh.. i'm on a list full of deviants!! =) )


Well, my take on it is that dancing shouldn't really be qualified as "sexual" 
or "non-sexual".  As with most things, IMHO, it's never really just one way or 
the other.  For me, rather, I'd have to agree with what Tom said a while back, 
that dancing doesn't come from sexual energy or vice versa, but rather both 
come from the same source of energy.  Therefore, while one does not come from 
the other, the two are still related without actually being dependent on each 
other.  For me, that one energy source seems to fuel both.  Therefore dance can 
be a very sensual experience without actually being a sexual experience, at 
least for me.  That energy makes it feel good to just move your body, whether 
it be dancin or boffin! :)


>going back to the music style thing again, maybe everyone listens to a bit
>too much house? ;)  IMO, house is a more "sexy" form that say, gabber or
>acid trance. just imagine trying to have sex with gabba in the background.
>those 240 bpm might make it a bit difficult...


HA HAH!  Interesting mental image, "humphumphumphumphumphump"  Hee hee!  


Love,
Shawna

Precedence: bulk

> O.k. Mr. Jake- I have to ask what is 'frisbee golf' and how is it
>played? I tried to get a mental pisture on this one, but.......here is my
>post instead.........
>                             -Reagan
>
Frisbee golf is played just like regular golf,  except the "Holes" are
baskets with chains hanging over a flat top that "catches" the frisbee
when tossed into it.   If you hit it squarely in the middle,  it will
catch the frisbee,  but if you miss,  it will glance off.   Golf frisbees
have evolved into these things that are smaller and heavier and look a lot
like a discus.   There are 18 "holes" with "hazards" like the Bay,  marshes,
thick brush and other inaccessabe areas you can lose your frisbee in.

My frisbee glows in the dark,  and I remember losing it one time,  and
returning in the night.   Using a spolight,  I was able to locate it by
shining the light around,  because when light strikes it,  it glows
brighter.   It was under a small stream.

Each hole is marked with a "Par" and some are more difficult than others.
I highly recommend it.    In fact,  several raves were held there,  like
the summer Solstice last year,  but nobody noticed the "holes" or
wondered what they were....   :-)

The Crunchman

>I heard that 420 was really good.  Did anyone go? of course you did but how
>was it?  Inquiring minds would like to know. What's this about a giant
>buda(sp?)??
>
The Daytime party was really GREAT,  although the weather was cool and
partly cloudy,  I managed to get a ride with a non-raver friend who
dropped me off ad picked me up later.

The location was primo,  by this lake near Novato,  and totally inaccessable
unless you had a car.   I got there late (Around 4 pm) and the music was
really good.  Galen spun,   and another dude in dreads spun the sickest
trip-hop style set that was quite interesting to dance to...  then later
on,  spun some jungle until Buck went on.    Then,  galen went back on
to finish the party...   I would say about 250 - 300 people showed up,
but it's remote location made it hard for the city folks to make it.

It was free (Except the parking or park fees of $5),  but with a car full,
it was a bargain.   I heard they got a permit,  as the park rangers were
really cooperative and supportive.

Crunchman

Message-Id: <199604230721.AAA11101@shellx.best.com>
X-Sender: tgrigsby@best.com (Unverified)
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: SDream@tgrigsby.com (SDream)
Subject: Review: All in the Family
X-Mailer: <PC Eudora Version 1.4>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Friday night and it's time to DANCE....

So we head out to catch "All in the Family", put on by In Touch Prods., the 
same fine folx that brought you the "Planet Rock Strikes Back" rave at the 
Home Base in Oakland.  Map point: Ameba.  Immediate problem: the space was 
busted.  As we arrive at Ameba, everyone is hanging out out front waiting 
for a new space to be determined.  The folks at Ameba were getting 
frustrated with the mob that was being generated out front, the cops were 
cruising past keeping an eye on us, and the crowd just kept getting bigger.

Not good.

Now, I have a little question I'd like to pose to the group at large.  A 
rumor was going around that some other promoters had the party busted.  
Those promoters are on this list.  Anyone have any input, pro or con, 
regarding this rumor?  I don't find the rumor hard to believe since I've 
come away with the impression that these promoters are far more interested 
in the dollar than in a quality event (they are NOT in Martin's league), as 
evidenced by every event I've ever been to that they put on.  There is never 
a good vibe.  There's only fair music, poor lights, and as many people 
*crammed* into a space as it will hold.  

Is it just me that sees something evil in a "rave promoter" that would get 
other raves busted?  I have their names, but I'd rather not say who it is 
until I see solid evidence.

Well, just when things were starting to get a little tense, a new location 
was found.  After attending one horrible party there and one really 
fantastic party there, I had mixed emotions about going to the deli on 
Jerrold.  Turns out there was already a hip hop party going that wouldn't 
adjourn until 1:30am.

And off we went to a rave on Howard St.  I don't know what this party was 
called (anyone know?), but it was pretty cool.  It was more trip hop/jungle 
than anything else.  Underground, low budget, nicely done, very small crowd, 
good vibe.  The problem was, my crew was just not that into the music, so we 
left after about an hour to head back to the deli -- just in time for the 
party to begin!

And I beheld the party, and saw that it was good...

Donald Glaude was all the way ON!  That man was tearing it up!!  Folx, this 
guy is one of the DJs I look for now.  He does more than just spin an 
incredible set, he puts on a show.  The guy that followed was also dynamite, 
but I didn't catch his name.  Could it have been Buck?  The lighting was 
good, the visuals were decent this time, and the A/C was on -- huge relief 
there...  Not too many people.  Only the diehards would wait until 2am for a 
party to *start*.

My one complaint: The price.  $15 for a party that started at 2am.  Not 
good.  And from  what I understand, it was not the promoter's fault.  In 
fact, due to the reduced attendance, he lost money.  Rather than give him a 
price break, the owners of the space gave him the space from 2am to 10am.  

I think we can chalk this up to the greed of the owners of that space, 
something I've heard from other people that have participated in putting on 
parties there.  I saw the promoter having a chat with someone who appeared 
to be one of the owners or a representative of the owner.  And it was not 
exactly a friendly chat.  In fact, I really thought there'd be a fight right 
there in the front lobby.  Well, kudos to the promoter for putting up with 
that crap to bring us what turned out to be a pretty decent party.  I hope 
this doesn't put him off of promoting entirely...

So anyway, I'll be waiting for the next "All in the Family" knowing that, 
even in the face of dire evil owners and villainous rival promoters, it will 
not disappoint!

S

             <Pine.A32.3.93.960422171816.163277D-100000@itsa.ucsf.edu> 
Date: Tue, 23 Apr 1996 10:27:50 -0700
From: George Feil <george@unrrts.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I too am one who was very self conscious about dancing until I
discovered raves...

I remember those high school dances of 15-odd years ago (oh god, I'm
getting old), with lots of disco and new wave, strobes, and flashing
gel spotlights. I was only slightly trained in any of the fad steps of
the day, and dancing for me was simply expressing the music through my
body. There were those moments when my partner and I were the only two
on the dance floor, and everyone else seemed soooooo uninspired...

Somehow, I lost that feeling during my college days, and dancing for
me degenerated into that body exhibitionism, demonstrating the right
moves. I recall that breakdancing was getting really popular around
that time. I lost interest, and stopped dancing at all venues, except
at concerts, where everyone was focused on the band, and no one was
looking at each other. Two concerts that particularly come to mind
were Skinny Puppy and Ministry (around 1988), since both had an
incredible vibe present. [I didn't consider myself physically brave
enough to endure slamming at hardcore shows, although I attended them,
too.] 

The few times I attended crowded dance clubs in New York City while I
lived there, I really hated the dancing, and would often drink lots of
alcohol to deaden my mind and the experience. [I retch from just
thinking about those scenes.] I rarely danced at small parties,
because I knew everyone was looking at me, and I couldn't deal with
the attention.

At my first rave, my friend Jerry told me to close my eyes, feel the
music, and let my body react naturally to it. When I did this, I
discovered my body moving in ways I never imagined, and felt really
turned on! I now use this practice whenever I feel self-conscious at a
party or rave -- it works every time.

The sensation of letting every thought in my mind go, and letting my
body take over to the beat, is what attracts me to raves the
most. Having a scene where no one cares how I look, dress, or dance,
contributes in a big way.

-G

I would just like to point out that being in my late thirties, and having
facial hair, and long wacky hair does not make me a non raver........while
I may not be a drunken stewbum, its descriptions of  this kind that upset
me because there is no age, or drug, or alchahol perameters that make up a
"raver".........you can be or look like many different things..........gee
should I shave and lie about my age, to be accepted as a "raver", should I
only wear baggy pants and a t-shirt to be a raver.......should I only do
the accepted raver drugs...........I've seen many a drunk raver, I've seen
many an old raver, and I've seen many a stubbled raver....... 
 
so I ask you to be more careful in describing a person who turned you off
as a (phseudo) raver, you could inadvertanly insult a fellow human being
who shares some of the same qualities of life as you........moonpup

Last night I made a rare mid-week club excursion to witness the double whammy
of Dave Clarke's 2nd (3rd?) U.S. appearance and Mad's slick new space.  The
space is indeed slick as hell, reminiscent of a Latin disco from some Al
Pacino
movie, replete with red vinyl wrap-around booths and courtesy telephones.  Of
course the more relevant amenities included 6 (?) intellibeams, dataflash
strobes, other lights I can't really describe, and a fat healthy sound system,
bass booming at your feet, mids and highs hanging above your head.  Wandering
around the space, I found the upstairs/downstairs chill room, the tripped-out
flourescent-explosion pool room, and the outdoor patio (nice!).  Definitely a
classy joint, the only major drawback being the 21+ policy, still a problem
for
a wee lad like me.

The crowd was definitely a different set.  I missed the energy of some of the
younger kids (no offense to you old fogies!).  ;)  But all that was forgotten
when the red man Dave Clarke threw down.  What a set!  It has been soooo long
since I've heard music like that at a party: fast (140++), minimal, fun
techno,
almost reminiscent of the sort of stuff you'd hear at 4 a.m. at early hardcore
"raves" in '92.  And Dave tore up those turntables, cutting records fast as
hell, working it true midwest style.  He did this one trick where he had two
records going, but they were out of sync by half a beat, so he'd cut them back
and forth, creating this crazy breakbeat out of two four-on-the-floor techno
records.  Then he would grab one record, pull one of the beats back, scratch
it
for one beat, and then drop it back in on beat, then do it again and drop it
back in so that they were off by a half-beat again.  Describing it doesn't
really do it justice.  I'm not really sure too many people really got off on
it
the way I did either.  I heard some people saying that he kept breaking the
"groove" by doing shit like that.  Oh well.  I guess some SFers are too well
fed on slow geriatric mixes that last two minutes.

Anyway, it was a fun night.  The space is cool, but I hope perhaps a search
continues for an 18+ location.

inhuman@work.it.work.it

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Apr 23 10:56:35 1996

From: geoffw@cybertribe.com (Geoff White)
Subject: Re: Is discussing sexuality offensive/NRR?
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


>The topic of sexuality at raves had already been raised.  The reason why I
>brought up the "orgy" I attended (although I specified it was primarily
>sensual, not sexual) was to illustrate what a healthier, more consensual
>type of "sexuality" might look like in a group setting - to add a new
>notion of sexuality to the questioning of mainstream values that goes on in
>raving.
>

Nancy, I think it took a lot of courage to tell us about your experiences
in the light of what societal conditioning has done to some people. In general,
I believe in the slogan "Fight Sexism, not Sex".  To those that were offended
by Nancy's post, I'm sorry that you feel the way that you do, and I can
understand that you feel that way, but I don't think that Nancy's self
expression
was impinging on your rights or on the rights of the group. If you felt that
the post was inappropriate you can always hit delete (something I do a lot of).


>I strongly believe that what we are doing in the rave scene is exploring
>our identities, our society and our notion of community.  Implicit in that,
>I believe, is a questioning of the hierarchical gender order that
>undergirds our society - ESPECIALLY evident in mainstream sexuality.  When
>people express discomfort with "sex" at raves, I believe it refers to what
>we have come to think of as "sex" - nasty come-ons, leering, casual sex
>with strangers.  I was trying to bring up the idea of a transformation of
>our idea of sex to include sensuality (rather than focus on
>intercourse/objectification).  This concept of sex, I wrote in my post,
>incorporates FEMALE sexuality (which I believe is more sensual, less
>inclined to have meaningless encounters).  This new idea that is equal
>female-male sexuality rather than the current male-oriented definition has
>revolutionary potential for our society.
>

Well our society is male dominated that's for sure, not sure that it would be
any better if it were female dominated, but we definitely need more balance.
This reminds me of a party I went to a few weeks ago called :The rebirth of the
Goddess" where Female sexual/sensual energy was in full effect! It went _way_
beyond mere issues of groping, come_ons, and physical contact, many of the women
who participated were truly transformed into _goddesses_ (not just sex
goddesses)
and the level of sex/sensuality was clearly raised an octave. In this
environment, I noticed that the men in the room were in awe, they realized
that they had to opperate at a level beyond simple physical objectification.

>I did not feel this topic advocates overt sex or is NRR.  I did not mean an
>orgy at a rave.  I was trying to expand the discussion of whether there is
>sexual energy at raves, etc., to a new definition of sexuality - one based
>on peace, love, unity and respect!
>

There is tremendous sexual energies at raves (at least the parties that I like
to go to :) In fact, one of my laments is that the energy has decreased over the
years. (Some of my fondest memories were the basement Wicked @1015 on friday
nights starting at 2:00am, where you had sexuality totally across the spectrum
all "cuming-together" in one hot-house sweat-box, many a person use to "see the
light" at those parties :)  Sex, like eating, is a GOOD thing!, now some people
have sexual disorders, like some have eating disorders, some have special diets,
some like bland food, others like it *spicy*, some like variety some eat the
same meal(s) day in and day out.  It's all good.  People change when they
want to,
if someone offers you candy at raves, you can always refuse!

>For many of us raving has been an all-encompassing journey where we have
>learned MANY lessons about our lives.  How can we say our attitudes toward
>sexuality are not affected by what we learn there?  This thread was not
>pornographic - no-one offered graphic detail of sex acts or propositioned
>people.  It was an exploration on the role of sexuality IN RAVING.
>

I have learned so much about myself and especially my sexuality at raves that it
isn't funny. I think people tend to be way too in their heads about this stuff
and could do well to follow the age old axiom...


        SHUT UP AND DANCE!

                                        G

Subject: Re: Is discussing sexuality offensive/NRR? 
In-reply-to: Your message of "Mon, 22 Apr 1996 17:23:51 -0800."
             <v02130500ada1dd5d5871@[128.32.160.52]> 
Date: Tue, 23 Apr 1996 10:51:06 -0700
From: George Feil <george@unrrts.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hi, Nancy. I've been enjoying your posts on the list for quite some
time now...

I don't feel at all offended by your posts about orgies. In fact, I
agree with most of what you have said on the subject. This is an
important topic for discussion here, since we all have different views
on the subject, and may not be aware of them. The fact that some of us
ravers are also offended by sexual acts at parties may be absent from
the minds of those participating in the act!

If I saw a couple engaging in intercourse in the chill space at an
event, I would feel uncomfortable. However, when I see two people
kissing and touching each other in a sensual manner, it doesn't bother
me at all. [Hell, I've been involved in a few of these moments
myself!]  I feel much more sensual than sexual at raves, and I love to
explore and express that sensuality with other people. What I mean is,
while I enjoy the experience of giving and receiving touch from
another person, I never develop the urge to screw at raves.

Raves are excellent opportunities for people to explore all their
senses -- touch included. Consider the possibility that those people
who express "offense" at the subject are actually expressing their
discomfort with their own feelings about the subject. They have yet to
confront their own emotions and views on the beautiful, sensual
experiences that are often had at raves that are not sexual in
nature.

-G

        In this scene and in all scenes, broadening out to every aspect of
life, when are men gonna realize that women are where it's at?  Women are
all goddesses, just as men are all gods, because we all spring from the
divine energy of the multiverse, and carry some of it with us in the
essence of our being.  Women are complex and special creatures in far more
ways than are men.  Women are to be revered and respected, not worshipped
or degraded.  To go a step further, everyone has value, unless he/she
devalues him/herself.  Women are still making breakthroughs in our society,
though many times they are met with resistance, and many times for no good
reason.  The human species cannot grow and develop to our maximum potential
unless men and women are encouraged to contribute unlimited.
        MHO?  Yes, but more than that.  My Viking and Celtic ancestors
treated women in their societies much better than many other societies
throughout history; they were allowed to own land and participate in
government for centuries.  Where/when did things go wrong?  Anyone care to
comment on any of this?
        (Inspired by Nancy, who encouraged me to initiate a post, rather
than just replying all the time :))

Love & respect,

Speaking from a woman's point of view in her late twenties, I'd just like
to comment and respond by saying thank you to Eric.
I'm in the multimedia field and although it is quite competitive in general
over here in Marin, I'm finding that respect is given to both sexes who
"know" their shit.  I for one have always strived to be strong and
independent.  I practice viewing people not by gender but by their skills,
talent and kindness...we are all special human beings and we should all
utilize the freedom we have to excel however we want whether we are men or
women!

Unity,

On Mon, 22 Apr 1996, John Draper wrote:

> >I heard that 420 was really good.  Did anyone go? of course you did but how
> >was it?  Inquiring minds would like to know. What's this about a giant
> >buda(sp?)??
> >
> The Daytime party was really GREAT,  although the weather was cool and
> partly cloudy,  
> The location was primo,  by this lake near Novato,  

I'd have to reiterate how beautiful the spot was.  It was held on a very 
green baseball field.  The dj was under some trees (willows, possibly) 
and faced the water.  The lake is a reservoir (Stafford Lake) and the 
whole area was the brightest green ever.  It was absolutely a beautiful 
spot, and the rangers were very supportive.  When we arrived, they told 
us where it was, said it looked like a great party, good crowd, etc.  
Very friendly.  They kind of wandered around a bit during the party, but 
as far as I saw, never harrassed nor interfered with anyone.  They did 
close it up at exactly 8 pm, but that didn't really matter to me because 
they were so cool about everything else.

> really good.  Galen spun,   and another dude in dreads spun the sickest
> trip-hop style set that was quite interesting to dance to...  then later
> on,  spun some jungle until Buck went on.    Then,  galen went back on
> to finish the party...   I would say about 250 - 300 people showed up,
> but it's remote location made it hard for the city folks to make it.

The music was excellent, lots of house.  To me it just seemed like the 
music was perfect for the day and the setting.  I love all kinds of 
music, but this just seemed perfect at the time!  It was really great 
dancing on soft, but firm grass.  You could really bounce!!!  Dancing on 
concrete is so hard on my body :(

The one thing I had a problem with was the nitrous tanks (which I did see 
one get confiscated at the end by a ranger).  Is it just me, or does 
nitrous turn people into greedy, selfish imps?  Nitrous is fun and all, 
but whenever I have seen it at parties, the people are always greedy 
about it.  (duh, maybe that's why it's called hippie crack!)  It is a 
strange occurance that I've seen wherever there is nitrous.  Maybe it is 
because a lot of people want to do it, and the ones who get it know 
this and can use it to their advantage?  Maybe it is its ephemeral nature 
and ppl want to continue doing it?  (maybe I am blabbering?!!)

cheers,
kc

Oh how I love to read about everyone's experiences.  What happened at 
Gaia?  Anyone, anyone?  Bueller? Bueller?  

I saw Krista at about 4 am at Progress.  We had never heard her 
before and we really thought she was great.  The room she spun in was 
pretty empty, but when she came on, more people came to dance, although 
it was never very dense.  She was really good, spinning progressive 
house.  I will definitely look for her again.

MIME-Version: 1.0
To: SFRaves Mailing List <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Midafternoon Poetry
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hi All!
I just found this incredible poem, and KNEW you'd all love it! :^) ENJOY!
	xxxooo
Jeremy

*BEGIN*
                The Search For Happiness

        Now the day had come at last
        To put this problem in the past--
        To solve for good the question deep
        Regarding joy's eternal keep.

        From far and wide the people came,
        Each to try and make the claim--
        Each one with a different thought
        Of where this treasure should be sought.

        Some looked in vaults and mined for gold,
        Sure that money would this treasure hold.
        Others tried a far resort
        Or vacationing of a different sort.

        Still others went to parties all
        And looked in bottles short and tall.
        Some even searched through books of lore,
        For guidance to that distant shore.

        Some said it came from a simple game
        Or freedom, love, or power and fame;
        But none of these endeavors brought
        The answer to the question sought.

        For happiness cannot be seen
        In seas of blue or fields of green;
        Nor even in the star-lit skies
        Or in a loved one's sparkling eyes.

        Far more treasures hold the soul
        Than physical creation whole.
        And though those things may draw them out,
        They can't alone these treasures sprout.

        Happiness is one of these;
        The soul alone can hold the keys--
        The keys to open every door
        And let the happy spirit soar.

        Many people yet remain
        Entrapped by fear and mortal pain.
        But none need linger in the dark;
        They only lack one crucial spark:

        The key to happiness, you'll find
        Lies not on earth but in the mind.
        To understand this is to be,
        In thought and spirit, truly free.


        Doug Lee
        7/23/89
*END*
-- 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
W. Jeremy Nauck                 |"This above all: to thine own self be true;
E-Mail: nauckwj@netcom.com      | And it must follow, as the night the day,
                                | Thou canst not then be false to any man."
                                             -William Shakespeare

My extraneous SFraves post for the quarter:

(btw i should be up in the area May 17-25th
to anyone who actually remembers me :)

>         MHO?  Yes, but more than that.  My Viking and Celtic ancestors
> treated women in their societies much better than many other societies
> throughout history; they were allowed to own land and participate in
> government for centuries.  Where/when did things go wrong?  Anyone care to
> comment on any of this?

Sure.  Your viking ancestors raped your celtic ancestors, i think
that could be one area where things went wrong.

I'm not sure exactly which history books you read, but there are 
plenty examples of civilizations/societies that gave a high status 
to women.  Most of them were long killed off by the
people who raped your Celtic ancestors after the Vikings,
(The Normans and Anglo-saxons.) because (esp the anglos) were
pretty good at absorbing other people's cutlures.  

Or were you only talking about European societies?

We should all respect each other.  Some people in society have been
show a lot less respect and therefore deserve more respect and consideration
because they've put up with all this disrespect for so long.
Women, making up over half of the population, are the largest
group, but there are more than a barrelful of others.

just some thoughts...

 ,
dana

yet some people still drive without a fuzzbox."

For anyone who can be in the San Jose/Santa Clara area tonight:
        Stella Luna will be performing at Cafe Leviticus, at 1445 The
Alameda, San Jose.  The number is (408)279-8877.
        Stella Luna is a musical adventure, very ambient/eerie/mysterious,
with soundscapes created by many differnent instruments.  The atmosphere of
the event is permeated by an incredible, unique, ethereal vibe, a feeling
I've never experienced from anything else.  I've seen them perform twice,
and they thoroughly impressed and satisfied me, as well as the rest of the
audience.  Dancing/trancing out is encouraged during their show.
        It's free :)  It starts at 8:43pm, and should go for a couple
hours.  One of the members is a very dear, beautiful friend named Jonathan,
and he says the band is very excited about this event.  If you can make it,
I highly encourage you to come out and experience.  You'll be glad you did!

Thanks (I'm not getting paid for this :)),

- E

the problem with hippie crack is that unlike the DJ's or the equipment that
are being donated to a free event, the hippie crack owner will not just
give away his product. 
 
I've had my hippie crack days (mostly during 91' at flamable liquid in L.A.
etc...) and when I am DJ'ing for free to help create a vibe, I expected the
hippie crack dealer to donate the gas, I REFUSE to allow gas to be sold, so
one guy can make a profit off of a free vibe.......(i know, what about a
pot dealer or an e dealer etc.......) I feel that at least they don't
display there wears the way balloons do......an obvious physical entity
(like a lot of strewn around beer bottles) it's just bad
advertizing......every-one including cops can see that were all doing
drugs......... 
 
even if they are free (which is totally rare) it's a drug you can
see........being done.....it just creates a bad vibe........greedy dealers
and greedy users, those that pay get hassled by those that don't (can I
have a hit of your gas ???)  etc..... 
 
                        overall,  bad news..........moonpup

On 23 Apr 1996, Michael wrote:

> 
> Last night I made a rare mid-week club excursion to witness the double whammy
> of Dave Clarke's 2nd (3rd?) U.S. appearance and Mad's slick new space.  The

(stuff deleted)

> "raves" in '92.  And Dave tore up those turntables, cutting records fast as
> hell, working it true midwest style.  He did this one trick where he had two
> records going, but they were out of sync by half a beat, so he'd cut them back
> and forth, creating this crazy breakbeat out of two four-on-the-floor techno
> records.  Then he would grab one record, pull one of the beats back, scratch
> it
> for one beat, and then drop it back in on beat, then do it again and drop it
> back in so that they were off by a half-beat again.  Describing it doesn't
> really do it justice.  I'm not really sure too many people really got off on
> it
> the way I did either.  I heard some people saying that he kept breaking the
> "groove" by doing shit like that.  Oh well.  I guess some SFers are too well
> fed on slow geriatric mixes that last two minutes.

Yeah,  i thought that it was some sick mixing also.  I was talking to
one person who went to Mad last night and she was like "The scratching was
cool, but it was a bit messy, and the beats were off and all."  When i
told her that he intentionally did the off beat mixing, she was suprised
that it was intentions.  Just goes to show you that there is more to 
mixing then just puting them together flawlessly.  something id like
to see more SF dj's do.


> 
> Anyway, it was a fun night.  The space is cool, but I hope perhaps a search
> continues for an 18+ location.

so do i!! =)

I didn't like 420 much.  Everyone was huddled in little circles far
from the speakers.  Few dancers.  The crowd was  mostly
nitrous-huffing local youth and a few hockey-coiffed exurbanites with
nothing better to do than sit around and drink beer.  Or maybe I was
just too tired, because I didn't feel like trying to help the vibe. I
left early, maybe it improved later.   My walk in the nearby hills was
much more enjoyable.

David  

On Tue, 23 Apr 1996 14:33:29 -0700 (PDT), you wrote:

>
>On Mon, 22 Apr 1996, John Draper wrote:
>
>> >I heard that 420 was really good.  Did anyone go? of course you did but how
>> >was it?  Inquiring minds would like to know. What's this about a giant
>> >buda(sp?)??
>> >
>> The Daytime party was really GREAT,  although the weather was cool and
>> partly cloudy,  
>> The location was primo,  by this lake near Novato,  
>
>I'd have to reiterate how beautiful the spot was.  It was held on a very 
>green baseball field.  The dj was under some trees (willows, possibly) 
>and faced the water.  The lake is a reservoir (Stafford Lake) and the 
>whole area was the brightest green ever.  It was absolutely a beautiful 
>spot, and the rangers were very supportive.  When we arrived, they told 
>us where it was, said it looked like a great party, good crowd, etc.  
>Very friendly.  They kind of wandered around a bit during the party, but 
>as far as I saw, never harrassed nor interfered with anyone.  They did 
>close it up at exactly 8 pm, but that didn't really matter to me because 
>they were so cool about everything else.
>
>> really good.  Galen spun,   and another dude in dreads spun the sickest
>> trip-hop style set that was quite interesting to dance to...  then later
>> on,  spun some jungle until Buck went on.    Then,  galen went back on
>> to finish the party...   I would say about 250 - 300 people showed up,
>> but it's remote location made it hard for the city folks to make it.
>
>The music was excellent, lots of house.  To me it just seemed like the 
>music was perfect for the day and the setting.  I love all kinds of 
>music, but this just seemed perfect at the time!  It was really great 
>dancing on soft, but firm grass.  You could really bounce!!!  Dancing on 
>concrete is so hard on my body :(
>
>The one thing I had a problem with was the nitrous tanks (which I did see 
>one get confiscated at the end by a ranger).  Is it just me, or does 
>nitrous turn people into greedy, selfish imps?  Nitrous is fun and all, 
>but whenever I have seen it at parties, the people are always greedy 
>about it.  (duh, maybe that's why it's called hippie crack!)  It is a 
>strange occurance that I've seen wherever there is nitrous.  Maybe it is 
>because a lot of people want to do it, and the ones who get it know 
>this and can use it to their advantage?  Maybe it is its ephemeral nature 
>and ppl want to continue doing it?  (maybe I am blabbering?!!)
>
>cheers,
>kc
>

David Minuk(davidmin@crl.com)

> eek. be nice now..
> major flame bait. come now, we can't go dissing everyone because of choices
> they made in their past, or even for the life they live. we should accept
> everyone for who they are, regardless of our feelings towards their way of

You are right, brendan-
The rational, compassionate side of me agrees with you entirely.  But 
there are some things in life that disgust me so greatly that it is 
extremely difficult to get past it.  I've been flamed about TL before on 
sfraves about a year ago, and my stance has still not changed.  Once a 
person is so severly tainted, it is hard to wash off the stain.  Sad, 
yes, but to many people, that is the way it is.  I don't care if Traci 
Lords became a saint.  I would always see her as a washed up ex porn 
queen who helped in degrading women.  Really, I do try and see the good 
in people and I give her credit for trying.  I'm sure not perfect either 
-  I sincerely try not to judge and like I said in a previous post: I try 
and see beauty in all people.  Just with someone like Traci Lords I have to 
sit down and try really really really hard to see it because it is minute 
to me. Her beauty as a human being is quite less obvious to me than with 
most people (kinda like saying a murderer is still a beautiful person, 
see what I mean?)  Hope this explains my position, and if not, well, I tried.

love,
Amy

it to the address below. Thanks!

Nicole

thrown in the proverbial trash heap because of it.  We want the rigt to
assemble and to "rave" yet we are so ready to condemn another for their
choice in profession and their proclivities?  Is PLUR only extended to
those that we find FIT in our moral paradigm?  An it harm none (I
translate this as everyone involved is consenting) do what you will. 

> -  I sincerely try not to judge and like I said in a previous post: I try 
> and see beauty in all people.  Just with someone like Traci Lords I have to 
> sit down and try really really really hard to see it because it is minute 
> to me. Her beauty as a human being is quite less obvious to me than with 
> most people (kinda like saying a murderer is still a beautiful person,

> 
> love,
> Amy

now officially stepping down from the "beautiful human being" category.
;)  Lump me in with the porn-queens, murderers and the like. 

All sexed up all the time

Hi all,

Warning--this is very long, and really only related to raving in that 
it responds to comments about DJ Traci Lords. So disclaimer having been 
made, read at your own risk!

Obrave: hmmm, let's see. Had a great time at Nikita Friday night. 
Didn't find it too clubby, although the front room was a little scary. 
Thanks again to Sarah and Paul and your friends for bringing the vibe with you, 
thanks to Andrew for being Andrew, and thanks to the djs for playing it 
hard hard hard and FAST all night long! I love it when there's no let up 
in the music's intensity until the needle goes up for the last time and 
the lights come on. I danced til 6, which I haven't done in ages. 

See you at "Wish" May 1--Doran's spinning! 

The rest of my post is below.

Kathryn


On Tue, 23 Apr 1996, Amy R Starkey wrote:

> person is so severly tainted, it is hard to wash off the stain.  Sad, 
> yes, but to many people, that is the way it is.  I don't care if Traci 
> Lords became a saint.  I would always see her as a washed up ex porn 
> queen who helped in degrading women.  Really, I do try and see the good 

(snip)

Well, you'll get no argument from me about whether pornography is 
degrading to women. I think it's also fairly degrading to men. Be that as 
it may, I wanted to relay something I read recently about the women who 
participate in pornography and/or prostitution, namely, that an incredibly 
high percentage of them had been physically or, more often, sexually abused 
as children. I can't remember the exact number, but I'm sure it was over 60%, 
and perhaps higher. I'll look around for the study if anyone's interested. 
Perhaps their experiences during childhood led them to feel valued only 
when they perceive themselves as sexual objects. This is not at all 
uncommon for children who have been abused, and I think the study was 
formulated around that idea.
 
I've also read Linda Lovelace's autobiography (Deep Throat) and a 
biography of SF's own Mitchell Brothers, plus other assorted materials on 
pornography. My sense coming away from all this is that, while some women 
(and men) may go into pornography willingly, many more are somehow duped 
or forced into it. Regardless of how they arrive, they are soon 
controlled by the larger interests that be. I have serious serious doubts 
about whether the actors/actresses/posers/etc. are really in control of their 
careers or most of their so-called choices. How freely did Traci Lords make 
her decisions about her body and her life? Was it she who made the 
decisions, or the lucrative Traci Lords industry that grew up around her? 
Who really has the power and the money? I'll bet Hugh Hefner has more 
money than all the Playboy bunnies combined.

Finally, I have to say that I think pornography, and other industries that 
exploit women's bodies and souls will be around just as long as we AS A 
SOCIETY exploit women's bodies and souls. By degrading women in myriad 
ways every single day, society sends the message that women are not 
valuable, that we are just bodies (and we'd better be skinny, 
big-breasted ones), that someone else has to tell us what to do, that we 
are not worth as much as men, and by extension, that we should despise 
ourselves and our sisters.  

United we stand...

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Apr 24 00:59:23 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id AAA04639; Wed, 24 Apr 1996 00:59:23 -0700

Received: from  (sequoia1@sac-ca4-16.ix.netcom.com [199.35.220.144]) by dfw-ix5.ix.netcom.com (8.6.13/8.6.12) with SMTP id BAA11258 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Wed, 24 Apr 1996 01:03:31 -0700
Date: Wed, 24 Apr 1996 01:03:31 -0700
Message-Id: <199604240803.BAA11258@dfw-ix5.ix.netcom.com>
From: sequoia1@ix.netcom.com (Chris Chervin )
Subject: Rad vibe in Sacramento over weekend!
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Yeah!!! I ran into two cool vibe events in Sac this weekend so i 
thought I'd share it with you-all.

1st was a decent size 420 party at a really cool guys house.  About 50 
or so people (I'm not a good estimator) and chill ambient grooves by 
different local area dj's.  The whole thing felt like one big awesome 
chill room at some Sf rave.  The vibe was laid back and friendly.  
People were having a good time and i got to meet some groovy 
individuals.  Talked with Rick from the list (about an hour long song 
with a German name).  All in all I could see what might be the 
foundation for a good scene in Sacramento.  At bigger parties too many 
fronters and hommies get in the way of the vibe but at smaller "house" 
events the energy gets concentrated and focused.  Hope to go to more 
stuff like this in the near future!


2nd event was on Sunday.  There was a really phat drum circle in Fair 
Oaks park in old town Fair Oaks.  I'd say about 50+ people were there 
hanging out on blankets while drummers went at it all day long.  It was 
so beautiful!  The energy was laid back, friendly, and without 
attitude.  It was a perfect gathering of hippies, ravers, skaters, and 
grunger/alternatives.  It seemed like the future of a Sacramento scene 
of peace, love and happiness may evolve out of an event like this that 
draws together people from different groups.  People were drinking 
(including me) but no one was out of hand or rude.  

The best part was that you can go up to the circle and grab a drum and 
start beating.  No one cared as it appeared that people brought extra 
drums to throw into the circle for whomever wanted to play.  I got 
behind some phat congos and fell into a cool groove. Can't wait to go 
again!  The drum circle happens every Sunday from sometime in the 
afternoon till the sun goes down.  As far as I can tell the locals 
don't seem to mind and it may be going on all summer (I hope).

If anyone needs directions to the park send me some mail.

love chris

Folks PLEASE be careful here because many of you know not of what you speak!
While it is very true that many women in the world (especially poor women)
are forced into the sex trade, many DO choose it willingly, in fact MANY
a young raver RIGHT HERE IN San Francisco has made money performing before
men as either "exotic dancers", "strippers", "lap dancer's", etc.  In fact it
seems like it is a rather common way for some women to make money and many
like what they are doing (for a while at lease :), in fact I'm sure many of you
out there know some of these people and can attest that they are very nice,
intelligent and MORAL people.  As far as degrading women, well some of the
women that I know stopped doing it not because they thought it was degrading
to women but because they thought it was degrading to Men, (many of which
would give them a significant amount of their paycheks each week as this was the
only source of female companionship in their life.) In fact, being the door
person at a few parties, I've been surprised at how many women in the rave
scene make at least part of their living as "dancers, hookers and hoes".
Sometimes $600+ a day (tax free) for "shakin it" is just too much for some
people to pass up. Also please remember that there is a big wide awsome
world out there in
Earth' (Earth Prime, the opposite of Cyberspace) and many things may not be what
they seem to be, perhapse if some of started talking to people outside of your
own cliques, you would discover that SOME strippers are not gutter trash at all,
some have more honesty, integrity and vibe then many of you put together.

(Don't feel bad Amy, it blew my mind when I discovered this fact as well :)

Yowsa,

HAte ex-porno stars huh?  Words were kinda harsh, but I guess that's how
you felt.

I don't buy her dreck because she's a horrbile DJ.  The rest of your
characterizations of her, are IMO, mean-spirited.  Why the vitriol?  The
girl is pure hollywood, plain and simple.  I see little difference between
what she does, and what other people have done in front of and behind the
camera.  I mean, Madonna, literally slept her way to the top, and is seen
by some women as some type of liberated soul.  Whatever...Ol Norma Kuzman
(Traci Lords), is just trying to make a buck at the music thing.  Her porn
career is over for now, she might return if this music & movie stint she's
on doesn't pan out.

I just see it as being mean for being mean's sake.  What makes you think
she's a slut?  Becuase she was on drugs at one point and made porno, or is
it that she might have actually enjoyed making porno?  Also, why is it
whenever we see women who are sexually liberated enough not to care what
anyone thinks and is sexually active & enjoys it, she's a slut, but when
guys do it, they are labelled studs or at worse womanizer?  Who the hell
came up with the notion that you should have a steady mate anyway?  There
are very few animals that are monogamous, and we KNOW that our monogamy is
a socially imposed strcuture.  Woe is the woman who would dare go against
such mores.

The longer I live, the more contradictions I see in the world.

Now mind you, I would not want any daughter or son of mine to engage in
such activites, but I would still love them and never disown them unless
they were bringing harm to others.  And calling them slut, when in fact if
you work you are somebody's whore, is a contradiction in the worse sense.
When it comes down to it, in capitalism, there is always a whore and a
pimp.  And I can tell you this, Uncle Sam is the biggest pimp around, he's
got EVERYONE working for him!  As for calling her trash, have problem with
that and other sayings that dehumanize someone, as the term trash certainly
does.

I do NOT think:
-People are never trash.  Trash is disposable.  People are not disposable!
-There is no such thing as an illegitimate child.  ALL children are legitimate!

We gotta get out of this ghetto of the mind.  It is making our world most
insane.

But then again, that is my opinion.

Peace,
John
