some smaller events but we could be running into some problems there.

double as the Computer Music Research LAb - whose composers by the way
should be heard.  Very interesting electronic equipment.

[ to sfraves list ]

 It's good to see some more folks interested in doing events within 
"striking distance" of San Jose! As a Sunnyvale resident, I'd be interested
in what you folks develop. 

 Also , for "nuts-and-bolts" discussions of event logistics , who's 
doing what, etc. , you could try using the dormant 

 sfraves-planners@hyperreal.com 

 mailist. I think the way to subscribe to that list is the same procedure
you used to subscribe to sfraves ( send a message to majordomo@hyperreal.com ).

 I forget whether you have to put "subscribe sfraves-planners" in the
subject line or the body of the message - probably doing both can't hurt!

 Just to add a bit of paranoia to the present mix ... I've read that the
usual way narcs bust up a "drug ring" is to arrest some users , looking
for someone with a lot of dope in their possesion. Then , they pressure
that user into narcing for them. So - cops don't have to infiltrate 
someone into a scene , they pressure someone who's already a part of that
scene to inform on the dealers and , worst , their fellow users.

On Fri, 26 Apr 1996, Dana Watanabe wrote:

[snippty snip]

> He said "Uh.. no, but my hands feel tingly, and my body temperature
> is really high, and different surfaces feel fun to rub"
> He spent a few hours curled up in a ball, dripping sweat
> and just feeling absolutely miserable until things calmed down.
> He then was pretty sick (although not close to that bad) for the next
> few days.
> 
> Being the experimental little pup that he is, he took the second
> pill he bought in the hopes that there was just some wierd
> reaction the first time.  But the same exact thing
> (including the following sickness) happened. 
> 
> Many, many, many people said: "That must have been heroin."
> 
> (Quite a few people also said "Heroin isn't really orally active,
> so that couldn't have been heroin."  but didn't have any
> other, better or worse, suggestions.)

[more editing}

As I have stated before, every body is a different, chemical-based, 
biosystem. There is always the possibility that someone may have an 
allergic, or otherwise dissimilar, reaction to any chemical that is 
ingested. I'm not saying that is the case here or everytime that someone 
has a wierd reaction to a given substance, but it is one of the many 
possibilities. 

 The above reaction sounds like a reaction to a stimulate to me, but I'm 
no doctor (or pharmacist).

 I know that I need to take less E than most folks (about 100 milligrams) 
to have a great time  =). If I consume 125 milligrams (1/8 gram) or more 
than I start to have similar reactions described above. I usually 
describe it as a reverse of a good experience where I DO NOT love 
everyone and feel generally BAD. Just as a context, I used to get E when 
it was only $8 a dose. The good 'ol days =), before Raves had even hit 
the US of A

Ran @ Dionysus Dreams

                                  -=*=-/

Subject: The Devil Went Down to Frisco
X-Mailer: <PC Eudora Version 1.4>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


The Devil went down to Frisco
He was lookin' for a soul to steal.
He was in a bind, he was way behind
and he was willing to make a deal,

When he came across this young man
circle dancing and playing it hot.
The devil jumped up on a 6 foot speaker,
said, "Boy, let me tell ya what!

"I guess you didn't know it
but I'm a circle dancer too,
and if you care to take a dare
I'll make a bet with you.

Now you're a pretty good dancer
but give the Devil his due,
I bet a whistle of gold against your soul
cause I think I'm better 'n' you!"

The boy said, "My name's John S. Lee
and it might be a sin,
but I'll take yer bet and yer gonna regret
cause I'm the best that's ever been!"

John S. Lee you better stretch out
and dance with all your heart,
cause Hell's broke loose in Frisco
and the Devil's dealing hard.

If you win you get this shiny whistle made of gold,
but if you lose, the Devil gets your soul!

The devil whipped out his tennis shoes
and he said, "I'll start this show!"
And fire flew from his fingertips
as he tied the laces in a bow.

He slid across the floor
and those shoes made an evil hiss
The he danced and he twirled and he jumped
and everyone one in the crowd he dissed.

When the devil was finished, 
John S. Lee said, "Well you're pretty good old son,
but sit down and get a backrub from those pretty rave chicks
and let me show you how it's done!"

John danced like a man possessed
but suddenly he couldn't dance anymore.
In the middle of the circle someone built an altar 
and plopped their butts in the middle of the floor!

John S. Lee hung his head
because he knew that he'd been beat.
The devil picked him up and 
slung over his shoulder by his feet.

A gate to Hell opened.
As the Devil descended into the ground
he said, "If you kiddies ever want to try again
you know where I can be found!"

John S. Lee's still dancin';
he's dancin' day and night too,
but you can bet when someone sits in the floor now,
John comes kickin' through!

- SDream

Received: from uclink4.berkeley.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id PAA07324; Sat, 27 Apr 1996 15:09:23 -0700
Received: from [128.32.160.44] (hmfmac6.Berkeley.EDU [128.32.160.44]) by uclink4.berkeley.edu (8.7.4/8.6.12) with SMTP id PAA07951 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Sat, 27 Apr 1996 15:09:08 -0700 (PDT)

Mime-Version: 1.0

Date: Sat, 27 Apr 1996 15:07:40 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: nancys@uclink4.berkeley.edu (Nancy)
Subject: (NRR) re: Traci Lords
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Is pornography degrading to women or sexually liberating for our society?

>From my perspective, what I think is important to understand is that being
disturbed by pornography does not mean a woman is anti-sex or repressed.
The disturbance for me comes from the fact that pornography, almost by
definition, OBJECTIFIES women.  It is a VISUAL medium, focusing on graphic
sex acts and body parts.  Narrative, thought, is largely absent.  This
seems to correspond to a more masculine sexuality, i.e. being turned-on
visually, bodies and acts arousing rather than minds and personalities.
For many women, this impersonal sexuality is inexplicable - and actually
threatening.  Unfortunately for all of us, male sexual response has
translated to a hierarchical social structure (i.e. sexism).

Women experience that objectification based on our bodies - the
dehumanization - every day of our lives.  When we walk down the street, we
are sexually harassed; a blatant power play emphasizing that men like to
impose their sexuality on us without any regard for our consent, simply
because we have female bodies.  The extreme emphasis on our looks
overshadows every aspect of our lives.   Feminism and the women's movement
is our struggle to be evaluated and advance on our merits and talents, to
escape that objectification so that we can actually be acknowledged as
equal human beings.  I strongly suspect that the objectifying male
sexuality is a subconscious basis for the unequal status of women in our
culture.

*Not that there's anything inherently wrong with male sexuality - men are
how they are, getting turned on by seeing breasts is not evil.   However,
the problem arises when that concept of women extends beyond actual sex to
encompass how we are viewed in our entirety.

Also, mainstream porn (made almost exclusively for men) is damaging in that
it is NOT A REALISTIC PORTRAYAL OF FEMALE SEXUALITY.  The women are
portrayed as having the exact same sexual response as men.  i.e. there is
no foreplay required, a woman is ready to go at a moment's notice, she is
willing to have sex with anyone in the room without having to have any sort
of relationship with them, and she has uncontrollable orgasms from
intercourse.  As this is, for most women, the diametric opposite of our
actual sexuality, this portrayal discourages paying attention to women's
actual needs.  In that way it is a sexist institution that continues the
dehumanization of women (i.e., does not respect or acknowledge our
different needs from men).  Set that against a backdrop of society
discouraging women to be sexually assertive, and you have tons and tons of
women who cannot communicate just what they really need from a lover.

As for women in porn and prostitution, many claim personal liberation in
the experience.  I think we have to listen to individuals and not pass our
own judgements on their choices.  It is important to realize, however, that
many women in these professions are exploited: someone (a pimp, a producer)
gets most of her earnings, many women are drug-addicted, and many have been
raped or abused.  There ARE, however, healthy people who choose sex work
based on their own morals.  I have known a couple of women who have my
utmost respect as it is their own thoughtful, intelligent, informed
decision (they are students, in business on the side with their own steady
clients - different situation from most street-walkers).

Sex work IN ITSELF does not seem, to me, inherently terrible.  Human beings
need sex, it's pleasure.  So why not contract with someone for the service?
It's just touching, it's being LOVING to someone to give them pleasure.
Pornography is filming people having sex.  The problem seems to lie not in
the fact of sex work, but in its MISUSE - exploited streetwalkers, sexist
portrayals of women.  It is telling that our society feels that any sex
work is disgusting - the only way we can conceive of it is as something
sick, perverted and abusive.  People enjoying pleasure and being kind to
each other without exploitation does not seem to be possible within that
societal mind-set.   Sex work in a culture with a different view of
sexuality would look, I think, entirely different!

Hopefully as a society we can move beyond our current model of sex as a) a
display of dehumanized women for the man, and b) nasty and degrading to
women.  This whole concept of what sex is evidences, to me, the sickness of
our society.  Hopefully we can move toward a healthy, loving, equitable
sexuality - and hopefully the mindset that will birth it is what we are
creating in rave.  (This was my exact topic in a previous post and I caught
a lot of flames for being "offensive"! ).

Change starts with the individual.  For myself, I have thrown away
societal's pressure on my sexuality and proudly claim MY real desires - a
loving relationship, my own pleasure (foreplay), respect and consensuality,
and absolute enjoyment of sex.  I will support erotica and writings and
photography from women - a sexuality that is beautiful, arousing, and
equitable.  I refuse to believe that being disturbed by current pornography
means we cannot be sexually liberated.   Instead, perhaps it means an
entirely new concept of sexuality.

Awaiting angry flames,
Nancy

Nancy,

  I like your overall viewpoint .... but sadly while many people agree
with you - their METHOD for improvement seems to be to create a new form
of puritanism... sort of like dieters or alcoholics - if food or whatever
is being abused just avoid and deny it.... This path leads us into a
spiral of sexual denial which all too often is the path we are lead down...

  So the way we use, express and control our sexualities as a society is 
pathetic at best. I am also still shocked at the double standard - that
a woman who enjoys and/or engages in open and frequent sex acts is "tainted"
which was implied about T. Lords ( if not actually said ). Apparently
the idea that sex is dirty.... and the "will you respect me if I do IT with
you?" question still has a healthy life in our society. Women who become
sex objects of our society all too often end up not only exploited through
objectivication but also end up wearing a modern scarlet letter of 
disapproval.

  On the other hand, many people who express their sexuality publicly such
as Madonna do very little for me at least.... I don't find her sexuality
particurly liberating or respect oriented (IMO of course). I don't think
of her as bad but merely representing a sexuality that lacks real 
romantic sentiment, respect or deep person to person contact. So from male
pronographers to female sex mistresses we too often lack good models for a
healthy sexuality ... and let's not even begin to talk about religious or
at least christian training regrading sex.....


  What we need is a really great tantric master on Channel 50.... ;-)

 Mike

 Good reading on sex and eastern philosophy : 

 Sexual Secrets : The Alchemy of Ecstacy

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Apr 27 17:30:06 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id RAA17177; Sat, 27 Apr 1996 17:30:06 -0700
Received: from shellx.best.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id RAA17172; Sat, 27 Apr 1996 17:30:03 -0700
Received: from tgrigsby.vip.best.com (tgrigsby.vip.best.com [205.149.169.221]) by shellx.best.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id QAA20886 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Sat, 27 Apr 1996 16:19:03 -0700
Date: Sat, 27 Apr 1996 16:19:03 -0700
Message-Id: <199604272319.QAA20886@shellx.best.com>
X-Sender: tgrigsby@best.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: SDream@tgrigsby.com (SDream)
Subject: Review: Fusion
X-Mailer: <PC Eudora Version 1.4>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Warning: kinda long...

After a rather bad week, I needed to do some dancing.  Our plans of keeping 
the night a sedate one were changed when our non-rave visitor from Kansas 
decided she didn't have the energy to bop, and suddenly it became a RAVE 
NIGHT.  So all the little kiddies skipped off into the night in search of 
adventure...

I was overruled on the beach party.  As much as I've always wanted to go to 
a rave on the beach overlooking the ocean at night, it still hasn't 
happened.  <heavy sigh>  No, the draw last night was Doc Martin, so the 
target of our mission was ... Fusion!

This was held at the Jerrold St. deli <quiet grumbling>.  The music was 
*very* good, the lighting was ok, the acid visuals were good, and ... drum 
roll ... the A/C was working!  :)  Ok, I figured I ought to say that since 
that was the major gripe going around after one party a while back...  ;)  
It still gets pretty toasty upstairs, but heat rises, and with 700+ bodies 
(my estimate), you have to expect that.  Also, a new twist in decoration, 
there were these beach blowup toys, (a few beach balls, a shark raft, a 
hippo raft) and they were spray painted in DayGlo colors and hung across the 
dance area right where the black lights would hit them.  Very nice effect, I 
thought, a la DV8 and the dolphin room with a psychadelic touch.  There was 
some fun artwork upstairs where they were selling smart drinks and fruit -- 
always a welcome addition.

Prior to Doc coming out the black lights were turned off.  :(  I like black 
lights, but I guess it was just a little bright in there for someone.  
Still, by that time, I was so into dancing and boogying, the strobes and 
acid visuals were just fine.

Cool moment: some guy was going around selling glo sticks, so a lot of 
people were playing with them.  Since they were on strings, some folks would 
just spin them in circles over their head or whatever.  I was looking up and 
tripping on the guys overhead that had two glo sticks in one hand, red and 
green, and spining them in a circle.  Faster, slower, depending on the 
music.  The effect was weird...

Cool moment: I chatted with a pixie!  Ya gotta give it to people who come to 
a party with a gimmick.  There was a girl in a fairy outfit, complete with 
wings and sparkles on her face, informing people that she was a pixie.  
There was also a guy there with the cat-in-the-hat hat and the four fingered 
cartoon gloves.  I love that get-up -- I should get one for myself...

Cool moment: By coming to Fusion, I got a chance to talk to Stacey in person 
and get things straightened out regarding the stupid rumors going around and 
the negativity online the other day.  She was very sweet about it -- no 
karate chops or kicks to the kneecaps. 8)   So let's set the record 
straight: Tom and Stacey did NOT get the original space for "All in the 
Family" busted.  They throw parties.  'nuff said.  And Tom and Stacey are 
NOT narcs, like that should need saying.   Although she did share with me 
that they are in fact aliens who are intent on stealing all the pop rocks in 
the world -- seems pop rocks are beyond their technology...  (oh no! another 
rumor!)

The Vibe: It was ok.  I think there's just a certain vibe at events like 
Sunset or Chrysalis that are tough to come by.  I had a good time, but there 
wasn't a group energy that I could detect.  I came across some ravers with 
toys and candy and we hung for a bit, but even they didn't really seem into 
it.  It was just a good night to dance...

Unfortunately my crew pooped out before Doc came on, and we left about 5 
minutes before he was supposed to start.  :(

Bad moment:  Can I gripe about how the deli is run?  This has nothing to do 
with how the party itself was produced.  I got a clear cut example of 
immediate inflation last night when I bought one orange for $.40 and then 
five minutes later tried to buy another one and was told it was $.75.  Not 
that $.75 is going to break me anytime soon, but I was offended.  This is 
the treatment I have come to expect.  Look, there's a guy that works behind 
the counter with a moustache.  He's cool, he doesn't size you up and try to 
figure out how much he can take you for.  He charges you a fair price.  
Shoot, I bet he'd be cool to party with, even.  There's a woman behind the 
counter, and she's Satan in drag, the Anti-Raver.  She'll jack the price up 
on you in a heartbeat.  She tries to stick it to me everytime I walk up to 
the counter.  She'd probably try to charge you for a napkin...  And of 
course, water is $3 (probably more if Satan-woman is selling them) with no 
refills allowed -- at least in the guys restroom.  Fortunately there's 
usually a lady in the group I go with, so we're covered, but it's a hassle 
just the same.

S

Hi everybody- my name's John, and I wanted to (re)introduce myself,
having just (re)subscribed to sfraves...  I'm moving to the South Bay
from Vail, Colorado, where I was on mtn-raves, which is a very 
beautiful community of people!  (I will miss dancing with them!!!!!)

I'm really excited to be living in the bay area, and psyched to reconnect
with the sharp minds and warm hearts of this area's community...  I've 
been on the WELL since 1991 or something-- and plan to be there forever.
I was on this list before-- in 1994 while traveling with some infamous
(and slightly mis-judged) UK rave promoters and performers called the 
"zippy pronoia tour"...   (yeah yeah, I know I know).  We threw a few good
parties in the Bay region, in conjunction with the awesome SPAZ crew,
most notably the "Jupiter Bash" in downtown SF the night that comet
smashed into the planet Jupiter.   

Anyway, I've been meditating up in the Rockies, snowboarding and weaving
websites for the company I'm a producer for-- Eagle River Interactive.
We've just opened a Mountain View office, and so I jumped at the chance
to come out here.  I hope to move into the City by the end of the summer
and commute via Caltrain.

Looking forward to meeting lots of you, and groovin at some of those
famous beach parties this summer!!!

PeaceLoveUnityRespect
John

acme


(I thought about just leaving it at that one word, but realize that there 
is more to be said)

one bottle of water included with entry fee:  very cool

wasn't very crowded, which is good, but it took a toll on the vibe 
factor.  I got my dancing in but I can't say I got my hootin' and 
hollerin' in.

alittle bit sticky but nothing unbearable.

since the building is basically a long hallway, lots of traffic causes 
disruption to dancers, however last night it was not so pushy, just alot 
of weaving.

concistent beats.  I suppose that would be house in the main room.  
alittle bit more techno-y in the basement but still housey speeds.  I did 
catch a break in there and that was a joyous but brief moment indeed.

can't wait to do the Wickedslip(tm) next week...

all helped me to move into the 21st century. I will miss having my computer
so readily available, but after I arrive in the uk, I will get set up with
some kind of ability to post from the uk so look for me soon.....

to make this trip possible by sub-renting my house. His name is Eric D and
I met him through SFRaves. (he is from DCRaves, and has posted on SFR) he
is going to move here, and he will use my pad to transition himself to S.F.

"Paranoia strikes deep, into you life it will creep"

Another thought...
Sorry to say that a lot of younger than I ravers think that because 
someone is in their mid thirties or forties that they are a narc.
 
I remember a Sunset a while back where a male friend of mine age 44 was 
actually asked, "Are you a narc?" He just laughed.

People need to become more observant and much greater readers of 'energy'.
I don't care how polished in a role a cop or rat might be, they can't hide 
their hearts.

Also, many folks need to be a  
bit less judgemental...I just have to talk about this here even 
though I know non of you have made such acusations.  Anyway, I recommend 
that these folks take an hour to observe the aledged narc and see who 
they are hugging at the party, or perhaps who they share their heart pipes 
with.  

Now on a possibly really paranoid side, I did see two folks this evening 
who radiated a narc-like vibe.  What I thought I was reading was a spying 
energy...Believe me there are organizations within the walls of right 
wing fascist Christian churches who do in fact gather the sinful facts & 
information (pagans, drugs, sex, indescent clothing) which is used during 
sermons against us (remember these people have increasingly enormous 
clout as voters).  Perhaps it was parents spying on their sons and daughters 
who just don't like their kids being there.  E.g. my dad once spied on me 
from the Hermosa Beach Pier when I was 12 having just a little too much 
fun on the beach--grounded for two weeks)  Anyway, I bear a watchful eye 
all the time, as a warrior a macumazon (he who sleeps with one eye open)  
as a guardian watching for anything potentially 
harmful to our House.    

And to end on a positive note....  I arrived after 6 tonight and when 
Galen went on, it was simply amazing, one of the Bay areas's best Dj's 
IMHO... Anyone taping  tonight?  Man I would love a tape of his set...

If interested, at the next Sunset, you can find me... I always wear a big 
straw hat with lots of weird and interesting shit hot glued to the brim...  
until sunset..

Lastly, often folks ask for good energy sent their way...my mom (age 67) 
is visiting this Saturday for a week.  From the deepest place in my heart 
I want to share my 'church' so to speak with her..  take her to a day 
small party.  I humbly ask for the energy of patience be sent my 
way..good thoughts, so that I can give this to  her in a gentle beauty way.

Thanks and always peace...

Maureen

Message-Id: <199604291623.JAA23094@franc.ucdavis.edu>
X-Sender: szriffle@peseta.ucdavis.edu
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Pro Version 2.1.2
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Rick Riffle <rdriffle@ucdavis.edu>
Subject: Amazing Sunset
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

After driving home from Portland and dropping the SF members of C-Lab off,
my friend Eric and I thought we'd check out Sunset for a little while before
we drove back to Sacramento.  We got there just as the sun was setting, and
cashing a few karma points, scored a great parking place really close to the
festivities.  We proceeded to dance to the sounds of Galen, and almost
immediately were entranced.  It was really tribal at first with lots of hand
drum type sounds, then after a couple of songs I heard a nice round 303
sound going WOUMP WOUMP....WOUMP WOUMP.... And for some reason, more than
usual I started to really get into it.  I was flailing all over place, and
the croud started getting a little crazey too.  People seemed to be really
"in it" at that point.  I danced really hard through that song, then out of
know where, this oh so familiar breakbeat comes in and the sample "this is
it", and the crowd goes nuts.  It was "Helter Skelter" by Meat Beat
Manifesto.  This is one of my favorite songs of all time, and I have only
heard it one other time at a rave in my life.  Needless to say, I went
ballistic at this point and so did everyone else.  People were screaming and
buggin out and I just loved it.  I was so tweaked after that song that I had
to go rest.  Walked around, ran into some friends from Sac, then headed home.  

Thank you Galen for playing that song, it really caped off the weekend in
all the best ways.

Thanks for listening.

Rick

Oh the love I felt and shared! I had a great time! There were so many
beautiful people! I couldn't believe I was hearing Helter Skelter, what a
classic! The sunset was so awesome....True storie...I had brought with me a
backpack full of candy....I was planning on passing it out, well I never got
a chance too, and I think there was a reason, because, when I was leaving I
heard someone screaming,"Does anyone have any candy??" I thought oh I do, So
I said yes, I looked down on the street and some girl had  gone into insulin
shock(diabetic shock) Im not sure, but I busted out my Andes Candies, my
rocky roads, and my kit kats, and this girl ate chocolate like mad! Well I
guess it helped her, because she seemed to be doing better after 20 candy
bars! End of true story! Hope you all had as great a time as I did!
Peace love and chocolate!
Jonathan

Bounce was an odd party ....

First, it was NOT $5 before 11, they said they have no idea why that got posted
- and it was at the Acme, but it wasn't ever really crowded, so that was ok, but
it kept you wondering when people were going to arrive...

I actually saw NO ONE I even recognized until 2:30 a.m. when I saw Spun (which
is part of the reason I went) ...  

But the house music upstairs kept me very happy all night long...  I had a fine
thoughtful, primarily solo night, a nice change...

Have to mention there was a beautiful and amazing live ambient performance by a
group called Soulstice with electronic drums, violin, keyboard and a wonderful
vocalist --- they played for hours, it was so beautiful, I felt blessed to be
there!

Leslie  : )

The mark of a good DJ is that they know what song to play next, ulitmately
it doesn't matter what type of music one is into, if you play from your heart
and are sensitive to the crowd, you will be guided to the Next Record in your
crate, when this happens, you go beyound being a "trance DJ" or a "House DJ"
you simply identify with just being a DJ.

From: Jess Fogler <jfogler@itsa.ucsf.EDU>
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: review of All in the Family
Message-ID: <Pine.A32.3.93.960429095939.187010E-100000@itsa.ucsf.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Hummmm, I had a mixed time.

I went with Renaud who really is a blast and he made the evening good fun
but the party?.....

When we first got there the music was EAR BLISTERINGLY LOUD.  It was
postively painful and most un-fun.  After a while I asked them to turn it
down (telling them that people were leaving because of it - little white
lie in a good cause) and they did a little.  After that it was just
extremely loud.  In fact you couldn't even hear people whoot and holler or
whistle - to me that just killed the community vibe - no aural contact
between fellow ravers.

And people seemed to be very withdrawn.  I had to basically stand right in
front of people and force them to smile in order to connect.  Dancing was
low key, with very few people really letting loose except to amazing
circle dancers who were fun to watch but - again - no community feeling.

Also, people puking in the toilets and talking about puking and many
people so fried that they didn't even seem to know where they were.

EVEN SO - the music was good and trippy, the visuals were quite nice and
the space was lovely - an old victorian town hall type building.  What the
hell, I danced hard and had a good time anyway.  BUT it DEFINITELY wasn't
worth $20. 

Where's the PLUR?

Jess

>
>"Paranoia strikes deep, into you life it will creep"
>
>Another thought...
>Sorry to say that a lot of younger than I ravers think that because 
>someone is in their mid thirties or forties that they are a narc.
> 
>I remember a Sunset a while back where a male friend of mine age 44 was 
>actually asked, "Are you a narc?" He just laughed.
>
>People need to become more observant and much greater readers of 'energy'.
>I don't care how polished in a role a cop or rat might be, they can't hide 
>their hearts.
>


So true, so true, and yes indeed there DO seem to be some "crispy critters"
walking around our Scene these days.  I don't know whether they are "Narcs"
or Spies for the Right or just unskilled Drug Fiends but some of them tend to
give one pause.  I don't think it's anything to get paranoid about, a little
common sense and some observation should do the trick.  Share your heart most
of all, show them that the Scene _is not_ simply about how many drugs you can
score/take/sell, etc but something that runs much deeper than that.  Maybe
eventually they will come to understand (maybe not)...

All in all...

                Be vigilent/send love.


                                        G

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: epaul@Synopsys.COM (Eric P. Peterson)
Subject: F-8 beach party review
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

        My friend Jeremy and I got to the location just after 10pm.  Only a
few others were there, and the people setting up on the beach.  We went
down the trail, and a guy was setting glo stix along the trail to help
people find their way.  We helped move the turntables to a place that
wouldn't get wet, and explored the area a bit.
        Very nice place!  There were lots of little rock statues all over
the place, and the left half of the area, just before the cliff rose from
the beach, consisted of small cleared spots in the rocks, perfect for
people to spread blankets, stash their stuff, and chill (or should I say
warm?) between dancing, etc.  There were some tunnels and climbs up the
cliffs, and the entire area was a large alcove, with the water meeting the
rocks on both sides.
        I was very happy to hear lots of trance, at just the right speed to
dance to.  My friend Nicole and I found each other, and were very happy and
impressed by the music and the location.  Before we parted, she called my
attention to the music and said "THIS is what I mean by 'beautiful
trance'!"  I concurred and enjoyed.
        This was my first beach party, and dancing under the moon and stars
(some of them shooting!) was fun and very special!  I found that it's hard
to dance on the sand unless you don't do much stepping/stomping.  People
were mostly moving from the knees up, with some easy steps, but not
elaborate as on a floor.  It was a nice change of pace.
        Somewhere in the middle of the party, the music was faster, and I
couldn't keep up, so I rested and hung out with Jeremy at our spot.  We
invited the people below us to hang out, and we sat and talked for a while.
When we felt we could brave the cool night some more (it never got too
cold), we went off again.
        I found Crunchman, and he gave me a body tune-up.  It helped my
circulation and loosened my shoulders, and made me good to dance some more.
Gradually, the tide encroached upon our dance space, reclaiming it little
by little.  The moon was well gone, but there were lots of beautiful stars
out.  Many of us danced at the edge of the water.  I noticed that people
were still friendly, smiling and groovin' to the tunes.
        I stood on a rock in defiance of the tide, and when the water hit
the rock, it splashed up and thoroughly drenched my jeans from mid-thigh
down :P  I thought it was hillarious, but couldn't dance very well after
that, so I returned to the little campsite for the remainder of the
morning, as the sky was brightening.  Jeremy and I were among the last to
leave.
        There were lots of people sucking on balloons that night, but those
days are long over for me, so I just observed amusedly.  It seemed that
people weren't as sociable as usual overall, but maybe that was due to the
cold, or the small number of people there (the crowd never got too big,
which was nice).  The size of the event made it feel more intimate, though,
like it was our event instead of an event put on for us.  A good time all
around, I must say!

looking forward to more beach/outdoor parties,

- E

	wonderful to me... (two DJs spinning together). Three of them 
	were advertised for _All Together Now_, but the sample I heard 
	has not been convincing at all.
	I personnally think that what I listened to was mostly 2 mixes 
	played together, not one mix played by two DJs.. It didn't
	sound *correct* except during short periods of time (minutes,
	I would say).

	Well, I guess it depends on the DJs too, of course.
	But Surge who done a good job at _Progress_ wasn't impressive 
	at all when mixed (I would say, destroyed) with another guy
	last night.
	Any DJ's opinion about those NxM mixes?

	All in all, the music at _All Together Now_ seemed quite diversified
	to me--i.e. too diversified, lacking of an homogeneity on which 
	to grow even your personnal vibe (hopefully, Jess is a vibe
	by herself--she saved the party ;-).

	So it was not worth 20 bucks, even if the lights 
	were great!

______________

I agree with Mark here ... I've wanted to share some suggestions for voice mail
messages from promoters....  I'm sure not everyone will agree with these, but
these are my thoughts .....


1. TELL US HOW MUCH IT COSTS!!!  If it's $20 say so!  Tell us you wish it could
be less but at least say how much it is!  Why is this kept a secret so often?  

2. I'd prefer you don't ramble on about your philosophical beliefs -- if you
want to share a spiritual message that is the theme of the party, that's great,
but please make it brief and thought-out.  (I do like when we're reminded to
bring a smile and positive vibe, that can't hurt!)  There was a voicemail for a
party a few months ago that went on and on with the oddest, most vague greek god
story that my friends and I called it three times just for laughs -- needless to
say, we didn't go to that party.

3.  Be punctual -- if you say you'll post directions after 8pm, please do that.
If it's 9pm and there's no message yet, we have to wonder if you've been busted,
lost the space, or are just not organized (not a good sign for the party in
general)

4.  Keep the music at the beginning to a minimum -- I swear I've heard messages
with two or three full minutes of music (a long long time when you're waiting to
get information) before a word was said.  (It's also nice if the music you play
represents what we might hear at the party.)  And make sure the music isn't so
loud we can't hear you talking!

5.  Please tell us where the party is first... then give directions.... if it's
in downtown SF, why start with "if you're coming from Sacramento.... " in the
directions first.

6. Don't insult us or overstate the lineup -- the guy on the All in the Family
Line said something like "if you don't know who this guy is then you don't know
music and you better get on it" or something ... yep, that made me feel all warm
and fuzzy ....  

The voicemail is our first introduction to lots of parties, and it's always nice
to get off on the right foot!  Thanks for listening....

Leslie  : )

	id NAA12449; Mon, 29 Apr 1996 13:30:48 -0700 (PDT)
Date: Mon, 29 Apr 1996 13:30:48 -0700 (PDT)
Message-Id: <199604292030.NAA12449@franc.ucdavis.edu>
X-Sender: szriffle@peseta.ucdavis.edu
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Pro Version 2.1.2
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Rick Riffle <rdriffle@ucdavis.edu>
Subject: Reed College is Crazy (weekend recap) (long)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Spent the weekend up at Reed College for thier annual "Renn. Faire".  Can I
just say these people are completely nuts.  We (Consciousness Lab) were
scheduled to play ambient music as part of the festivities for the event.
We played live music and dj'd for about 20 hours.  It was totally fun and I
met several really cool people.  They had a big tent with a pretty large
sound system set up and dj's spun there both Friday and Saturday night.  I
was told that the Saturday night tent got shut down early by the cops
because of several noise complaints. 
It was really cool for the time it was going though....although it was quite
cold at night there.

I experienced more out of the ordinary things this weekend than....well..
uh..than I get the pleasure of normally experiencing.

This Renn Faire thing.....I just couldn't belive it.  I was told that the
college funds the whole thing.  There were over 70 kegs of free beer. (I'm
not into alcohol, but still....wow!)  There was a big bug eating contest,
which I wasn't into either, but had to watch a little just for the
experience.  People were seeing who could out bid each other to get to eat
the bug.  They would start at like $10, then the next person would say "I'll
eat it for $9...and so on all the way down to like $1.  There were bugs that
were several inches long involved in this thing.....  Yuck!  It was amazing
to see so many people gathered around to see this spectical.  

They had naked blue people.  About 30 of them....naked, painted blue that
just ran around the campus shrieking and halloring, jumping up and down, and
being generally mischievious.  They chased lots of people.   I wish I would
have known before hand about them, cuz it looked like alot of fun.

They had a 200 foot long naked slip-n-slide down this grassy hill.  I don't
know if any of you have ever naked slip-n-slided before, but I highly
recommend it.  It was a blast.  Why am I thinking of Karen from Canada...I
have a feeling she would have liked this.

They had a free feast.  Tons of free food on Saturday.

They had bagel carts.  These people with tons-o-bagels in a cart just
pushing it around giving them away day and night.

And Water people...walking around giving out free bottled water. 

They had a crazy custome bicycle race.  They made psychotic looking bikes
out of other bike parts.  Crazy chopper bikes with the peddels two feet off
the ground.  One guy wrapped his bike in construction paper, lit it on fire
and proceeded to ride it around with the flames all around him.  I was
amazed that he didn't catch on fire himself.  Once the paper had burned
through there were many bottle rockets attached to the frame which shot off
in all directions.  COMPLETELY INSANE!!!!!

M-80's going off all around. BOOM!

There was free expression in every shape and form immaginable.

The dorm we played in was co-ed with co-ed bathrooms.  Not that spectacular,
but I thought it was cool that they were that open.

People smoking what ever they wanted at all times and places.

Free warm air!  There was this vent thing that people were just standing on.
It was shooting warm air up to the sky.  About four people could experience
it at once.  We stayed there for about 45 minutes.  We had no idea where it
was coming from or if it was toxic or not....but we, in our ....uh...well
the state of mind we were in...didn't really care.  The free warm air was
fantastic.  We poured water on it and it split into millions of little drops
and hovered a few feet off the ground then disbursed.....or I could have
just been seeing things....but the other people saw it too.

The nicest people.

A totally beautiful campus.

Music of all kinds everywhere all the time.  Several different areas with
lots-o-bands galore.

One of the greatest experience yet so far this life.

On Saturday night, Gateway Sound put on a Light party in the same area of
Portland, and Brad and Seth from C-Lab went and dj'd ambient music.  The
seemed to have alot of fun, but we didn't talk much about it.  I think the
party "went off" though.  When we picked up the boys around 4:30 a.m. the
whole building was thumpin and all the windows were vibrating.  I think it
was good.

I'm sure there were many more things that happened but I really havn't slept
much the past three days, and I'm sure I'll remember later.

Bye.

Rick

Hey hey!

I went to the party as well and I had totally amazing time.  Maybe it 
was just because it was my first outdoor night party, or maybe because I 
am pretty new to this entire rave scene...  

I spend most of the time next to the fire because I was cold and tired and 
dancing on the sand was a little hard at times :).  I met some really fun 
people and although I don't even know/remember many of their names I 
would like to thank all of them for creating the friendly atmosphere. 

About balloons....  the only thing that bugged me a little bit was that 
the guy was very closed to me and the sound of the baloons beeing filled 
up got to be a little annoying (it felt like it was destroying the magic 
of the place).  But I guess it made many people happy, so...

I loved it and I can't wait for another outdoor, night party...  I wish 
more of my friends were there, because it was *beautiful*.

Hugz,
Branka

P.S.  Thanks to Melissa for taking me and to everybody who participated 
(I have no clue how all that equipment got dragged to the beach - I had 
hard time getting my back-pack and myself down).

to bust someone for.  In the case of marijuana, this is easy enough.  If
whoever is selling it thinks that a potential customer is kind of sketchy,
he could just offer him a hit off his pipe.  I guess this doesn't work as
well with ingestible products, though...

Just a thought,
Jake

Hey kids!

As a member of Gateway Systems, I know it's a little unprofessional for me
to do due a review of our party in Portland, but someone's gotta do it, and
so I will try and be as objective as possible...

Gateway shredded the fucking walls off Portland Saturday night!

Okay, maybe that's a little vague.  And let me start at the beginning...

I was looking forward to this event because it would give me some quality
time with some of the people I've come to love in the SF rave community.
Since most of our time is spent frantically setting-up, frantically dancing
or working shifts, or frantically breaking down, I was excited about calmly
sharing meals and just plain relaxing with the likes of Claire, John,
Ethan, Jenny, Minor Minor, Monty, Michelle, Joe Rice, Greg & Cindy, Wayne,
Dave, Joel, Holly, and a host of others.  It was to me like an SF rave
field trip, and that made it all the more special.  It even felt a little
like a field trip when Monty started telling us sick and twisted stories in
the back of the van on the way from the airport to the space.   (Use your
imagination, but unless you have a penchant for Milkbone Dog Biscuits, you
won't even come close...;^)

The space was an Acme style, art studio that supposedly has no one living
there, however it seemed like there was an endless stream of people coming
out of the multitude of rooms through out the day.  They were all cool and
friendly and were down with the party, so that was nice and made set-up
(and the party) go smoothly.  There was a sizable hallway in which the
ambient area was set-up, and Claire and Michelle worked the usual Gateway
magic with the space (it was beautiful, replete with shrine.  Definitely a
labor of love.)  Upstairs there was a large dance area with a gymnasium
style floor (good for dancing!).  The sound was amazing.  I honestly felt
that since it was so crisp, and so clear, it was actually *good* for your
ears.  Like a little eardrum work-out, without over stressing them.  Four
stacks in the corners; balanced perfectly.  Lights (by Dave) and laser (by
Joel) made the room into a den of visual treasure.  Juice bar by Holly for
tasty treats.  Upstairs, from the main floor was a nice chill area that
looked down on the dancers in revelry.  Upstairs even further was a huge
roof deck.  (Which people were thoroughly enjoying until some asshole threw
an orange peel at a security guard below and that forced us to clear the
roof in a hurry.  Kudos to the party goers for not questioning our request
that they vacate the roof quickly, so that by the time the three security
people got up there it was barren.)

The stage was set for a wonderful party, the place decked, the sound ready,
energy was at a high-vibe level.

Appreciate the SF scene - reason #1:  The door

We had more fucking excuses, stories, and blatant lies than I've ever seen
at an SF party.  Part of the problem was that the Modish building is known
for parties, and the people that live there have lots of friends, so, many
people came up saying that they knew so-and-so and should get in free.  We
tried to explain that $10 was very reasonable and that we were only
covering costs, which we were, but that didn't seem to have much of an
effect on people.  What we later realized is that Portland's scene is at an
interesting point, and so people are not accustomed to respecting the
promoters/party (maybe?).  It made me realize how nice it is in SF where
the majority of people respect the door and don't try and weasel their way
in.  We didn't let the door hassles bring us down though, relying on karma
to take its revenge on those that lied straight to our faces.  (I don't
know, maybe they'd pull a muscle or something.  Or get a parking ticket.
:^p)

Appreciate the SF scene - #2:  The music

Ladies and gentlemen, I have to say, I have not heard such flawless DJing
out of every single DJ in the same night.  The line-up went Joe Rice, Minor
Minor, Ethan, John Carel, Monty.  It was amazing.  The people were frantic,
out of their heads.  I don't know if they've ever heard such quality
workmanship.  Combined with the quality of the sound, all one can say
is...sublime.  Unfortunately I missed most of Joe's set because I was
listening to lame excuses at the door, but what I snuck up to hear was nice
powerful techno.  Frank took the stage next and spun an amazing set.  So
good was his set, that John was dancing as I had never seen him dance
before.  The party by this time was (excuse the expression) balls-out!  We
knew it was heading totally off the Portland charts and I think that lent
even more energy to everyone there.  (The excitement in knowing you're
setting a benchmark, or rather, making history.)  If you've seen Frank
spin, you know the more into it he gets, the lower he gets to the decks.
Let's just say that Frank and I were seeing eye-to-eye through most of his
set.  ;^)

Meanwhile C-lab sent down a representative from Reed to spin a long set in
the chill area, followed by Darkstar [? Darkhorse], followed by Rob.  Very
swarthy, cool, ambient music too, from Portishead to Paul's Boutique and
everything in between.  Again I lament not being able to be in two places
at once, for I always miss the best ambient areas.

(Special moment for Tony:  In the middle of Frank's set I turned around and
saw Ethan, Joe and Monty all in a line dancing that sub-dude DJ dance and
couldn't help but feel proud to be friends with some of the top brass in
the SF scene, and paused for a moment to appreciate how cool, and
unpretentious they are.  I turned around again a moment later and John
Carel had joined them and that made my smile even wider.  You should have
seen Frank's smile when he looked up and saw them all smiling at him.
Unforgettable!)

The music was fast by this time, fast and hard and driving and
techno/techno trance/acid trance -- Fucking Acid Trance (FAT!) -- what have
you.  Ethan took control after Frank and spun to the hoots and hollers of
the crowd.  The party was in full swing.  It was amazing to see the
syncronicity from DJ to DJ.  Ethan picked up and took the party higher, and
higher and higher.  People were literally turning in amazement and
shrieking and dancing.  John came on and amazingly kept the energy
building.  It was toward the end of John's set that reliable sources stated
that "this may be the best party to ever happen in Portland."  Now I won't
go so far as to say that, but shit, given that this would have been one of
the best parties so far this year in SF, there most likely is some basis
for believing what they say.

John drove the decks like an Italian race car driver: fast, furious,
flawless, with confidence and passion.  The man was the shit!  (I really
must say, the *men* were the shit!  It would be an injustice to single
anyone out, it was amazing teamwork.)  If this were a Crunchman review,
insert "this is when I really started moving my ass."  I later learned John
dusted off some old records, pre my indoctrination to the scene, and man
did they rock.  At one point he mixed something so powerful it truly
sounded like a freight train was running through the building.

Appreciate the SF scene - #3:  Musical Diversity

Monty came on and dropped some seriously housey records.  It was a slight
change-up from the previous DJs, but it was a great way to show the
diversity that we can bring from SF, and how the DJs, working together can
offer more than one style in a night.  (I know it's heavily debated, but
the music you like is out there in SF, you just have to go find it.)
Toward the end Monty spun some fast-house/acid house -- Phat Housey Acid
Trance (PHAT!) -- that had the majority of people dancing at that late
hour.

When it was all over, a big circle and some thank yous sent the Portland
ravers on their way, and there was no lack of broad grins and wild staring
eyes as if to say "did that really just happen here, in Portland?!"  We
were proud, happy, and tired.  Clean-up, slept, eat and came home.

Appreciate the SF scene #4: The People

I can't say enough about the people in the underground scene in SF.  I am
so proud to say that I'm a part of it, the words flow out of me coated with
pride like a donut coated with sugar.  It takes a party away from the scene
to help realize what you have at home.

Appreciate the SF scene #5:  The Scene

Keep it alive people, and appreciate every moment, for it will not last
forever, and when you're old and crusty, you will have the most amazing
stories to tell someone else's grandkids.  Plus, it's so nice to have
someone ask "When would a good weekend be for me to come visit SF to have a
good time?"  and be able to respond, "Dude, *any* weekend!"  :^)

Thanks to Gateway, the Modish people, Manage' [sp] (our host and liaison)
and everyone who made it a trip worthwhile.

Peace and love!

Tone

P.S.  Sunday afternoon, as we were all hanging around resting, a woman came
up to us and said, "I have lived in this building for a long time, and
there has never been a better party in all that time.  Thank you so
much...when are you coming back?"  All we could do was smile, thank her,
and assure her very soon.

Y'know, this smacks of the "ten commandments"...

THE TEN COMMANDMENTS OF PARTY PHONE MESSAGES:

1. Thou shalt include the ticket price information.
2. Thou shalt refrain from rambling about thy philosophical beliefs.
3. Thou shalt be punctual.  Tary not after the promised hour.
4. Thou shalt keep the music at the beginning to a minimum.
5. Thou shalt play music representative of the music played at the gathering.
6. Thou shalt keep the background music low enough for callers to hear thy 
message.
7. Thou shalt summarize the location before going into long-winded directions.
8. Thou shalt not insult the caller or overstate the lineup, lest bad karma 
accumulate against thee.
9. Thou shalt not record the message if thou hast an heavy accent; be not 
full of pride, but let thy non-accented brother or sister record the message.
10. Thou shalt not speak of PLUR on the phone message, only to hold a party 
that looketh like no more than a beer bust, lest thy fellow ravers strike 
thee for blasphemy.

 -- On Mon, Apr 29, 1996, Jake "F. Lee Bailey" Reichert  asserted: 

>>>Nice thought, but generally false. I actually had opportunity to ask a cop
>>>about this once and he basically laughed at the suggestion. I've read that
>>>legally they may have to, but there are several exceptions, such as if they
>>>feel they'd be endangering themselves by admitting the truth.
>>>
>>>Joe

>However, by law they cannot partake of any of the substances they are trying
>to bust someone for.  In the case of marijuana, this is easy enough.  If
>whoever is selling it thinks that a potential customer is kind of sketchy,
>he could just offer him a hit off his pipe.  I guess this doesn't work as
>well with ingestible products, though...

>Just a thought,
>Jake

No, this is also incorrect. Police have specific legal authority to do drugs
in undercover operations, if not doing so would blow their cover. This has
been documented many times, including a couple of movies where undercover cops
become addicts in the course of sting operations.

Please people, don't just spread rumors you heard about the law. Unless you
have specific knowledge and can back it up with sources and/or disclaimers,
this is dangerous advice that could land someone in jail. There are no
clear-cut lines you can give like "Cops can't do XXX or your case will be
thrown out of court." Previous posts have shown that there is always a special
case or circumstance that allows cops to skirt the law. Believe me, the laws
are stacked in their favor. If you haven't noticed, there has been this war on
drugs going on for a while now, and the courts seem to have no problem with
taking away individual freedoms in the interest of fighting drugs. The result
is frightening.

So, if you want to give advice, please give it in the form of anecdotal
evidence (like, "I/FOAF got busted for selling XXX and it was thrown out
because the cops screwed up and did YYY.") or some other kind of authoritative
support (magazine/newspaper/journal article, etc.) I don't want to seem like a
hard-ass, but people here are giving specific legal that they are not
qualified to give. I guess smart people will not act on any advice given in
such a non-legal forum, but I don't like people spreading rumors that might
land someone in jail.

Doug

Ummm... not that this is really easy, but citing sources on 
"by law cops have to..." statements is really helpful.

By stating inaccurate info on things like drug stings,
you could be costing someone a LOT if they trust what you post.

----------

>From what i have seen on TV and talking to folks into drugs,
and from recent posts on SFraves, i'd believe:

Undercover Cops have to tell you if they are a narc.

Undercover Cops can't do drugs themselves.

Undercover Cops can't have sex with people they are investigating.
(not mentioned on SFraves :)

>From reading around on the net for however many years,
i've come to believe:

Cops have to tell you they are a narc unless their lives are in danger.
(as Joe stated)
ANY situtation involving a drug deal is considered life threatening.
   .
  . .
If an undercover cop is trying to buy/sell drugs from you,
they don't have to tell you anything.

Also from reading accounts of drug busts and stories of undercover cops
who got addicted to drugs:

Cops can and do use drugs in the presence of people they are gathering evidence
on. 

(They aren't likely  to bust you if they are high/fucked up,
but if it's a sting operation, they'll catch you on videotape.)

On the sex thing, i still think that's true, but wouldn't
necesarily encourage people to abide by that becuase
it would probably just make you a very popular/unpopular dealer
if you slept with everyone you sold to.

---------------

Aside from actual laws...

A cop can do whatever she wants.  She can put you under arrest
and take all your drugs and do it all in a manner that isn't legal.

You lose your drugs and have to hire a lawyer.

The cop gets a slap on the wrist for a sloppy arrest,
and a pat on the back for taking some drugs off the street
but not crowding a jail already full of drug offenders.

On Mon, 29 Apr 1996, Rick Riffle wrote:

> "in it" at that point.  I danced really hard through that song, then out of
> know where, this oh so familiar breakbeat comes in and the sample "this is
> it", and the crowd goes nuts.  It was "Helter Skelter" by Meat Beat
> Manifesto.  This is one of my favorite songs of all time, and I have only
> heard it one other time at a rave in my life.  Needless to say, I went
> ballistic at this point and so did everyone else.  People were screaming and
> buggin out and I just loved it.  I was so tweaked after that song that I had
> to go rest.  Walked around, ran into some friends from Sac, then headed home.  

 Oh god YES--I was waiting for a friend to go down to the water with and 
when I heard this song I picked my tired self up and ran up to the front
of the crowd and just went off. I was extremly happy that Galen played this 
song.
 That was the first time that I've heard a Dj bring any of Manifesto's 
songs into their set. After that I struggled back and collapsed:).

                               _Reagan

They have quite a few songs that still sound fresh - "Helter Skelter," "God
O.D.", "Psyche Out," their mix of MC900ft Jesus' "Killer Inside Me," even
"Now" works great in ambient sets. Plus almost all of Storm the Studio. I
think they're a much bigger influence on house and techno than they get
credit for. Jack Dangers lives in Mill Valley. Wonder if he ever makes it
out to parties...

Joe

[ to sfraves list ]

 Just to add a bit of paranoia to the present mix ... I've read that the
usual way narcs bust up a "drug ring" is to arrest some users , looking
for someone with a lot of dope in their possesion. Then , they pressure
that user into narcing for them. So - cops don't have to infiltrate 
someone into a scene , they pressure someone who's already a part of that
scene to inform on the dealers and , worst , their fellow users.

 Have a nice friday ( and have any of your friends been acting , well,

> and just feeling absolutely miserable until things calmed down.
> He then was pretty sick (although not close to that bad) for the next
> few days.
> 
> Being the experimental little pup that he is, he took the second
> pill he bought in the hopes that there was just some wierd
> reaction the first time.  But the same exact thing
> (including the following sickness) happened. 
> 
> Many, many, many people said: "That must have been heroin."
> 
> (Quite a few people also said "Heroin isn't really orally active,
> so that couldn't have been heroin."  but didn't have any
> other, better or worse, suggestions.)

[more editing}

As I have stated before, every body is a different, chemical-based, 
biosystem. There is always the possibility that someone may have an 
allergic, or otherwise dissimilar, reaction to any chemical that is 
ingested. I'm not saying that is the case here or everytime that someone 
has a wierd reaction to a given substance, but it is one of the many 
possibilities. 

 The above reaction sounds like a reaction to a stimulate to me, but I'm 
no doctor (or pharmacist).

 I know that I need to take less E than most folks (about 100 milligrams) 
to have a great time  =). If I consume 125 milligrams (1/8 gram) or more 
than I start to have similar reactions described above. I usually 
describe it as a reverse of a good experience where I DO NOT love 
everyone and feel generally BAD. Just as a context, I used to get E when 
it was only $8 a dose. The good 'ol days =), before Raves had even hit 
the US of A

Subject: The Devil Went Down to Frisco
X-Mailer: <PC Eudora Version 1.4>
Message-Id: <96Apr29.183158pdt.3341@godzilla.ADOC.xerox.com>
Date: Mon, 29 Apr 1996 16:55:04 PDT

The Devil went down to Frisco
He was lookin' for a soul to steal.
He was in a bind, he was way behind
and he was willing to make a deal,

When he came across this young man
circle dancing and playing it hot.
The devil jumped up on a 6 foot speaker,
said, "Boy, let me tell ya what!

"I guess you didn't know it
but I'm a circle dancer too,
and if you care to take a dare
I'll make a bet with you.

Now you're a pretty good dancer
but give the Devil his due,
I bet a whistle of gold against your soul
cause I think I'm better 'n' you!"

The boy said, "My name's John S. Lee
and it might be a sin,
but I'll take yer bet and yer gonna regret
cause I'm the best that's ever been!"

John S. Lee you better stretch out
and dance with all your heart,
cause Hell's broke loose in Frisco
and the Devil's dealing hard.

If you win you get this shiny whistle made of gold,
but if you lose, the Devil gets your soul!

The devil whipped out his tennis shoes
and he said, "I'll start this show!"
And fire flew from his fingertips
as he tied the laces in a bow.

He slid across the floor
and those shoes made an evil hiss
The he danced and he twirled and he jumped
and everyone one in the crowd he dissed.

When the devil was finished, 
John S. Lee said, "Well you're pretty good old son,
but sit down and get a backrub from those pretty rave chicks
and let me show you how it's done!"

John danced like a man possessed
but suddenly he couldn't dance anymore.
In the middle of the circle someone built an altar 
and plopped their butts in the middle of the floor!

John S. Lee hung his head
because he knew that he'd been beat.
The devil picked him up and 
slung over his shoulder by his feet.

A gate to Hell opened.
As the Devil descended into the ground
he said, "If you kiddies ever want to try again
you know where I can be found!"

John S. Lee's still dancin';
he's dancin' day and night too,
but you can bet when someone sits in the floor now,
John comes kickin' through!

- SDream

Subject: (NRR) re: Traci Lords
Message-Id: <96Apr29.183736pdt.4063@godzilla.ADOC.xerox.com>
Date: Mon, 29 Apr 1996 17:22:32 PDT

Precedence: bulk

Is pornography degrading to women or sexually liberating for our society?

>From my perspective, what I think is important to understand is that being
disturbed by pornography does not mean a woman is anti-sex or repressed.
The disturbance for me comes from the fact that pornography, almost by
definition, OBJECTIFIES women.  It is a VISUAL medium, focusing on graphic
sex acts and body parts.  Narrative, thought, is largely absent.  This
seems to correspond to a more masculine sexuality, i.e. being turned-on
visually, bodies and acts arousing rather than minds and personalities.
For many women, this impersonal sexuality is inexplicable - and actually
threatening.  Unfortunately for all of us, male sexual response has
translated to a hierarchical social structure (i.e. sexism).

Women experience that objectification based on our bodies - the
dehumanization - every day of our lives.  When we walk down the street, we
are sexually harassed; a blatant power play emphasizing that men like to
impose their sexuality on us without any regard for our consent, simply
because we have female bodies.  The extreme emphasis on our looks
overshadows every aspect of our lives.   Feminism and the women's movement
is our struggle to be evaluated and advance on our merits and talents, to
escape that objectification so that we can actually be acknowledged as
equal human beings.  I strongly suspect that the objectifying male
sexuality is a subconscious basis for the unequal status of women in our
culture.

*Not that there's anything inherently wrong with male sexuality - men are
how they are, getting turned on by seeing breasts is not evil.   However,
the problem arises when that concept of women extends beyond actual sex to
encompass how we are viewed in our entirety.

Also, mainstream porn (made almost exclusively for men) is damaging in that
it is NOT A REALISTIC PORTRAYAL OF FEMALE SEXUALITY.  The women are
portrayed as having the exact same sexual response as men.  i.e. there is
no foreplay required, a woman is ready to go at a moment's notice, she is
willing to have sex with anyone in the room without having to have any sort
of relationship with them, and she has uncontrollable orgasms from
intercourse.  As this is, for most women, the diametric opposite of our
actual sexuality, this portrayal discourages paying attention to women's
actual needs.  In that way it is a sexist institution that continues the
dehumanization of women (i.e., does not respect or acknowledge our
different needs from men).  Set that against a backdrop of society
discouraging women to be sexually assertive, and you have tons and tons of
women who cannot communicate just what they really need from a lover.

As for women in porn and prostitution, many claim personal liberation in
the experience.  I think we have to listen to individuals and not pass our
own judgements on their choices.  It is important to realize, however, that
many women in these professions are exploited: someone (a pimp, a producer)
gets most of her earnings, many women are drug-addicted, and many have been
raped or abused.  There ARE, however, healthy people who choose sex work
based on their own morals.  I have known a couple of women who have my
utmost respect as it is their own thoughtful, intelligent, informed
decision (they are students, in business on the side with their own steady
clients - different situation from most street-walkers).

Sex work IN ITSELF does not seem, to me, inherently terrible.  Human beings
need sex, it's pleasure.  So why not contract with someone for the service?
It's just touching, it's being LOVING to someone to give them pleasure.
Pornography is filming people having sex.  The problem seems to lie not in
the fact of sex work, but in its MISUSE - exploited streetwalkers, sexist
portrayals of women.  It is telling that our society feels that any sex
work is disgusting - the only way we can conceive of it is as something
sick, perverted and abusive.  People enjoying pleasure and being kind to
each other without exploitation does not seem to be possible within that
societal mind-set.   Sex work in a culture with a different view of
sexuality would look, I think, entirely different!

Hopefully as a society we can move beyond our current model of sex as a) a
display of dehumanized women for the man, and b) nasty and degrading to
women.  This whole concept of what sex is evidences, to me, the sickness of
our society.  Hopefully we can move toward a healthy, loving, equitable
sexuality - and hopefully the mindset that will birth it is what we are
creating in rave.  (This was my exact topic in a previous post and I caught
a lot of flames for being "offensive"! ).

Change starts with the individual.  For myself, I have thrown away
societal's pressure on my sexuality and proudly claim MY real desires - a
loving relationship, my own pleasure (foreplay), respect and consensuality,
and absolute enjoyment of sex.  I will support erotica and writings and
photography from women - a sexuality that is beautiful, arousing, and
equitable.  I refuse to believe that being disturbed by current pornography
means we cannot be sexually liberated.   Instead, perhaps it means an
entirely new concept of sexuality.

Awaiting angry flames,
Nancy

Nancy,

  I like your overall viewpoint .... but sadly while many people agree
with you - their METHOD for improvement seems to be to create a new form
of puritanism... sort of like dieters or alcoholics - if food or whatever
is being abused just avoid and deny it.... This path leads us into a
spiral of sexual denial which all too often is the path we are lead down...

  So the way we use, express and control our sexualities as a society is 
pathetic at best. I am also still shocked at the double standard - that
a woman who enjoys and/or engages in open and frequent sex acts is "tainted"
which was implied about T. Lords ( if not actually said ). Apparently
the idea that sex is dirty.... and the "will you respect me if I do IT with
you?" question still has a healthy life in our society. Women who become
sex objects of our society all too often end up not only exploited through
objectivication but also end up wearing a modern scarlet letter of 
disapproval.

  On the other hand, many people who express their sexuality publicly such
as Madonna do very little for me at least.... I don't find her sexuality
particurly liberating or respect oriented (IMO of course). I don't think
of her as bad but merely representing a sexuality that lacks real 
romantic sentiment, respect or deep person to person contact. So from male
pronographers to female sex mistresses we too often lack good models for a
healthy sexuality ... and let's not even begin to talk about religious or
at least christian training regrading sex.....


  What we need is a really great tantric master on Channel 50.... ;-)

 Mike

 Good reading on sex and eastern philosophy : 

 Sexual Secrets : The Alchemy of Ecstacy

> overshadows every aspect of our lives.   Feminism and the women's movement
> is our struggle to be evaluated and advance on our merits and talents, to
> escape that objectification so that we can actually be acknowledged as
> equal human beings.  I strongly suspect that the objectifying male
> sexuality is a subconscious basis for the unequal status of women in our
> culture.
>
> *Not that there's anything inherently wrong with male sexuality - men are
> how they are, getting turned on by seeing breasts is not evil.   However,
> the problem arises when that concept of women extends beyond actual sex to
> encompass how we are viewed in our entirety.
>
> Also, mainstream porn (made almost exclusively for men) is damaging in that
> it is NOT A REALISTIC PORTRAYAL OF FEMALE SEXUALITY.  The women are
> portrayed as having the exact same sexual response as men.  i.e. there is
> no foreplay required, a woman is ready to go at a moment's notice, she is
> willing to have sex with anyone in the room without having to have any sort
> of relationship with them, and she has uncontrollable orgasms from
> intercourse.  As this is, for most women, the diametric opposite of our
> actual sexuality, this portrayal discourages paying attention to women's
> actual needs.  In that way it is a sexist institution that continues the
> dehumanization of women (i.e., does not respect or acknowledge our
> different needs from men).  Set that against a backdrop of society
> discouraging women to be sexually assertive, and you have tons and tons of
> women who cannot communicate just what they really need from a lover.
>
> As for women in porn and prostitution, many claim personal liberation in
> the experience.  I think we have to listen to individuals and not pass our
> own judgements on their choices.  It is important to realize, however, that
> many women in these professions are exploited: someone (a pimp, a producer)
> gets most of her earnings, many women are drug-addicted, and many have been
> raped or abused.  There ARE, however, healthy people who choose sex work
> based on their own morals.  I have known a couple of women who have my
> utmost respect as it is their own thoughtful, intelligent, informed
> decision (they are students, in business on the side with their own steady
> clients - different situation from most street-walkers).
>
> Sex work IN ITSELF does not seem, to me, inherently terrible.  Human beings
> need sex, it's pleasure.  So why not contract with someone for the service?
> It's just touching, it's being LOVING to someone to give them pleasure.
> Pornography is filming people having sex.  The problem seems to lie not in
> the fact of sex work, but in its MISUSE - exploited streetwalkers, sexist
> portrayals of women.  It is telling that our society feels that any sex
> work is disgusting - the only way we can conceive of it is as something
> sick, perverted and abusive.  People enjoying pleasure and being kind to
> each other without exploitation does not seem to be possible within that
> societal mind-set.   Sex work in a culture with a different view of
> sexuality would look, I think, entirely different!
>
> Hopefully as a society we can move beyond our current model of sex as a) a
> display of dehumanized women for the man, and b) nasty and degrading to
> women.  This whole concept of what sex is evidences, to me, the sickness of
> our society.  Hopefully we can move toward a healthy, loving, equitable
> sexuality - and hopefully the mindset that will birth it is what we are
> creating in rave.  (This was my exact topic in a previous post and I caught
> a lot of flames for being "offensive"! ).
>
> Change starts with the individual.  For myself, I have thrown away
> societal's pressure on my sexuality and proudly claim MY real desires - a
> loving relationship, my own pleasure (foreplay), respect and consensuality,
> and absolute enjoyment of sex.  I will support erotica and writings and
> photography from women - a sexuality that is beautiful, arousing, and
> equitable.  I refuse to believe that being disturbed by current pornography
> means we cannot be sexually liberated.   Instead, perhaps it means an
> entirely new concept of sexuality.
>
> Awaiting angry flames,
> Nancy
>
>

		        http://www.ahau.com/~shakti


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Apr 29 18:45:50 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id SAA05593; Mon, 29 Apr 1996 18:45:50 -0700

Received: by godzilla.ADOC.xerox.com id <4109>; Mon, 29 Apr 1996 18:44:48 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: SDream@tgrigsby.com (SDream)
Subject: Review: Fusion
X-Mailer: <PC Eudora Version 1.4>
Message-Id: <96Apr29.184448pdt.4109@godzilla.ADOC.xerox.com>
Date: Mon, 29 Apr 1996 17:27:43 PDT
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Warning: kinda long...

After a rather bad week, I needed to do some dancing.  Our plans of keeping 
the night a sedate one were changed when our non-rave visitor from Kansas 
decided she didn't have the energy to bop, and suddenly it became a RAVE 
NIGHT.  So all the little kiddies skipped off into the night in search of 
adventure...

I was overruled on the beach party.  As much as I've always wanted to go to 
a rave on the beach overlooking the ocean at night, it still hasn't 
happened.  <heavy sigh>  No, the draw last night was Doc Martin, so the 
target of our mission was ... Fusion!

This was held at the Jerrold St. deli <quiet grumbling>.  The music was 
*very* good, the lighting was ok, the acid visuals were good, and ... drum 
roll ... the A/C was working!  :)  Ok, I figured I ought to say that since 
that was the major gripe going around after one party a while back...  ;)  
It still gets pretty toasty upstairs, but heat rises, and with 700+ bodies 
(my estimate), you have to expect that.  Also, a new twist in decoration, 
there were these beach blowup toys, (a few beach balls, a shark raft, a 
hippo raft) and they were spray painted in DayGlo colors and hung across the 
dance area right where the black lights would hit them.  Very nice effect, I 
thought, a la DV8 and the dolphin room with a psychadelic touch.  There was 
some fun artwork upstairs where they were selling smart drinks and fruit -- 
always a welcome addition.

Prior to Doc coming out the black lights were turned off.  :(  I like black 
lights, but I guess it was just a little bright in there for someone.  
Still, by that time, I was so into dancing and boogying, the strobes and 
acid visuals were just fine.

Cool moment: some guy was going around selling glo sticks, so a lot of 
people were playing with them.  Since they were on strings, some folks would 
just spin them in circles over their head or whatever.  I was looking up and 
tripping on the guys overhead that had two glo sticks in one hand, red and 
green, and spining them in a circle.  Faster, slower, depending on the 
music.  The effect was weird...

Cool moment: I chatted with a pixie!  Ya gotta give it to people who come to 
a party with a gimmick.  There was a girl in a fairy outfit, complete with 
wings and sparkles on her face, informing people that she was a pixie.  
There was also a guy there with the cat-in-the-hat hat and the four fingered 
cartoon gloves.  I love that get-up -- I should get one for myself...

Cool moment: By coming to Fusion, I got a chance to talk to Stacey in person 
and get things straightened out regarding the stupid rumors going around and 
the negativity online the other day.  She was very sweet about it -- no 
karate chops or kicks to the kneecaps. 8)   So let's set the record 
straight: Tom and Stacey did NOT get the original space for "All in the 
Family" busted.  They throw parties.  'nuff said.  And Tom and Stacey are 
NOT narcs, like that should need saying.   Although she did share with me 
that they are in fact aliens who are intent on stealing all the pop rocks in 
the world -- seems pop rocks are beyond their technology...  (oh no! another 
rumor!)

The Vibe: It was ok.  I think there's just a certain vibe at events like 
Sunset or Chrysalis that are tough to come by.  I had a good time, but there 
wasn't a group energy that I could detect.  I came across some ravers with 
toys and candy and we hung for a bit, but even they didn't really seem into 
it.  It was just a good night to dance...

Unfortunately my crew pooped out before Doc came on, and we left about 5 
minutes before he was supposed to start.  :(

Bad moment:  Can I gripe about how the deli is run?  This has nothing to do 
with how the party itself was produced.  I got a clear cut example of 
immediate inflation last night when I bought one orange for $.40 and then 
five minutes later tried to buy another one and was told it was $.75.  Not 
that $.75 is going to break me anytime soon, but I was offended.  This is 
the treatment I have come to expect.  Look, there's a guy that works behind 
the counter with a moustache.  He's cool, he doesn't size you up and try to 
figure out how much he can take you for.  He charges you a fair price.  
Shoot, I bet he'd be cool to party with, even.  There's a woman behind the 
counter, and she's Satan in drag, the Anti-Raver.  She'll jack the price up 
on you in a heartbeat.  She tries to stick it to me everytime I walk up to 
the counter.  She'd probably try to charge you for a napkin...  And of 
course, water is $3 (probably more if Satan-woman is selling them) with no 
refills allowed -- at least in the guys restroom.  Fortunately there's 
usually a lady in the group I go with, so we're covered, but it's a hassle 
just the same.

S
