Hi everybody- my name's John, and I wanted to (re)introduce myself,
having just (re)subscribed to sfraves...  I'm moving to the South Bay
from Vail, Colorado, where I was on mtn-raves, which is a very 
beautiful community of people!  (I will miss dancing with them!!!!!)

I'm really excited to be living in the bay area, and psyched to reconnect
with the sharp minds and warm hearts of this area's community...  I've 
been on the WELL since 1991 or something-- and plan to be there forever.
I was on this list before-- in 1994 while traveling with some infamous
(and slightly mis-judged) UK rave promoters and performers called the 
"zippy pronoia tour"...   (yeah yeah, I know I know).  We threw a few good
parties in the Bay region, in conjunction with the awesome SPAZ crew,
most notably the "Jupiter Bash" in downtown SF the night that comet
smashed into the planet Jupiter.   

Anyway, I've been meditating up in the Rockies, snowboarding and weaving
websites for the company I'm a producer for-- Eagle River Interactive.
We've just opened a Mountain View office, and so I jumped at the chance
to come out here.  I hope to move into the City by the end of the summer
and commute via Caltrain.

Looking forward to meeting lots of you, and groovin at some of those
famous beach parties this summer!!!

PeaceLoveUnityRespect
John

acme


(I thought about just leaving it at that one word, but realize that there 
is more to be said)

one bottle of water included with entry fee:  very cool

wasn't very crowded, which is good, but it took a toll on the vibe 
factor.  I got my dancing in but I can't say I got my hootin' and 
hollerin' in.

alittle bit sticky but nothing unbearable.

since the building is basically a long hallway, lots of traffic causes 
disruption to dancers, however last night it was not so pushy, just alot 
of weaving.

concistent beats.  I suppose that would be house in the main room.  
alittle bit more techno-y in the basement but still housey speeds.  I did 
catch a break in there and that was a joyous but brief moment indeed.

can't wait to do the Wickedslip(tm) next week...

all helped me to move into the 21st century. I will miss having my computer
so readily available, but after I arrive in the uk, I will get set up with
some kind of ability to post from the uk so look for me soon.....

to make this trip possible by sub-renting my house. His name is Eric D and
I met him through SFRaves. (he is from DCRaves, and has posted on SFR) he
is going to move here, and he will use my pad to transition himself to S.F.

considered such a progressive and friendly place.

"Paranoia strikes deep, into you life it will creep"

Another thought...
Sorry to say that a lot of younger than I ravers think that because 
someone is in their mid thirties or forties that they are a narc.
 
I remember a Sunset a while back where a male friend of mine age 44 was 
actually asked, "Are you a narc?" He just laughed.

People need to become more observant and much greater readers of 'energy'.
I don't care how polished in a role a cop or rat might be, they can't hide 
their hearts.

Also, many folks need to be a  
bit less judgemental...I just have to talk about this here even 
though I know non of you have made such acusations.  Anyway, I recommend 
that these folks take an hour to observe the aledged narc and see who 
they are hugging at the party, or perhaps who they share their heart pipes 
with.  

Now on a possibly really paranoid side, I did see two folks this evening 
who radiated a narc-like vibe.  What I thought I was reading was a spying 
energy...Believe me there are organizations within the walls of right 
wing fascist Christian churches who do in fact gather the sinful facts & 
information (pagans, drugs, sex, indescent clothing) which is used during 
sermons against us (remember these people have increasingly enormous 
clout as voters).  Perhaps it was parents spying on their sons and daughters 
who just don't like their kids being there.  E.g. my dad once spied on me 
from the Hermosa Beach Pier when I was 12 having just a little too much 
fun on the beach--grounded for two weeks)  Anyway, I bear a watchful eye 
all the time, as a warrior a macumazon (he who sleeps with one eye open)  
as a guardian watching for anything potentially 
harmful to our House.    

And to end on a positive note....  I arrived after 6 tonight and when 
Galen went on, it was simply amazing, one of the Bay areas's best Dj's 
IMHO... Anyone taping  tonight?  Man I would love a tape of his set...

If interested, at the next Sunset, you can find me... I always wear a big 
straw hat with lots of weird and interesting shit hot glued to the brim...  
until sunset..

Lastly, often folks ask for good energy sent their way...my mom (age 67) 
is visiting this Saturday for a week.  From the deepest place in my heart 
I want to share my 'church' so to speak with her..  take her to a day 
small party.  I humbly ask for the energy of patience be sent my 
way..good thoughts, so that I can give this to  her in a gentle beauty way.

Thanks and always peace...

Maureen

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Apr 29 21:09:37 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id VAA20102; Mon, 29 Apr 1996 21:09:37 -0700
Received: from well.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id VAA19965; Mon, 29 Apr 1996 21:08:07 -0700
Received: (from phred@localhost) by well.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) id VAA19543; Mon, 29 Apr 1996 21:08:04 -0700
Date: Mon, 29 Apr 1996 21:08:04 -0700
From: Fred Heutte <phred@well.com>
Message-Id: <199604300408.VAA19543@well.com>
To: nw-raves@hyperreal.com, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Gateway/Portland
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Portland has always had such great *potential*.  Portland has always seemed
to get some momentum going and then . . . just not get going.  

I think the Gateway party Saturday night finally achieved the potential
for a really great event in Portland.  I'm kicking myself a bit because
it was my friends from San Francisco who put it on, and for a variety
of reasons, none of them very good (like "being busy" and so forth)
I didn't help out with this one.  

They did just fine without me, though!

The Modish Building, 333 Park Ave, has a long and complicated history in
the local scene.  The only real "rave club" we ever had in town was there
in the early 1990s (other places had "rave" nights but generally were
normal club spaces at other times).  The upper floors of the Modish have
gradually been taken over since then by a variety of organizations, 
musicians, bands and whatnot, so the building has gradually evolved into
a sort of alterna-cultural center.  Meanwhile, the ground floor has gone
through several ownership changes and is now a pretty nice live music club
but catering more to a professional audience.  

There have been lots of events at the Modish, but none that ever came close
to jelling like Gateway did.  It's kind of hard to describe the scene here,
everyone says "young" but young is not a problem, inwardly-withdrawn-
insecure-unsocial *is* a problem.  About halfway through the night
I recognized I was actually having a really good time and didn't feel the
emotional drain I usually get from being at Portland events.  Not to
overdraw this or anything, because there have been some good events here,
but it always seems like a struggle to keep the vibe flowing.

All the logistical aspects were totally covered -- awesome, I mean *awesome*
lights and sound, by far the best sound I've heard in Portland, even
eclipsing the excellent job that Jeff from Platinum did last week for the
4-20 event DRC spun at.  Excellent use of serious lights and lasers in
a small space.  It was great to go up on the balcony and watch the show
from above -- just like my best moments at 1015 . . . The DJs, well what
can I say, all excellent.  I only regret I had to leave before Monty
played in order to catch some sleep before my Seattle trip (business
business business!).  

And the crowd?  Well, sure there were about 30 SF and net-ravers there,
but for the large part it was the same locals who usually go and are part
of the same downcast crowd, but there was enough production, good music
and good feeling from the Gateway crew and Manoj and the Modish folks
that it completely changed the atmosphere.  

A really big win for Gateway, for Portland and for the Modish crew,
especially Manoj, who've put a lot into making things happen there.
Having an event like this one was, I think, an eye-opener for everyone.
I sure hope so.

I was asking my friend Phil where he would put the party on a scale of
Portland parties, and I put my hands out about a foot apart to give
him a 1-to-10 type scale.  So he started at 10 and his hand went up
and up and up . . .

Right around the time the party started, I was around the corner at
Umbra Penumbra, a coffeehouse, which has live ambient/electronic events
every couple of weeks.  My friend David ("Mr. Pharmacist") did one of
the performances, playing live analogue stuff (101s and the like) as
a backdrop to a couple of animated films.  Sort of like the theater
organist for silent movies, except for the 1990s instead of the 1920s.

Now if we could put together an event that combined that kind of live
stuff with house/techno and the ambient and the sophisticated funk from
the ground floor of the Modish . . . yow!!

Anyway, thanks so much to all of the Gateway crew for coming up here and
making it happen.  I just wish I'd been able to spend more time with y'all.

c u in the future!
phred

Thanks for the delightful review...
Except for the dorm, co-ed and campus references, sounds like a Burning 
Man review...wow  

Ya know, if you felt compelled to be blue and nekid, it could be 
way cool to have a bunch of ravers painted blue, among other things, 
inviting everyone at Main camp and other camps (they are estimating 
10,000 people this year) to check out rave camp.  My understanding last 
year, as was discussed some months ago here, is that many ravers never 
actually participated in the other camps.  For many of us, our goal is 
to contribute even more to the festival...

More on this later.  Are there any artists on this list who 
will be going to BM?  I will post this again.  Please send private email 
regarding same.  Thanks!  :)  --Mau



On Mon, 29 Apr 1996, Rick Riffle wrote:

> Spent the weekend up at Reed College for thier annual "Renn. Faire".  Can I
> just say these people are completely nuts.  We (Consciousness Lab) were
> scheduled to play ambient music as part of the festivities for the event.
> We played live music and dj'd for about 20 hours.  It was totally fun and I
> met several really cool people.  They had a big tent with a pretty large
> sound system set up and dj's spun there both Friday and Saturday night.  I
> was told that the Saturday night tent got shut down early by the cops
> because of several noise complaints. 
> It was really cool for the time it was going though....although it was quite
> cold at night there.
> 
> I experienced more out of the ordinary things this weekend than....well..
> uh..than I get the pleasure of normally experiencing.
> 
> This Renn Faire thing.....I just couldn't belive it.  I was told that the
> college funds the whole thing.  There were over 70 kegs of free beer. (I'm
> not into alcohol, but still....wow!)  There was a big bug eating contest,
> which I wasn't into either, but had to watch a little just for the
> experience.  People were seeing who could out bid each other to get to eat
> the bug.  They would start at like $10, then the next person would say "I'll
> eat it for $9...and so on all the way down to like $1.  There were bugs that
> were several inches long involved in this thing.....  Yuck!  It was amazing
> to see so many people gathered around to see this spectical.  
> 
> They had naked blue people.  About 30 of them....naked, painted blue that
> just ran around the campus shrieking and halloring, jumping up and down, and
> being generally mischievious.  They chased lots of people.   I wish I would
> have known before hand about them, cuz it looked like alot of fun.
> 
> They had a 200 foot long naked slip-n-slide down this grassy hill.  I don't
> know if any of you have ever naked slip-n-slided before, but I highly
> recommend it.  It was a blast.  Why am I thinking of Karen from Canada...I
> have a feeling she would have liked this.
> 
> They had a free feast.  Tons of free food on Saturday.
> 
> They had bagel carts.  These people with tons-o-bagels in a cart just
> pushing it around giving them away day and night.
> 
> And Water people...walking around giving out free bottled water. 
> 
> They had a crazy custome bicycle race.  They made psychotic looking bikes
> out of other bike parts.  Crazy chopper bikes with the peddels two feet off
> the ground.  One guy wrapped his bike in construction paper, lit it on fire
> and proceeded to ride it around with the flames all around him.  I was
> amazed that he didn't catch on fire himself.  Once the paper had burned
> through there were many bottle rockets attached to the frame which shot off
> in all directions.  COMPLETELY INSANE!!!!!
> 
> M-80's going off all around. BOOM!
> 
> There was free expression in every shape and form immaginable.
> 
> The dorm we played in was co-ed with co-ed bathrooms.  Not that spectacular,
> but I thought it was cool that they were that open.
> 
> People smoking what ever they wanted at all times and places.
> 
> Free warm air!  There was this vent thing that people were just standing on.
> It was shooting warm air up to the sky.  About four people could experience
> it at once.  We stayed there for about 45 minutes.  We had no idea where it
> was coming from or if it was toxic or not....but we, in our ....uh...well
> the state of mind we were in...didn't really care.  The free warm air was
> fantastic.  We poured water on it and it split into millions of little drops
> and hovered a few feet off the ground then disbursed.....or I could have
> just been seeing things....but the other people saw it too.
> 
> The nicest people.
> 
> A totally beautiful campus.
> 
> Music of all kinds everywhere all the time.  Several different areas with
> lots-o-bands galore.
> 
> One of the greatest experience yet so far this life.
> 
> On Saturday night, Gateway Sound put on a Light party in the same area of
> Portland, and Brad and Seth from C-Lab went and dj'd ambient music.  The
> seemed to have alot of fun, but we didn't talk much about it.  I think the
> party "went off" though.  When we picked up the boys around 4:30 a.m. the
> whole building was thumpin and all the windows were vibrating.  I think it
> was good.
> 
> I'm sure there were many more things that happened but I really havn't slept
> much the past three days, and I'm sure I'll remember later.
> 
> Bye.
> 
> Rick
> 
> 
>

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Apr 30 03:17:29 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id DAA25987; Tue, 30 Apr 1996 03:17:29 -0700
Received: from freedom.regenx.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id DAA25982; Tue, 30 Apr 1996 03:17:25 -0700
Received: from freedom (root@localhost [127.0.0.1]) by freedom.regenx.com (8.6.12/8.6.9) with SMTP id CAA04319 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Wed, 1 May 1996 02:18:10 -0700
Message-ID: <31872C4F.7AA2B09B@sundance.sjsu.edu>
Date: Wed, 01 May 1996 02:18:07 -0700
From: benedict pereira <pere0103@sundance.sjsu.edu>
Organization: r e g e n e r a t i o n  X
X-Mailer: Mozilla 2.01 (X11; I; Linux 1.3.97 i586)
MIME-Version: 1.0
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: re:f-8 party review
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

This message is to all the fellow ravers who experienced the blissful
state of oblivion that i was at on friday night at the f-8 party. It was
the closest that i ever came to experiencing the homo-gestalt feeling.
After experiencing huge events like Lucky Charms, Gaia etc. I was
delighted to find that there was such a feeling of community flowing
through the crowd ( if i can call it a crowd) on the beach. I was glad
that I didn't stay at home and go to bed like I had originally planned
to. Me and two friends of mine go there about 11:30 and were amazed at
the intimacy that the venue provided. The people at the entrance told us
that the event cost $6 but that we could pay whatever we wanted. When I
attempted to give them $7 I was given a dollar back and told that there
was no reason to pay more than $6. I knew this was the start of a good
night. The trek down did not even begin to prepare us for the unexpected
sight of a cul-de-sac so perfect that it might have been designed for
that night. I was pleased with the people tha I met and their overall
attitude. Like I told this very nice lady, that I met, seeing this
turnout gave me hope for the future of or society, sentimental as that
may sound. After the sun had been up for some time, we helped the Dj
carry his equipment back to civilization. All in all, it was one of the
more spiritual experiences that I've had in the last couple of months. 

Doran

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Apr 30 07:18:13 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id HAA14947; Tue, 30 Apr 1996 07:18:13 -0700
Received: from netcom3.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id HAA14939; Tue, 30 Apr 1996 07:18:07 -0700
Received: from DialupEudora (jsl@localhost.netcom.com [127.0.0.1]) by netcom3.netcom.com (8.6.13/Netcom)
	id HAA02808; Tue, 30 Apr 1996 07:18:00 -0700

>> Is pornography degrading to women or sexually liberating for our society?
>>
>> >From my perspective, what I think is important to understand is that being
>> disturbed by pornography does not mean a woman is anti-sex or repressed.

Certainly not.  But when you hear someone call a person who does pron,
dirty or slutty, I think it is very clear the puritanical if not
self-righteous tone of such phrases.  Who's objectifying who now?
I think it all depends on the person.  Obviously there are people here who
feel that sex is still a very strange and alien thing.

I am disturbed by many things I see portryed in film.  especially the
respresentation of black people.  I however refrain from saying that the
people hwo do land roles are "uncle tom's", etc.  Or that there is some
type of Jewish conspiracy (ala Brando & others), guiding this whole thing.
We see what we want to see sometimes.


>> The disturbance for me comes from the fact that pornography, almost by
>> definition, OBJECTIFIES women.  It is a VISUAL medium, focusing on graphic
>> sex acts and body parts.

All movies ever made are of the visual medium.  Sound was added much later.
"Regular" movies focus on body parts as well; faces, eyes, arms, gestures.
There really is no difference.  The focus of porn is sex/entertainment.
The focus of mainstream movies is personalities/entertainment.  The real
argument here is about sex, and somehow porn , because it is sex based,
having greater impact on the society at large.  Unfortuantly all studies
are very mixed and haphazard.  There are plenty of philosophical arguments
for and against porn.  But like everything else, there is no conclusive
evidence to say whether the people who watch porn are affected.  We *do*
know people who do not appreciate porn are affected though.

The only fact is that porn is porn.  All movies objectify something, and
most woemn in movies are usually whores or helpless victims.  And people
call it mainstream because of the narrative?  Whatever, it's all the same
stuff to me.

>> Narrative, thought, is largely absent.

Looking at the current crop of movies (mainstream) of late, I think this is
true of most films made.  Mainstream and porn.  And WHO decided that a real
or good movie needs narration.  Some of the most powerful movies made were
silent films (See Dr. Caligari).  I go to movies to be entertained.  I f I
learn something, bonus round.  But the main reason is entertainment.
Mainstream movies, as lilly-white as it might be, along with porn , as
lilly-white as *it* can be, both entertain.

The rest, whether porn is less becuase of it's focus, is all a matter of
opinion.

To me, it is no more or less than anything else out there.


>> This
>> seems to correspond to a more masculine sexuality, i.e. being turned-on
>> visually, bodies and acts arousing rather than minds and personalities.

Not a porn afficionado huh?  There are plenty of female producers now.
Porn encompases many different genres, from the raunch to the romantic.
There is a whole line of erotica (read pron), put out by Candida Royale,
ex-porn star (you should see her in "Hot Rackets"), and she is trying to
cater to women.  There are other female producers.  These ladies focus less
on the act than on the interaction.  There are vidoes where people don't
even have sex (see some of the wierd tantric stuff...) per se.  Anyway
there are many different genres of porn.  You are grouping all of porn into
one neat box so you can argue against it.  By not being aware of the
variety, all you are doing is making a gross generalization.

Generalizing is a very narrow path to being wrong.


>> For many women, this impersonal sexuality is inexplicable - and actually
>> threatening.

And for many women it is not threatening, but liberating.  LArger and
larger numbers of women are making thier own porn movies now. Whtere it be
professional or amatuer, women are in it.  Please try not to speak for all
your sisters.  Many would disagree with you from jump.

This whole conversation sounds like one of those "Feminists Against Porn"
arguments I've heard over and over.  The end result?  The lefties of F.A.P,
join right up with the far right X-Tain Coalition and others, to stop the
common disease of objectification and sexually oriented movies.

Yikes!!! It's 1984 all over again! ;)


>> Unfortunately for all of us, male sexual response has
>> translated to a hierarchical social structure (i.e. sexism).

I see, and what of the female sexual response?

At this point, it seems like nothing more than an anti-porn, anti-male
response.  Ther rest of the analysis does not examine why women go into
porn, or even why many women enjoy it as much as men.  And it doesn't
answer the question as to why the industry, from all accounts, is growing
in acceptance for the most part.

I dunno, puritanism is far from dead.  I just wish people would leave each
other alone, and respect each other, instead of casting judgement after
judgement against each other for all kinds of weird resons.

Movies, all movies, are entertainment.  Some are even informative (porn is
no different).  If you don;t like it, don't watch it.  But before passing
judgment, I would suggest spending some time researching the subject.

Out,
John

P.S.  The Pilgrims have landed on SFR.  And they are as right as ever.

Anytime you think you are going to be narced siimply go up to the person 
who you think is going to narc you and say to him, "if your going 
to narc me narc me but for fucks sake get on with it if you are."  This 
instantly has the effect of a) shocking the guy because you recognized 
him in the first place and b) if he really is a narc he has to tell you 
there and then; if he doesn't that's entrapment and, while he may still 
get your stash, the case will be thrown out of court.
More star ideas from your friends at united way.

yup, it's all true :)  i want to thank all the gateway people for helping
us kick off a new era in Portland.  loving Portland as much as i do, *my*
community, we have alot of work to do here and alot of love to
spread...and knowing how to throw a good party with such a positive intent
is a great begining.  i feel that for those of us who live here, staying
centered and loving and holding each other up and helping each other learn
is equally important...and being ready to pick each other up when we fall.
this was a very new and fresh experience for our community...a catalyst
for change...a night to remember, and model as we create our future and
draw out the highest aspects of ourselves individually and collectively.

so, again, specifically, i want to thank all our new and old friends...i
LOVE you wayne and marcy and i'm sooo happy i had the best of both of my
families together!  ican't remember everyone's name i met...the dj's
were all delightful to meet...of course, much of the time spent by the
gateway people was taking care of the production.  monty?  hard
house...thanks for letting me massage your crown :)  thanks for the extra
special happy vibe from the woman with the short red hair (name???) ethan,
thanks for the hug on the dance floor, you have great energy, and clair
and everyone who decorated...you guys know how to create ambience :)

so now you guys know why i come to SF so often!  but, also why we're
working towards things here.  i know i speak for everyone at Ahau when i
say thank you from the bottom of our hearts!

peace out,

bren, aka, shakti
the Ahau collective


On Mon, 29 Apr 1996, Tony Rotundo wrote:

> (BSR = Blatent Self Review)
>
> Hey kids!
>
> As a member of Gateway Systems, I know it's a little unprofessional for me
> to do due a review of our party in Portland, but someone's gotta do it, and
> so I will try and be as objective as possible...
>
> Gateway shredded the fucking walls off Portland Saturday night!
>
> Okay, maybe that's a little vague.  And let me start at the beginning...
>
> I was looking forward to this event because it would give me some quality
> time with some of the people I've come to love in the SF rave community.
> Since most of our time is spent frantically setting-up, frantically dancing
> or working shifts, or frantically breaking down, I was excited about calmly
> sharing meals and just plain relaxing with the likes of Claire, John,
> Ethan, Jenny, Minor Minor, Monty, Michelle, Joe Rice, Greg & Cindy, Wayne,
> Dave, Joel, Holly, and a host of others.  It was to me like an SF rave
> field trip, and that made it all the more special.  It even felt a little
> like a field trip when Monty started telling us sick and twisted stories in
> the back of the van on the way from the airport to the space.   (Use your
> imagination, but unless you have a penchant for Milkbone Dog Biscuits, you
> won't even come close...;^)
>
> The space was an Acme style, art studio that supposedly has no one living
> there, however it seemed like there was an endless stream of people coming
> out of the multitude of rooms through out the day.  They were all cool and
> friendly and were down with the party, so that was nice and made set-up
> (and the party) go smoothly.  There was a sizable hallway in which the
> ambient area was set-up, and Claire and Michelle worked the usual Gateway
> magic with the space (it was beautiful, replete with shrine.  Definitely a
> labor of love.)  Upstairs there was a large dance area with a gymnasium
> style floor (good for dancing!).  The sound was amazing.  I honestly felt
> that since it was so crisp, and so clear, it was actually *good* for your
> ears.  Like a little eardrum work-out, without over stressing them.  Four
> stacks in the corners; balanced perfectly.  Lights (by Dave) and laser (by
> Joel) made the room into a den of visual treasure.  Juice bar by Holly for
> tasty treats.  Upstairs, from the main floor was a nice chill area that
> looked down on the dancers in revelry.  Upstairs even further was a huge
> roof deck.  (Which people were thoroughly enjoying until some asshole threw
> an orange peel at a security guard below and that forced us to clear the
> roof in a hurry.  Kudos to the party goers for not questioning our request
> that they vacate the roof quickly, so that by the time the three security
> people got up there it was barren.)
>
> The stage was set for a wonderful party, the place decked, the sound ready,
> energy was at a high-vibe level.
>
> Appreciate the SF scene - reason #1:  The door
>
> We had more fucking excuses, stories, and blatant lies than I've ever seen
> at an SF party.  Part of the problem was that the Modish building is known
> for parties, and the people that live there have lots of friends, so, many
> people came up saying that they knew so-and-so and should get in free.  We
> tried to explain that $10 was very reasonable and that we were only
> covering costs, which we were, but that didn't seem to have much of an
> effect on people.  What we later realized is that Portland's scene is at an
> interesting point, and so people are not accustomed to respecting the
> promoters/party (maybe?).  It made me realize how nice it is in SF where
> the majority of people respect the door and don't try and weasel their way
> in.  We didn't let the door hassles bring us down though, relying on karma
> to take its revenge on those that lied straight to our faces.  (I don't
> know, maybe they'd pull a muscle or something.  Or get a parking ticket.
> :^p)
>
> Appreciate the SF scene - #2:  The music
>
> Ladies and gentlemen, I have to say, I have not heard such flawless DJing
> out of every single DJ in the same night.  The line-up went Joe Rice, Minor
> Minor, Ethan, John Carel, Monty.  It was amazing.  The people were frantic,
> out of their heads.  I don't know if they've ever heard such quality
> workmanship.  Combined with the quality of the sound, all one can say
> is...sublime.  Unfortunately I missed most of Joe's set because I was
> listening to lame excuses at the door, but what I snuck up to hear was nice
> powerful techno.  Frank took the stage next and spun an amazing set.  So
> good was his set, that John was dancing as I had never seen him dance
> before.  The party by this time was (excuse the expression) balls-out!  We
> knew it was heading totally off the Portland charts and I think that lent
> even more energy to everyone there.  (The excitement in knowing you're
> setting a benchmark, or rather, making history.)  If you've seen Frank
> spin, you know the more into it he gets, the lower he gets to the decks.
> Let's just say that Frank and I were seeing eye-to-eye through most of his
> set.  ;^)
>
> Meanwhile C-lab sent down a representative from Reed to spin a long set in
> the chill area, followed by Darkstar [? Darkhorse], followed by Rob.  Very
> swarthy, cool, ambient music too, from Portishead to Paul's Boutique and
> everything in between.  Again I lament not being able to be in two places
> at once, for I always miss the best ambient areas.
>
> (Special moment for Tony:  In the middle of Frank's set I turned around and
> saw Ethan, Joe and Monty all in a line dancing that sub-dude DJ dance and
> couldn't help but feel proud to be friends with some of the top brass in
> the SF scene, and paused for a moment to appreciate how cool, and
> unpretentious they are.  I turned around again a moment later and John
> Carel had joined them and that made my smile even wider.  You should have
> seen Frank's smile when he looked up and saw them all smiling at him.
> Unforgettable!)
>
> The music was fast by this time, fast and hard and driving and
> techno/techno trance/acid trance -- Fucking Acid Trance (FAT!) -- what have
> you.  Ethan took control after Frank and spun to the hoots and hollers of
> the crowd.  The party was in full swing.  It was amazing to see the
> syncronicity from DJ to DJ.  Ethan picked up and took the party higher, and
> higher and higher.  People were literally turning in amazement and
> shrieking and dancing.  John came on and amazingly kept the energy
> building.  It was toward the end of John's set that reliable sources stated
> that "this may be the best party to ever happen in Portland."  Now I won't
> go so far as to say that, but shit, given that this would have been one of
> the best parties so far this year in SF, there most likely is some basis
> for believing what they say.
>
> John drove the decks like an Italian race car driver: fast, furious,
> flawless, with confidence and passion.  The man was the shit!  (I really
> must say, the *men* were the shit!  It would be an injustice to single
> anyone out, it was amazing teamwork.)  If this were a Crunchman review,
> insert "this is when I really started moving my ass."  I later learned John
> dusted off some old records, pre my indoctrination to the scene, and man
> did they rock.  At one point he mixed something so powerful it truly
> sounded like a freight train was running through the building.
>
> Appreciate the SF scene - #3:  Musical Diversity
>
> Monty came on and dropped some seriously housey records.  It was a slight
> change-up from the previous DJs, but it was a great way to show the
> diversity that we can bring from SF, and how the DJs, working together can
> offer more than one style in a night.  (I know it's heavily debated, but
> the music you like is out there in SF, you just have to go find it.)
> Toward the end Monty spun some fast-house/acid house -- Phat Housey Acid
> Trance (PHAT!) -- that had the majority of people dancing at that late
> hour.
>
> When it was all over, a big circle and some thank yous sent the Portland
> ravers on their way, and there was no lack of broad grins and wild staring
> eyes as if to say "did that really just happen here, in Portland?!"  We
> were proud, happy, and tired.  Clean-up, slept, eat and came home.
>
> Appreciate the SF scene #4: The People
>
> I can't say enough about the people in the underground scene in SF.  I am
> so proud to say that I'm a part of it, the words flow out of me coated with
> pride like a donut coated with sugar.  It takes a party away from the scene
> to help realize what you have at home.
>
> Appreciate the SF scene #5:  The Scene
>
> Keep it alive people, and appreciate every moment, for it will not last
> forever, and when you're old and crusty, you will have the most amazing
> stories to tell someone else's grandkids.  Plus, it's so nice to have
> someone ask "When would a good weekend be for me to come visit SF to have a
> good time?"  and be able to respond, "Dude, *any* weekend!"  :^)
>
> Thanks to Gateway, the Modish people, Manage' [sp] (our host and liaison)
> and everyone who made it a trip worthwhile.
>
> Peace and love!
>
> Tone
>
> P.S.  Sunday afternoon, as we were all hanging around resting, a woman came
> up to us and said, "I have lived in this building for a long time, and
> there has never been a better party in all that time.  Thank you so
> much...when are you coming back?"  All we could do was smile, thank her,
> and assure her very soon.
>
>
>

		        http://www.ahau.com/~shakti

Subject: Re: re:f-8 party review
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>This message is to all the fellow ravers who experienced the blissful
>state of oblivion that i was at on friday night at the f-8 party. It was
>the closest that i ever came to experiencing the homo-gestalt feeling.
>After experiencing huge events like Lucky Charms, Gaia etc. I was
>delighted to find that there was such a feeling of community flowing
>through the crowd ( if i can call it a crowd) on the beach. I was glad
>that I didn't stay at home and go to bed like I had originally planned
>to. Me and two friends of mine go there about 11:30 and were amazed at
>the intimacy that the venue provided. The people at the entrance told us
>that the event cost $6 but that we could pay whatever we wanted. When I
>attempted to give them $7 I was given a dollar back and told that there
>was no reason to pay more than $6. I knew this was the start of a good
>night. The trek down did not even begin to prepare us for the unexpected
>sight of a cul-de-sac so perfect that it might have been designed for
>that night. I was pleased with the people tha I met and their overall
>attitude. Like I told this very nice lady, that I met, seeing this
>turnout gave me hope for the future of or society, sentimental as that
>may sound. After the sun had been up for some time, we helped the Dj
>carry his equipment back to civilization. All in all, it was one of the
>more spiritual experiences that I've had in the last couple of months. 
>
>Doran


plus mr mojo (who was veeery friendly with his bottle of absolut...) and
those AMAZIN 'tunnel trips' with glo stix! (*now* i know what you meant :>)

melis

> they'll let you go. Give them your name and call me. They can let you go,
> arrest you later.
>

> say more stupid shit that they will use against you. like "this is
> entrapment" or "i didnt do it." Trust me, you aren't going to talk your way

If we get enough advance notice of the end of the world, someone should
throw and End of the World Party!  It could be a synchronized event
occurring in every major raving city in the world.  Would they be massives
or undergrounds?  Would we want whistles?  Drums?  Clapping?  Live music of
any kind?  How about the music?  Techno?  House?  Trance?  Trip-hop?  What
would make the best end of the world party?  It would definitely have to
last longer than any party has in history; maybe it could incorporate
everything that everyone likes the most.  The spaces would have to be
fairly large, cool, and unusual.  Anyone want to start a planning
committee?

Peace in the end times,

- E

Hey everybody-
	(sorry for the cross posting BUT this is the bes and only way to 
get the question out to all the lists that I know of!!)
	Everyone has been doing a super job helping us and we appreciate 
it so much!!! And as we get responses to our questions, our numbers go 
down by the hundreds BUT as you all know new parties are always happening 
so our number goes up very quickly again...SOOO..I know that a lot of 
people are cramming for finals (Good luck!) but this should be the last 
question for awhile (at least from me since my budget is technologically 
behind the times and I don't have net access...but Matt does) so please 
if you know where are any of these dj's are from (city and state) we'd 
really appreciate...the dj number is up to the 1400's now, so anybody 
that doesn't see dj names that were on here before don'y worry that means 
we just have the city now thanks to you guys!!!
	Again Thank you so much and good luck to those of you with finals!!!
Love -
Nicole
"Rave Info Compiler"

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Apr 30 13:59:25 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id NAA00885; Tue, 30 Apr 1996 13:59:25 -0700
Received: from xinet.COM by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id NAA00873; Tue, 30 Apr 1996 13:59:21 -0700
Received: from DialupEudora by xinet.COM via SMTP (940816.SGI.8.6.9/931108.SGI.ANONFTP)
	for <sfraves@hyperreal.com> id NAA17687; Tue, 30 Apr 1996 13:59:09 -0700
Message-Id: <v02120d39adac37b5e304@DialupEudora>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Tue, 30 Apr 1996 13:59:08 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: tony@xinet.COM (Tony Rotundo)
Subject: Quick review of MAD
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

MAD got off to a nice mellow start, most likely due to the quality of the
weekend here at home and abroad.  I figure one can tell just how good the
weekend was by the size/energy of an early-in-the-week party.

V is an intesting club, and *could* be a great place for a weekly, or even
a larger event, but there are enough limitations to it that I don't know if
it will ever become a choice venue.  The 21+ rule is a major issue for the
guys doing MAD and it's to their credit that they want this party to be
accessible to more people.  The security is pretty hard-ass as well, and
the cheapest beer one can score is like $3.75.

It's a nice looking place however, with several side rooms with black
lights and trippy carpeting, and a nice big roof deck which was great last
night in the unsually warm SF weather.

Jon Santos got things rolling with his creative, fast paced, eclectic
flare.  Joe Rice came on next and kept things moving along nicely, working
the mixer in a unique esoteric style; flipping switches this way and that
to create some cool effects.  By this time the majority of about a 100 or
so people were either dancing or watching people dance (others were milling
about, or on the roof, or playing pool).

Around 12:30 Freaky Chakra and Single Cell Orchestra came on and brough the
pace down to a very slow, whoomping, swaying sort of start.  They
gradually, slowly, teasingly picked up the pace, and as I left, the dance
floor was almost entirely full of swaying, swinging, gyrating hips and arms
and smiles.  I got to my motorcycle parked just outside the door where the
DJ was set up and the pace in a span of about five minutes had picked up to
a very dancable level.  I could only smile and think of the people inside
flailing and bouncing and rocking out to the live performance.

I couldn't help but smile on the way home. :^)

Peace!

Tone

P.S.  Thanks to MAD!!

> Dave

Well here's a brief guide to *Koh Phangan*.

1. Take a plane to *Bangkok*, the capitol of *Thailand*. That's near
Vietnam and India.

2. Next take a bus to *Haadyai*, but that's not where u take the boat.
The boat has to be taken from *Surathani* so if u can get a bus or
train from *Bangkok* to Surathani* go for it.

3. If u have made it this far, It's almost over. Take the ferry to *Koh
Phangan*. The journey takes about 5 hours so pack a bowl and relax.

4. Upon landing on Koh Phangan, u need to catch a ride to Haad-rin
Beach across the island.

5. If u made it, go to the beach, take off your shoes and give everyone
around u a hug. Next find somewhere to stay.

here's the address of The original full moon party place

Paradise Bungalow
Haadrin Beach
Koh Phangan
Suratthani 84280
Thailand
tel: (66) 1-725-0661

The journey is half the fun, oh boy will u have some trippy stories to
tell after that.

The Party never stops on Koh Phangan and one can live off fresh air the
sun, ocean, crstal clear ocean,calm waters, beautiful people, no
police,love, positive vibes, goa trance and this could go on foever.


Love 
Ben aka ionX

PS I will be down there this summer hope to see some of u there.
Or if interested buzzzzzzzzzzzzzz.

PPS: Great job by F-8 last friday, I felt true bliss once again.

>>> Is pornography degrading to women or sexually liberating for our society?

>>> disturbed by pornography does not mean a woman is anti-sex or repressed.
>
>Certainly not.  But when you hear someone call a person who does pron,
>dirty or slutty, I think it is very clear the puritanical if not
>self-righteous tone of such phrases.

I NEVER said that.  I don't believe in "dirty" or "slutty."  Sex is
beautiful, it is pleasure.

Who's objectifying who now?
>I think it all depends on the person.  Obviously there are people here who
>feel that sex is still a very strange and alien thing.
>
>I am disturbed by many things I see portryed in film.  especially the
>respresentation of black people.  I however refrain from saying that the
>people hwo do land roles are "uncle tom's", etc.  Or that there is some
>type of Jewish conspiracy (ala Brando & others), guiding this whole thing.
>We see what we want to see sometimes.
>
>
>>> The disturbance for me comes from the fact that pornography, almost by
>>> definition, OBJECTIFIES women.  It is a VISUAL medium, focusing on graphic
>>> sex acts and body parts.
>
>All movies ever made are of the visual medium.

Yes, I was thinking this as I wrote it.  But what I was trying to get
across was a sexuality based on visualness which then
objectifies/fetishizes women's bodies, which has serious ramifications for
women's struggle for equal rights and respect in the whole of society.



 Sound was added much later.
>"Regular" movies focus on body parts as well; faces, eyes, arms, gestures.
>There really is no difference.  The focus of porn is sex/entertainment.
>The focus of mainstream movies is personalities/entertainment.  The real
>argument here is about sex, and somehow porn , because it is sex based,
>having greater impact on the society at large.  Unfortuantly all studies
>are very mixed and haphazard.  There are plenty of philosophical arguments
>for and against porn.  But like everything else, there is no conclusive
>evidence to say whether the people who watch porn are affected.  We *do*
>know people who do not appreciate porn are affected though.

Yes, I've studied this, too.  I refrained from stating that porn actually
causes violence against women.  I know men who enjoy porn and strip clubs
who are absolutely respectful - they just enjoy seeing sex acts and naked
women, but don't take that to their entire relations with women.  Porn as
actually dangerous depends on the individual watching it, but I still think
we should be cognizant of its messages (like what women respond to
sexually, because it is very misleading in most cases).


>
>The only fact is that porn is porn.  All movies objectify something, and
>most woemn in movies are usually whores or helpless victims.  And people
>call it mainstream because of the narrative?  Whatever, it's all the same
>stuff to me.
>
>>> Narrative, thought, is largely absent.
>
>Looking at the current crop of movies (mainstream) of late, I think this is
>true of most films made.  Mainstream and porn.  And WHO decided that a real
>or good movie needs narration.  Some of the most powerful movies made were
>silent films (See Dr. Caligari).  I go to movies to be entertained.  I f I
>learn something, bonus round.  But the main reason is entertainment.
>Mainstream movies, as lilly-white as it might be, along with porn , as
>lilly-white as *it* can be, both entertain.
>
>The rest, whether porn is less becuase of it's focus, is all a matter of
>opinion.
>
>To me, it is no more or less than anything else out there.

Yeah, most Hollywood creations are fluff.  What I meant was that there was
no character development, emphasizing a sexuality based on bodies only,
which is primarily a male sexuality.  (By "male sexuality" I mean what's
accepted in the mainstream, I know many men whose sexuality is much more
complex and subtle than society allows them).  Bodies-only sexuality means
individual personalities don't count, turning the women into
interchangeable objects (the men are positioned as the actors, and the
consumers).

>
>
>>> This
>>> seems to correspond to a more masculine sexuality, i.e. being turned-on
>>> visually, bodies and acts arousing rather than minds and personalities.
>
>Not a porn afficionado huh?  There are plenty of female producers now.
>Porn encompases many different genres, from the raunch to the romantic.
>There is a whole line of erotica (read pron), put out by Candida Royale,
>ex-porn star (you should see her in "Hot Rackets"), and she is trying to
>cater to women.  There are other female producers.  These ladies focus less
>on the act than on the interaction.  There are vidoes where people don't
>even have sex (see some of the wierd tantric stuff...) per se.  Anyway
>there are many different genres of porn.  You are grouping all of porn into
>one neat box so you can argue against it.  By not being aware of the
>variety, all you are doing is making a gross generalization.
>
>Generalizing is a very narrow path to being wrong.

Perhaps you didn't read my entire message, which concluded that an
alternate view of sexuality is found in women's erotica, etc.  I should
have also mentioned gay & lesbian porn.  When people talk of "porn," they
usually are referring to the male-oriented pornography.  Women's writings,
films, etc., have flourished in the last ten years - a self-liberation of
claiming our own sexuality and our right to be aroused.

I would appreciate it if you would pay attention to the entire argument
rather than misinterpreting things so that you can be offended.  You could
easily be accused of generalizing (something you'll probably take offense
to, even though you quickly accused me of the same!).

I am very hesitant to even respond because I have seen you absolutely tear
apart people, for no other reason than something (sometimes seemingly
inocuous) riled you.  I know that to even answer your post will mean a
heated response.  I think you have some VERY interesting and important
insights, but I am also disturbed by the ferocity of your tone.  I wonder
where the respect is.  I find it ironic that in the name of justice, you
feel justified in belittling and abusing people, and twisting their words.
Puritanism?  How did you get THAT out of a feminist critique of mainstream
porn? (NOT necessarily anti-porn!).  Don't you see any common ground
between feminism and civil rights/the position of black folk?  Or are you
too blinded by watching "betties shaking it" (at a RAVE, where women hope
for respect) and calling porn's portrayal of women "entertainment" ?  Why
is YOUR concept of injustice the only one that matters?  And why does it
only encompass capitalism (I agree with you) and racism (I agree with you),
but not sexism?

John, I read your posts with interest.  You have an incisive wit, and an
analysis of society that is needed.  But often these ideas are couched in
anger and disrespect.  I feel you contradict yourself by being for social
justice while viciously tearing into somebody/some position you have
invented for them.



>
>
>>> For many women, this impersonal sexuality is inexplicable - and actually
>>> threatening.
>
>And for many women it is not threatening, but liberating.  LArger and
>larger numbers of women are making thier own porn movies now.

Yes, but the sexuality is envisioned differently, right?  THAT's what I'm
referring to!!!  One way to equality is acknowledging women's own
sexuality.

Whtere it be
>professional or amatuer, women are in it.  Please try not to speak for all
>your sisters.  Many would disagree with you from jump.

I qualified my arguments with statements like "many" or "some," not "all."

>
>This whole conversation sounds like one of those "Feminists Against Porn"
>arguments I've heard over and over.  The end result?  The lefties of F.A.P,
>join right up with the far right X-Tain Coalition and others, to stop the
>common disease of objectification and sexually oriented movies.
>
>Yikes!!! It's 1984 all over again! ;)

I said I was "disturbed" by that certain kind of pornography - not opposed.
If you think I support puritanism and repression, you haven't read my
posts!  What exactly are you responding to, because it's not what I wrote.
Censorship?? No!  I wrote of changing consciousness, transformation of
ideas.  We are dealing with the realm of thought, how to change societal
mind-sets that may be destructive (like sexism).  That is not about
silencing people, it's about putting forth alternative ideas.

To point out some of the elements of porn that are sexist is not
puritanical.  I am not anti-sex -- far from it.  I am interested in how all
sexualities can be celebrated.  I am supportive of all pornography - I
specified the problem with mainstream pornography is when a certain
mind-set translates to women's role in society.

Questioning assumptions about sexuality is not puritanical, but the opposite.



>
>
>>> Unfortunately for all of us, male sexual response has
>>> translated to a hierarchical social structure (i.e. sexism).
>
>I see, and what of the female sexual response?
>
>At this point, it seems like nothing more than an anti-porn, anti-male
>response.

Being anti-sexist is anti-male?  That's pretty insulting to men.

 Ther rest of the analysis does not examine why women go into
>porn,

um, yes it did.

 or even why many women enjoy it as much as men.  And it doesn't
>answer the question as to why the industry, from all accounts, is growing
>in acceptance for the most part.
>
>I dunno, puritanism is far from dead.  I just wish people would leave each
>other alone, and respect each other, instead of casting judgement after
>judgement against each other for all kinds of weird resons.
>
>Movies, all movies, are entertainment.  Some are even informative (porn is
>no different).  If you don;t like it, don't watch it.  But before passing
>judgment, I would suggest spending some time researching the subject.


I have taken classes on Feminism and Pornography and on Women's Erotica.
However, it is too bad one must credential themselves before their opinion
is valid.

Tony-
	Thank you for having the faith in us that I thought everyone 
would have...I have responded to both Black Adder and Troy, but I don't 
know if what I said got through. The on-going project will be available 
on the WEB and on CD-Rom making it available for both netravers and for 
ravers not able to be on the net! And as I have said before the only 
reason for us charging for the CD-Roms is because it costs to get them 
pressed, we are not in any way trying to make money. We love raving that 
is the simple fact we are tryng to make it easier for felloe ravers to 
get in touch with who and what they need to. Why would we take advantage 
of people we respect. We cross post for the simle reason that dj's are 
located across the US and we want to make sure we have them all with 
correct information.
-Nicole
"Rave Info Compiler"

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Apr 30 21:55:23 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id VAA11159; Tue, 30 Apr 1996 21:55:23 -0700
Received: from mh1.well.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id VAA11149; Tue, 30 Apr 1996 21:55:19 -0700
Received: from well (mh2o@well.com [206.15.64.10]) by mh1.well.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) with SMTP id VAA05734 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Tue, 30 Apr 1996 21:55:18 -0700
Date: Tue, 30 Apr 1996 21:55:13 -0700 (PDT)
From: Maureen Garrett <mh2o@well.com>
Subject: Re: F-8 beach party review
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <v02130508adaa5730cbdf@[146.225.72.168]>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9604302002.A5531-0100000@well>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


It pleases me to have read so many positive reviews of the F8 party.  In 
some ways it makes me wonder, "Are we talking about the same party?"

Perhaps it is far from fair to compare parties, for many are intensely 
unique in all ways.  however I was at the same site for the NMR the 
previous Friday and was still basking in the glow from that experience 
when I descended, unbeknownst to me at the time, into F8's littered hell. 
As I descended, I ran into two friends heading up and elsewhere, inviting 
me along.  The man spoke and expressed concern that if we didn't stop 
trashing this space, we would no longer be allowed to have parties there. 

Having seen this spot for the first time the previous week, I now 
understood why residents are extremely protective of it.  For
this location is magical, powerful, beautiful and more.  It embodies 
so much of what we all believe as we dance to heal ourselves and the 
injuries to our planet...that it simply boggles my mind..

Descending further, the music could be heard, glow sticks marked the way,
and the darkened majestic rock formations came into view. I believe they 
look like turtles, especially during the day, sea turtle heads..The surf 
was quite large and hammered the formations which are in their own way, 
crumbling into the sea..The sound was amazing..and the water was forced 
back out from under the land under greater pressure and 
speed.hissing loudly..Knowing there are hot springs down below  
defines the land even further.

Making my way down the somewhat trecherous steps (Deep appreciation to 
those of such sound body able to carry such loads so we can dance), and 
onto the first smaller cove, you could see these wondrous rock sculptures 
made by humans.. two last glow sticks lead the final leg to the larger 
cove which revealed the beach I have seen in photos (nudie beachg during the 
day) however the F8 crew back lite the cliffs in the cool colors of 
green and blue, with the campfire providing the warm colors. 

Looking around, I recognized two people I had met before, two F8 
DJ's, however over the course of the night, I had a few deeply 
interesting conversations with new friends.  At one point, I was given a 
vision for yet another painting, I sat with it for a long time, judging 
by the moon's descent into the sea.

Musically I have heard better weaving by everyone there, where it is 
seamless yet builds from one journey to the next...and while IMHO the 
mixing was so so this time around, the music itself, trance, as always
was fantastic...I especially liked Cyr's choices for the AM, however I 
was exhausted and left about 1/2 hour into his set...

What I took with me I had gathered during the night as the tide came in 
over the course of several hours.

When it was dark, and the sea sent one huge wave about every 20 minutes 
that touched more blankets than the last time, I walked the cove and picked 
up garbage which would have been washed out to sea rather shortly.
The pile of garbage grew as I placed them around the tiki torch I 
brought. I even asked for help several times and was met with blank faces..
Nothing hurt more during the night then to hear the glass breaking in the 
distance over the rocks.  I thought about the local residents who 
might cut their feet by noon on the same day. It is irrelevant that 
mother nature's natural rock tumbler will turn the glass back into sand. 
Second was having to listen to the nitrous balloons. Third was the 
silence of few smiles and laughter.

As I ascended, early light revealed beautiful plants and natures 
fractals.... Ferns...  I made peace with the plants as my hayfever slowly 
kicked in..Perhaps next time there won't be such a blatant disrespect for 
this sacred place...and I won't have to carry up such a load...more than 
the bottles, cans, and water botles and 'rubber balloons', but a 
heaviness in my heart, and a sadness that too many in the house really 
don't give a fuck.

Tonight, some 30+ rave waste items finds their way to a recycle bin instead 
of someone else's beach on another day.  Yes I counted them as an 
interesting statistic and one which I have been observing for some 
time.  It seems as if about 25% of the people who attend parties litter.   

I believe that something has to be done with those who are asleep 
environmentally...no excuses, no matter what age.  Being a hormone 
crazed high school student is no excuse, being too stoned is no excuse
there are none.  Teaching must begin immediately by all of us in a beauty 
way to these non-Green lost souls. 

I spoke with Mars briefly at Sunset about an idea I had for their next 
outdoor party regarding the above.

For now, I send those 25%, sweet green peace....

--Maureen

So now you have a respect metric that you determine what is good and what
is bad.  I think we can both agree that some things are bad (i.e. where one
person has no choice or will in the matter).  But beyond that your
statement denies the fact that there may be women who enjoy a certain level
of interaction with men.  Same with men.  There are some people who live
for desire sake alone.  And how someone deals with their realtionships is
no business of mine.

If a guy doens't want permanence and likes objectification, there are
others in the world that will feel similarly and they might be of service
to each other.  The world, IMO, is to wide and varied for me to interpret
the motives of others.  And engaging in such tactics, determing what is
healthy/good by looking at how someone processes their sexuality is the
height of arrogance.  As if we can ever really understand the complexities
of any given individual.

I just ain't that smart.

Basically if a guy likes porn and doesn't want to integrate it, fine.  If a
guy like porn and wants a woman like the kind he sees in movies, fine, as
long as the one he ends up with really wants to be there with him, by HER
choice.

Micromanagaing and overanalyzing sexuality is beyond my mortal capabilites.
As  far as I understand nature, we eat, we fuck/multiply, and we die.  One
we need to get to the next phase so that others may continue the struggle,
the other is a direct end result of such pursuits.

Dante's inferno.

It all depends on how you interpret civil rights.  Basically what one wants
out of civil rihts is recognition/respect outside of race/gender/etc. as a
human being.  But the other end of that sword asks that you be judged like
all other humans responsible for their own actions.

So in one way I see the struggles similarly, although the feminist movement
has left out sisters of color for some time now, and this is straight FACT.
Look at the memebers of the major feminist organizations.  You will see,
much as you see in most corporate boardrooms, a sea os sameness, with
little variation in hue.  The feminist movemnt could do much, with it's
mighty $$$ warchest, to bridge the gap of cimmunication with their sisters
of color, who have been all but left out.

my ass.  I like other PEOPLE around me shaking their asses.  If I think the

shouldn't dance in public (There was a time when I couldn't look at no

>is YOUR concept of injustice the only one that matters?

Mine is the nly one that matters. Simply said, I cannot account for others.
Some of my brothers AND sisters in Africa think that denying a woman a
circumsicion is an injustice.  I do not agree.  Therefore, I try to only
account for my rules, and ways of being.  If others agree fine, then maybe
we can form a union, a country whatever, maybe even a govt.  But I have to
start somewhere, might as well be with me.  Dig?

>And why does it
>only encompass capitalism (I agree with you) and racism (I agree with you),
>but not sexism?

My posts in the past noted sexism.  But I see sexism as a two way street.
There are as many men who objectify women as women who objectify men.  This
is all done under various guises.  But for women, I certainly do wonder how
many of them would enjoy the lifelong company of someone who couldn't earn
a buck (like the bums who sleep in the park near my house).  I don't see
many SF women seeing them as a prize.  Men have often felt that we are
assumed certain tasks and responsibilites ($$$).  One of them is earning
power.  Yeah, yeah, personality is all fine, but it don't pay the bills.
Objectification at some levels serves a purpose I think.

Men are often seen as money, and women are often seen as sex.

Like I said, objectification can take many forms.  And both sides are
guilty.  What I find absent from your commentary (all that which was not an
attack on/of my character), is this dual edged sword fact.

thing anyone can accuse me of is being me.

I am straightforward and to the point.  I don't fuck around and expect
nothing less from those I talk with.  Solar has called me a "very serious"
guy, but is puzzled at my capability to laugh, even at myself (touche'

don't couch my speech with anything.

I am right as often as I am wrong.  Like everyone else.

Well that's pretty much it.

You will know when I am agnry, and I can say, that I haven't been really
angry in a while....but maybe my time is near.

>mind-sets that may be destructive (like sexism).  That is not about
>silencing people, it's about putting forth alternative ideas.

But what is the net effect.  I think this needs to be analyzed as well.
When you say that somethign does something, one must consider how people
will react to change the situation.  The porn = objectification has been
used quite effectively to stifle certain forms of speech/art.

I am sure you are aware of this historical fact.

>
>To point out some of the elements of porn that are sexist is not
>puritanical.  I am not anti-sex -- far from it.  I am interested in how all
>sexualities can be celebrated.  I am supportive of all pornography - I
>specified the problem with mainstream pornography is when a certain
>mind-set translates to women's role in society.

them out to you if necessary.  Inherently sexist, since males follow all
kinds of patterns.  It all depends on how one was raised.

retort.  Maybe you might want to broaden the discussion to include all
genders?

Being anti-sexist means that you must also account for objectification
wherever it occurs.  And it happens with men, moreso than women.  The
effects are different becuase the expectations are different, on both sides
(or many) of the gender isle.

Just a thought.

 Just a couple of thoughts -- I did a research paper on pornography.  
Unfortunately it was not as in depth as I would have liked it to be. One 
thing I did learn, however, was that the word 'pornagraphy' originally meant 
stories told by prostitutes in order to incite men to lust (and 
supposedly encourage them to buy their services). We should keep in mind 
that the only surviving records of these events were supposed to have 
been written by men (who were absolutely unbiased ;) ). Eventually  porn 
became synonymus with violence and domination of women (by men). I 
believe this occured first in Europe and eventually moved to 
America via monograms and eventually photographs, during the Victorian 
era. If anyone is interested, e-mail me and I can dig out my old paper and 
more accurately remember the contents and refer to sources.


Ran @ Dionysus Dreams
